text_human: Early reviews were mixed in their assessment. Ken Tucker of Entertainment Weekly considered that "As TV, American Idol is crazily entertaining; as music, it's dust-mote inconsequential". Others, however, thought that "the most striking aspect of the series was the genuine talent it revealed". It was also described as a "sadistic musical bake-off", and "a romp in humiliation". Other aspects of the show have attracted criticisms. The product placement in the show in particular was noted, and some critics were harsh about what they perceived as its blatant commercial calculations – Karla Peterson of The San Diego Union-Tribune charged that American Idol is "a conniving multimedia monster" that has "absorbed the sin of our debauched culture and spit them out in a lump of reconstituted evil". The decision to send the season one winner to sing the national anthem at the Lincoln Memorial on the first anniversary of the September 11 attacks in 2002 was also poorly received by many. Lisa de Moraes of The Washington Post noted sarcastically that "The terrorists have won" and, with a sideswipe at the show's commercialism and voting process, that the decision as to who "gets to turn this important site into just another cog in the 'Great American Idol Marketing Mandala' is in the hands of the millions of girls who have made American Idol a hit. Them and a handful of phone-redialer geeks who have been clocking up to 10,000 calls each week for their contestant of choice (but who, according to Fox, are in absolutely no way skewing the outcome)."

In contrast, others were struck by the genuine talent the series showcased. Critics also described it as a "sadistic musical bake-off" and "a romp in humiliation." Various aspects of the show drew criticism, particularly the product placements, which some considered blatant commercial tactics. Karla Peterson of The San Diego Union-Tribune accused "American Idol" of being a "conniving multimedia monster" that mirrors and amplifies the vices of our culture into "a lump of reconstituted evil." Additionally, the decision to have the first season's winner sing the national anthem at the Lincoln Memorial on the first anniversary of the September 11 attacks in 2002 was poorly received. Lisa de Moraes of The Washington Post sarcastically remarked, "The terrorists have won," criticizing the commercialism and voting process. She noted that the decision to "turn this important site into just another cog in the 'Great American Idol Marketing Mandala'" was placed in the hands of millions of young fans and a few avid phone-redialers, allegedly affecting the outcome despite assurances from Fox to the contrary.
text_ai_humanized: The debut of "American Idol" garnered a medley of reactions from the critics. While Ken Tucker from Entertainment Weekly labeled the show as a captivating spectacle on the TV screen, he dismissed its musical significance. Others, however, were drawn in by the real talent shining through. Some reviewers didn’t hold back, branding it a “sadistic musical bake-off” and likening it to a “romp in humiliation.” The flurry of critiques wasn’t limited to the contestants themselves; rather, it included sharp disapproval of how product placements were seen as overtly commercial. Karla Peterson from The San Diego Union-Tribune fired shots at the show, calling it a "conniving multimedia monster" that seems to reflect the darker sides of culture, turning them into something akin to “reconstituted evil.” Moreover, the choice to feature the first season’s winner singing the national anthem at the Lincoln Memorial, one year after the September 11 attacks, was met with displeasure. Lisa de Moraes from The Washington Post didn’t hesitate to employ sarcasm, remarking, “The terrorists have won,” taking aim at the rampant commercialism and the voting mechanics. She suggested that millions of young fans and persistent phone-redialers essentially monopolized the decision-making process, undermining the assurances from Fox that claimed otherwise. This decision, as she bluntly described, seemed to reduce the revered site to a mere component in what she dubbed the "Great American Idol Marketing Mandala."

text_human: Soon Lutyens started considering other places. Indeed, the Delhi Town Planning Committee, set up to plan the new imperial capital, with George Swinton as chairman and John A. Brodie and Lutyens as members, submitted reports for both North and South sites. However, it was rejected by the Viceroy when the cost of acquiring the necessary properties was found to be too high. The central axis of New Delhi, which today faces east at India Gate, was previously meant to be a north-south axis linking the Viceroy's House at one end with Paharganj at the other. During the project's early years, many tourists believed it was a gate from Earth to Heaven itself. Eventually, owing to space constraints and the presence of a large number of heritage sites in the North side, the committee settled on the South site. A site atop the Raisina Hill, formerly Raisina Village, a Meo village, was chosen for the Rashtrapati Bhawan, then known as the Viceroy's House. The reason for this choice was that the hill lay directly opposite the Dinapanah citadel, which was also considered the site of Indraprastha, the ancient region of Delhi. Subsequently, the foundation stone was shifted from the site of Delhi Durbar of 1911–1912, where the Coronation Pillar stood, and embedded in the walls of the forecourt of the Secretariat. The Rajpath, also known as King's Way, stretched from the India Gate to the Rashtrapati Bhawan. The Secretariat building, the two blocks of which flank the Rashtrapati Bhawan and houses ministries of the Government of India, and the Parliament House, both designed by Herbert Baker, are located at the Sansad Marg and run parallel to the Rajpath.

The Secretariat building, consisting of two blocks flanking the Rashtrapati Bhawan and housing Indian government ministries, along with the Parliament House, both designed by Herbert Baker, are located at Sansad Marg, running parallel to Rajpath.

message.content:
Not long after the initial plans were laid out, Lutyens began to explore alternative locations for the new capital. The establishment of the Delhi Town Planning Committee was a significant step toward shaping this imperial landscape. Under the leadership of George Swinton, with John A. Brodie and Lutyens alongside him, the committee began its work. At first, they proposed both northern and southern sites for development. However, these plans faced an obstacle: the hefty price tag associated with acquiring the necessary land, leading the Viceroy to dismiss them.

Initially, the vision for New Delhi's main axis aimed to create a north-south corridor linking the Viceroy's House with Paharganj. Some early visitors believed this design had an almost mystical quality, suggesting a pathway connecting Earth and Heaven. Yet, practical concerns, like space shortages and the presence of numerous heritage sites in the northern areas, prompted the committee to pivot to a southern location. They settled on an elevated position atop Raisina Hill—originally Raisina Village—for the Viceroy's House, now known proudly as the Rashtrapati Bhawan. This site stood directly across from the Dinapanah citadel, a place long thought to be Indraprastha, believed by many to be the ancient heartbeat of Delhi.

In a symbolic gesture, the foundation stone was moved from its initial 1911-1912 placement at the Delhi Durbar site, once marked by the Coronation Pillar, and was carefully integrated into the forecourt walls of the Secretariat. Rajpath, which was originally named King's Way, now stretches majestically from India Gate to the Rashtrapati Bhawan. On either side of the Rashtrapati Bhawan stand the majestic blocks of the Secretariat building, designed by Herbert Baker, which house various Indian government ministries. Meanwhile, the Parliament House, also a Baker masterpiece, commands presence at Sansad Marg, running smoothly parallel to the iconic Rajpath.

text_human: Formal discipline is administered by congregation elders. When a baptized member is accused of committing a serious sin—usually cases of sexual misconduct or charges of apostasy for disputing Jehovah's Witness doctrines—a judicial committee is formed to determine guilt, provide help and possibly administer discipline. Disfellowshipping, a form of shunning, is the strongest form of discipline, administered to an offender deemed unrepentant. Contact with disfellowshipped individuals is limited to direct family members living in the same home, and with congregation elders who may invite disfellowshipped persons to apply for reinstatement; formal business dealings may continue if contractually or financially obliged. Witnesses are taught that avoiding social and spiritual interaction with disfellowshipped individuals keeps the congregation free from immoral influence and that "losing precious fellowship with loved ones may help [the shunned individual] to come 'to his senses,' see the seriousness of his wrong, and take steps to return to Jehovah." The practice of shunning may also serve to deter other members from dissident behavior. Members who disassociate (formally resign) are described in Watch Tower Society literature as wicked and are also shunned. Expelled individuals may eventually be reinstated to the congregation if deemed repentant by elders in the congregation in which the disfellowshipping was enforced. Reproof is a lesser form of discipline given formally by a judicial committee to a baptized Witness who is considered repentant of serious sin; the reproved person temporarily loses conspicuous privileges of service, but suffers no restriction of social or spiritual fellowship. Marking, a curtailing of social but not spiritual fellowship, is practiced if a baptized member persists in a course of action regarded as a violation of Bible principles but not a serious sin.[note 4]
text_ai_base: Congregation elders oversee formal discipline within the Jehovah's Witnesses community. When a baptized member faces accusations of serious wrongdoing—typically involving sexual misconduct or apostasy by challenging Jehovah's Witness doctrines—a judicial committee is created to assess the situation. This committee determines guilt, offers help, and may impose disciplinary measures. The most severe form of discipline is disfellowshipping, or shunning, which is applied when the offender is seen as unrepentant. Communication with disfellowshipped individuals is restricted to direct family members within the same household and congregation elders who may extend an invitation for reinstatement. Business interactions can continue if there is a contractual or financial obligation. The organization teaches that avoiding social and spiritual interactions with disfellowshipped members preserves the congregation's spiritual integrity and encourages the shunned individual to "come to his senses," recognize the gravity of their actions, and consider returning to Jehovah. Shunning also serves as a deterrent against dissent within the community. Individuals who formally resign, or disassociate, are labeled as wicked in Watch Tower Society publications and are similarly shunned. Disfellowshipped individuals can be reinstated if they later exhibit repentance, evaluated by the same congregation's elders. Less severe than disfellowshipping, reproof is given to a repentant baptized Witness guilty of serious sin. Although temporarily losing certain service privileges, the reproved member retains full social and spiritual fellowship. Marking, which reduces social interaction but not spiritual fellowship, is applied to members who persist in actions violating Bible principles without committing a serious sin.
text_ai_humanized: Elders within the Jehovah's Witnesses community play a pivotal role in overseeing formal disciplinary procedures. When a baptized member is accused of grave misconduct—often of a nature such as sexual impropriety or doctrinal apostasy—a judicial committee is convened to handle the matter. This committee’s responsibilities include assessing culpability, offering support, and potentially enforcing disciplinary actions. Disfellowshipping, or the practice of shunning, stands as the most severe form of discipline. It occurs when the person involved is deemed unrepentant, and this leads to restricted communication, confined primarily to immediate family living under the same roof or to congregation elders who might later offer a path to reinstatement. Business interactions can proceed only when there's an existing financial or contractual obligation that necessitates them. The rationale behind avoiding social and spiritual interactions with those disfellowshipped is largely rooted in safeguarding the congregation’s spiritual purity and nudging the separated individual to reflect on their missteps. It’s intended to spur a recognition of the consequences of their actions and encourage a potential return to Jehovah’s teachings. Moreover, shunning acts as a deterrent against internal dissent. In noteworthy cases, individuals who choose to resign, a move termed as disassociation, are viewed unfavorably in publications by the Watch Tower Society and are also subject to shunning. Yet, there is a possibility of redemption; those disfellowshipped can be welcomed back if they display genuine repentance, a decision again resting with the elders of the congregation. Reproof, which is a lesser form of censure, is imposed when a baptized Witness acknowledges their serious misstep. While this leads to a temporary loss of certain service privileges, the individual's social and spiritual ties within the community remain intact. As for the process known as marking, it is used to signal disapproval of a member who continues engaging in behavior that diverges from Biblical principles, albeit without involving serious sin; in this case, social interaction is curtailed, but spiritual fellowship is maintained.

text_human: In 1969 the Cubs, managed by Leo Durocher, built a substantial lead in the newly created National League Eastern Division by mid-August. Ken Holtzman pitched a no-hitter on August 19, and the division lead grew to 8 1⁄2 games over the St. Louis Cardinals and by 9 1⁄2 games over the New York Mets. After the game of September 2, the Cubs record was 84-52 with the Mets in second place at 77-55. But then a losing streak began just as a Mets winning streak was beginning. The Cubs lost the final game of a series at Cincinnati, then came home to play the resurgent Pittsburgh Pirates (who would finish in third place). After losing the first two games by scores of 9-2 and 13-4, the Cubs led going into the ninth inning. A win would be a positive springboard since the Cubs were to play a crucial series with the Mets the very next day. But Willie Stargell drilled a 2-out, 2-strike pitch from the Cubs' ace reliever, Phil Regan, onto Sheffield Avenue to tie the score in the top of the ninth. The Cubs would lose 7-5 in extra innings. Burdened by a four-game losing streak, the Cubs traveled to Shea Stadium for a short two-game set. The Mets won both games, and the Cubs left New York with a record of 84-58 just 1⁄2 game in front. Disaster followed in Philadelphia, as a 99 loss Phillies team nonetheless defeated the Cubs twice, to extend Chicago's losing streak to eight games. In a key play in the second game, on September 11, Cubs starter Dick Selma threw a surprise pickoff attempt to third baseman Ron Santo, who was nowhere near the bag or the ball. Selma's throwing error opened the gates to a Phillies rally. After that second Philly loss, the Cubs were 84-60 and the Mets had pulled ahead at 85-57. The Mets would not look back. The Cubs' eight-game losing streak finally ended the next day in St. Louis, but the Mets were in the midst of a ten-game winning streak, and the Cubs, wilting from team fatigue, generally deteriorated in all phases of the game. The Mets (who had lost a record 120 games 7 years earlier), would go on to win the World Series. The Cubs, despite a respectable 92-70 record, would be remembered for having lost a remarkable 17½ games in the standings to the Mets in the last quarter of the season.
text_ai_base: In 1969, the Cubs, under manager Leo Durocher, held a commanding lead in the newly formed National League Eastern Division by mid-August. On August 19, Ken Holtzman pitched a no-hitter, expanding their lead to 8½ games over the St. Louis Cardinals and 9½ games over the New York Mets. By September 2, the Cubs had a record of 84-52, with the Mets trailing at 77-55. However, a Cubs' losing streak coincided with a Mets' winning streak. The Cubs lost the last game of a series against Cincinnati, then returned home to face the revitalized Pittsburgh Pirates (who would finish third). They lost the first two games 9-2 and 13-4 but were ahead in the ninth inning of the third game. A win could have been a momentum booster before a critical series against the Mets. Unfortunately, Willie Stargell hit a two-out, two-strike pitch from the Cubs' top reliever, Phil Regan, onto Sheffield Avenue, tying the game. The Cubs eventually lost 7-5 in extra innings. Now on a four-game losing streak, they moved to Shea Stadium for a brief two-game series. The Mets won both games, leaving the Cubs at 84-58, just ½ game ahead. Disaster continued in Philadelphia, where the 99-loss Phillies defeated the Cubs twice, extending their losing streak to eight games. A crucial play in the second game on September 11 saw Cubs pitcher Dick Selma making an unexpected pickoff attempt to third baseman Ron Santo, who was too far from the base, leading to a throwing error that triggered a Phillies' rally. After this loss, the Cubs were at 84-60, while the Mets surged ahead at 85-57 and never looked back. The Cubs ended their losing streak in St. Louis, but the Mets were on a ten-game winning spree, and the Cubs, exhausted, faltered in all areas. The Mets, who had lost a record 120 games seven years prior, went on to win the World Series. Despite a solid 92-70 record, the Cubs are remembered for losing a staggering 17½ games in the standings to the Mets in the last quarter of the season.
text_ai_humanized: Back in 1969, the Chicago Cubs, with Leo Durocher at the helm, seemed poised for greatness. By mid-August, they were comfortably leading the National League Eastern Division. The high point came on August 19, when Ken Holtzman dazzled with a no-hitter, pushing their lead over the St. Louis Cardinals to 8½ games and leaving the New York Mets 9½ games in their wake. However, just when it seemed like they were cruising to victory, things took a turn. Come September 2, the Cubs boasted an impressive 84-52 record, while the Mets were still grappling at 77-55. But then, as if the universe had flipped a switch, the Cubs hit a rough patch. It all began with losing the final game of a series against Cincinnati. Back home, they faced a spirited Pittsburgh Pirates crew, who were clawing their way toward a third-place finish. The Cubs were mauled in the first two matchups, falling 9-2 and 13-4. In the third game, despite leading into the ninth inning, when a win felt tantalizingly close, disaster struck. Willie Stargell launched a last-ditch, two-out, two-strike missile off the Cubs' ace reliever, Phil Regan, sending the ball onto Sheffield Avenue and knotting up the score. They ended up dropping that game 7-5 in extra innings. Now reeling on a four-game losing slope, the Cubs headed to Shea Stadium for what turned into a nightmare—a two-game sweep by the Mets. This sequence left Chicago at 84-58, with their lead now whittled down to a mere half-game. As if scripted by the baseball gods, their bad luck followed them to Philadelphia, where the Phillies, a team destined for 99 losses, twice stole victories from them. One particularly crushing moment occurred in the second game on September 11, when pitcher Dick Selma made a dubious pickoff attempt to third baseman Ron Santo, who, unfortunately, had drifted too far from the bag, resulting in a throwing error that ultimately ignited a Phillies' rally. By the end of this debacle, the Cubs stood at 84-60. Meanwhile, the Mets had surged ahead to 85-57 and stayed untouchable after that. The Cubs managed to stop the bleeding briefly in St. Louis, but elsewhere, the Mets were ripping off a ten-game winning streak. Exhaustion seemed to set in for the Cubs as they struggled on all fronts. Remarkably, the Mets, who had infamously lost 120 games just seven years prior, rode this momentum straight to a World Series triumph. The Cubs wrapped up their season with a still-respectable 92-70 record. Still, they're often remembered for watching their division lead evaporate, as they lost a daunting 17½ games to the unstoppable Mets as the season drew to a close.

However, just when it seemed like they were cruising to victory, things took a turn.

Come September 2, the Cubs boasted an impressive 84-52 record, while the Mets were still grappling at 77-55. But then, as if the universe had flipped a switch, the Cubs hit a rough patch. It all began with losing the final game of a series against Cincinnati. Back home, they faced a spirited Pittsburgh Pirates crew, who were clawing their way toward a third-place finish. The Cubs were mauled in the first two matchups, falling 9-2 and 13-4. In the third game, despite leading into the ninth inning, when a win felt tantalizingly close, disaster struck. Willie Stargell launched a last-ditch, two-out, two-strike missile off the Cubs' ace reliever, Phil Regan, sending the ball onto Sheffield Avenue and knotting up the score. They ended up dropping that game 7-5 in extra innings. Now reeling on a four-game losing slope, the Cubs headed to Shea Stadium for what turned into a nightmare—a two-game sweep by the Mets.

This sequence left Chicago at 84-58, with their lead now whittled down to a mere half-game. As if scripted by the baseball gods, their bad luck followed them to Philadelphia, where the Phillies, a team destined for 99 losses, twice stole victories from them. One particularly crushing moment occurred in the second game on September 11, when pitcher Dick Selma made a dubious pickoff attempt to third baseman Ron Santo, who, unfortunately, had drifted too far from the bag, resulting in a throwing error that ultimately ignited a Phillies' rally. By the end of this debacle, the Cubs stood at 84-60. Meanwhile, the Mets had surged ahead to 85-57 and stayed untouchable after that.

text_human: Copper occurs naturally as native copper and was known to some of the oldest civilizations on record. It has a history of use that is at least 10,000 years old, and estimates of its discovery place it at 9000 BC in the Middle East; a copper pendant was found in northern Iraq that dates to 8700 BC. There is evidence that gold and meteoric iron (but not iron smelting) were the only metals used by humans before copper. The history of copper metallurgy is thought to have followed the following sequence: 1) cold working of native copper, 2) annealing, 3) smelting, and 4) the lost wax method. In southeastern Anatolia, all four of these metallurgical techniques appears more or less simultaneously at the beginning of the Neolithic c. 7500 BC. However, just as agriculture was independently invented in several parts of the world, copper smelting was invented locally in several different places. It was probably discovered independently in China before 2800 BC, in Central America perhaps around 600 AD, and in West Africa about the 9th or 10th century AD. Investment casting was invented in 4500–4000 BC in Southeast Asia and carbon dating has established mining at Alderley Edge in Cheshire, UK at 2280 to 1890 BC. Ötzi the Iceman, a male dated from 3300–3200 BC, was found with an axe with a copper head 99.7% pure; high levels of arsenic in his hair suggest his involvement in copper smelting. Experience with copper has assisted the development of other metals; in particular, copper smelting led to the discovery of iron smelting. Production in the Old Copper Complex in Michigan and Wisconsin is dated between 6000 and 3000 BC. Natural bronze, a type of copper made from ores rich in silicon, arsenic, and (rarely) tin, came into general use in the Balkans around 5500 BC.[citation needed]

The development of copper metallurgy likely unfolded as follows: 1) cold working of native copper, 2) annealing, 3) smelting, and 4) the lost wax technique. Elevated arsenic levels in his hair suggest he might have been involved in smelting processes himself. The skills gained through working with copper eventually laid the groundwork for the smelting of iron. The Old Copper Complex, operating in what is now Michigan and Wisconsin, churned out copper artifacts from 6000 to 3000 BC. In the Balkans, around 5500 BC, natural bronze—a form of copper alloyed with elements like silicon, arsenic, and occasionally tin—began to circulate. Notably, this variant of copper [citation needed] rode the wave of technological innovation alongside these early metallurgical feats.

message.content:
Copper, often found in its native form, has been intertwined with human history from the dawn of early civilizations. Tracing back roughly 10,000 years, it was first unearthed around 9000 BC in the Middle East. Notably, an ancient copper pendant discovered in northern Iraq, dating to 8700 BC, attests to this ancient timeline. Before humanity harnessed copper, gold and meteoric iron were the only metals familiar to us. The journey of copper metallurgy is believed to have unfolded in several steps: initially through cold working of native copper, followed by annealing, then smelting, and eventually the intricate lost wax casting technique. Intriguingly, these metallurgical advancements emerged almost simultaneously in southeastern Anatolia with the onset of the Neolithic era around 7500 BC. 

Like the development of agriculture, the innovation of copper smelting took root independently across different corners of the world. It blossomed in China before 2800 BC, found its way to Central America by approximately 600 AD, and took hold in West Africa around the 9th or 10th century AD. As for investment casting, it made its mark between 4500–4000 BC in Southeast Asia. Meanwhile, radiocarbon dating provides evidence of mining in Alderley Edge, Cheshire, UK, dating back to between 2280 and 1890 BC. 

Ötzi the Iceman, a fascinating relic from 3300–3200 BC, was discovered with an axe whose copper head possessed an impressive purity of 99.7%. Elevated arsenic levels in his hair suggest he might have been involved in smelting processes himself. The skills gained through working with copper eventually laid the groundwork for the smelting of iron. 

The Old Copper Complex, operating in what is now Michigan and Wisconsin, churned out copper artifacts from 6000 to 3000 BC. In the Balkans, around 5500 BC, natural bronze—a form of copper alloyed with elements like silicon, arsenic, and occasionally tin—began to circulate. Notably, this variant of copper [citation needed] rode the wave of technological innovation alongside these early metallurgical feats.

text_human: The implications are multiple as various research traditions are now[when?] heavily utilizing the lens of identity to examine phenomena.[citation needed] One implication of identity and of identity construction can be seen in occupational settings. This becomes increasing challenging in stigmatized jobs or "dirty work" (Hughes, 1951). Tracy and Trethewey (2005) state that "individuals gravitate toward and turn away from particular jobs depending in part, on the extent to which they validate a "preferred organizational self" (Tracy & Tretheway 2005, p. 169). Some jobs carry different stigmas or acclaims. In her analysis Tracy uses the example of correctional officers trying to shake the stigma of "glorified maids" (Tracy & Tretheway 2005). "The process by which people arrive at justifications of and values for various occupational choices." Among these are workplace satisfaction and overall quality of life (Tracy & Scott 2006, p. 33). People in these types of jobs are forced to find ways in order to create an identity they can live with. "Crafting a positive sense of self at work is more challenging when one's work is considered "dirty" by societal standards" (Tracy & Scott 2006, p. 7). "In other words, doing taint management is not just about allowing the employee to feel good in that job. "If employees must navigate discourses that question the viability of their work, and/ or experience obstacles in managing taint through transforming dirty work into a badge of honor, it is likely they will find blaming the client to be an efficacious route in affirming their identity" (Tracy & Scott 2006, p. 33).

One significant area where identity and its construction play a role is in occupational settings—a challenge that becomes even more difficult in stigmatized jobs or "dirty work" (Hughes, 1951). According to Tracy and Trethewey (2005), people are drawn to or avoid certain jobs based partly on whether those roles affirm their "preferred organizational self" (Tracy & Trethewey 2005, p. 169). Some occupations carry specific stigmas or levels of esteem. For instance, Tracy explores how correctional officers struggle against the stigma of being perceived as "glorified maids" (Tracy & Trethewey 2005). The process through which individuals justify and assign value to their occupational choices affects their workplace satisfaction and overall quality of life (Tracy & Scott 2006, p. 33). Those in stigmatized occupations must find ways to shape an identity they can accept. "Crafting a positive sense of self at work is more challenging when one's work is considered 'dirty' by societal standards" (Tracy & Scott 2006, p. 7). Engaging in "taint management" goes beyond simply allowing an employee to feel good about their job. If employees face societal doubts about the legitimacy of their work and face challenges in reframing it as honorable, they may resort to blaming the client as a way to affirm their identity (Tracy & Scott 2006, p. 33).

text_human: The term "house music" is said to have originated from a Chicago club called The Warehouse, which existed from 1977 to 1983. Clubbers to The Warehouse were primarily black and gay, who came to dance to music played by the club's resident DJ Frankie Knuckles, whom fans refer to as the "godfather of house". After the Warehouse closed in 1983, the crowds went to Knuckles' new club, The Power Plant. In the Channel 4 documentary Pump Up The Volume, Knuckles remarks that the first time he heard the term "house music" was upon seeing "we play house music" on a sign in the window of a bar on Chicago's South Side. One of the people in the car with him joked, "you know, that's the kind of music you play down at the Warehouse!", and then everybody laughed. South-Side Chicago DJ Leonard "Remix" Roy, in self-published statements, claims he put such a sign in a tavern window because it was where he played music that one might find in one's home; in his case, it referred to his mother's soul & disco records, which he worked into his sets. Farley Jackmaster Funk was quoted as saying "In 1982, I was DJing at a club called The Playground and there was this kid named Leonard 'Remix' Roy who was a DJ at a rival club called The Rink. He came over to my club one night, and into the DJ booth and said to me, 'I've got the gimmick that's gonna take all the people out of your club and into mine – it's called House music.' Now, where he got that name from or what made him think of it I don't know, so the answer lies with him."

text_human: T. Gilmartin, (Professor of History, Maynooth, 1890), writes in Church History, Vol. 1, Ch XVII: The Arians sought the approval of an Ecumenical Council. They sought to hold two councils. Constantius, summoned the bishops of the East to meet at Seleucia in Isauria, and those of the West to Rimini in Italy. A preliminary conference was held by the Arians at Sirmium, to agree a formula of faith. A "Homoeon" creed was adopted, declaring The Son to be "like the Father". The two met in autumn of 359. At Seleucia, one hundred and fifty bishops, of which one hundred and five were semi-Arian. The semi-Arians refused to accept anything less than the "Homoiousion", (see: Homoiousian), formulary of faith. The Imperial Prefect was obliged to disband, without agreeing on any creed. Acacius, the leader of the "Homoean" party went to Constantinople, where the Sirmian formulary of faith was approved by the "Home Synod", (consisted of those bishops who happened to be present at the Court for the time), and a decree of deposition issued against the leaders of the semi-Arians. At Rimini were over four hundred of which eighty were Arian, the rest were orthodox. The orthodox fathers refused to accept any creed but the Nicene, while the others were equally in favour of the Sirmian. Each party sent a deputation to the Emperor to say there was no probability to agreement, and asked for the bishops to return to their dioceses. For the purpose of wearing-down the orthodox bishops; (Sulpitius Severius says), Constantius delayed his answer for several months, and finally prevailed on them to accept the Sirmian creed. It was after this Council that Jerome said: " ...the whole world groaned in astonishment to find itself Arian."
text_ai_base: T. Gilmartin, a Professor of History at Maynooth in 1890, writes in Church History, Vol. 1, Ch XVII: The Arians sought the endorsement of an Ecumenical Council by organizing two separate councils. Constantius called the Eastern bishops to convene at Seleucia in Isauria and the Western bishops at Rimini in Italy. Before these meetings, the Arians held a preliminary conference at Sirmium to establish a consensus on a formula of faith. They adopted the "Homoeon" creed, asserting that the Son was "like the Father." The councils convened in the autumn of 359; Seleucia hosted 150 bishops, of whom 105 were semi-Arian. These semi-Arians insisted on the "Homoiousion" creed (see: Homoiousian) and would accept nothing less. Consequently, without any agreed creed, the Imperial Prefect disbanded the council. Acacius, the leader of the "Homoean" faction, traveled to Constantinople, where the Sirmian creed was ratified by the "Home Synod," comprising bishops present at the Court, and a decree was issued against the semi-Arian leaders. At Rimini, over 400 bishops attended, with 80 being Arian and the remainder orthodox. The orthodox fathers were steadfast in accepting only the Nicene creed, while the others preferred the Sirmian creed. Both parties sent delegations to the Emperor, expressing that an agreement was unlikely and requesting the bishops be allowed to return to their dioceses. Constantius delayed his response for several months, intending to exhaust the orthodox bishops, and ultimately persuaded them to accept the Sirmian creed. Following this Council, Jerome famously remarked, "The whole world groaned in astonishment to find itself Arian."

Gilmartin, a History Professor at Maynooth, detailed in Church History how the Arians maneuvered to secure support from an Ecumenical Council by cleverly orchestrating two separate gatherings. Constantius summoned Eastern bishops to gather at Seleucia in Isauria, while their Western counterparts were called to Rimini in Italy. But even before these councils, the Arians had a strategy session at Sirmium, aiming to hammer out a unified belief statement. What emerged was the "Homoeon" creed, proclaiming the Son as "like the Father." In the autumn of 359, the councils finally convened. Seleucia saw 150 bishops in attendance, 105 of whom leaned towards semi-Arian views. These semi-Arians remained steadfast, championing the "Homoiousion" creed ("alike in essence"), refusing to budge an inch. Such stubbornness led the Imperial Prefect to dismiss the meeting with nothing resolved. Meanwhile, Acacius headed to Constantinople, where he successfully secured approval for the Sirmian creed from the "Home Synod," a gathering of court-present bishops, alongside issuing decrees targeting semi-Arian leaders. Over at Rimini, the scene was even more bustling with more than 400 bishops, including 80 Arians, while the rest adhered to orthodox beliefs. The orthodox bishops were resolute, accepting solely the Nicene creed and nothing else. Yet, the Arian-aligned were pushing the Sirmian creed. With the two factions at an impasse, they approached the Emperor, requesting leave to return to their dioceses due to the deadlock. Constantius, however, played a waiting game for months, perhaps hoping to wear down the orthodox contingent. His maneuver eventually bore fruit as they conceded to the Sirmian creed. In the wake of this development, Jerome famously sighed, "The whole world groaned in astonishment to find itself Arian."

text_human: Sleep does not affect acquisition or recall while one is awake. Therefore, sleep has the greatest effect on memory consolidation. During sleep, the neural connections in the brain are strengthened. This enhances the brain’s abilities to stabilize and retain memories. There have been several studies which show that sleep improves the retention of memory, as memories are enhanced through active consolidation. System consolidation takes place during slow-wave sleep (SWS). This process implicates that memories are reactivated during sleep, but that the process doesn’t enhance every memory. It also implicates that qualitative changes are made to the memories when they are transferred to long-term store during sleep. When you are sleeping, the hippocampus replays the events of the day for the neocortex. The neocortex then reviews and processes memories, which moves them into long-term memory. When you do not get enough sleep it makes it more difficult to learn as these neural connections are not as strong, resulting in a lower retention rate of memories. Sleep deprivation makes it harder to focus, resulting in inefficient learning. Furthermore, some studies have shown that sleep deprivation can lead to false memories as the memories are not properly transferred to long-term memory. Therefore, it is important to get the proper amount of sleep so that memory can function at the highest level. One of the primary functions of sleep is thought to be the improvement of the consolidation of information, as several studies have demonstrated that memory depends on getting sufficient sleep between training and test. Additionally, data obtained from neuroimaging studies have shown activation patterns in the sleeping brain that mirror those recorded during the learning of tasks from the previous day, suggesting that new memories may be solidified through such rehearsal.

This process occurs during slow-wave sleep (SWS), where memories are reactivated but not all are enhanced. During this reactivation, qualitative changes occur as memories are transferred into long-term storage. While you sleep, the hippocampus replays the day's events for the neocortex to review and process, which ultimately moves them into long-term memory. Insufficient sleep weakens these neural connections, making it difficult to learn and retain information. Sleep deprivation not only hampers focus and learning efficiency but also risks the creation of false memories due to improper memory transfer. This compelling process unfolds mainly during slow-wave sleep (SWS), a phase where memories undergo a sort of reactivation. Yet, not all memories receive this enhancement; only selected ones make it into the vault of long-term storage. Imagine your hippocampus as a nightly storyteller, replaying the day's tales for the neocortex—like running a familiar script through for review and refinement, eventually leading to long-term memory transfer. When you skimp on sleep, these storytelling sessions falter, neural connections wobble, and learning becomes a struggle. Worse, sleep deprivation doesn’t just muddle focus and reduce learning efficiency—it might even prompt the creation of misleading memories through improper transfers. That's why catching enough z's is absolutely crucial for peak memory performance. In essence, sleep's pivotal role is to bolster information consolidation. Numerous studies point to the necessity of sufficient sleep for memory to effectively settle between learning and testing phases. What’s more, intriguing neuroimaging research reveals that the brain echoes familiar activation patterns during sleep, mirroring those seen during task learning. This tells us one thing: new memories may get solidified through this nocturnal rehearsal.

text_human: After gaining the Master Sword, Link is cleansed of the magic that kept him in wolf form, obtaining the Shadow Crystal. Now able to use it to switch between both forms at will, Link is led by Midna to the Mirror of Twilight located deep within the Gerudo Desert, the only known gateway between the Twilight Realm and Hyrule. However, they discover that the mirror is broken. The Sages there explain that Zant tried to destroy it, but he was only able to shatter it into fragments; only the true ruler of the Twili can completely destroy the Mirror of Twilight. They also reveal that they used it a century ago to banish Ganondorf, the Gerudo leader who attempted to steal the Triforce, to the Twilight Realm when executing him failed. Assisted by an underground resistance group they meet in Castle Town, Link and Midna set out to retrieve the missing shards of the Mirror, defeating those they infected. Once the portal has been restored, Midna is revealed to be the true ruler of the Twilight Realm, usurped by Zant when he cursed her into her current form. Confronting Zant, Link and Midna learn that Zant's coup was made possible when he forged a pact with Ganondorf, who asked for Zant's assistance in conquering Hyrule. After Link defeats Zant, Midna recovers the Fused Shadows, but destroys Zant after learning that only Ganondorf's death can release her from her curse. Returning to Hyrule, Link and Midna find Ganondorf in Hyrule Castle, with a lifeless Zelda suspended above his head. Ganondorf fights Link by possessing Zelda's body and eventually by transforming into a beast, but Link defeats him and Midna is able to resurrect Zelda.

They find the mirror shattered, and the Sages explain that Zant attempted to destroy it. The Sages share a history of power and betrayal, noting they had exiled Ganondorf, the formidable Gerudo leader, a century before—an exile enacted using this very mirror after unsuccessful efforts to execute him for trying to claim the Triforce. Teaming up with a secretive resistance in Castle Town's depths, Link and Midna embark on a perilous quest to locate the scattered shards of the mirror. Each shard poses its own challenge, guarded by those who've fallen under dark influence.

As the pieces come together, revelations emerge: Midna, rightful ruler of the Twilight Realm, had been usurped by Zant, who cursed her into her diminutive form. Upon confronting Zant, Link and Midna uncover a deeper betrayal—Zant had forged an alliance with Ganondorf, aiding the tyrant's ambition to conquer Hyrule. Their battle culminates in Zant's defeat; Midna retrieves the Fused Shadows, unleashing her full power upon Zant, knowing her curse lingers until Ganondorf is vanquished.

The journey circles back to ominous Hyrule Castle, where Ganondorf waits, holding Zelda's lifeless form captive. The ensuing battle is fierce and multifaceted. First, Ganondorf possesses Zelda to battle Link, then transforms into a monstrous beast. Despite the odds, Link triumphs, rescuing Zelda from her unnatural slumber with Midna's help. And thus, the cycle of evil is thwarted once more, but was it truly the end?

text_human: Several explanations have been offered for Yale’s representation in national elections since the end of the Vietnam War. Various sources note the spirit of campus activism that has existed at Yale since the 1960s, and the intellectual influence of Reverend William Sloane Coffin on many of the future candidates. Yale President Richard Levin attributes the run to Yale’s focus on creating "a laboratory for future leaders," an institutional priority that began during the tenure of Yale Presidents Alfred Whitney Griswold and Kingman Brewster. Richard H. Brodhead, former dean of Yale College and now president of Duke University, stated: "We do give very significant attention to orientation to the community in our admissions, and there is a very strong tradition of volunteerism at Yale." Yale historian Gaddis Smith notes "an ethos of organized activity" at Yale during the 20th century that led John Kerry to lead the Yale Political Union's Liberal Party, George Pataki the Conservative Party, and Joseph Lieberman to manage the Yale Daily News. Camille Paglia points to a history of networking and elitism: "It has to do with a web of friendships and affiliations built up in school." CNN suggests that George W. Bush benefited from preferential admissions policies for the "son and grandson of alumni", and for a "member of a politically influential family." New York Times correspondent Elisabeth Bumiller and The Atlantic Monthly correspondent James Fallows credit the culture of community and cooperation that exists between students, faculty, and administration, which downplays self-interest and reinforces commitment to others.

text_human: Allusions to legal issues in To Kill a Mockingbird, particularly in scenes outside of the courtroom, has drawn the attention from legal scholars. Claudia Durst Johnson writes that "a greater volume of critical readings has been amassed by two legal scholars in law journals than by all the literary scholars in literary journals". The opening quote by the 19th-century essayist Charles Lamb reads: "Lawyers, I suppose, were children once." Johnson notes that even in Scout and Jem's childhood world, compromises and treaties are struck with each other by spitting on one's palm and laws are discussed by Atticus and his children: is it right that Bob Ewell hunts and traps out of season? Many social codes are broken by people in symbolic courtrooms: Mr. Dolphus Raymond has been exiled by society for taking a black woman as his common-law wife and having interracial children; Mayella Ewell is beaten by her father in punishment for kissing Tom Robinson; by being turned into a non-person, Boo Radley receives a punishment far greater than any court could have given him. Scout repeatedly breaks codes and laws and reacts to her punishment for them. For example, she refuses to wear frilly clothes, saying that Aunt Alexandra's "fanatical" attempts to place her in them made her feel "a pink cotton penitentiary closing in on [her]". Johnson states, "[t]he novel is a study of how Jem and Scout begin to perceive the complexity of social codes and how the configuration of relationships dictated by or set off by those codes fails or nurtures the inhabitants of (their) small worlds."

Scout frequently violates social codes and laws and faces consequences for her actions. She resists wearing frilly clothes, feeling that Aunt Alexandra’s "fanatical" insistence traps her in "a pink cotton penitentiary." Johnson comments that the novel explores Jem and Scout's growing awareness of social codes and how these relationships, dictated by such codes, either fail or support the residents of their small world.
text_ai_humanized: The intricate legal themes woven throughout *To Kill a Mockingbird*, especially beyond the courtroom's dramatic confines, have long intrigued legal scholars. Claudia Durst Johnson notes an interesting phenomenon: legal experts seem to engage more deeply with the book's themes, as evidenced by their frequent analysis in law journals, compared to the attention literary scholars give it in their own publications. The book’s opening line, borrowed from 19th-century essayist Charles Lamb—"Lawyers, I suppose, were children once"—sets a tone that resonates throughout the story, highlighting how even the youthful antics of Scout and Jem reflect aspects of legal negotiation. Their earnest pacts, sealed through the ritual of spitting on palms, and the candid discussions with Atticus about laws and morality—like Bob Ewell's dubious right to hunt out of season—reveal an early understanding of justice. The novel portrays symbolic courtroom dramas in everyday life, where societal norms are tested and defied. Mr. Dolphus Raymond, for instance, finds himself on the fringes of society—his choice to live with a black partner and raise interracial children earns him scorn and ostracism. Similarly, Mayella Ewell suffers at the hands of her abusive father after she innocently attempts to kiss Tom Robinson, while Boo Radley’s reclusive existence is met with whispers and rumors—a punishment harsher, in some ways, than any legal action might dictate. Scout, with her unwavering spirit, often brushes against the rigid community expectations. Her refusal to don frilly dresses becomes a battleground between her and Aunt Alexandra, whose "fanatical" insistence on propriety feels like a "pink cotton penitentiary" to Scout. Johnson delves into how Jem and Scout grapple with these social codes, exploring how relationships shaped by such conventions can either crumble or bolster the fabric of their close-knit community.

text_human: In late 1203, John attempted to relieve Château Gaillard, which although besieged by Philip was guarding the eastern flank of Normandy. John attempted a synchronised operation involving land-based and water-borne forces, considered by most historians today to have been imaginative in conception, but overly complex for forces of the period to have carried out successfully. John's relief operation was blocked by Philip's forces, and John turned back to Brittany in an attempt to draw Philip away from eastern Normandy. John successfully devastated much of Brittany, but did not deflect Philip's main thrust into the east of Normandy. Opinions vary amongst historians as to the military skill shown by John during this campaign, with most recent historians arguing that his performance was passable, although not impressive.[nb 8] John's situation began to deteriorate rapidly. The eastern border region of Normandy had been extensively cultivated by Philip and his predecessors for several years, whilst Angevin authority in the south had been undermined by Richard's giving away of various key castles some years before. His use of routier mercenaries in the central regions had rapidly eaten away his remaining support in this area too, which set the stage for a sudden collapse of Angevin power.[nb 9] John retreated back across the Channel in December, sending orders for the establishment of a fresh defensive line to the west of Chateau Gaillard. In March 1204, Gaillard fell. John's mother Eleanor died the following month. This was not just a personal blow for John, but threatened to unravel the widespread Angevin alliances across the far south of France. Philip moved south around the new defensive line and struck upwards at the heart of the Duchy, now facing little resistance. By August, Philip had taken Normandy and advanced south to occupy Anjou and Poitou as well. John's only remaining possession on the Continent was now the Duchy of Aquitaine.

Philip bypassed the new defenses and struck at the core of the Duchy, meeting little resistance. By August, Philip had seized control of Normandy and advanced south, capturing Anjou and Poitou. The Duchy of Aquitaine was John's last remaining possession on the continent.

text_human: With respect to these outer regions, the Qing maintained imperial control, with the emperor acting as Mongol khan, patron of Tibetan Buddhism and protector of Muslims. However, Qing policy changed with the establishment of Xinjiang province in 1884. During The Great Game era, taking advantage of the Dungan revolt in northwest China, Yaqub Beg invaded Xinjiang from Central Asia with support from the British Empire, and made himself the ruler of the kingdom of Kashgaria. The Qing court sent forces to defeat Yaqub Beg and Xinjiang was reconquered, and then the political system of China proper was formally applied onto Xinjiang. The Kumul Khanate, which was incorporated into the Qing empire as a vassal after helping Qing defeat the Zunghars in 1757, maintained its status after Xinjiang turned into a province through the end of the dynasty in the Xinhai Revolution up until 1930. In early 20th century, Britain sent an expedition force to Tibet and forced Tibetans to sign a treaty. The Qing court responded by asserting Chinese sovereignty over Tibet, resulting in the 1906 Anglo-Chinese Convention signed between Britain and China. The British agreed not to annex Tibetan territory or to interfere in the administration of Tibet, while China engaged not to permit any other foreign state to interfere with the territory or internal administration of Tibet. Furthermore, similar to Xinjiang which was converted into a province earlier, the Qing government also turned Manchuria into three provinces in the early 20th century, officially known as the "Three Northeast Provinces", and established the post of Viceroy of the Three Northeast Provinces to oversee these provinces, making the total number of regional viceroys to nine.

This approach shifted when Xinjiang was established as a province in 1884. During the era of The Great Game, Yaqub Beg, exploiting the Dungan revolt in northwest China, invaded Xinjiang from Central Asia with support from the British Empire and proclaimed himself ruler of Kashgaria. The Qing court dispatched forces to defeat Yaqub Beg and reconquer Xinjiang, after which the political system of China proper was applied to the region. The Kumul Khanate, which joined the Qing empire as a vassal after assisting in the defeat of the Zunghars in 1757, retained its status through the end of the dynasty and until 1930, even as Xinjiang transitioned into a province. In the early 20th century, Britain sent an expeditionary force to Tibet, compelling the Tibetans to sign a treaty. The Qing court responded by declaring Chinese sovereignty over Tibet, leading to the 1906 Anglo-Chinese Convention between Britain and China. In this agreement, Britain vowed not to annex Tibetan territory or interfere in Tibet's administration, while China pledged to prevent any other foreign state from doing so. Much like Xinjiang's conversion into a province, the Qing government also reorganized Manchuria into the "Three Northeast Provinces" and established the role of Viceroy of the Three Northeast Provinces to supervise these areas, increasing the number of regional viceroys to nine.

message.content:
Under the Qing dynasty, control over distant territories was maintained by strategically embracing multifaceted roles—acting as the Mongol khan, a patron of Tibetan Buddhism, and a defender of Muslims. However, a notable shift occurred in 1884 when Xinjiang was officially reclassified as a province. During the tumultuous era referred to as the Great Game, Yaqub Beg seized the upheaval caused by the Dungan revolt in northwest China. With backing from the British Empire, he invaded Xinjiang from Central Asia, establishing himself as the ruler of Kashgaria. In response, the Qing court sent out its military forces to defeat Yaqub Beg, reclaiming Xinjiang and subsequently imposing the political system of China proper upon the region.

Meanwhile, the Kumul Khanate—an entity with historical ties to the empire—had initially become a vassal state in 1757 after aiding in the defeat of the Zunghar army. Remarkably, it held onto its vassal status well beyond the dynasty's conclusion, continuing this relationship until 1930 even after Xinjiang's provincial transition. Fast forward to the early 20th century, when Britain orchestrated an expedition into Tibet that pressured Tibetan leaders to ink a treaty. This provoked the Qing court to assert Chinese sovereignty, culminating in the 1906 Anglo-Chinese Convention with Britain. The pact involved Britain pledging not to annex Tibetan land or meddle in its governance, while China promised to prevent other foreign influences from doing so.

Similarly, another significant administrative overhaul took place in Manchuria. The Qing regime reorganized this region into the "Three Northeast Provinces," appointing a Viceroy of the Three Northeast Provinces to oversee them, expanding the potential of regional governance through nine viceroys. This reorganization represented a broader strategy to consolidate power and streamline the administration of these critical areas.

text_human: The most persistent theme throughout his films is tension in parent-child relationships. Parents (often fathers) are reluctant, absent or ignorant. Peter Banning in Hook starts off in the beginning of the film as a reluctant married-to-his-work parent who through the course of the film regains the respect of his children. The notable absence of Elliott's father in E.T., is the most famous example of this theme. In Indiana Jones and the Last Crusade, it is revealed that Indy has always had a very strained relationship with his father, who is a professor of medieval literature, as his father always seemed more interested in his work, specifically in his studies of the Holy Grail, than in his own son, although his father does not seem to realize or understand the negative effect that his aloof nature had on Indy (he even believes he was a good father in the sense that he taught his son "self reliance," which is not how Indy saw it). Even Oskar Schindler, from Schindler's List, is reluctant to have a child with his wife. Munich depicts Avner as a man away from his wife and newborn daughter. There are of course exceptions; Brody in Jaws is a committed family man, while John Anderton in Minority Report is a shattered man after the disappearance of his son. This theme is arguably the most autobiographical aspect of Spielberg's films, since Spielberg himself was affected by his parents' divorce as a child and by the absence of his father. Furthermore, to this theme, protagonists in his films often come from families with divorced parents, most notably E.T. the Extra-Terrestrial (protagonist Elliot's mother is divorced) and Catch Me If You Can (Frank Abagnale's mother and father split early on in the film). Little known also is Tim in Jurassic Park (early in the film, another secondary character mentions Tim and Lex's parents' divorce). The family often shown divided is often resolved in the ending as well. Following this theme of reluctant fathers and father figures, Tim looks to Dr. Alan Grant as a father figure. Initially, Dr. Grant is reluctant to return those paternal feelings to Tim. However, by the end of the film, he has changed, and the kids even fall asleep with their heads on his shoulders.
text_ai_base: A persistent theme in many of his films is the tension within parent-child relationships, often characterized by reluctant, absent, or ignorant parents, particularly fathers. In "Hook," Peter Banning begins as a parent overly focused on his career but eventually regains his children's respect. A well-known example of this theme is the absence of Elliott's father in "E.T." In "Indiana Jones and the Last Crusade," Indy has a strained relationship with his father, a professor of medieval literature, who seems more consumed by his research on the Holy Grail than by his son. Indy's father mistakenly believes that his aloof parenting instilled "self-reliance," a view not shared by Indy. Similarly, in "Schindler's List," Oskar Schindler is hesitant about starting a family. "Munich" depicts Avner, who is separated from his wife and newborn daughter. However, there are exceptions, such as Brody in "Jaws," a dedicated family man, and John Anderton in "Minority Report," who is devastated by his son's disappearance. This theme arguably reflects Spielberg's own experiences, as he was deeply affected by his parents' divorce and his father's absence. Many of his protagonists come from broken families, as seen in "E.T. the Extra-Terrestrial," where Elliott's mother is divorced, and "Catch Me If You Can," where Frank Abagnale's parents split early in the film. Less known is the reference to Tim's parents' divorce in "Jurassic Park." Often, these divided families find resolution by the film's end. This theme of reluctant father figures is further illustrated in "Jurassic Park," where Tim looks to Dr. Alan Grant as a father figure. Initially hesitant to embrace this role, Dr. Grant eventually softens, culminating in a scene where the children rest their heads on his shoulders.

You can see this evolution in a tender scene where the children find comfort, resting their heads on his shoulders.

However, exceptions exist, such as Chief Brody in "Jaws," who emerges as a steadfast family man, or John Anderton in "Minority Report," grappling with the anguish of his son's disappearance. Interestingly, many surmise this theme mirrors Spielberg’s own past, marked by the impact of his parents' divorce and his father's absence. His protagonists often spring from fractured families, like in "E.T.," where Elliott’s mother handles life post-divorce, or "Catch Me If You Can," where Frank Abagnale witnesses his parents' separation early on. Even in "Jurassic Park,” there’s a subtler nod to family divides with Tim's parents having split.

Yet, the fractured families in these narratives frequently seek some semblance of resolution by the movie's conclusion. The motif of reluctant father figures finds another expression in "Jurassic Park," where Dr. Alan Grant, initially hesitant to assume a paternal role, eventually embraces it. You can see this evolution in a tender scene where the children find comfort, resting their heads on his shoulders.

text_human: For its complete North American release, the Nintendo Entertainment System was progressively released over the ensuing years in four different bundles: the Deluxe Set, the Control Deck, the Action Set and the Power Set. The Deluxe Set, retailing at US$199.99 (equivalent to $475 in 2016), included R.O.B., a light gun called the NES Zapper, two controllers, and two Game Paks: Gyromite, and Duck Hunt. The Basic Set, retailing at US$89.99 with no game, and US$99.99 bundled with "Super Mario Bros." The Action Set, retailing in 1988 for US$149.99, came with the Control Deck, two game controllers, an NES Zapper, and a dual Game Pak containing both Super Mario Bros. and Duck Hunt. In 1989, the Power Set included the console, two game controllers, a NES Zapper, a Power Pad, and a triple Game Pak containing Super Mario Bros, Duck Hunt, and World Class Track Meet. In 1990, a Sports Set bundle was released, including the console, an NES Satellite infrared wireless multitap adapter, four game controllers, and a dual Game Pak containing Super Spike V'Ball and Nintendo World Cup. Two more bundle packages were later released using the original model NES console. The Challenge Set of 1992 included the console, two controllers, and a Super Mario Bros. 3 Game Pak for a retail price of US$89.99. The Basic Set, first released in 1987, was repackaged for a retail US$89.99. It included only the console and two controllers, and no longer was bundled with a cartridge. Instead, it contained a book called the Official Nintendo Player's Guide, which contained detailed information for every NES game made up to that point.

text_human: Northwestern's School of Communication has been especially fruitful in the number of actors, actresses, playwrights, and film and television writers and directors it has produced. Alumni who have made their mark on film and television include Ann-Margret, Warren Beatty, Jodie Markell, Paul Lynde, David Schwimmer, Anne Dudek, Zach Braff, Zooey Deschanel, Marg Helgenberger, Julia Louis-Dreyfus, Jerry Orbach, Jennifer Jones, Megan Mullally, John Cameron Mitchell, Dermot Mulroney, Charlton Heston, Richard Kind, Ana Gasteyer, Brad Hall, Shelley Long, William Daniels, Cloris Leachman, Bonnie Bartlett, Paula Prentiss, Richard Benjamin, Laura Innes, Charles Busch, Stephanie March, Tony Roberts, Jeri Ryan, Kimberly Williams-Paisley, McLean Stevenson, Tony Randall, Charlotte Rae, Paul Lynde, Patricia Neal, Nancy Dussault, Robert Reed, Mara Brock Akil, Greg Berlanti, Bill Nuss, Dusty Kay, Dan Shor, Seth Meyers, Frank DeCaro, Zach Gilford, Nicole Sullivan, Stephen Colbert, Sandra Seacat and Garry Marshall. Directors who were graduated from Northwestern include Gerald Freedman, Stuart Hagmann, Marshall W. Mason, and Mary Zimmerman. Lee Phillip Bell hosted a talk show in Chicago from 1952 to 1986 and co-created the Daytime Emmy Award-winning soap operas The Young and the Restless in 1973 and The Bold and the Beautiful in 1987. Alumni such as Sheldon Harnick, Stephanie D'Abruzzo, Heather Headley, Kristen Schaal, Lily Rabe, and Walter Kerr have distinguished themselves on Broadway, as has designer Bob Mackie. Amsterdam-based comedy theater Boom Chicago was founded by Northwestern alumni, and the school has become a training ground for future The Second City, I.O., ComedySportz, Mad TV and Saturday Night Live talent. Tam Spiva wrote scripts for The Brady Bunch and Gentle Ben. In New York, Los Angeles, and Chicago, the number of Northwestern alumni involved in theater, film, and television is so large that a perception has formed that there's such a thing as a "Northwestern mafia."

text_human: Many cultures define the transition into adultlike sexuality by specific biological or social milestones in an adolescent's life. For example, menarche (the first menstrual period of a female), or semenarche (the first ejaculation of a male) are frequent sexual defining points for many cultures. In addition to biological factors, an adolescent's sexual socialization is highly dependent upon whether their culture takes a restrictive or permissive attitude toward teen or premarital sexual activity. Restrictive cultures overtly discourage sexual activity in unmarried adolescents or until an adolescent undergoes a formal rite of passage. These cultures may attempt to restrict sexual activity by separating males and females throughout their development, or through public shaming and physical punishment when sexual activity does occur. In less restrictive cultures, there is more tolerance for displays of adolescent sexuality, or of the interaction between males and females in public and private spaces. Less restrictive cultures may tolerate some aspects of adolescent sexuality, while objecting to other aspects. For instance, some cultures find teenage sexual activity acceptable but teenage pregnancy highly undesirable. Other cultures do not object to teenage sexual activity or teenage pregnancy, as long as they occur after marriage. In permissive societies, overt sexual behavior among unmarried teens is perceived as acceptable, and is sometimes even encouraged. Regardless of whether a culture is restrictive or permissive, there are likely to be discrepancies in how females versus males are expected to express their sexuality. Cultures vary in how overt this double standard is—in some it is legally inscribed, while in others it is communicated through social convention. Lesbian, gay, bi-sexual and transsexual youth face much discrimination through bullying from those unlike them and may find telling others that they are gay to be a traumatic experience. The range of sexual attitudes that a culture embraces could thus be seen to affect the beliefs, lifestyles, and societal perceptions of its adolescents.
text_ai_base: Many cultures mark the transition to adult sexuality through specific biological or social milestones during adolescence. Menarche, the onset of menstruation in females, and semenarche, the first ejaculation in males, often serve as key indicators in this transition. However, an adolescent's sexual socialization is also heavily influenced by the cultural stance on teen and premarital sexual activity, which can be either restrictive or permissive. Restrictive cultures discourage sexual activity in unmarried adolescents, at times enforcing separation of genders during development or using public shaming and physical punishment as deterrents. In contrast, less restrictive cultures may allow more freedom for adolescent sexual expression and interaction between genders in both public and private settings. While some less restrictive cultures may tolerate teenage sexual activity, they might still object to teenage pregnancy unless it occurs after marriage. Permissive societies often accept and sometimes encourage overt sexual behavior among unmarried teens. Regardless of cultural views, there tends to be a disparity in expectations for male and female expression of sexuality, which can be ingrained through legal means or social norms. Additionally, lesbian, gay, bisexual, and transgender youths frequently face discrimination and bullying, and revealing their sexual identity can be distressing. The spectrum of sexual attitudes a culture adopts profoundly affects the beliefs, lifestyles, and social perceptions of its adolescents.
text_ai_humanized: Across the globe, various cultures have distinct ways of acknowledging the shift into adult sexuality, typically marked by certain biological or social milestones during one's teenage years. For many, menarche—the onset of menstruation for young women—and semenarche—when young men experience their first ejaculation—stand out as significant milestones. But the journey doesn't end there; cultural perceptions and attitudes toward teen and premarital sexual activities play a significant role in an adolescent's sexual development. In some societies, strict boundaries guide adolescent behavior, often discouraging sexual activity outside the bounds of marriage. They might enforce these limits through gender segregation during formative years or, at times, through harsher tactics such as public humiliation or corporal punishment as a means of deterrence. But not all cultures take such a firm stance. Others, which are less restrictive, might provide adolescents with the freedom to explore their sexual identities and foster interactions between genders, whether openly in public or quietly in private. Despite this latitude, even these cultures might draw the line at teenage pregnancy unless it's sanctioned by marriage. Then, there are permissive societies that not only accept but occasionally even cultivate the expression of sexuality among unmarried teens. Yet, regardless of how open or repressed a society might be about adolescent sexuality, there remains a noticeable mismatch in expectations placed on males versus females. These discrepancies are often enshrined in laws or deeply rooted social customs. Moreover, adolescents who identify as lesbian, gay, bisexual, or transgender often navigate additional challenges, like discrimination and harassment, and might find coming out to be an intimidating ordeal. Ultimately, the way a culture approaches sexual norms shapes the beliefs, lifestyles, and social narratives experienced by its youth, with impacts that ripple through their formative years and beyond.

text_human: The Empire was established in 1336 by Harihara I and his brother Bukka Raya I of Sangama Dynasty. The empire rose to prominence as a culmination of attempts by the southern powers to ward off Islamic invasions by the end of the 13th century. The empire is named after its capital city of Vijayanagara, whose ruins surround present day Hampi, now a World Heritage Site in Karnataka, India. The empire's legacy includes many monuments spread over South India, the best known of which is the group at Hampi. The previous temple building traditions in South India came together in the Vijayanagara Architecture style. The mingling of all faiths and vernaculars inspired architectural innovation of Hindu temple construction, first in the Deccan and later in the Dravidian idioms using the local granite. South Indian mathematics flourished under the protection of the Vijayanagara Empire in Kerala. The south Indian mathematician Madhava of Sangamagrama founded the famous Kerala school of astronomy and mathematics in the 14th century which produced a lot of great south Indian mathematicians like Parameshvara, Nilakantha Somayaji and Jyeṣṭhadeva in medieval south India. Efficient administration and vigorous overseas trade brought new technologies such as water management systems for irrigation. The empire's patronage enabled fine arts and literature to reach new heights in Kannada, Telugu, Tamil and Sanskrit, while Carnatic music evolved into its current form. The Vijayanagara Empire created an epoch in South Indian history that transcended regionalism by promoting Hinduism as a unifying factor. The empire reached its peak during the rule of Sri Krishnadevaraya when Vijayanagara armies were consistently victorious. The empire annexed areas formerly under the Sultanates in the northern Deccan and the territories in the eastern Deccan, including Kalinga, while simultaneously maintaining control over all its subordinates in the south. Many important monuments were either completed or commissioned during the time of Krishna Deva Raya. Vijayanagara went into decline after the defeat in the Battle of Talikota (1565).

text_ai_humanized: The Vijayanagara Empire, established in 1336 by the Sangama Dynasty brothers Harihara I and Bukka Raya I, rose to prominence just as southern states grappled with warding off late 13th-century Islamic invasions. Named after its capital, Vijayanagara, the empire's vestiges surround today's Hampi, a UNESCO World Heritage Site nestled in Karnataka, India. Its enduring legacy is vividly etched in numerous monuments scattered across South India, with those at Hampi standing out as particularly renowned. Architectural evolution during this period saw local temple-building traditions merging into what became known as Vijayanagara Architecture, characterized by its use of local granite and innovative Hindu temple designs developed across the Deccan and Dravidian regions. Interestingly, a vibrant period for South Indian mathematics coincided with the empire's heyday, notably in Kerala. It was here that the illustrious mathematician Madhava of Sangamagrama laid the groundwork for the Kerala school of astronomy and mathematics during the 14th century. This school became a cradle for eminent mathematicians like Parameshvara, Nilakantha Somayaji, and Jyeṣṭhadeva during medieval times. Additionally, the empire's efficient governance and flourishing overseas trade ushered in advanced technologies, such as sophisticated irrigation water management systems. A cultural renaissance unfolded as the empire cultivated the fine arts and literature, particularly nurturing works in Kannada, Telugu, Tamil, and Sanskrit. Notably, this period saw the evolution of Carnatic music into the form we recognize today. The Vijayanagara Empire didn't just straddle regional boundaries; it championed Hinduism as a cohesive force. Under the illustrious rule of Sri Krishnadevaraya, the empire soared to its zenith, marked by military successes and territorial expansion. Regions from the northern Deccan Sultanates to eastern territories like Kalinga fell under its sway, alongside the steadfast allegiance from southern vassals. Substantial monuments were either completed or began under Krishna Deva Raya's direction. Yet, as with many empires, its decline was inevitable. The decisive blow came with the empire's defeat at the Battle of Talikota in 1565, marking the beginning of a slow waning of its once-mighty influence.

text_human: Before forming Queen, Brian May and Roger Taylor had played together in a band named Smile. Freddie Mercury (then known by his birth name of Farrokh "Freddie" Bulsara) was a fan of Smile and encouraged them to experiment with more elaborate stage and recording techniques. Mercury joined the band in 1970, suggested "Queen" as a new band name, and adopted his familiar stage name. John Deacon was recruited prior to recording their eponymous debut album in 1973. Queen first charted in the UK with their second album, Queen II, in 1974, but it was the release of Sheer Heart Attack later that year and A Night at the Opera in 1975 which brought them international success. The latter featured "Bohemian Rhapsody", which stayed at number one in the UK for nine weeks and popularised the music video. Their 1977 album, News of the World, contained "We Will Rock You" and "We Are the Champions", which have become anthems at sporting events. By the early 1980s, Queen were one of the biggest stadium rock bands in the world. Their performance at 1985's Live Aid is ranked among the greatest in rock history by various music publications, with a 2005 industry poll ranking it the best. In 1991, Mercury died of bronchopneumonia, a complication of AIDS, and Deacon retired in 1997. Since then, May and Taylor have occasionally performed together, including with Paul Rodgers (2004–09) and with Adam Lambert (since 2011). In November 2014, Queen released a new album, Queen Forever, featuring vocals from the late Mercury.

Although their first breakthrough in the UK charts came with their second album, Queen II, in 1974, it was the releases of Sheer Heart Attack later that year and A Night at the Opera in 1975 that truly brought them international fame. The latter included "Bohemian Rhapsody," which topped the UK charts for nine weeks and popularized the music video format. Their 1977 album, News of the World, featured "We Will Rock You" and "We Are the Champions," both of which became anthems at sports events. By the early 1980s, Queen had become one of the world's biggest stadium rock bands. Their performance at Live Aid in 1985 is considered one of rock history's greatest by many music publications, with a 2005 industry poll naming it the best. In 1991, Mercury died of bronchopneumonia related to AIDS, and Deacon retired in 1997. Since then, May and Taylor have occasionally performed together, including with Paul Rodgers from 2004 to 2009 and with Adam Lambert since 2011. In November 2014, Queen released the album Queen Forever, featuring vocals from the late Mercury.
