text_human: Compared to other team sports, the National Football League preseason is very structured. Every NFL team plays exactly four pre-season exhibition games a year, two at home and two away, with the exception of two teams each year who play a fifth game, the Pro Football Hall of Fame Game. These exhibition games, most of which are held in the month of August, are played for the purpose of helping coaches narrow down the roster from the offseason limit of 90 players to the regular-season limit of 53 players. While the scheduling formula is not as rigid for preseason games as they are for the regular season, there are numerous restrictions and traditions that limit the choices of preseason opponents; teams are also restricted on what days and times they can play these games. Split-squad games, a practice common in baseball and hockey, where a team that is scheduled to play two games on the same day splits their team into two squads, are prohibited. The NFL has played exhibition games in Europe, Japan, Canada, Australia (including the American Bowl in 1999) and Mexico to spread the league's popularity (a game of this type was proposed for China but, due to financial and logistical problems, was eventually canceled). The league has tacitly forbidden the playing of non-league opponents, with the last interleague game having come in 1972 and the last game against a team other than an NFL team (the all-NFL rookie College All-Stars) was held in 1976. Exhibition games are quite unpopular with many fans, who resent having to pay regular-season prices for two home exhibition games as part of a season-ticket package. Numerous lawsuits have been brought by fans and classes of fans against the NFL or its member teams regarding this practice, but none have been successful in halting it.[citation needed] The Pro Bowl, traditionally played after the end of the NFL season (since 2011 is played the week prior to the Super Bowl), is also considered an exhibition game.
text_ai_base: Compared to other team sports, the National Football League (NFL) preseason is highly structured. Each NFL team typically plays four preseason exhibition games: two at home and two away. However, two teams play a fifth game in the Pro Football Hall of Fame Game. These exhibition matches, mostly held in August, help coaches reduce the roster from 90 offseason players to the regular-season limit of 53. Although the scheduling for preseason games is less rigid than the regular season, there are many restrictions and traditions that influence opponent selection and game timing. Unlike baseball and hockey, where split-squad games are common, the NFL prohibits teams from splitting their roster to play two games in one day. The NFL has hosted exhibition games in locations such as Europe, Japan, Canada, Australia, and Mexico to expand the league's global reach. A game was once proposed for China but was canceled due to financial and logistical difficulties. Playing against non-league teams is largely forbidden since the last such game occurred in 1972, and the last non-NFL opponent was the College All-Stars in 1976. Many fans dislike exhibition games, as they are required to pay regular-season prices for them within season-ticket packages, leading to numerous, albeit unsuccessful, lawsuits against the NFL. The Pro Bowl, considered an exhibition game, traditionally occurs after the season ends, though since 2011, it has been played the week before the Super Bowl.
text_ai_humanized: In comparison to other team sports, the NFL preseason stands out for its structured nature. Typically, each team participates in four exhibition games: two on their home turf and two away. Interestingly, there are exceptions—two lucky teams get to play an additional fifth game at the iconic Pro Football Hall of Fame Game. August is generally the month for these matchups, allowing coaches to whittle down rosters from 90 offseason players to the 53 who suit up for the regular season. Unlike the rigid scheduling of the regular season, the preseason follows a looser outline, yet it remains guided by various traditions and restrictions that affect how opponents and game dates are chosen. The NFL, unlike baseball or hockey, doesn’t allow for the roster-splitting antics seen in doubleheaders; no team gets to play two games on the same day. In its quest to broaden its international appeal, the NFL has staged exhibition games in diverse spots like Europe, Japan, Canada, Australia, and Mexico. There was even talk of heading to China, but that plan fell apart over financial and logistical hurdles. Playing against teams outside the NFL is mostly off the table these days. The last time NFL teams faced non-league opponents was back in 1972, with the College All-Stars lining up against NFL squads until 1976. There's a fair amount of grumbling among fans when it comes to these exhibition games, mainly because these games often carry the same hefty price tags as regular-season games in season ticket packages. This has sparked quite a few lawsuits against the league, although none have made much headway. The Pro Bowl, which also falls under the banner of an exhibition game, traditionally wrapped up the season. Interestingly, since 2011, it’s been held a week before the Super Bowl instead.

text_human: The palace measures 108 metres (354 ft) by 120 metres (390 ft), is 24 metres (79 ft) high and contains over 77,000 m2 (830,000 sq ft) of floorspace. The floor area is smaller than the Royal Palace of Madrid, the Papal Palace in Rome, the Louvre in Paris, the Hofburg Palace in Vienna, or the Forbidden City. There are 775 rooms, including 19 state rooms, 52 principal bedrooms, 188 staff bedrooms, 92 offices, and 78 bathrooms. The principal rooms are contained on the piano nobile behind the west-facing garden façade at the rear of the palace. The centre of this ornate suite of state rooms is the Music Room, its large bow the dominant feature of the façade. Flanking the Music Room are the Blue and the White Drawing Rooms. At the centre of the suite, serving as a corridor to link the state rooms, is the Picture Gallery, which is top-lit and 55 yards (50 m) long. The Gallery is hung with numerous works including some by Rembrandt, van Dyck, Rubens and Vermeer; other rooms leading from the Picture Gallery are the Throne Room and the Green Drawing Room. The Green Drawing Room serves as a huge anteroom to the Throne Room, and is part of the ceremonial route to the throne from the Guard Room at the top of the Grand Staircase. The Guard Room contains white marble statues of Queen Victoria and Prince Albert, in Roman costume, set in a tribune lined with tapestries. These very formal rooms are used only for ceremonial and official entertaining, but are open to the public every summer.

text_human: As Muslim institutions of higher learning, the madrasa had the legal designation of waqf. In central and eastern Islamic lands, the view that the madrasa, as a charitable endowment, will remain under the control of the donor (and their descendent), resulted in a "spurt" of establishment of madaris in the 11th and 12th centuries. However, in Western Islamic lands, where the Maliki views prohibited donors from controlling their endowment, madaris were not as popular. Unlike the corporate designation of Western institutions of higher learning, the waqf designation seemed to have led to the exclusion of non-orthodox religious subjects such a philosophy and natural science from the curricula. The madrasa of al-Qarawīyīn, one of the two surviving madaris that predate the founding of the earliest medieval universities and are thus claimed to be the "first universities" by some authors, has acquired official university status as late as 1947. The other, al-Azhar, did acquire this status in name and essence only in the course of numerous reforms during the 19th and 20th century, notably the one of 1961 which introduced non-religious subjects to its curriculum, such as economics, engineering, medicine, and agriculture. It should also be noted that many medieval universities were run for centuries as Christian cathedral schools or monastic schools prior to their formal establishment as universitas scholarium; evidence of these immediate forerunners of the university dates back to the 6th century AD, thus well preceding the earliest madaris. George Makdisi, who has published most extensively on the topic concludes in his comparison between the two institutions:
text_ai_base: Madrasas, as Islamic higher learning institutions, were legally designated as waqf, charitable endowments, in central and eastern Islamic regions. This designation allowed donors and their descendants to retain control, leading to a boom in establishing madrasas during the 11th and 12th centuries. Conversely, in Western Islamic areas, the Maliki school's prohibition on donor control over endowments made madrasas less prevalent. Unlike Western educational institutions with corporate status, the waqf model often excluded non-orthodox subjects like philosophy and natural sciences from madrasa curricula. The Madrasa of al-Qarawīyīn, one of the two remaining madrasas predating the earliest medieval universities, has been recognized as an official university only since 1947. The other, al-Azhar, achieved university status through reforms in the 19th and 20th centuries, specifically in 1961, when it included secular subjects like economics, engineering, medicine, and agriculture in its curriculum. Historically, many medieval universities functioned for centuries as Christian cathedral or monastic schools before formally becoming universitas scholarium, with their origins traceable to the 6th century AD, predating even the earliest madrasas. Scholar George Makdisi, who has extensively studied this topic, concludes in his comparison between these two types of educational institutions:
text_ai_humanized: Madrasas, prominent as centers of Islamic higher education, were intricately woven into the fabric of society as waqf—charitable endowments—in the heart of central and eastern Islamic regions. Such a legal status offered donors and their heirs lasting authority, sparking a boom in madrasa establishments during the vibrant 11th and 12th centuries. In contrast, however, the Maliki school's stringent prohibition on personal control over waqfs in Western Islamic lands curbed the expansion of madrasas there. This setup, differing fundamentally from Western educational institutions which often enjoyed corporate independence, led to madrasas generally excluding disciplines such as philosophy and the natural sciences, regarded as non-orthodox. One of the historical gems, the Madrasa of al-Qarawīyīn, traces its antiquity alongside al-Azhar, predating the most ancient medieval universities. Although al-Qarawīyīn officially earned the title of a university only in 1947, al-Azhar underwent transformative reforms in the 19th and 20th centuries, notably embracing secular subjects like economics, engineering, medicine, and agriculture in 1961, thus expanding its academic horizons. Meanwhile, medieval European universities took shape over centuries, emerging from Christian cathedral or monastic educational traditions that hark back to the 6th century AD—remarkably predating even the earliest madrasas. In this intriguing tapestry of educational evolution, scholar George Makdisi, who has poured immense effort into studying these realms, offers comparisons that delve into the subtleties of both Islamic and Western educational institutions. An endeavor not without its complexities! His insights potentially illuminate the contrasts and shared threads linking madrasas and medieval universities across history.

text_human: The '98 season would begin on a somber note with the death of legendary broadcaster Harry Caray. After the retirement of Sandberg and the trade of Dunston, the Cubs had holes to fill and the signing of Henry Rodríguez, known affectionately as "H-Rod" to bat cleanup provided protection for Sammy Sosa in the lineup, as Rodriguez slugged 31 round-trippers in his first season in Chicago. Kevin Tapani led the club with a career high 19 wins, Rod Beck anchored a strong bullpen and Mark Grace turned in one of his best seasons. The Cubs were swamped by media attention in 1998, and the team's two biggest headliners were Sosa and rookie flamethrower Kerry Wood. Wood's signature performance was one-hitting the Houston Astros, a game in which he tied the major league record of 20 strikeouts in nine innings. His torrid strikeout numbers earned Wood the nickname "Kid K," and ultimately earned him the 1998 NL Rookie of the Year award. Sosa caught fire in June, hitting a major league record 20 home runs in the month, and his home run race with Cardinals slugger Mark McGwire transformed the pair into international superstars in a matter of weeks. McGwire finished the season with a new major league record of 70 home runs, but Sosa's .308 average and 66 homers earned him the National League MVP Award. After a down-to-the-wire Wild Card chase with the San Francisco Giants, Chicago and San Francisco ended the regular season tied, and thus squared off in a one-game playoff at Wrigley Field in which third baseman Gary Gaetti hit the eventual game winning homer. The win propelled the Cubs into the postseason once again with a 90–73 regular season tally. Unfortunately, the bats went cold in October, as manager Jim Riggleman's club batted .183 and scored only four runs en route to being swept by Atlanta. On a positive note, the home run chase between Sosa, McGwire and Ken Griffey, Jr. helped professional baseball to bring in a new crop of fans as well as bringing back some fans who had been disillusioned by the 1994 strike. The Cubs retained many players who experienced career years in '98, and after a fast start in 1999, they collapsed again (starting with being swept at the hands of the cross-town White Sox in mid-June) and finished in the bottom of the division for the next two seasons.

text_human: Despite efforts to revive Hebrew as the national language of the Jewish people, knowledge of the language is not commonly possessed by Jews worldwide and English has emerged as the lingua franca of the Jewish diaspora. Although many Jews once had sufficient knowledge of Hebrew to study the classic literature, and Jewish languages like Yiddish and Ladino were commonly used as recently as the early 20th century, most Jews lack such knowledge today and English has by and large superseded most Jewish vernaculars. The three most commonly spoken languages among Jews today are Hebrew, English, and Russian. Some Romance languages, particularly French and Spanish, are also widely used. Yiddish has been spoken by more Jews in history than any other language, but it is far less used today following the Holocaust and the adoption of Modern Hebrew by the Zionist movement and the State of Israel. In some places, the mother language of the Jewish community differs from that of the general population or the dominant group. For example, in Quebec, the Ashkenazic majority has adopted English, while the Sephardic minority uses French as its primary language. Similarly, South African Jews adopted English rather than Afrikaans. Due to both Czarist and Soviet policies, Russian has superseded Yiddish as the language of Russian Jews, but these policies have also affected neighboring communities. Today, Russian is the first language for many Jewish communities in a number of Post-Soviet states, such as Ukraine and Uzbekistan, as well as for Ashkenazic Jews in Azerbaijan, Georgia, and Tajikistan. Although communities in North Africa today are small and dwindling, Jews there had shifted from a multilingual group to a monolingual one (or nearly so), speaking French in Algeria, Morocco, and the city of Tunis, while most North Africans continue to use Arabic as their mother tongue.[citation needed]

Instead, English has become the common language among the Jewish diaspora. While many Jews in the past were familiar enough with Hebrew to explore classical texts, and languages like Yiddish and Ladino were prevalently used as recently as the early 20th century, today most Jews lack proficiency in these languages, with English largely overtaking traditional Jewish dialects. Currently, the top languages spoken by Jews are Hebrew, English, and Russian, with French and Spanish also widely used among some Jewish communities. Historically, more Jews have spoken Yiddish than any other language, but its usage has declined significantly post-Holocaust, with Modern Hebrew’s adoption by the Zionist movement and Israel. In some regions, the Jewish community's predominant language differs from that of the wider population. For instance, in Quebec, the Ashkenazic majority speaks English, while the Sephardic minority primarily uses French. Similarly, South African Jews have chosen English over Afrikaans. In Russia, both Czarist and Soviet policies shifted Jew's language from Yiddish to Russian, influencing neighboring communities as well. Today, Russian is the primary language for many Jewish communities in post-Soviet areas like Ukraine, Uzbekistan, and for Ashkenazic Jews in Azerbaijan, Georgia, and Tajikistan. Though North African Jewish communities are currently small and shrinking, they transitioned from multilingualism to speaking predominantly French in Algeria, Morocco, and Tunis, whereas most North Africans continued using Arabic as their native language.

In contrast, English has effectively become the lingua franca across the Jewish diaspora. Historically, Hebrew facilitated exploration of classical texts among many Jews, while Yiddish and Ladino were dominant until as recently as the early 20th century. Although historically Yiddish enjoyed unparalleled prevalence among Jews, its speakers dwindled post-Holocaust. The rise of Modern Hebrew, spurred by the Zionist movement and Israel’s establishment, further eroded Yiddish's usage. Interesting linguistic dynamics emerge in Jewish populations where the prime language diverges from the nation's dominant tongue. Take Quebec, for example, where the Ashkenazic majority opts for English, while their Sephardic counterparts prefer French. Meanwhile, South African Jews gravitate towards English over Afrikaans. It's also the primary tongue for Ashkenazic Jews in countries like Azerbaijan, Georgia, and Tajikistan. In North Africa, Jewish communities, now dwindling, have shifted predominantly to French—a transition evident in Algeria, Morocco, and Tunisia—while most local populations continue using Arabic natively. This linguistic evolution mirrors broader cultural shifts, where languages ebb and flow, adapting to new identities and geopolitical landscapes.

message.content:
The endeavor to position Hebrew as the definitive language for the Jewish people has encountered significant challenges, largely because fluency in Hebrew isn't widespread among the global Jewish population. In contrast, English has effectively become the lingua franca across the Jewish diaspora. Historically, Hebrew facilitated exploration of classical texts among many Jews, while Yiddish and Ladino were dominant until as recently as the early 20th century. Nowadays, however, English has considerably overtaken these traditional languages, as Jews rarely engage with Yiddish and Ladino.

Presently, three primary languages echo across Jewish communities—Hebrew, English, and Russian—with French and Spanish also gaining footholds in specific locales. Although historically Yiddish enjoyed unparalleled prevalence among Jews, its speakers dwindled post-Holocaust. The rise of Modern Hebrew, spurred by the Zionist movement and Israel’s establishment, further eroded Yiddish's usage.

Interesting linguistic dynamics emerge in Jewish populations where the prime language diverges from the nation's dominant tongue. Take Quebec, for example, where the Ashkenazic majority opts for English, while their Sephardic counterparts prefer French. Meanwhile, South African Jews gravitate towards English over Afrikaans. In Russia, both under the Czar and during Soviet times, policies nudged Jews from Yiddish to Russian, creating ripples in adjacent regions. Today, Russian persists as the leading language for numerous Jewish communities in post-Soviet territories such as Ukraine and Uzbekistan. It's also the primary tongue for Ashkenazic Jews in countries like Azerbaijan, Georgia, and Tajikistan.

In North Africa, Jewish communities, now dwindling, have shifted predominantly to French—a transition evident in Algeria, Morocco, and Tunisia—while most local populations continue using Arabic natively. This linguistic evolution mirrors broader cultural shifts, where languages ebb and flow, adapting to new identities and geopolitical landscapes.

text_human: Terry Eastland, the author who wrote From Ending Affirmative Action: The Case for Colorblind Justice states, "Most arguments for affirmative action fall into two categories: remedying past discrimination and promoting diversity". Eastland believes that the founders of affirmative action did not anticipate how the benefits of affirmative action would go to those who did not need it, mostly middle class minorities. Additionally, she argues that affirmative action carries with it a stigma that can create feelings of self-doubt and entitlement in minorities. Eastland believes that affirmative action is a great risk that only sometimes pays off, and that without it we would be able to compete more freely with one another. Libertarian economist Thomas Sowell identified what he says are negative results of affirmative action in his book, Affirmative Action Around the World: An Empirical Study. Sowell writes that affirmative action policies encourage non-preferred groups to designate themselves as members of preferred groups [i.e., primary beneficiaries of affirmative action] to take advantage of group preference policies; that they tend to benefit primarily the most fortunate among the preferred group (e.g., upper and middle class blacks), often to the detriment of the least fortunate among the non-preferred groups (e.g., poor white or Asian); that they reduce the incentives of both the preferred and non-preferred to perform at their best – the former because doing so is unnecessary and the latter because it can prove futile – thereby resulting in net losses for society as a whole; and that they engender animosity toward preferred groups as well.:115–147
text_ai_base: In "Ending Affirmative Action: The Case for Colorblind Justice," Terry Eastland discusses the primary justifications for affirmative action: correcting past discrimination and promoting diversity. Eastland argues that affirmative action’s founders did not foresee how its benefits would predominantly aid those who do not truly need it, namely middle-class minorities. She also believes that affirmative action perpetuates a stigma, fostering feelings of self-doubt and entitlement among minorities. According to Eastland, these measures pose considerable risks and only occasionally yield positive outcomes. She suggests that removing affirmative action would enable more open competition. Libertarian economist Thomas Sowell echoes similar concerns in "Affirmative Action Around the World: An Empirical Study," where he highlights negative consequences of affirmative action. Sowell claims such policies prompt non-preferred groups to identify themselves as members of preferred groups to benefit from preferential treatment. He notes that affirmative action largely benefits the privileged members of preferred groups, like upper and middle-class blacks, while neglecting less fortunate individuals from non-preferred groups, such as impoverished whites or Asians. Furthermore, Sowell argues that these policies decrease the incentives for both preferred and non-preferred groups to strive for excellence; the former because it’s unnecessary, and the latter because it seems pointless. Ultimately, this leads to societal losses and breeds animosity towards preferred groups.
text_ai_humanized: In "Ending Affirmative Action: The Case for Colorblind Justice," Terry Eastland dives into the core arguments championing affirmative action: rectifying historical injustices and enhancing diversity. However, Eastland asserts that the visionaries behind affirmative action could hardly imagine the unintended trajectory it would take—a course primarily benefitting those who arguably need it less, particularly middle-class minorities. This dynamic, she contends, perpetuates a stigma that may breed self-doubt and entitlement among minority recipients. Eastland expresses concern that these initiatives often usher in substantial risks while only sporadically delivering positive outcomes. Her suggestion? Abolishing affirmative action would pave the way for more transparent competition. Adding weight to this discourse, libertarian economist Thomas Sowell, in "Affirmative Action Around the World: An Empirical Study," offers critical insights into the adverse effects stemming from such policies. He observes a paradox: individuals from non-preferred groups sometimes masquerade as members of preferred categories to tap into the benefits of affirmative action. Sowell points out that the real winners here tend to be the affluent members within preferred groups, like upper and middle-class blacks, leaving behind those less fortunate—impoverished whites or Asians—not quite in the picture. He further argues that these measures dilute the motivation to excel among both preferred and non-preferred factions. Preferred groups might feel excellence is redundant, whereas non-preferred groups may see striving as a futile endeavor. Such dynamics, Sowell warns, lead to societal setbacks and can stir resentment towards those who are favored.

Eastland expresses concern that these initiatives often usher in substantial risks while only sporadically delivering positive outcomes. Her suggestion? text_human: Van Praag states that the Ming court established diplomatic delegations with Tibet merely to secure urgently needed horses. Wang and Nyima argue that these were not diplomatic delegations at all, that Tibetan areas were ruled by the Ming since Tibetan leaders were granted positions as Ming officials, that horses were collected from Tibet as a mandatory "corvée" tax, and therefore Tibetans were "undertaking domestic affairs, not foreign diplomacy". Sperling writes that the Ming simultaneously bought horses in the Kham region while fighting Tibetan tribes in Amdo and receiving Tibetan embassies in Nanjing. He also argues that the embassies of Tibetan lamas visiting the Ming court were for the most part efforts to promote commercial transactions between the lamas' large, wealthy entourage and Ming Chinese merchants and officials. Kolmaš writes that while the Ming maintained a laissez-faire policy towards Tibet and limited the numbers of the Tibetan retinues, the Tibetans sought to maintain a tributary relationship with the Ming because imperial patronage provided them with wealth and power. Laird writes that Tibetans eagerly sought Ming court invitations since the gifts the Tibetans received for bringing tribute were much greater in value than the latter. As for the Yongle Emperor's gifts to his Tibetan and Nepalese vassals such as silver wares, Buddha relics, utensils for Buddhist temples and religious ceremonies, and gowns and robes for monks, Tsai writes "in his effort to draw neighboring states to the Ming orbit so that he could bask in glory, the Yongle Emperor was quite willing to pay a small price". The Information Office of the State Council of the PRC lists the Tibetan tribute items as oxen, horses, camels, sheep, fur products, medical herbs, Tibetan incenses, thangkas (painted scrolls), and handicrafts; while the Ming awarded Tibetan tribute-bearers an equal value of gold, silver, satin and brocade, bolts of cloth, grains, and tea leaves. Silk workshops during the Ming also catered specifically to the Tibetan market with silk clothes and furnishings featuring Tibetan Buddhist iconography.

Sperling notes that the Ming simultaneously purchased horses in the Kham region while fighting Tibetan tribes in Amdo and receiving Tibetan embassies in Nanjing, contending that visits by Tibetan lamas to the Ming court primarily aimed to foster commercial exchanges between the lamas' affluent entourage and Ming merchants and officials. Ming silk workshops also catered to the Tibetan market with silk garments and furnishings adorned with Tibetan Buddhist designs.

In return, the Ming gifted gold, silver, satin, brocade, bolts of cloth, grains, and tea leaves. Moreover, Ming silk workshops made items for the Tibetan market, designing silk garments and furnishings adorned with Tibetan Buddhist motifs.

He claims that the visits from Tibetan lamas were mostly about nurturing commercial enterprises between the lavish entourages of the lamas and the merchants at the Ming court.

Kolmaš adds to the discourse, pointing out the Ming's laissez-faire policy concerning Tibet, alongside restrictions on the size of Tibetan entourages. Despite these limitations, Tibetans were keen to maintain a tributary relationship with the Ming, as the imperial patronage brought them wealth and sway. And why wouldn't they? According to Laird, Tibetans were motivated to seek invitations to the Ming court because the gifts they received for their tribute were far more valuable than the tribute itself.

On the subject of opulent gifts, Tsai highlights how the Yongle Emperor bestowed upon his Tibetan and Nepalese vassals items like silver wares, Buddha relics, temple utensils, and monks' robes. text_human: Unlike the Spanish milled dollar the U.S. dollar is based upon a decimal system of values. In addition to the dollar the coinage act officially established monetary units of mill or one-thousandth of a dollar (symbol ₥), cent or one-hundredth of a dollar (symbol ¢), dime or one-tenth of a dollar, and eagle or ten dollars, with prescribed weights and composition of gold, silver, or copper for each. It was proposed in the mid-1800s that one hundred dollars be known as a union, but no union coins were ever struck and only patterns for the $50 half union exist. However, only cents are in everyday use as divisions of the dollar; "dime" is used solely as the name of the coin with the value of 10¢, while "eagle" and "mill" are largely unknown to the general public, though mills are sometimes used in matters of tax levies, and gasoline prices are usually in the form of $X.XX9 per gallon, e.g., $3.599, sometimes written as $3.599⁄10. When currently issued in circulating form, denominations equal to or less than a dollar are emitted as U.S. coins while denominations equal to or greater than a dollar are emitted as Federal Reserve notes (with the exception of gold, silver and platinum coins valued up to $100 as legal tender, but worth far more as bullion). Both one-dollar coins and notes are produced today, although the note form is significantly more common. In the past, "paper money" was occasionally issued in denominations less than a dollar (fractional currency) and gold coins were issued for circulation up to the value of $20 (known as the "double eagle", discontinued in the 1930s). The term eagle was used in the Coinage Act of 1792 for the denomination of ten dollars, and subsequently was used in naming gold coins. Paper currency less than one dollar in denomination, known as "fractional currency", was also sometimes pejoratively referred to as "shinplasters". In 1854, James Guthrie, then Secretary of the Treasury, proposed creating $100, $50 and $25 gold coins, which were referred to as a "Union", "Half Union", and "Quarter Union", thus implying a denomination of 1 Union = $100.
text_ai_base: Unlike the Spanish milled dollar, the U.S. dollar is structured on a decimal system. The Coinage Act not only introduced the dollar but also established other monetary units: the mill, which is one-thousandth of a dollar (symbol ₥); the cent, or one-hundredth of a dollar (symbol ¢); the dime, or one-tenth of a dollar; and the eagle, or ten dollars. Each had specific weights and compositions of gold, silver, or copper. In the mid-1800s, there was a proposal to name a hundred-dollar coin the "union," but no such coins were minted. Patterns for the $50 "half union" do exist. Today, only the cent is commonly used as a subdivision of the dollar. The term "dime" refers specifically to the 10¢ coin. "Eagle" and "mill" are largely unfamiliar, though mills are occasionally used in tax calculations, and fuel prices are often noted as $X.XX9 per gallon, such as $3.599, sometimes written as $3.599⁄10. Currently, denominations less than a dollar are issued as U.S. coins, while those equal to or greater than a dollar are typically Federal Reserve notes, except for gold, silver, and platinum coins valued up to $100 as legal tender, though their bullion worth is much higher. Both one-dollar coins and notes are produced today, with notes being more common. Historically, "paper money" included denominations under a dollar (fractional currency), and gold coins were circulated with values up to $20 (the "double eagle"), discontinued in the 1930s. The Coinage Act of 1792 introduced "eagle" as the term for a ten-dollar denomination, also used for naming gold coins. Fractional currency was sometimes derogatorily called "shinplasters". In 1854, James Guthrie, the Secretary of the Treasury, suggested minting $100, $50, and $25 gold coins referred to as a "Union," "Half Union," and "Quarter Union," thereby suggesting a value of 1 Union = $100.
text_ai_humanized: Unlike the Spanish milled dollar, which didn't adopt a decimal framework, the U.S. dollar came to life anchored firmly in a decimal system. Enshrined within the Coinage Act, this new currency not only introduced the dollar but laid out an intricate weave of monetary units. The mill, denoted by ₥, equates to one-thousandth of a dollar, while the cent (¢) is one-hundredth, and the dime—one-tenth. Then there's the eagle, an imposing ten-dollar counterpart. Each denomination bore unique weights and metal compositions, often gold, silver, or copper. Stepping into the mid-1800s, an ambitious yet ultimately shelved idea emerged: the "union" proposed as a new name for a hundred-dollar coin. Oddly enough, no union coins saw the light of day. But for coin collectors, the $50 "half union" patterns offer a glimpse into what could have been. Fast forward to today, and it's the humble cent that remains the dollar's steadfast subdivision. The 'dime' has become synonymous with the 10¢ coin, while "eagle" and "mill" have drifted into obscurity. Yet curious relics remain: mills still pop up in tax calculations, and at gas stations, fuel prices tease with endings like $3.599, occasionally firing our neurons as $3.599⁄10. In the modern era, coins under a dollar circulate with regularity, while anything dollar-sized or heftier shows up mostly as Federal Reserve notes—unless you consider those shiny gold, silver, and platinum legal tender coins with face values reaching $100. Of course, their actual bullion value stretches much further. Today, both one-dollar coins and paper notes co-exist, though notes seem to edge ahead in popularity. Back in the day, paper money dipped below the dollar mark in the form of fractional currency, not-so-affectionately dubbed "shinplasters" by some. Gold coins once played their part, too, parading values up to $20, such as the "double eagle," until their circulation was halted in the 1930s. Our ten-dollar "eagle," named by the Coinage Act of 1792, lends its name to distinguish gold coins as well. And let's not forget, in 1854, Treasury Secretary James Guthrie floated the idea of minting $100, $50, and $25 gold coins, whimsically christened as the "Union," "Half Union," and "Quarter Union," effectively suggesting a value scale where 1 Union was pegged at $100. Quite the fascinating journey for a currency!

message.content:

Each denomination bore unique weights and metal compositions, often gold, silver, or copper.

Stepping into the mid-1800s, an ambitious yet ultimately shelved idea emerged: the "union" proposed as a new name for a hundred-dollar coin. Oddly enough, no union coins saw the light of day. But for coin collectors, the $50 "half union" patterns offer a glimpse into what could have been. Fast forward to today, and it's the humble cent that remains the dollar's steadfast subdivision. The 'dime' has become synonymous with the 10¢ coin, while "eagle" and "mill" have drifted into obscurity. Yet curious relics remain: mills still pop up in tax calculations, and at gas stations, fuel prices tease with endings like $3.599, occasionally firing our neurons as $3.599⁄10.

In the modern era, coins under a dollar circulate with regularity, while anything dollar-sized or heftier shows up mostly as Federal Reserve notes—unless you consider those shiny gold, silver, and platinum legal tender coins with face values reaching $100. Of course, their actual bullion value stretches much further. Today, both one-dollar coins and paper notes co-exist, though notes seem to edge ahead in popularity.

Back in the day, paper money dipped below the dollar mark in the form of fractional currency, not-so-affectionately dubbed "shinplasters" by some. Gold coins once played their part, too, parading values up to $20, such as the "double eagle," until their circulation was halted in the 1930s. text_human: In 2012, Abigail Fisher, an undergraduate student at Louisiana State University, and Rachel Multer Michalewicz, a law student at Southern Methodist University, filed a lawsuit to challenge the University of Texas admissions policy, asserting it had a "race-conscious policy" that "violated their civil and constitutional rights". The University of Texas employs the "Top Ten Percent Law", under which admission to any public college or university in Texas is guaranteed to high school students who graduate in the top ten percent of their high school class. Fisher has brought the admissions policy to court because she believes that she was denied acceptance to the University of Texas based on her race, and thus, her right to equal protection according to the 14th Amendment was violated. The Supreme Court heard oral arguments in Fisher on October 10, 2012, and rendered an ambiguous ruling in 2013 that sent the case back to the lower court, stipulating only that the University must demonstrate that it could not achieve diversity through other, non-race sensitive means. In July 2014, the US Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit concluded that U of T maintained a "holistic" approach in its application of affirmative action, and could continue the practice. On February 10, 2015, lawyers for Fisher filed a new case in the Supreme Court. It is a renewed complaint that the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit got the issue wrong — on the second try as well as on the first. The Supreme Court agreed in June 2015 to hear the case a second time. It will likely be decided by June 2016.
text_ai_base: In 2012, Abigail Fisher, a student at Louisiana State University, and Rachel Multer Michalewicz, a law student at Southern Methodist University, filed a lawsuit against the University of Texas, challenging its admissions policy. They claimed the policy was "race-conscious" and violated their civil and constitutional rights. Texas's "Top Ten Percent Law" guarantees admission to any state public college or university for high school students graduating in the top ten percent of their class. Fisher argued that her rejection from the University of Texas was based on her race, violating her 14th Amendment right to equal protection. The Supreme Court heard the case on October 10, 2012, and issued a vague ruling in 2013, instructing the lower court to reconsider, asking the University to prove that achieving diversity couldn't be done through race-neutral means. In July 2014, the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit decided that the University of Texas could continue its "holistic" affirmative action approach. On February 10, 2015, Fisher's lawyers brought the case back to the Supreme Court, contending that the Fifth Circuit was wrong both times. The Supreme Court agreed in June 2015 to review the case again, with a decision expected by June 2016.

Agreeing to take another look, the Supreme Court set June 2015 as the time frame to reexamine the case once more, with a ruling anticipated by June 2016. Keep your eyes peeled—this legal saga had much still to unfold.

When the Supreme Court took up the matter on October 10, 2012, they delivered a rather ambiguous verdict a year later, directing the lower court to reevaluate. They wanted the University of Texas to demonstrate that there was no alternative to fostering diversity other than race-conscious methods.

Fast forward to July 2014, and the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit firmly supported the university's comprehensive affirmative action initiatives. Undeterred, Fisher’s attorneys presented the case once more before the Supreme Court on February 10, 2015, insisting the previous decisions by the Fifth Circuit were mistaken. Agreeing to take another look, the Supreme Court set June 2015 as the time frame to reexamine the case once more, with a ruling anticipated by June 2016. Keep your eyes peeled—this legal saga had much still to unfold.

text_human: Athanasius recounts being a student, as well as being educated by the Martyrs of the Great (tenth) and last persecution of Christianity by pagan Rome.[citation needed] This persecution was most severe in the East, particularly in Egypt and Palestine. Peter of Alexandria, the 17th archbishop of Alexandria, was martyred in 311 in the closing days of that persecution, and may have been one of those teachers. His successor as bishop of Alexandria, Alexander of Alexandria (312–328) was an Origenist as well as a documented mentor of Athanasius. According to Sozomen, Bishop Alexander "invited Athanasius to be his commensal and secretary. He had been well educated, and was versed in grammar and rhetoric, and had already, while still a young man, and before reaching the episcopate, given proof to those who dwelt with him of his wisdom and acumen". Athanasius's earliest work, Against the Heathen – On the Incarnation (written before 319), bears traces of Origenist Alexandrian thought (such as repeatedly quoting Plato and used a definition from Aristotle's Organon) but in an orthodox way. Athanasius was also familiar with the theories of various philosophical schools, and in particular with the developments of Neo-Platonism. Ultimately, Athanasius would modify the philosophical thought of the School of Alexandria away from the Origenist principles such as the "entirely allegorical interpretation of the text". Still, in later works, Athanasius quotes Homer more than once (Hist. Ar. 68, Orat. iv. 29). In his letter to Emperor Constantius, he presents a defense of himself bearing unmistakable traces of a study of Demosthenes de Corona.

text_human: From the 8th to the 10th century, three dynasties contested for control of northern India: the Gurjara Pratiharas of Malwa, the Palas of Bengal, and the Rashtrakutas of the Deccan. The Sena dynasty would later assume control of the Pala Empire, and the Gurjara Pratiharas fragmented into various states. These were the first of the Rajput states. The first recorded Rajput kingdoms emerged in Rajasthan in the 6th century, and small Rajput dynasties later ruled much of northern India. One Gurjar Rajput of the Chauhan clan, Prithvi Raj Chauhan, was known for bloody conflicts against the advancing Turkic sultanates. The Chola empire emerged as a major power during the reign of Raja Raja Chola I and Rajendra Chola I who successfully invaded parts of Southeast Asia and Sri Lanka in the 11th century. Lalitaditya Muktapida (r. 724 CE–760 CE) was an emperor of the Kashmiri Karkoṭa dynasty, which exercised influence in northwestern India from 625 CE until 1003, and was followed by Lohara dynasty. He is known primarily for his successful battles against the Muslim and Tibetan advances into Kashmiri-dominated regions. Kalhana in his Rajatarangini credits king Lalitaditya with leading an aggressive military campaign in Northern India and Central Asia. He broke into the Uttarapatha and defeated the rebellious tribes of the Kambojas, Tukharas (Turks in Turkmenistan and Tocharians in Badakhshan), Bhautas (Tibetans in Baltistan and Tibet) and Daradas (Dards). His campaign then led him to subjugate the kingdoms of Pragjyotisha, Strirajya and the Uttarakurus. The Shahi dynasty ruled portions of eastern Afghanistan, northern Pakistan, and Kashmir from the mid-7th century to the early 11th century.

Eventually, the Sena dynasty took over the Pala Empire, while the Gurjara Pratiharas disintegrated into several Rajput states. These Rajput kingdoms first appeared in Rajasthan in the 6th century, leading to small Rajput dynasties governing much of northern India. Notably, a Gurjar Rajput from the Chauhan clan, Prithvi Raj Chauhan, became famous for his fierce battles against the advancing Turkic sultanates. The Chola empire rose to prominence under Raja Raja Chola I and Rajendra Chola I, who successfully invaded regions of Southeast Asia and Sri Lanka in the 11th century. Lalitaditya Muktapida (r. 724–760 CE) was an emperor of the Kashmiri Karkoṭa dynasty, which influenced northwestern India from 625 to 1003 CE and was succeeded by the Lohara dynasty. He is renowned for his victories against Muslim and Tibetan expansions into regions controlled by Kashmir. The historian Kalhana, in his *Rajatarangini*, credits Lalitaditya with leading an aggressive military campaign across Northern India and Central Asia. Meanwhile, the Shahi dynasty ruled parts of eastern Afghanistan, northern Pakistan, and Kashmir from the mid-7th to early 11th centuries.
text_ai_humanized: Between the 8th and 10th centuries, a power struggle unfolded in northern India, featuring three formidable dynasties: the Gurjara Pratiharas in Malwa, the Palas in Bengal, and the Rashtrakutas down south in the Deccan. Over time, the Pala Empire succumbed to the rise of the Sena dynasty, and the Gurjara Pratiharas gradually splintered into what became several independent Rajput states. It's interesting to note that the Rajputs first emerged in the 6th century in Rajasthan, eventually forming small dynasties that stretched their influence across much of northern India. Among these Rajputs, Prithvi Raj Chauhan of the Chauhan clan became legendary for his determined battles against the encroaching Turkic sultanates. Simultaneously, in the south, the Chola Empire reached its zenith under the leadership of Raja Raja Chola I and his successor, Rajendra Chola I. Their reigns marked a period of remarkable expansion, as they launched successful military campaigns into Southeast Asia and Sri Lanka during the 11th century. Turning to the northwest, the Karkoṭa dynasty of Kashmir, under the leadership of Lalitaditya Muktapida (ruling from 724 to 760 CE), wielded significant influence over the region from 625 to 1003 CE. This dynasty was later succeeded by the Lohara dynasty. Lalitaditya is particularly celebrated for his triumphs over Muslim and Tibetan advances threatening Kashmirian territories. The historian Kalhana, writing in the *Rajatarangini*, extols Lalitaditya for his ambitious military campaigns that spanned Northern India and reached into Central Asia. His conquests included subjugating the tribes of the Uttarapatha – notably, the Kambojas, the Tukharas from regions like Turkmenistan and Badakhshan, as well as the Bhautas in areas such as Baltistan and Tibet, and the Daradas or Dards. Furthermore, he extended his influence over Pragjyotisha, Strirajya, and the Uttarakurus. Meanwhile, the Shahi dynasty maintained its rule over segments of eastern Afghanistan, northern Pakistan, and parts of Kashmir, weathering the historical tide from the mid-7th through the early 11th centuries.

message.content:
Between the 8th and 10th centuries, a power struggle unfolded in northern India, featuring three formidable dynasties: the Gurjara Pratiharas in Malwa, the Palas in Bengal, and the Rashtrakutas down south in the Deccan. Over time, the Pala Empire succumbed to the rise of the Sena dynasty, and the Gurjara Pratiharas gradually splintered into what became several independent Rajput states. It's interesting to note that the Rajputs first emerged in the 6th century in Rajasthan, eventually forming small dynasties that stretched their influence across much of northern India. Among these Rajputs, Prithvi Raj Chauhan of the Chauhan clan became legendary for his determined battles against the encroaching Turkic sultanates.

Simultaneously, in the south, the Chola Empire reached its zenith under the leadership of Raja Raja Chola I and his successor, Rajendra Chola I. Their reigns marked a period of remarkable expansion, as they launched successful military campaigns into Southeast Asia and Sri Lanka during the 11th century. 

Turning to the northwest, the Karkoṭa dynasty of Kashmir, under the leadership of Lalitaditya Muktapida (ruling from 724 to 760 CE), wielded significant influence over the region from 625 to 1003 CE. This dynasty was later succeeded by the Lohara dynasty. Lalitaditya is particularly celebrated for his triumphs over Muslim and Tibetan advances threatening Kashmirian territories. The historian Kalhana, writing in the *Rajatarangini*, extols Lalitaditya for his ambitious military campaigns that spanned Northern India and reached into Central Asia. His conquests included subjugating the tribes of the Uttarapatha – notably, the Kambojas, the Tukharas from regions like Turkmenistan and Badakhshan, as well as the Bhautas in areas such as Baltistan and Tibet, and the Daradas or Dards. Furthermore, he extended his influence over Pragjyotisha, Strirajya, and the Uttarakurus.

Meanwhile, the Shahi dynasty maintained its rule over segments of eastern Afghanistan, northern Pakistan, and parts of Kashmir, weathering the historical tide from the mid-7th through the early 11th centuries.

text_human: Regardless, the Luftwaffe could still inflict huge damage. With the German occupation of Western Europe, the intensification of submarine and air attack on Britain's sea communications was feared by the British. Such an event would have serious consequences on the future course of the war, should the Germans succeed. Liverpool and its port became an important destination for convoys heading through the Western Approaches from North America, bringing supplies and materials. The considerable rail network distributed to the rest of the country. Operations against Liverpool in the Liverpool Blitz were successful. Air attacks sank 39,126 long tons (39,754 t) of shipping, with another 111,601 long tons (113,392 t) damaged. Minister of Home Security Herbert Morrison was also worried morale was breaking, noting the defeatism expressed by civilians. Other sources point to half of the port's 144 berths rendered unusable, while cargo unloading capability was reduced by 75%. Roads and railways were blocked and ships could not leave harbour. On 8 May 1941, 57 ships were destroyed, sunk or damaged amounting to 80,000 long tons (81,000 t). Around 66,000 houses were destroyed, 77,000 people made homeless, and 1,900 people killed and 1,450 seriously hurt on one night. Operations against London up until May 1941 could also have a severe impact on morale. The populace of the port of Hull became 'trekkers', people who underwent a mass exodus from cities before, during, and after attacks. However, the attacks failed to knock out or damage railways, or port facilities for long, even in the Port of London, a target of many attacks. The Port of London in particular was an important target, bringing in one-third of overseas trade.
text_ai_base: Despite setbacks, the Luftwaffe was still capable of causing significant damage. With Germany occupying Western Europe, Britain feared intensified submarine and air assaults on its sea routes. Such an escalation could have grave implications for the war's outcome if the Germans prevailed. Liverpool and its port became vital destinations for convoys from North America, carrying supplies and materials. From there, a robust rail network distributed the goods across the country. The Liverpool Blitz proved successful for the attackers; air assaults sank 39,126 long tons (39,754 t) of shipping and damaged another 111,601 long tons (113,392 t). Herbert Morrison, the Minister of Home Security, worried about a drop in morale, as civilians expressed defeatist attitudes. Reports suggested that half of the port's 144 berths were unusable, and cargo unloading capabilities fell by 75%. Roads and railways were blocked, and ships couldn't leave the harbor. On May 8, 1941, 57 ships were either destroyed, sunk, or damaged amounting to 80,000 long tons (81,000 t). Approximately 66,000 homes were destroyed, leaving 77,000 people homeless, with 1,900 killed and 1,450 seriously injured in just one night. Operations against London up until May 1941 threatened to impact morale severely. In Hull, residents became "trekkers," fleeing the city before, during, and after attacks. However, the bombardments failed to disable railways or port facilities for long, even in the frequently targeted Port of London, which handled one-third of overseas trade.
text_ai_humanized: Despite facing numerous setbacks, the Luftwaffe still posed a formidable threat, unleashing substantial destruction during its campaigns. With Germany holding dominion over Western Europe, there loomed a palpable anxiety in Britain about escalated submarine and air assaults on vital sea lanes. Should these intensified offensives succeed, the war's trajectory could shift dramatically in favor of the Germans. In the thick of these concerns, Liverpool emerged as a crucial hub. The port stood as a beacon for convoys arriving from North America, laden with essential supplies and materials. Once these goods arrived, they were whisked away from the docks and dispersed across the United Kingdom via an efficient railway system. Nonetheless, the city and its port did not escape unscathed. The Liverpool Blitz, marking unforgettable nights of destruction, saw air raids that sank a total of 39,126 long tons (39,754 t) of shipping while leaving another 111,601 long tons (113,392 t) severely damaged

The Liverpool Blitz, marking unforgettable nights of destruction, saw air raids that sank a total of 39,126 long tons (39,754 t) of shipping while leaving another 111,601 long tons (113,392 t) severely damaged

text_human: After its release, Evita garnered critical appreciation. Zach Conner from Time magazine commented, "It's a relief to say that Evita is pretty damn fine, well cast and handsomely visualized. Madonna once again confounds our expectations. She plays Evita with a poignant weariness and has more than just a bit of star quality. Love or hate Madonna-Eva, she is a magnet for all eyes." Madonna won a Golden Globe Award for Best Actress in Motion Picture Musical or Comedy for the role. She released three singles from the Evita soundtrack album, including "You Must Love Me" (which won an Academy Award for Best Original Song in 1997) and "Don't Cry for Me Argentina". Madonna was later presented with the Artist Achievement Award by Tony Bennett at the 1996 Billboard Music Awards. On October 14, 1996, Madonna gave birth to Lourdes Maria Ciccone Leon, her daughter with Leon. Biographer Mary Cross writes that although Madonna was often ill during the filming and worried that her pregnancy would harm the film, she reached some important personal goals: "Now 38 years old, Madonna had at last triumphed on screen and achieved her dream of having a child, both in the same year. She had reached another turning point in her career, reinventing herself and her image with the public." Her relationship with Carlos Leon ended in May 1997; she declared that they were "better off as best friends." After Lourdes' birth, Madonna became involved in Eastern mysticism and Kabbalah. She was introduced to Jewish mysticism by actress Sandra Bernhard in 1997.

text_human: The area of modern Zhejiang was outside the major sphere of influence of the Shang civilization during the second millennium BC. Instead, this area was populated by peoples collectively known as the Hundred Yue, including the Dongyue and the Ouyue. The kingdom of Yue began to appear in the chronicles and records written during the Spring and Autumn Period. According to the chronicles, the kingdom of Yue was located in northern Zhejiang. Shiji claims that its leaders were descended from the Shang founder Yu the Great. Evidence suggests that Baiyue and the kingdom of Yue possessed their own culture and history that are different from those kingdoms in north and central China, whose cultures and histories were carefully recorded in chronicles and histories during the Spring and Autumn Period and into the Qin dynasty. The Song of the Yue Boatman (Chinese: 越人歌, p Yuèrén Gē, lit. "Song of the man of Yue") was transliterated into Chinese and recorded by authors in north China or inland China of Hebei and Henan around 528 BC. The song shows that the Yue people spoke a language that was mutually unintelligible with the dialects spoken in north and inland China. The Yue peoples seem to have had their own written script. The Sword of Goujian bears bird-worm seal script. Yuenü (Chinese: 越女; pinyin: Yuènǚ; Wade–Giles: Yüeh-nü; literally: "the Lady of Yue") was a swordswoman from the state of Yue. In order to check the growth of the kingdom of Wu, Chu pursued a policy of strengthening Yue. Under King Goujian, Yue recovered from its early reverses and fully annexed the lands of its rival in 473 BC. The Yue kings then moved their capital center from their original home around Mount Kuaiji in present-day Shaoxing to the former Wu capital at present-day Suzhou. With no southern power to turn against Yue, Chu opposed it directly and, in 333 BC, succeeded in destroying it. Yue's former lands were annexed by the Qin Empire in 222 BC and organized into a commandery named for Kuaiji in Zhejiang but initially headquartered in Wu in Jiangsu.
text_ai_base: During the second millennium BC, the area now known as Zhejiang was not heavily influenced by the Shang civilization. It was inhabited by groups collectively called the Hundred Yue, including tribes like the Dongyue and Ouyue. The kingdom of Yue first appeared in written records during the Spring and Autumn Period, with these chronicles placing it in northern Zhejiang. The Shiji asserts that Yue's rulers were descendants of Shang's founder, Yu the Great. Evidence indicates that the Baiyue and the kingdom of Yue had distinctive cultures and histories compared to those in northern and central China, whose pasts were well-documented during the Spring and Autumn Period and into the Qin dynasty. One remarkable artifact from this era is "The Song of the Yue Boatman" (Chinese: 越人歌, pinyin: Yuèrén Gē, meaning "Song of the Man of Yue"), which was transliterated into Chinese around 528 BC by authors from Hebei and Henan. This song reveals that the Yue people spoke a language unintelligible to those in northern China. It appears the Yue also had their own written script, as evidenced by the Sword of Goujian inscribed with bird-worm seal script. A notable figure from Yue was Yuenü (Chinese: 越女; pinyin: Yuènǚ, meaning "the Lady of Yue"), a renowned swordswoman. The state of Chu supported Yue to curb the expansion of the kingdom of Wu. Under King Goujian, Yue rebounded from its early setbacks and fully annexed Wu's territories in 473 BC. Subsequently, the Yue changed their capital from the area near Mount Kuaiji in present-day Shaoxing to Wu's former capital in present-day Suzhou. With no southern adversaries remaining, Chu directly confronted Yue and successfully destroyed it in 333 BC. Yue's former territories were absorbed by the Qin Empire in 222 BC and formed into a commandery named Kuaiji in Zhejiang, with its initial headquarters located in Wu in Jiangsu.
text_ai_humanized: During the second millennium BC, the region we now call Zhejiang was largely untouched by the Shang civilization's grasp. Instead, a diverse tapestry of tribes, collectively referred to as the Hundred Yue, including the Dongyue and Ouyue, populated the land. Chronicles from the Spring and Autumn Period first introduce the kingdom of Yue, situating it in northern Zhejiang. According to the historical text Shiji, the ruling lineage of Yue traced back to Yu the Great, the legendary founder of the Shang. Unlike the northern and central regions of China, whose stories have been meticulously chronicled since the Spring and Autumn Period and into the Qin dynasty, the Baiyue and the kingdom of Yue presented unique cultural tales and histories. Interestingly, a tangible legacy from these times is found in "The Song of the Yue Boatman" (Chinese: 越人歌, pinyin: Yuèrén Gē), a piece transliterated into Chinese by scribes from Hebei and Henan around 528 BC. This song offers a window into the linguistic world of the Yue, highlighting a tongue foreign to northern Chinese ears. Furthermore, the Yue possessed a distinctive script, as demonstrated by inscriptions on the Sword of Goujian, showcasing elegant bird-worm seal script. Among notable figures from Yue emerges Yuenü (Chinese: 越女; pinyin: Yuènǚ), celebrated for her prowess in swordsmanship. During a period of rising conflict, the state of Chu lent its support to Yue, aiming to rein in the burgeoning might of the kingdom of Wu. Under the leadership of King Goujian, Yue not only recovered from setbacks but went on to completely annex Wu's territories in 473 BC. The capital then relocated from the vicinity of Mount Kuaiji, nestled in what is today's Shaoxing, to Wu's former capital in modern-day Suzhou. With Wu no longer a threat, Yue faced off with Chu directly. Eventually, Chu dismantled the kingdom of Yue in 333 BC. As Yue's power waned, its lands were absorbed into the Qin Empire by 222 BC, becoming the commandery of Kuaiji in Zhejiang, initially administered from Wu in Jiangsu. This period marked the end of an era for the Yue people's sovereignty.

Interestingly, a tangible legacy from these times is found in "The Song of the Yue Boatman" (Chinese: 越人歌, pinyin: Yuèrén Gē), a piece transliterated into Chinese by scribes from Hebei and Henan around 528 BC. This song offers a window into the linguistic world of the Yue, highlighting a tongue foreign to northern Chinese ears. Furthermore, the Yue possessed a distinctive script, as demonstrated by inscriptions on the Sword of Goujian, showcasing elegant bird-worm seal script.

Among notable figures from Yue emerges Yuenü (Chinese: 越女; pinyin: Yuènǚ), celebrated for her prowess in swordsmanship. During a period of rising conflict, the state of Chu lent its support to Yue, aiming to rein in the burgeoning might of the kingdom of Wu. Under the leadership of King Goujian, Yue not only recovered from setbacks but went on to completely annex Wu's territories in 473 BC. The capital then relocated from the vicinity of Mount Kuaiji, nestled in what is today's Shaoxing, to Wu's former capital in modern-day Suzhou.

With Wu no longer a threat, Yue faced off with Chu directly. Eventually, Chu dismantled the kingdom of Yue in 333 BC. As Yue's power waned, its lands were absorbed into the Qin Empire by 222 BC, becoming the commandery of Kuaiji in Zhejiang, initially administered from Wu in Jiangsu. This period marked the end of an era for the Yue people's sovereignty.

text_human: Romantic relationships tend to increase in prevalence throughout adolescence. By age 15, 53% of adolescents have had a romantic relationship that lasted at least one month over the course of the previous 18 months. In a 2008 study conducted by YouGov for Channel 4, 20% of 14−17-year-olds surveyed revealed that they had their first sexual experience at 13 or under in the United Kingdom. A 2002 American study found that those aged 15–44 reported that the average age of first sexual intercourse was 17.0 for males and 17.3 for females. The typical duration of relationships increases throughout the teenage years as well. This constant increase in the likelihood of a long-term relationship can be explained by sexual maturation and the development of cognitive skills necessary to maintain a romantic bond (e.g. caregiving, appropriate attachment), although these skills are not strongly developed until late adolescence. Long-term relationships allow adolescents to gain the skills necessary for high-quality relationships later in life and develop feelings of self-worth. Overall, positive romantic relationships among adolescents can result in long-term benefits. High-quality romantic relationships are associated with higher commitment in early adulthood and are positively associated with self-esteem, self-confidence, and social competence. For example, an adolescent with positive self-confidence is likely to consider themselves a more successful partner, whereas negative experiences may lead to low confidence as a romantic partner. Adolescents often date within their demographic in regards to race, ethnicity, popularity, and physical attractiveness. However, there are traits in which certain individuals, particularly adolescent girls, seek diversity. While most adolescents date people approximately their own age, boys typically date partners the same age or younger; girls typically date partners the same age or older.

text_human: Microbiological culture is a principal tool used to diagnose infectious disease. In a microbial culture, a growth medium is provided for a specific agent. A sample taken from potentially diseased tissue or fluid is then tested for the presence of an infectious agent able to grow within that medium. Most pathogenic bacteria are easily grown on nutrient agar, a form of solid medium that supplies carbohydrates and proteins necessary for growth of a bacterium, along with copious amounts of water. A single bacterium will grow into a visible mound on the surface of the plate called a colony, which may be separated from other colonies or melded together into a "lawn". The size, color, shape and form of a colony is characteristic of the bacterial species, its specific genetic makeup (its strain), and the environment that supports its growth. Other ingredients are often added to the plate to aid in identification. Plates may contain substances that permit the growth of some bacteria and not others, or that change color in response to certain bacteria and not others. Bacteriological plates such as these are commonly used in the clinical identification of infectious bacterium. Microbial culture may also be used in the identification of viruses: the medium in this case being cells grown in culture that the virus can infect, and then alter or kill. In the case of viral identification, a region of dead cells results from viral growth, and is called a "plaque". Eukaryotic parasites may also be grown in culture as a means of identifying a particular agent.
text_ai_base: Microbiological culture is a key method for diagnosing infectious diseases. It involves providing a growth medium tailored for a specific microorganism. A sample from potentially infected tissue or fluid is then tested for the presence of an infectious agent that can thrive in that medium. Pathogenic bacteria generally grow well on nutrient agar, a type of solid medium that supplies the carbohydrates, proteins, and water essential for bacterial growth. A single bacterium will proliferate into a visible mound on the plate's surface, known as a colony, which can either be isolated or merge into what is called a "lawn." The colony's size, color, shape, and form are distinctive to the bacterial species, its strain, and the growth-supporting environment. Additional ingredients are frequently incorporated into the plate to assist with identification. These plates may contain substances that allow certain bacteria to grow over others or change color depending on the bacterial type. Such bacteriological plates are standard in the clinical identification of infectious bacteria. Microbial culture is also used to identify viruses, using a medium of cells grown in culture that the virus can infect, modify, or destroy. For viruses, areas of dead cells from viral activity are known as "plaques." Similarly, eukaryotic parasites can be cultured for identification purposes.
text_ai_humanized: Diagnosing infectious diseases often hinges on a fundamental technique: microbiological culture. This process requires a growth medium specifically suited to foster a particular microorganism's development. Samples, whether derived from potentially infected tissues or fluids, are examined to identify an infectious agent capable of flourishing in that environment. Nutrient agar, a form of solid medium, is particularly effective for cultivating pathogenic bacteria as it provides the necessary carbohydrates, proteins, and water for growth. Picture this: a lone bacterium lands and eventually multiplies into a small, visible cluster on the surface—this is called a colony. These colonies can appear either discretely spaced or grow together to form what's known as a "lawn." The distinct characteristics of these colonies—size, color, shape, and overall form—offer clues to the bacterial species, strain, and the nurturing conditions of the medium. To aid in identification, plates often include additional components that select for certain bacteria, sometimes inducing color changes that help pinpoint the bacterial type. Such plates are a staple in the clinical detection and identification of infectious bacteria. But the story doesn't end with bacteria. Viral identification also employs culture techniques, albeit with a medium comprised of living cells, which the virus can infect or destroy. The aftermath of viral destruction leads to "plaques," areas of cell death indicative of viral presence. Eukaryotic parasites, too, find themselves subject to culture methods for accurate characterization and identification. By using these varied culture techniques, we can accurately identify a broad spectrum of pathogens, ensuring precise diagnosis and effective treatment of infectious diseases.

text_human: Switzerland lies between latitudes 45° and 48° N, and longitudes 5° and 11° E. It contains three basic topographical areas: the Swiss Alps to the south, the Swiss Plateau or Central Plateau, and the Jura mountains on the west. The Alps are a high mountain range running across the central-south of the country, comprising about 60% of the country's total area. The majority of the Swiss population live in the Swiss Plateau. Among the high valleys of the Swiss Alps many glaciers are found, totalling an area of 1,063 square kilometres (410 sq mi). From these originate the headwaters of several major rivers, such as the Rhine, Inn, Ticino and Rhône, which flow in the four cardinal directions into the whole of Europe. The hydrographic network includes several of the largest bodies of freshwater in Central and Western Europe, among which are included Lake Geneva (also called le Lac Léman in French), Lake Constance (known as Bodensee in German) and Lake Maggiore. Switzerland has more than 1500 lakes, and contains 6% of Europe's stock of fresh water. Lakes and glaciers cover about 6% of the national territory. The largest lake is Lake Geneva, in western Switzerland shared with France. The Rhône is both the main source and outflow of Lake Geneva. Lake Constance is the second largest Swiss lake and, like the Lake Geneva, an intermediate step by the Rhine at the border to Austria and Germany. While the Rhône flows into the Mediterranean Sea at the French Camarque region and the Rhine flows into the North Sea at Rotterdam in the Netherlands, about 1000 km apart, both springs are only about 22 km apart from each other in the Swiss Alps.

This close proximity of their springs is a geographical curiosity worth noting.

text_human: On April 4, 2008, Beyoncé married Jay Z. She publicly revealed their marriage in a video montage at the listening party for her third studio album, I Am... Sasha Fierce, in Manhattan's Sony Club on October 22, 2008. I Am... Sasha Fierce was released on November 18, 2008 in the United States. The album formally introduces Beyoncé's alter ego Sasha Fierce, conceived during the making of her 2003 single "Crazy in Love", selling 482,000 copies in its first week, debuting atop the Billboard 200, and giving Beyoncé her third consecutive number-one album in the US. The album featured the number-one song "Single Ladies (Put a Ring on It)" and the top-five songs "If I Were a Boy" and "Halo". Achieving the accomplishment of becoming her longest-running Hot 100 single in her career, "Halo"'s success in the US helped Beyoncé attain more top-ten singles on the list than any other woman during the 2000s. It also included the successful "Sweet Dreams", and singles "Diva", "Ego", "Broken-Hearted Girl" and "Video Phone". The music video for "Single Ladies" has been parodied and imitated around the world, spawning the "first major dance craze" of the Internet age according to the Toronto Star. The video has won several awards, including Best Video at the 2009 MTV Europe Music Awards, the 2009 Scottish MOBO Awards, and the 2009 BET Awards. At the 2009 MTV Video Music Awards, the video was nominated for nine awards, ultimately winning three including Video of the Year. Its failure to win the Best Female Video category, which went to American country pop singer Taylor Swift's "You Belong with Me", led to Kanye West interrupting the ceremony and Beyoncé improvising a re-presentation of Swift's award during her own acceptance speech. In March 2009, Beyoncé embarked on the I Am... World Tour, her second headlining worldwide concert tour, consisting of 108 shows, grossing $119.5 million.

The album was released in the US on November 18, 2008, and introduced Beyoncé's alter ego, Sasha Fierce, which emerged during her 2003 hit single "Crazy in Love." It sold 482,000 copies in its first week, debuting at number one on the Billboard 200, marking Beyoncé's third straight US number-one album. The album included the number-one hit "Single Ladies (Put a Ring on It)" and top-five hits "If I Were a Boy" and "Halo." The success of "Halo" made it her longest-running Hot 100 single and helped her achieve more top-ten hits than any other female artist in the 2000s. Additional hits from the album included "Sweet Dreams" alongside singles "Diva," "Ego," "Broken-Hearted Girl," and "Video Phone." The music video for "Single Ladies" gained international fame, sparking what the Toronto Star called the "first major dance craze" of the Internet age. The video won numerous awards, including Best Video at the 2009 MTV Europe Music Awards, the 2009 Scottish MOBO Awards, and the 2009 BET Awards. At the 2009 MTV Video Music Awards, it was nominated for nine awards, winning three, including Video of the Year. However, its loss in the Best Female Video category to Taylor Swift's "You Belong with Me" led to Kanye West's infamous interruption and prompted Beyoncé to graciously share her acceptance speech time with Swift. In March 2009, Beyoncé launched the I Am... World Tour, her second solo global tour, comprising 108 shows and grossing $119.5 million.
text_ai_humanized: On a spring day, April 4, 2008, Beyoncé and Jay Z exchanged vows in a ceremony that marked the beginning of a new chapter for the superstar couple. Although they kept their wedding low-key, Beyoncé chose to reveal their matrimonial bliss later that year, on October 22, 2008, at a listening party for her third studio album, *I Am... Sasha Fierce*. The event took place at Manhattan's illustrious Sony Club. Just a month after this private disclosure, on November 18, the album hit the U.S. market, making waves with Beyoncé's intriguing alter ego, Sasha Fierce—a persona she first teased in her 2003 jam, "Crazy in Love." When *I Am... Sasha Fierce* dropped, it hit the ground running, selling a staggering 482,000 copies in its debut week. This impressive start secured the album the top spot on the Billboard 200, reinforcing Beyoncé’s streak of chart-topping success with her third consecutive U.S. number-one album. Packed with hits, the album featured chart-toppers like "Single Ladies (Put a Ring on It)" and high-ranking tracks such as "If I Were a Boy" and "Halo." In fact, "Halo" proved to be a standout, clinching Beyoncé’s record for the longest-running Hot 100 single and solidifying her status with more top-ten singles in the 2000s than any other female artist. That's no small feat! As the world soaked up Beyoncé's music, other tracks from the album also caught fire—hits like "Sweet Dreams" and irresistible singles such as "Diva," "Ego," "Broken-Hearted Girl," and "Video Phone" kept fans dancing. However, the music video for "Single Ladies" became a global phenomenon, igniting what the Toronto Star famously dubbed the "first major dance craze" of the Internet age. Garnering awards left and right, the video snagged Best Video accolades at the 2009 MTV Europe Music Awards, the Scottish MOBO Awards, and the BET Awards. The 2009 MTV Video Music Awards highlighted the video’s success even further with a whopping nine nominations and three wins—including Video of the Year. Yet, the ceremony didn’t pass without drama. Beyoncé's video lost Best Female Video to Taylor Swift's "You Belong with Me," sparking Kanye West’s notorious stage invasion. Amid the turmoil, Beyoncé’s grace shone through when she graciously used her acceptance speech moment to allow Swift a second chance at the podium. As if the year wasn’t eventful enough, March 2009 ushered in Beyoncé’s electrifying I Am... World Tour. This marked her second solo endeavor across the globe, sprawling across 108 shows and pulling in a jaw-dropping $119.5 million. In the world of tours, that’s serious coin.
