text_human: Many ground crew at the airport work at the aircraft. A tow tractor pulls the aircraft to one of the airbridges, The ground power unit is plugged in. It keeps the electricity running in the plane when it stands at the terminal. The engines are not working, therefore they do not generate the electricity, as they do in flight. The passengers disembark using the airbridge. Mobile stairs can give the ground crew more access to the aircraft's cabin. There is a cleaning service to clean the aircraft after the aircraft lands. Flight catering provides the food and drinks on flights. A toilet waste truck removes the human waste from the tank which holds the waste from the toilets in the aircraft. A water truck fills the water tanks of the aircraft. A fuel transfer vehicle transfers aviation fuel from fuel tanks underground, to the aircraft tanks. A tractor and its dollies bring in luggage from the terminal to the aircraft. They also carry luggage to the terminal if the aircraft has landed, and is being unloaded. Hi-loaders lift the heavy luggage containers to the gate of the cargo hold. The ground crew push the luggage containers into the hold. If it has landed, they rise, the ground crew push the luggage container on the hi-loader, which carries it down. The luggage container is then pushed on one of the tractors dollies. The conveyor, which is a conveyor belt on a truck, brings in the awkwardly shaped, or late luggage. The airbridge is used again by the new passengers to embark the aircraft. The tow tractor pushes the aircraft away from the terminal to a taxi area. The aircraft should be off of the airport and in the air in 90 minutes. The airport charges the airline for the time the aircraft spends at the airport.
text_ai_base: At the airport, many ground crew members are responsible for servicing aircraft. A tow tractor positions the plane at one of the airbridges, and a ground power unit is connected to maintain electrical systems while the aircraft is stationary, since the engines, which generate electricity in flight, are off. Passengers disembark via the airbridge, while mobile stairs may be used by the ground crew to access the cabin. After landing, a cleaning service tidies the aircraft, and flight catering supplies food and beverages for the next flight. A toilet waste truck removes waste from the onboard tanks, and a water truck refills the aircraft’s water supply. Fuel transfer vehicles deliver aviation fuel from underground tanks to the aircraft. Meanwhile, a tractor with dollies transports luggage between the terminal and aircraft. When unloading, luggage is conveyed to the terminal, and hi-loaders lift heavy luggage containers to the cargo hold gate, where ground crew load them in. After landing, these containers are placed on hi-loaders that lower them to the tarmac before transferring them onto dollies. A conveyor truck handles any awkwardly shaped or late luggage. The airbridge is used again for new passengers to board. The tow tractor then moves the aircraft from the terminal to a taxi area, aiming for a departure within 90 minutes. The airport charges the airline for the time the aircraft spends there.
text_ai_humanized: In the bustling environment of an airport, the ground crew hustles with an array of tasks to service the arrived aircraft efficiently. A tow tractor—an indispensable piece of equipment—carefully maneuvers the plane towards one of the airbridges. Meanwhile, a ground power unit connects to the aircraft, essential to powering its systems while on the ground, given that the engines, which produce electricity during flight, are currently silent. Passengers make their way off the aircraft using the airbridge, though sometimes you'll see ground crew scrambling up mobile stairs to access the cabin for various jobs. It's a flurry of activity once the plane lands. Cleaning teams swoop in to refresh the cabin, while catering services bring in the next flight's meals and drinks. Now, addressing the less glamorous side, a toilet waste truck stops by to empty the aircraft's waste tanks, followed by a water truck to top off the fresh water supply. Over to the fueling operation, where special vehicles draw aviation fuel from vast underground reserves directly into the aircraft’s tanks. Simultaneously, there's a busy exchange of luggage. A tractor outfitted with dollies shuttles bags to and from the aircraft, ensuring everything is in its right place. Unloading involves a precise choreography: luggage heads to the terminal, with heavy-load hi-loaders taking charge of sizable containers at the cargo hold gate; the crew collaborates tirelessly to fit them snugly inside. When it's time to deboard these containers, hi-loaders descend them onto the tarmac, ready for transfer onto dollies. Odd-shaped or last-minute arrivals? A conveyor truck has a knack for handling those. After the whirlwind of servicing, attention shifts back to passengers. New travelers board via the airbridge. The trusty tow tractor, once more, guides the plane from the terminal to a nearby taxi area, all aiming to meet the tight 90-minute turnover target. The clock's ticking, quite literally, as the longer an aircraft occupies its airport spot, the heftier the fee the airline faces. It's a calculated race against time and logistics, where every minute—and indeed every member of the ground crew—counts.

message.content:
In the bustling environment of an airport, the ground crew hustles with an array of tasks to service the arrived aircraft efficiently. A tow tractor—an indispensable piece of equipment—carefully maneuvers the plane towards one of the airbridges. Meanwhile, a ground power unit connects to the aircraft, essential to powering its systems while on the ground, given that the engines, which produce electricity during flight, are currently silent. Passengers make their way off the aircraft using the airbridge, though sometimes you'll see ground crew scrambling up mobile stairs to access the cabin for various jobs.

It's a flurry of activity once the plane lands. Cleaning teams swoop in to refresh the cabin, while catering services bring in the next flight's meals and drinks. Now, addressing the less glamorous side, a toilet waste truck stops by to empty the aircraft's waste tanks, followed by a water truck to top off the fresh water supply. Over to the fueling operation, where special vehicles draw aviation fuel from vast underground reserves directly into the aircraft’s tanks.

Simultaneously, there's a busy exchange of luggage. A tractor outfitted with dollies shuttles bags to and from the aircraft, ensuring everything is in its right place. Unloading involves a precise choreography: luggage heads to the terminal, with heavy-load hi-loaders taking charge of sizable containers at the cargo hold gate; the crew collaborates tirelessly to fit them snugly inside. When it's time to deboard these containers, hi-loaders descend them onto the tarmac, ready for transfer onto dollies. Odd-shaped or last-minute arrivals? A conveyor truck has a knack for handling those.

After the whirlwind of servicing, attention shifts back to passengers. New travelers board via the airbridge. The trusty tow tractor, once more, guides the plane from the terminal to a nearby taxi area, all aiming to meet the tight 90-minute turnover target. The clock's ticking, quite literally, as the longer an aircraft occupies its airport spot, the heftier the fee the airline faces. It's a calculated race against time and logistics, where every minute—and indeed every member of the ground crew—counts.

text_human: Hidalgo is hailed as the Father of the Nation even though it was Agustin de Iturbide and not Hidalgo who achieved Mexican Independence in 1821. Shortly after gaining independence, the day to celebrate it varied between September 16, the day of Hidalgo's Grito, and September 27, the day Iturbide rode into Mexico City to end the war. Later, political movements would favor the more liberal Hidalgo over the conservative Iturbide, so that eventually September 16, 1810 became the officially recognized day of Mexican independence. The reason for this is that Hidalgo is considered to be "precursor and creator of the rest of the heroes of the (Mexican War of) Independence." Hidalgo has become an icon for Mexicans who resist tyranny in the country. Diego Rivera painted Hidalgo's image in half a dozen murals. José Clemente Orozco depicted him with a flaming torch of liberty and considered the painting among his best work. David Alfaro Siqueiros was commissioned by San Nicolas University in Morelia to paint a mural for a celebration commemorating the 200th anniversary of Hidalgo's birth. The town of his parish was renamed Dolores Hidalgo in his honor and the state of Hidalgo was created in 1869. Every year on the night of 15–16 September, the president of Mexico re-enacts the Grito from the balcony of the National Palace. This scene is repeated by the heads of cities and towns all over Mexico. The remains of Miguel Hidalgo y Costilla lie in the column of the Angel of Independence in Mexico City. Next to it is a lamp lit to represent the sacrifice of those who gave their lives for Mexican Independence.

Over time, political movements leaned towards the liberal Hidalgo rather than the conservative Iturbide, leading to September 16, 1810, being officially recognized as Mexican Independence Day. text_human: Usually a Presbyterian church will not have statues of saints, nor the ornate altar more typical of a Roman Catholic church. Instead, one will find a "communion table," usually on the same level as the congregation. There may be a rail between the communion table and the "Chancel" behind it, which may contain a more decorative altar-type table, choir loft, or choir stalls, lectern and clergy area. The altar is called the communion table and the altar area is called the Chancel by Presbyterians. In a Presbyterian (Reformed Church) there may be an altar cross, either on the communion table or on a table in the chancel. By using the "empty" cross, or cross of the resurrection, Presbyterians emphasize the resurrection and that Christ is not continually dying, but died once and is alive for all eternity. Some Presbyterian church buildings are often decorated with a cross that has a circle around the center, or Celtic cross. This not only emphasized the resurrection, but also acknowledges historical aspects of Presbyterianism. A baptismal font will be located either at the entrance or near the chancel area. Presbyterian architecture generally makes significant use of symbolism. You may also find decorative and ornate stained glass windows depicting scenes from the bible. Some Presbyterian churches will also have ornate statues of Christ or Graven Scenes from the Last Supper located behind the Chancel. St. Giles Cathedral ( Church Of Scotland- The Mother Church of Presbyterians) does have a Crucifix next to one of the Pulpits that hangs alongside. The image of Christ is more of faint image and more modern design.

A Presbyterian church might display an altar cross, either on the communion table or a table within the Chancel. A baptismal font is typically located at the entrance or near the Chancel. Some churches may include ornate statues of Christ or detailed depictions of the Last Supper behind the Chancel. For instance, St. Giles Cathedral, the Mother Church of the Church of Scotland, has a modern, faintly designed crucifix hanging next to one of the pulpits.

text_human: Of the 80 torch-bearers in London, Sir Steve Redgrave, who started the relay, mentioned to the media that he had received e-mailed pleas to boycott the event and could "see why they would like to make an issue" of it. Francesca Martinez and Richard Vaughan refused to carry the torch, while Konnie Huq decided to carry it and also speak out against China. The pro-Tibetan Member of Parliament Norman Baker asked all bearers to reconsider. Amid pressure from both directions, Prime Minister Gordon Brown welcomed the torch outside 10 Downing Street without holding or touching it. The London relay saw the torch surrounded by what the BBC described as "a mobile protective ring." Protests began as soon as Redgrave started the event, leading to at least thirty-five arrests. In Ladbroke Grove a demonstrator attempted to snatch the torch from Konnie Huq in a momentary struggle, and in a separate incident, a fire extinguisher was set off near the torch. The Chinese ambassador carried the torch through Chinatown after an unpublicized change to the route amid security concerns. The torch made an unscheduled move onto a bus along Fleet Street amid security concerns and efforts to evade the protesters. In an effort to counter the pro-Tibet protesters and show their support for the 2008 Beijing Olympics, more than 2,000 Chinese also gathered on the torch route and demonstrated with signs, banners and Chinese flags. A large number of supporters were concentrated in Trafalgar Square, displaying the Olympic slogan "One World, One Dream".

text_human: The album also featured the hit single "Bohemian Rhapsody", which was number one in the UK for nine weeks. Mercury's close friend and advisor, Capital London radio DJ Kenny Everett, played a pivotal role in giving the single exposure. It is the third-best-selling single of all time in the UK, surpassed only by Band Aid's "Do They Know It's Christmas?" and Elton John's "Candle in the Wind 1997", and is the best-selling commercial single in the UK. It also reached number nine in the United States (a 1992 re-release reached number two on the Billboard Hot 100 for five weeks). It is the only single ever to sell a million copies on two separate occasions, and became the Christmas number one twice in the UK, the only single ever to do so. "Bohemian Rhapsody" has been voted numerous times the greatest song of all time. The band decided to make a video to help go with the single and hired Trilion, a subsidiary of the former management company Trident Studios, using new technology to create the video; the result is generally considered to have been the first "true" music video ever produced, and popularised the medium. The album's first track "Death on Two Legs" is said to be written by Mercury about Norman Sheffield and the former management at Trident who helped make the video so popular. Although other bands, including the Beatles, had made short promotional films or videos of songs prior to this, generally, those were specifically made to be aired on specific television shows. On the impact of "Bohemian Rhapsody", Rolling Stone states: "Its influence cannot be overstated, practically inventing the music video seven years before MTV went on the air." The second single from the album, "You're My Best Friend", the second song composed by John Deacon, and his first single, peaked at number sixteen in the United States and went on to become a worldwide Top Ten hit. The band's A Night at the Opera Tour began in November 1975, and covered Europe, the United States, Japan, and Australia.

text_human: As cellular metabolism/energy production requires oxygen, potentially damaging (e.g., mutation causing) compounds known as free radicals can form. Most of these are oxidizers (i.e., acceptors of electrons) and some react very strongly. For the continued normal cellular maintenance, growth, and division, these free radicals must be sufficiently neutralized by antioxidant compounds. Recently, some researchers suggested an interesting theory of evolution of dietary antioxidants. Some are produced by the human body with adequate precursors (glutathione, Vitamin C), and those the body cannot produce may only be obtained in the diet via direct sources (Vitamin C in humans, Vitamin A, Vitamin K) or produced by the body from other compounds (Beta-carotene converted to Vitamin A by the body, Vitamin D synthesized from cholesterol by sunlight). Phytochemicals (Section Below) and their subgroup, polyphenols, make up the majority of antioxidants; about 4,000 are known. Different antioxidants are now known to function in a cooperative network. For example, Vitamin C can reactivate free radical-containing glutathione or Vitamin E by accepting the free radical itself. Some antioxidants are more effective than others at neutralizing different free radicals. Some cannot neutralize certain free radicals. Some cannot be present in certain areas of free radical development (Vitamin A is fat-soluble and protects fat areas, Vitamin C is water-soluble and protects those areas). When interacting with a free radical, some antioxidants produce a different free radical compound that is less dangerous or more dangerous than the previous compound. Having a variety of antioxidants allows any byproducts to be safely dealt with by more efficient antioxidants in neutralizing a free radical's butterfly effect.
text_ai_base: Cellular metabolism and energy production rely on oxygen, but this can lead to the formation of potentially harmful compounds known as free radicals, which can cause mutations. Most of these radicals are oxidizers that strongly react by accepting electrons. For normal cellular maintenance, growth, and division, it is essential to neutralize these free radicals with antioxidants. Recently, some researchers proposed an intriguing theory about the evolution of dietary antioxidants. The human body produces some antioxidants like glutathione and Vitamin C but requires others through diet, such as Vitamin C in humans, Vitamin A, and Vitamin K. Some antioxidants can be synthesized by the body from other substances, like Beta-carotene, which is converted into Vitamin A, and Vitamin D, which is made from cholesterol through sunlight exposure. Phytochemicals and their subset, polyphenols, form the majority of known antioxidants, totaling about 4,000. These antioxidants work in a cooperative network, with some like Vitamin C reactivating free radical-containing compounds like glutathione or Vitamin E by taking on the radical itself. Each antioxidant varies in its effectiveness against different free radicals, with some unable to neutralize certain types or function in specific areas—Vitamin A, being fat-soluble, protects fat regions, while Vitamin C, being water-soluble, guards watery areas. When antioxidants interact with free radicals, they may produce new radical compounds that can be less or more harmful than the original. A diverse array of antioxidants ensures that any resultant byproducts are efficiently handled, neutralizing the potential cascading effects of free radicals.
text_ai_humanized: While oxygen is crucial for cellular metabolism and energy production, it can also give rise to harmful compounds called free radicals, notorious for instigating mutations. Predominantly, these radicals are oxidizers, eager to snatch up electrons and wreak havoc. To keep cells running smoothly—supporting maintenance, growth, and division—it's vital to disarm these free radicals using antioxidants. An intriguing theory surfaced recently regarding the evolutionary role of dietary antioxidants. Our bodies do produce some antioxidants, such as glutathione and Vitamin C, yet they still require certain others from food, including Vitamin A and Vitamin K. Interestingly enough, our bodies can synthesize some antioxidants from different substances: Beta-carotene morphs into Vitamin A, while Vitamin D is conjured from cholesterol under sunlight’s tender embrace. When diving into the depths of phytochemicals and polyphenols, one discovers a vast world teeming with approximately 4,000 known antioxidants. These dynamic compounds weave a cooperative web, working in tandem. For example, Vitamin C can regenerate other antioxidants like glutathione or Vitamin E by tackling radicals head-on itself. But not all antioxidants are created equal—each has its own knack for tackling specific types of free radicals, and sometimes they simply aren't equipped to combat certain kinds. Consider Vitamin A, which thrives in fatty regions thanks to its fat-solubility, contrasting with Vitamin C, which defends watery areas due to its water-solubility. Yet, this dance of antioxidants and free radicals is not without its own intricacies. Occasionally, when antioxidants neutralize free radicals, they spawn new radical creatures—better or worse than their predecessors. A varied arsenal of antioxidants is crucial; it ensures that any rogue byproducts are swiftly managed, nipping potential cascades in the bud.

message.content:
While oxygen is crucial for cellular metabolism and energy production, it can also give rise to harmful compounds called free radicals, notorious for instigating mutations. Predominantly, these radicals are oxidizers, eager to snatch up electrons and wreak havoc. To keep cells running smoothly—supporting maintenance, growth, and division—it's vital to disarm these free radicals using antioxidants. An intriguing theory surfaced recently regarding the evolutionary role of dietary antioxidants. Our bodies do produce some antioxidants, such as glutathione and Vitamin C, yet they still require certain others from food, including Vitamin A and Vitamin K. Interestingly enough, our bodies can synthesize some antioxidants from different substances: Beta-carotene morphs into Vitamin A, while Vitamin D is conjured from cholesterol under sunlight’s tender embrace.

When diving into the depths of phytochemicals and polyphenols, one discovers a vast world teeming with approximately 4,000 known antioxidants. These dynamic compounds weave a cooperative web, working in tandem. For example, Vitamin C can regenerate other antioxidants like glutathione or Vitamin E by tackling radicals head-on itself. But not all antioxidants are created equal—each has its own knack for tackling specific types of free radicals, and sometimes they simply aren't equipped to combat certain kinds. Consider Vitamin A, which thrives in fatty regions thanks to its fat-solubility, contrasting with Vitamin C, which defends watery areas due to its water-solubility.

Yet, this dance of antioxidants and free radicals is not without its own intricacies. Occasionally, when antioxidants neutralize free radicals, they spawn new radical creatures—better or worse than their predecessors. A varied arsenal of antioxidants is crucial; it ensures that any rogue byproducts are swiftly managed, nipping potential cascades in the bud.

text_human: Zhejiang's main manufacturing sectors are electromechanical industries, textiles, chemical industries, food, and construction materials. In recent years Zhejiang has followed its own development model, dubbed the "Zhejiang model", which is based on prioritizing and encouraging entrepreneurship, an emphasis on small businesses responsive to the whims of the market, large public investments into infrastructure, and the production of low-cost goods in bulk for both domestic consumption and export. As a result, Zhejiang has made itself one of the richest provinces, and the "Zhejiang spirit" has become something of a legend within China. However, some economists now worry that this model is not sustainable, in that it is inefficient and places unreasonable demands on raw materials and public utilities, and also a dead end, in that the myriad small businesses in Zhejiang producing cheap goods in bulk are unable to move to more sophisticated or technologically more advanced industries. The economic heart of Zhejiang is moving from North Zhejiang, centered on Hangzhou, southeastward to the region centered on Wenzhou and Taizhou. The per capita disposable income of urbanites in Zhejiang reached 24,611 yuan (US$3,603) in 2009, an annual real growth of 8.3%. The per capita pure income of rural residents stood at 10,007 yuan (US$1,465), a real growth of 8.1% year-on-year. Zhejiang's nominal GDP for 2011 was 3.20 trillion yuan (US$506 billion) with a per capita GDP of 44,335 yuan (US$6,490). In 2009, Zhejiang's primary, secondary, and tertiary industries were worth 116.2 billion yuan (US$17 billion), 1.1843 trillion yuan (US$173.4 billion), and 982.7 billion yuan (US$143.9 billion) respectively.

text_ai_humanized: Zhejiang's economic landscape is rich and varied, with key sectors such as electromechanical industries, textiles, chemicals, food processing, and construction materials leading the charge. The province is known for its innovative "Zhejiang model" of development—a strategy that's been gaining attention for its unique approach. Central to this model are a few distinct principles: fostering entrepreneurship, supporting nimble small businesses that can swiftly pivot with market demands, and pouring substantial investments into infrastructure. Additionally, Zhejiang has carved out a niche in producing low-cost goods on a massive scale, catering to both local and international markets. Consequently, Zhejiang stands proudly as one of China's most affluent provinces, and the "Zhejiang spirit" has become a point of national pride. Yet, this model isn't without its critics. Some economists voice concerns over its long-term viability, pointing out potential inefficiencies and the heavy dependence on raw materials and public services. There's also a pressing question: Can these numerous small enterprises, rooted in low-cost production, effectively pivot towards more advanced industries? A notable economic shift is underway within the province itself, moving focus from the northern hub of Hangzhou to the southeastern areas such as Wenzhou and Taizhou. To put economic conditions in perspective, back in 2009, urban residents enjoyed a per capita disposable income of 24,611 yuan (around US$3,603), with an impressive real growth rate of 8.3% per annum. Meanwhile, rural inhabitants earned 10,007 yuan (about US$1,465) per person, growing at 8.1% year-on-year. By 2011, Zhejiang's economy had reached a significant milestone. The province's nominal GDP soared to 3.20 trillion yuan (approximately US$506 billion). Delving deeper, the per capita GDP stood at 44,335 yuan (US$6,490). In terms of industry valuation for 2009, Zhejiang's primary industries accounted for 116.2 billion yuan (US$17 billion), secondary industries 1.1843 trillion yuan (US$173.4 billion), and tertiary industries were valued at 982.7 billion yuan (US$143.9 billion). With these figures, one might wonder what's next for Zhejiang? The stage is set, but challenges lie ahead.

text_human: A central teaching of Jehovah's Witnesses is that the current world era, or "system of things", entered the "last days" in 1914 and faces imminent destruction through intervention by God and Jesus Christ, leading to deliverance for those who worship God acceptably. They consider all other present-day religions to be false, identifying them with "Babylon the Great", or the "harlot", of Revelation 17, and believe that they will soon be destroyed by the United Nations, which they believe is represented in scripture by the scarlet-colored wild beast of Revelation chapter 17. This development will mark the beginning of the "great tribulation". Satan will subsequently attack Jehovah's Witnesses, an action that will prompt God to begin the war of Armageddon, during which all forms of government and all people not counted as Christ's "sheep", or true followers, will be destroyed. After Armageddon, God will extend his heavenly kingdom to include earth, which will be transformed into a paradise similar to the Garden of Eden. After Armageddon, most of those who had died before God's intervention will gradually be resurrected during "judgment day" lasting for one thousand years. This judgment will be based on their actions after resurrection rather than past deeds. At the end of the thousand years, Christ will hand all authority back to God. Then a final test will take place when Satan is released to mislead perfect mankind. Those who fail will be destroyed, along with Satan and his demons. The end result will be a fully tested, glorified human race.

Afterward, Satan will assault Jehovah's Witnesses, triggering God's initiation of Armageddon, during which all governments and all individuals not identified as Christ's "sheep," or genuine followers, will be eliminated. Those who falter will perish with Satan and his minions, thus paving the way for a thoroughly vetted and glorified human existence.

text_human: Banner Armies were organized along ethnic lines, namely Manchu and Mongol, but included non-Manchu bondservants registered under the household of their Manchu masters. The years leading up to the conquest increased the number of Han Chinese under Manchu rule, leading Hong Taiji to create the Eight Han Banners (zh), and around the time of the Qing takeover of Beijing, their numbers rapidly swelled. Han Bannermen held high status and power in the early Qing period, especially immediately after the conquest during Shunzhi and Kangxi's reign where they dominated Governor-Generalships and Governorships across China at the expense of both Manchu Bannermen and Han civilians. Han also numerically dominated the Banners up until the mid 18th century. European visitors in Beijing called them "Tartarized Chinese" or "Tartarified Chinese". It was in Qianlong's reign that the Qianlong Emperor, concerned about maintaining Manchu identity, re-emphasized Manchu ethnicity, ancestry, language, and culture in the Eight Banners and started a mass discharge of Han Bannermen from the Eight Banners, either asking them to voluntarily resign from the Banner rolls or striking their names off. This led to a change from Han majority to a Manchu majority within the Banner system, and previous Han Bannermen garrisons in southern China such as at Fuzhou, Zhenjiang, Guangzhou, were replaced by Manchu Bannermen in the purge, which started in 1754. The turnover by Qianlong most heavily impacted Han banner garrisons stationed in the provinces while it less impacted Han Bannermen in Beijing, leaving a larger proportion of remaining Han Bannermen in Beijing than the provinces. Han Bannermen's status was decreased from that point on with Manchu Banners gaining higher status. Han Bannermen numbered 75% in 1648 Shunzhi's reign, 72% in 1723 Yongzheng's reign, but decreased to 43% in 1796 during the first year of Jiaqing's reign, which was after Qianlong's purge. The mass discharge was known as the Disbandment of the Han Banners (zh). Qianlong directed most of his ire at those Han Bannermen descended from defectors who joined the Qing after the Qing passed through the Great Wall at Shanhai Pass in 1644, deeming their ancestors as traitors to the Ming and therefore untrustworthy, while retaining Han Bannermen who were descended from defectors who joined the Qing before 1644 in Liaodong and marched through Shanhai pass, also known as those who "followed the Dragon through the pass" (從龍入關; cong long ru guan).
text_ai_base: The Banner Armies of the Qing dynasty were structured based on ethnic lines, primarily consisting of Manchu and Mongol groups, but they also included non-Manchu bondservants registered under their Manchu masters' households. As the Qing approached their conquest, the number of Han Chinese under Manchu rule grew significantly. To address this, Hong Taiji established the Eight Han Banners. Around the time of the Qing's capture of Beijing, the Han Chinese numbers in these Banners rapidly increased. In the early Qing period, particularly during the reigns of Shunzhi and Kangxi, Han Bannermen held significant status and power, often dominating positions such as Governor-Generalships and Governorships, overshadowing both Manchu Bannermen and Han civilians. The Han outnumbered other groups within the Banners until the mid-18th century. European visitors in Beijing referred to them as "Tartarized Chinese" or "Tartarified Chinese." During Emperor Qianlong's reign, concerned about preserving Manchu identity, there was a renewed focus on Manchu ethnicity, ancestry, language, and culture within the Eight Banners. This led to a large-scale removal of Han Bannermen, beginning in 1754, with many being asked to resign or having their names removed from the Banner rolls. Consequently, the Banner system shifted from a Han majority to a Manchu majority. Han garrisons in southern China, such as those in Fuzhou, Zhenjiang, and Guangzhou, were replaced by Manchu Bannermen. The turnover severely affected provincial Han Banner garrisons but had less impact on those in Beijing, where a higher proportion of Han Bannermen remained. From this period onward, the status of Han Bannermen diminished as Manchu Banners rose in prominence. During Shunzhi's reign in 1648, 75% of Bannermen were Han, which dropped to 72% in 1723 during Yongzheng's reign, and further to 43% in 1796, at the start of Jiaqing's reign after Qianlong's purge, known as the Disbandment of the Han Banners. Qianlong specifically targeted Han Bannermen descended from defectors who joined the Qing after they breached the Great Wall at Shanhai Pass in 1644, viewing them as traitors to the Ming and distrustful. However, he retained those descended from defectors who joined the Qing prior to 1644 in Liaodong and participated in the passage through Shanhai Pass, who were known as those who "followed the Dragon through the pass."
text_ai_humanized: The Banner Armies under the Qing dynasty featured a system organized along ethnic lines, predominantly composed of Manchu and Mongol contingents. However, within this structure, non-Manchu bondservants were also included, recorded under the household registers of their Manchu overlords. As the Qing empire expanded its grasp, notably racing towards conquest, the presence of Han Chinese within Manchu dominion swelled noticeably. To accommodate this influx, Hong Taiji took the pivotal step of forming the Eight Han Banners. By the time the Qing forces successfully took Beijing, the Han populations within these Banners multiplied at an astonishing pace. During the nascent years of the Qing, particularly under the rule of emperors Shunzhi and Kangxi, Han Bannermen not only held considerable influence but also frequently occupied key governmental roles such as governor-generalships and governorships. This dominance often eclipsed the standing not only of Manchu Bannermen but also Han civilians outside the Banner system. Up until the mid-1700s, Han Bannermen were more numerous than any other ethnic group within the Banners. European travelers who found themselves in Beijing termed them as "Tartarized Chinese" or "Tartarified Chinese," reflecting their perceived assimilation into Manchu culture. The reign of Emperor Qianlong ushered in a new era where concerns about preserving the distinct Manchu lifestyle prompted a heightened emphasis on Manchu ethnicity, lineage, linguistic heritage, and cultural traditions within the Eight Banners. This cultural reaffirmation sparked a substantial purge beginning in 1754, which saw many Han Bannermen ousted, either through resignation demands or removal from the Banner rolls. This transformation shifted the demographic makeup from a majority of Han Bannermen to a predominant Manchu presence. Particularly in southern China—Fuzhou, Zhenjiang, Guangzhou—the Han garrisons were replaced by their Manchu counterparts, shaking the foundations of provincial Han Banner contingents. In contrast, the capital city Beijing experienced less upheaval, maintaining a significant number of Han Bannermen. As this era progressed, the previously significant status of Han Bannermen waned, while the prominence of the Manchu Banners ascended substantially. Backtrack a bit to the Shunzhi era, circa 1648, Han Bannermen comprised 75% of the Banner members. This figure slightly decreased to 72% under Yongzheng in 1723 and noticeably plummeted to 43% by 1796 at Jiaqing's accession, following Qianlong's formidable purge known as the Disbandment of the Han Banners. Qianlong's purge targeted Han Bannermen who were descendants of defectors joining the Qing post-1644, when the Great Wall at Shanhai Pass was breached, branding them as traitors to the Ming dynasty and thus, untrustworthy. Interestingly, those who defected prior to 1644, aiding in the Shanhai Pass crossing and originally from Liaodong—a group celebrated as "those who followed the Dragon through the pass"—saw a different fate, remaining largely unaffected by the emperor's purge.

text_human: Based on earlier transmitted reports, in the year 632, after the demise of Muhammad a number of his companions who knew the Quran by heart were killed in a battle by Musaylimah, the first caliph Abu Bakr (d. 634) decided to collect the book in one volume so that it could be preserved. Zayd ibn Thabit (d. 655) was the person to collect the Quran since "he used to write the Divine Inspiration for Allah's Apostle". Thus, a group of scribes, most importantly Zayd, collected the verses and produced a hand-written manuscript of the complete book. The manuscript according to Zayd remained with Abu Bakr until he died. Zayd's reaction to the task and the difficulties in collecting the Quranic material from parchments, palm-leaf stalks, thin stones and from men who knew it by heart is recorded in earlier narratives. After Abu Bakr, Hafsa bint Umar, Muhammad's widow, was entrusted with the manuscript. In about 650, the third Caliph Uthman ibn Affan (d. 656) began noticing slight differences in pronunciation of the Quran as Islam expanded beyond the Arabian Peninsula into Persia, the Levant, and North Africa. In order to preserve the sanctity of the text, he ordered a committee headed by Zayd to use Abu Bakr's copy and prepare a standard copy of the Quran. Thus, within 20 years of Muhammad's death, the Quran was committed to written form. That text became the model from which copies were made and promulgated throughout the urban centers of the Muslim world, and other versions are believed to have been destroyed. The present form of the Quran text is accepted by Muslim scholars to be the original version compiled by Abu Bakr.
text_ai_base: According to earlier reports, in 632, following the death of Muhammad, several of his companions who had memorized the Quran were killed in a battle with Musaylimah. In response, the first caliph, Abu Bakr (d. 634), decided to compile the Quran into a single volume for preservation. Zayd ibn Thabit (d. 655), who wrote down divine revelations for Muhammad, took on the task of collecting the Quranic verses. He, along with a group of scribes, meticulously compiled the verses into a manuscript. This manuscript remained with Abu Bakr until his death. Zayd's challenges in gathering the Quranic material from parchments, palm-leaf stalks, stones, and the memories of men are detailed in early accounts. After Abu Bakr's death, the manuscript was entrusted to Hafsa bint Umar, one of Muhammad's widows. Around 650, the third Caliph, Uthman ibn Affan (d. 656), observed minor pronunciation differences in Quranic recitation as Islam spread beyond the Arabian Peninsula to Persia, the Levant, and North Africa. To preserve the text's authenticity, he commissioned a committee led by Zayd to use Abu Bakr's copy to prepare an official version of the Quran. Within two decades of Muhammad’s death, the Quran was thus formally documented. This text served as the foundation for copies distributed across the Muslim world, with other versions reportedly destroyed. Muslim scholars widely regard this version as the original Quran compiled by Abu Bakr.
text_ai_humanized: In the tumultuous year of 632, a significant wave of events unfolded following the passing of Muhammad. Several disciples, who had committed the Quran to memory, met their end in a clash against Musaylimah. Such losses underscored the urgency for preservation, prompting the first caliph, Abu Bakr, to initiate the compilation of the Quran into a singular, cohesive volume. Zayd ibn Thabit, tasked with recording Muhammad's divine communications, embarked on the monumental effort of gathering the scattered Quranic verses. Working alongside a dedicated team of scribes, Zayd painstakingly assembled the verses into a manuscript. Initially, this manuscript remained under Abu Bakr's stewardship until he passed away. The arduous challenge faced by Zayd in retrieving Quranic material from a myriad of sources—parchments, palm-leaf stalks, stones, and particularly from the memories of countless men—finds ample mention in early narratives. Upon Abu Bakr’s death, the responsibility of safeguarding the manuscript transferred to Hafsa bint Umar, one of Muhammad's widows. Fast forward to around 650, as Islam began its rapid expansion into territories like Persia, the Levant, and North Africa, the third caliph, Uthman ibn Affan, noticed slight variances in Quranic pronunciation emerging among the diverse communities of new followers. Concerned about maintaining the text's integrity, Uthman took decisive action. He appointed Zayd once again to spearhead a committee tasked with using Abu Bakr's copy as the template for an official version of the Quran. Remarkably, within just two decades after Muhammad’s death, this formal documentation was completed, laying the groundwork for distribution across the expanding Muslim world. Other existing versions were reportedly destroyed to eliminate discrepancies. Today, Muslim scholars affirm that the Quran, as compiled following Abu Bakr’s initiative, is indeed regarded as the authentic version.

text_human: During his life and especially in the first year after his death, several places were named after Tito. Several of these places have since returned to their original names, such as Podgorica, formerly Titograd (though Podgorica's international airport is still identified by the code TGD), and Užice, formerly Titovo Užice, which reverted to its original name in 1992. Streets in Belgrade, the capital, have all reverted to their original pre–World War II and pre-communist names as well. In 2004, Antun Augustinčić's statue of Broz in his birthplace of Kumrovec was decapitated in an explosion. It was subsequently repaired. Twice in 2008, protests took place in Zagreb's Marshal Tito Square, organized by a group called Circle for the Square (Krug za Trg), with an aim to force the city government to rename it to its previous name, while a counter-protest by Citizens' Initiative Against Ustašism (Građanska inicijativa protiv ustaštva) accused the "Circle for the Square" of historical revisionism and neo-fascism. Croatian president Stjepan Mesić criticized the demonstration to change the name. In the Croatian coastal city of Opatija the main street (also its longest street) still bears the name of Marshal Tito, as do streets in numerous towns in Serbia, mostly in the country's north. One of the main streets in downtown Sarajevo is called Marshal Tito Street, and Tito's statue in a park in front of the university campus (ex. JNA barrack "Maršal Tito") in Marijin Dvor is a place where Bosnians and Sarajevans still today commemorate and pay tribute to Tito (image on the right). The largest Tito monument in the world, about 10 m (33 ft) high, is located at Tito Square (Slovene: Titov trg), the central square in Velenje, Slovenia. One of the main bridges in Slovenia's second largest city of Maribor is Tito Bridge (Titov most). The central square in Koper, the largest Slovenian port city, is as well named Tito Square.

text_human: The northwestern portion of Rajasthan is generally sandy and dry. Most of this region are covered by the Thar Desert which extends into adjoining portions of Pakistan. The Aravalli Range does not intercept the moisture-giving southwest monsoon winds off the Arabian Sea, as it lies in a direction parallel to that of the coming monsoon winds, leaving the northwestern region in a rain shadow. The Thar Desert is thinly populated; the town of Jodhpur is the largest city in the desert and known as the gateway of thar desert. The desert has some major districts like Jodhpur, Jaisalmer, Barmer, Bikaner and Nagour. This area is also important defence point of view. Jodhpur airbase is Indias largest airbase and military, BSF bases are also situated here. A single civil airport is also situated in Jodhpur. The Northwestern thorn scrub forests lie in a band around the Thar Desert, between the desert and the Aravallis. This region receives less than 400 mm of rain in an average year. Temperatures can exceed 48 °C in the summer months and drop below freezing in the winter. The Godwar, Marwar, and Shekhawati regions lie in the thorn scrub forest zone, along with the city of Jodhpur. The Luni River and its tributaries are the major river system of Godwar and Marwar regions, draining the western slopes of the Aravallis and emptying southwest into the great Rann of Kutch wetland in neighboring Gujarat. This river is saline in the lower reaches and remains potable only up to Balotara in Barmer district. The Ghaggar River, which originates in Haryana, is an intermittent stream that disappears into the sands of the Thar Desert in the northern corner of the state and is seen as a remnant of the primitive Saraswati river.
text_ai_base: The northwestern region of Rajasthan is predominantly sandy and dry, largely dominated by the Thar Desert, which stretches into neighboring Pakistan. The Aravalli Range runs parallel to the southwest monsoon winds coming from the Arabian Sea, preventing them from bringing moisture to this area, resulting in a rain shadow. The Thar Desert is sparsely populated, with Jodhpur being its largest city and known as the gateway to the desert. Significant districts within the desert include Jodhpur, Jaisalmer, Barmer, Bikaner, and Nagour. This area is of strategic importance for defense, housing India's largest airbase in Jodhpur, along with military and BSF bases. Jodhpur also hosts a civilian airport. Encircling the Thar Desert are the Northwestern thorn scrub forests, situated between the desert and the Aravallis. This region typically receives under 400 mm of rainfall annually. Summer temperatures can soar above 48°C, while winter may see temperatures drop below freezing. The Godwar, Marwar, and Shekhawati regions, along with the city of Jodhpur, lie within this thorn scrub forest zone. The Luni River and its tributaries form the primary river system of the Godwar and Marwar regions, draining the western slopes of the Aravallis and flowing southwest into the Rann of Kutch wetland in Gujarat. The river is saline in its lower sections and drinkable only up to Balotara in Barmer district. The intermittently flowing Ghaggar River, originating in Haryana, vanishes into the sands of the Thar Desert in the state's northern corner and is believed to be a relic of the ancient Saraswati River.
text_ai_humanized: Nestled in the northwestern expanse of Rajasthan lies a vast landscape marked by the defining presence of the Thar Desert, whose golden sands spill over into neighboring Pakistan. The brooding Aravalli Range stands as a natural barrier, shielding this arid territory from the southwestern monsoon winds that gather moisture from the Arabian Sea. This phenomenon creates a stark rain shadow effect, limiting the region's annual precipitation to less than 400 mm. Summers in this harsh expanse can be blistering, with temperatures occasionally soaring above 48°C, while the cooler months might catch you off guard with readings dipping below the freezing mark. At the heart of the desert's sparsely populated terrain, Jodhpur emerges as the largest city, holding a strategic role not just as the gateway to the desert sands but also a crucial defense hub. This city boasts India's largest airbase, a civilian airport, and numerous military and Border Security Force installations. Traveling further into the desert unfolds a tapestry of districts—Jaisalmer, Barmer, Bikaner, and Nagour—each significant in its own right. Surrounding the Thar Desert are the Northwestern thorn scrub forests, tucked between the arid desert and the looming Aravallis. Within this thorny enclave lie the regions of Godwar, Marwar, and Shekhawati, along with the city of Jodhpur itself. Here, the land is etched with the winding paths of the Luni River and its tributaries. This river, a crucial lifeline draining the western slopes of the Aravallis, meanders southwest and finds its rest in the Rann of Kutch wetland in Gujarat. Intriguingly, its waters transition from drinkable in Balotara to saline as it stretches further downstream. The elusive Ghaggar River, tracing its origins back to Haryana, ends its modest journey by disappearing into the sandy expanse of the Thar. A whisper of history surrounds this river, as it is often speculated to be the remnants of the once-mighty Saraswati River, now buried beneath the desert's timeless dunes.

text_human: From 1988 to 1997, the BBC and Sky Sports had coverage of the FA Cup, the BBC had highlights on Match of the Day and usually one match per round while Sky had the same deal. From 1997 to 2001, ITV and Sky shared live coverage with both having two matches per round and BBC continuing with highlights on Match of the Day. From 2002 to 2008, BBC and Sky again shared coverage with BBC having two or three matches per round and Sky having one or two. From 2008–09 to 2013–14, FA Cup matches are shown live by ITV across England and Wales, with UTV broadcasting to Northern Ireland but STV refusing to show them. ITV shows 16 FA Cup games per season, including the first pick of live matches from each of the first to sixth rounds of the competition, plus one semi-final exclusively live. The final is also shown live on ITV. Under the same 2008 contract, Setanta Sports showed three games and one replay in each round from round three to five, two quarter-finals, one semi-final and the final. The channel also broadcast ITV's matches exclusively to Scotland, after the ITV franchise holder in Scotland, STV, decided not to broadcast FA Cup games. Setanta entered administration in June 2009 and as a result the FA terminated Setanta's deal to broadcast FA-sanctioned competitions and England internationals. As a result of Setanta going out of business ITV showed the competition exclusively in the 2009–10 season with between three and four matches per round, all quarter finals, semi-finals and final live as the FA could not find a pay TV broadcaster in time. ESPN bought the competition for the 2010–11 to 2012–13 season and during this time Rebecca Lowe became the first woman to host the FA Cup Final in the UK.
text_ai_base: From 1988 to 1997, the BBC and Sky Sports shared coverage of the FA Cup, each offering highlights on Match of the Day and typically broadcasting one match per round. Between 1997 and 2001, ITV and Sky divided live coverage, with both networks airing two matches per round, while the BBC continued to offer highlights. From 2002 to 2008, the BBC and Sky resumed joint coverage, with the BBC airing two or three matches per round and Sky showing one or two. From the 2008-09 season through 2013-14, ITV broadcast FA Cup matches live across England and Wales, while UTV covered Northern Ireland. However, STV in Scotland opted not to air them. ITV featured 16 FA Cup games each season, including the first-choice live matches from the first to sixth rounds, one semi-final exclusively live, and the final. Under the same 2008 contract, Setanta Sports aired three games and one replay per round from rounds three to five, two quarter-finals, one semi-final, and the final. Setanta also held exclusive rights to broadcast ITV’s matches in Scotland after STV chose not to broadcast FA Cup games. When Setanta went into administration in June 2009, the FA ended its agreement with them regarding FA-sanctioned competitions and England internationals. Consequently, ITV exclusively aired the competition in the 2009-10 season, featuring three to four matches per round, all quarter-finals, semi-finals, and the final live, as the FA could not secure a pay TV broadcaster in time. ESPN acquired the rights for the 2010-11 to 2012-13 seasons, during which Rebecca Lowe became the first woman to host the FA Cup Final in the UK.
text_ai_humanized: From 1988 to 1997, football fans enjoyed FA Cup coverage provided by both the BBC and Sky Sports. Each network catered to viewers with game highlights on Match of the Day and typically showcased one match per round. Shifting gears from 1997 to 2001, live coverage of the matches was split between ITV and Sky, with each channel transmitting two games per round. Meanwhile, the BBC maintained its tradition of airing highlights throughout this period. By the time 2002 rolled around, the BBC and Sky resumed their shared coverage strategy. The BBC generally broadcast two or three games per round, whereas Sky covered one or two. A notable change occurred from the 2008-09 season to 2013-14, when ITV took the reins on live broadcasting across England and Wales. In contrast, UTV handled Northern Ireland's coverage while STV in Scotland decided against airing games. ITV managed to showcase 16 games each season, including coveted match slots from the initial rounds up to the sixth, alongside one semi-final and, importantly, the final — all exclusively live. Under the 2008 contract, aside from ITV's selection, Setanta Sports also played a role, airing three games and one replay per round from rounds three to five, two quarter-finals, one semi-final, and the final. In Scotland, Setanta was the sole channel featuring ITV’s games after STV opted out. However, a hiccup came about when Setanta fell into administration in June 2009. The FA promptly ended their agreement with Setanta concerning FA-sanctioned competitions and England internationals. Left with no pay TV broadcaster, ITV stepped in to exclusively air the competition for the 2009-10 season, presenting three to four matches per round, along with all quarter-finals, semi-finals, and the final live. ESPN jumped in for the 2010-11 to 2012-13 seasons, marking a historic moment with Rebecca Lowe becoming the first woman to host the FA Cup Final in the UK.

From 1988 to 1997, football fans enjoyed FA Cup coverage provided by both the BBC and Sky Sports. Each network catered to viewers with game highlights on Match of the Day and typically showcased one match per round. Shifting gears from 1997 to 2001, live coverage of the matches was split between ITV and Sky, with each channel transmitting two games per round. Meanwhile, the BBC maintained its tradition of airing highlights throughout this period. 

By the time 2002 rolled around, the BBC and Sky resumed their shared coverage strategy. The BBC generally broadcast two or three games per round, whereas Sky covered one or two. A notable change occurred from the 2008-09 season to 2013-14, when ITV took the reins on live broadcasting across England and Wales. In contrast, UTV handled Northern Ireland's coverage while STV in Scotland decided against airing games. ITV managed to showcase 16 games each season, including coveted match slots from the initial rounds up to the sixth, alongside one semi-final and, importantly, the final — all exclusively live.

Under the 2008 contract, aside from ITV's selection, Setanta Sports also played a role, airing three games and one replay per round from rounds three to five, two quarter-finals, one semi-final, and the final. In Scotland, Setanta was the sole channel featuring ITV’s games after STV opted out.

However, a hiccup came about when Setanta fell into administration in June 2009. The FA promptly ended their agreement with Setanta concerning FA-sanctioned competitions and England internationals. Left with no pay TV broadcaster, ITV stepped in to exclusively air the competition for the 2009-10 season, presenting three to four matches per round, along with all quarter-finals, semi-finals, and the final live.

ESPN jumped in for the 2010-11 to 2012-13 seasons, marking a historic moment with Rebecca Lowe becoming the first woman to host the FA Cup Final in the UK.

text_human: The book was widely translated in Darwin's lifetime, but problems arose with translating concepts and metaphors, and some translations were biased by the translator's own agenda. Darwin distributed presentation copies in France and Germany, hoping that suitable applicants would come forward, as translators were expected to make their own arrangements with a local publisher. He welcomed the distinguished elderly naturalist and geologist Heinrich Georg Bronn, but the German translation published in 1860 imposed Bronn's own ideas, adding controversial themes that Darwin had deliberately omitted. Bronn translated "favoured races" as "perfected races", and added essays on issues including the origin of life, as well as a final chapter on religious implications partly inspired by Bronn's adherence to Naturphilosophie. In 1862, Bronn produced a second edition based on the third English edition and Darwin's suggested additions, but then died of a heart attack. Darwin corresponded closely with Julius Victor Carus, who published an improved translation in 1867. Darwin's attempts to find a translator in France fell through, and the translation by Clémence Royer published in 1862 added an introduction praising Darwin's ideas as an alternative to religious revelation and promoting ideas anticipating social Darwinism and eugenics, as well as numerous explanatory notes giving her own answers to doubts that Darwin expressed. Darwin corresponded with Royer about a second edition published in 1866 and a third in 1870, but he had difficulty getting her to remove her notes and was troubled by these editions. He remained unsatisfied until a translation by Edmond Barbier was published in 1876. A Dutch translation by Tiberius Cornelis Winkler was published in 1860. By 1864, additional translations had appeared in Italian and Russian. In Darwin's lifetime, Origin was published in Swedish in 1871, Danish in 1872, Polish in 1873, Hungarian in 1873–1874, Spanish in 1877 and Serbian in 1878. By 1977, it had appeared in an additional 18 languages.
text_ai_base: During Darwin's lifetime, his book was translated into many languages, but translating concepts and metaphors proved challenging. Some translations were influenced by the translators' biases. Darwin sent presentation copies to France and Germany, hoping qualified translators would emerge, as they were responsible for arranging publication with local publishers. He welcomed Heinrich Georg Bronn, a respected elderly naturalist and geologist, to translate the German edition in 1860. However, Bronn added his own ideas, introducing controversial themes that Darwin had purposely left out. Bronn translated "favoured races" as "perfected races" and added essays discussing the origin of life, concluding with a chapter on religious implications influenced by Bronn's belief in Naturphilosophie. A second edition by Bronn incorporating Darwin's suggestions appeared in 1862, but Bronn passed away from a heart attack shortly after. Darwin then collaborated closely with Julius Victor Carus, who produced a refined translation in 1867. Attempts to secure a French translator failed, and Clémence Royer's 1862 translation included an introduction that endorsed Darwin's ideas as an alternative to religious revelation and advocated early ideas of social Darwinism and eugenics, along with numerous notes offering her interpretations of Darwin's uncertainties. Darwin corresponded with Royer about subsequent editions in 1866 and 1870 but struggled to have her notes removed and was disturbed by her versions until Edmond Barbier's translation in 1876. A Dutch edition by Tiberius Cornelis Winkler came out in 1860. By 1864, Italian and Russian translations were available. During Darwin's lifetime, the book also appeared in Swedish (1871), Danish (1872), Polish (1873), Hungarian (1873-1874), Spanish (1877), and Serbian (1878). By 1977, it was published in 18 more languages.
text_ai_humanized: During Charles Darwin's era, his seminal work found its way into multiple languages. Still, translating the rich metaphors and nuanced ideas was no small feat. The translators, imbued with their own biases, sometimes altered the original meaning. Hoping for competent translations in France and Germany, Darwin distributed presentation copies, knowing these versions depended on local publishers' arrangements. In 1860, he entrusted the respected, albeit aging, naturalist and geologist Heinrich Georg Bronn with the German edition. However, Bronn took liberties, weaving in controversial themes Darwin had deliberately excluded. For instance, he rendered "favoured races" as "perfected races" and appended essays on life's origins, topped off with a chapter on religion, reflecting his penchant for Naturphilosophie. Although Bronn released a second edition in 1862 with Darwin's feedback in mind, he suffered a heart attack soon after, leaving the scene. In pursuit of a more faithful rendition, Darwin later partnered with Julius Victor Carus, whose 1867 translation was much more aligned with Darwin's original thought. Meanwhile, securing a French translator proved elusive. Clémence Royer’s 1862 rendition not only embraced Darwinian ideas over religious revelation but also mingled them with early social Darwinism and eugenics—a move that unnerved Darwin. Her translations were peppered with interpretive notes, which Darwin unsuccessfully tried to have removed, persisting through revised editions in 1866 and 1870. Only with Edmond Barbier's efforts in 1876 did Darwin find some reprieve from Royer's controversial interpretations. Alongside these developments, Tiberius Cornelis Winkler translated the work into Dutch in 1860. By 1864, Italian and Russian readers had their translations, and ensuing years saw the book appear in Swedish (1871), Danish (1872), Polish (1873), Hungarian (1873-1874), Spanish (1877), and Serbian (1878). Astonishingly, by 1977, Darwin's groundbreaking text had been translated into 18 additional languages, a testament to its wide-reaching impact and ongoing relevance.

In 1860, he entrusted the respected, albeit aging, naturalist and geologist Heinrich Georg Bronn with the German edition. However, Bronn took liberties, weaving in controversial themes Darwin had deliberately excluded. For instance, he rendered "favoured races" as "perfected races" and appended essays on life's origins, topped off with a chapter on religion, reflecting his penchant for Naturphilosophie. Although Bronn released a second edition in 1862 with Darwin's feedback in mind, he suffered a heart attack soon after, leaving the scene.

In pursuit of a more faithful rendition, Darwin later partnered with Julius Victor Carus, whose 1867 translation was much more aligned with Darwin's original thought. Meanwhile, securing a French translator proved elusive. Clémence Royer’s 1862 rendition not only embraced Darwinian ideas over religious revelation but also mingled them with early social Darwinism and eugenics—a move that unnerved Darwin. Her translations were peppered with interpretive notes, which Darwin unsuccessfully tried to have removed, persisting through revised editions in 1866 and 1870. Only with Edmond Barbier's efforts in 1876 did Darwin find some reprieve from Royer's controversial interpretations.

Alongside these developments, Tiberius Cornelis Winkler translated the work into Dutch in 1860. By 1864, Italian and Russian readers had their translations, and ensuing years saw the book appear in Swedish (1871), Danish (1872), Polish (1873), Hungarian (1873-1874), Spanish (1877), and Serbian (1878). text_human: In practice, not all rule violations will result in a disqualification as the referee may use their own judgement and is not obligated to stop the match. Usually, the only offenses that the referee will see and immediately disqualify the match on (as opposed to having multiple offenses) are low blows, weapon usage, interference, or assaulting the referee. In WWE, a referee must see the violation with their own eyes to rule that the match end in a disqualification (simply watching the video tape is not usually enough) and the referee's ruling is almost always final, although Dusty finishes (named after, and made famous by, Dusty Rhodes) will often result in the referee's decision being overturned. It is not uncommon for the referees themselves to get knocked out during a match, which is commonly referred to by the term "ref bump". While the referee remains "unconscious", wrestlers are free to violate rules until the referee is revived or replaced. In some cases, a referee might disqualify a person under the presumption that it was that wrestler who knocked them out; most referee knockouts are arranged to allow a wrestler, usually a heel, to gain an advantage. For example, a wrestler may get whipped into a referee at a slower speed, knocking the ref down for short amount of time; during that interim period, one wrestler may pin their opponent for a three-count and would have won the match but for the referee being down (sometimes, another referee will sprint to the ring from backstage to attempt to make the count, but by then, the other wrestler has had enough time to kick-out on their own accord).
text_ai_base: In practice, not all rule violations lead to a disqualification, as the referee may use their discretion and is not required to stop the match. Typically, offenses that result in immediate disqualification include low blows, weapon usage, interference, or assaulting the referee. In WWE, a referee must personally witness the violation to disqualify a match (viewing video footage is generally insufficient), and the referee's decision is usually final. However, "Dusty finishes," popularized by Dusty Rhodes, can lead to referee decisions being overturned. Referees are often knocked out during matches, a situation known as a "ref bump." While the referee is "unconscious," wrestlers may break rules until the referee recovers or is replaced. Sometimes, referees may disqualify a wrestler on the assumption that this wrestler knocked them out; most referee knockouts are planned to give a wrestler, often a heel, an advantage. For instance, a wrestler might be thrown into the referee at a slow speed, causing the ref to fall briefly. During this time, a wrestler might pin their opponent for a three-count that would have ended the match if the referee were attentive. Occasionally, another referee will rush from backstage to make the count, but by then, the other wrestler often has time to kick out on their own.
text_ai_humanized: In reality, violations of rules don't always result in a match's disqualification. Referees have the liberty to exercise judgment, meaning they're not obligated to halt a contest immediately. Disqualifications tend to occur for more blatant offenses, such as delivering a low blow, wielding a weapon, interfering in the match, or taking aggressive action against the referee. In WWE, the protocol is clear: a referee must directly witness an infraction to call for disqualification—relying solely on video footage won't cut it. Their call is typically the final word, but there's a twist in the wrestling world known as "Dusty finishes"—a term coined by Dusty Rhodes—which allows for referee decisions to be overturned at times. Referees in the ring may find themselves in the unfortunate situation of being knocked out—a predicament labeled as a "ref bump." When they're "out cold," wrestlers oftentimes seize the opportunity to bend or break rules until the referee comes around or another official steps in. Disqualification may come into play if the ref suspects foul play was the reason for their incapacitation; more often than not, these knockouts are strategically planned—usually advantaging a heel. Picture this: a wrestler deliberately colliding with the referee at a snail’s pace, ensuring the ref takes a dramatic tumble. Meanwhile, one competitor might secure what would be a match-ending pin if the referee were conscious. Another official may make a hasty entrance from backstage to attempt the count, yet by that time, the second wrestler is frequently alert enough to kick out, prolonging the match. Mixing unpredictable events with the scripted flow, wrestling choreography keeps its audience guessing, and referee roles are no exception to the drama unfolding in the ring.

message.content:
In reality, violations of rules don't always result in a match's disqualification. Referees have the liberty to exercise judgment, meaning they're not obligated to halt a contest immediately. Disqualifications tend to occur for more blatant offenses, such as delivering a low blow, wielding a weapon, interfering in the match, or taking aggressive action against the referee. In WWE, the protocol is clear: a referee must directly witness an infraction to call for disqualification—relying solely on video footage won't cut it. Their call is typically the final word, but there's a twist in the wrestling world known as "Dusty finishes"—a term coined by Dusty Rhodes—which allows for referee decisions to be overturned at times.

Referees in the ring may find themselves in the unfortunate situation of being knocked out—a predicament labeled as a "ref bump." When they're "out cold," wrestlers oftentimes seize the opportunity to bend or break rules until the referee comes around or another official steps in. Disqualification may come into play if the ref suspects foul play was the reason for their incapacitation; more often than not, these knockouts are strategically planned—usually advantaging a heel. Picture this: a wrestler deliberately colliding with the referee at a snail’s pace, ensuring the ref takes a dramatic tumble. Meanwhile, one competitor might secure what would be a match-ending pin if the referee were conscious. Another official may make a hasty entrance from backstage to attempt the count, yet by that time, the second wrestler is frequently alert enough to kick out, prolonging the match.

Mixing unpredictable events with the scripted flow, wrestling choreography keeps its audience guessing, and referee roles are no exception to the drama unfolding in the ring.

text_human: Initially, Burke did not condemn the French Revolution. In a letter of 9 August 1789, Burke wrote: "England gazing with astonishment at a French struggle for Liberty and not knowing whether to blame or to applaud! The thing indeed, though I thought I saw something like it in progress for several years, has still something in it paradoxical and Mysterious. The spirit it is impossible not to admire; but the old Parisian ferocity has broken out in a shocking manner". The events of 5–6 October 1789, when a crowd of Parisian women marched on Versailles to compel King Louis XVI to return to Paris, turned Burke against it. In a letter to his son, Richard Burke, dated 10 October he said: "This day I heard from Laurence who has sent me papers confirming the portentous state of France—where the Elements which compose Human Society seem all to be dissolved, and a world of Monsters to be produced in the place of it—where Mirabeau presides as the Grand Anarch; and the late Grand Monarch makes a figure as ridiculous as pitiable". On 4 November Charles-Jean-François Depont wrote to Burke, requesting that he endorse the Revolution. Burke replied that any critical language of it by him should be taken "as no more than the expression of doubt" but he added: "You may have subverted Monarchy, but not recover'd freedom". In the same month he described France as "a country undone". Burke's first public condemnation of the Revolution occurred on the debate in Parliament on the army estimates on 9 February 1790, provoked by praise of the Revolution by Pitt and Fox:

However, the actions of October 5–6, 1789, when Parisian women marched to Versailles to urge King Louis XVI's return to Paris, changed his stance. In an October 10 letter to his son, Richard Burke, he shared papers from Laurence warning of France's alarming state, where societal elements seemed dissolved, creating a monstrous world with Mirabeau as the "Grand Anarch" and the former Grand Monarch reduced to ridicule and pity. On November 4, Charles-Jean-François Depont asked Burke to support the Revolution. Burke responded that his criticisms were merely expressions of doubt, adding, "You may have subverted Monarchy, but not recovered freedom." In the same month, he called France "a country undone." Burke’s first public denouncement of the Revolution occurred during the Parliamentary debate on army estimates on February 9, 1790, triggered by praise from Pitt and Fox.

He talked about the odd and enigmatic nature of the events—captivated by the revolutionary zeal yet ill at ease with the emergence of Paris's old ferocity. Burke's first public rebuke of the Revolution came on February 9, 1790, during a Parliamentary debate on army estimates. This was prompted when leaders like Pitt and Fox offered praise he couldn't abide.

text_human: In 1592, and again in 1597, Toyotomi Hideyoshi, aiming to invade China (唐入り) through Korea, mobilized an army of 160,000 peasants and samurai and deployed them to Korea. (See Hideyoshi's invasions of Korea, Chōsen-seibatsu (朝鮮征伐?). Taking advantage of arquebus mastery and extensive wartime experience from the Sengoku period, Japanese samurai armies made major gains in most of Korea. Kato Kiyomasa advanced to Orangkai territory (present-day Manchuria) bordering Korea to the northeast and crossed the border into Manchuria, but withdrew after retaliatory attacks from the Jurchens there, as it was clear he had outpaced the rest of the Japanese invasion force. A few of the more famous samurai generals of this war were Katō Kiyomasa, Konishi Yukinaga, and Shimazu Yoshihiro. Shimazu Yoshihiro led some 7,000 samurai and, despite being heavily outnumbered, defeated a host of allied Ming and Korean forces at the Battle of Sacheon in 1598, near the conclusion of the campaigns. Yoshihiro was feared as Oni-Shimazu ("Shimazu ogre") and his nickname spread across not only Korea but to Ming Dynasty China. In spite of the superiority of Japanese land forces, ultimately the two expeditions failed (though they did devastate the Korean landmass) from factors such as Korean naval superiority (which, led by Admiral Yi Sun-shin, harassed Japanese supply lines continuously throughout the wars, resulting in supply shortages on land), the commitment of sizeable Ming forces to Korea, Korean guerrilla actions, the underestimation of resistance by Japanese commanders (in the first campaign of 1592, Korean defenses on land were caught unprepared, under-trained, and under-armed; they were rapidly overrun, with only a limited number of successfully resistant engagements against the more-experienced and battle-hardened Japanese forces - in the second campaign of 1597, Korean and Ming forces proved to be a far more difficult challenge and, with the support of continued Korean naval superiority, limited Japanese gains to parts southeastern Korea), and wavering Japanese commitment to the campaigns as the wars dragged on. The final death blow to the Japanese campaigns in Korea came with Hideyoshi's death in late 1598 and the recall of all Japanese forces in Korea by the Council of Five Elders (established by Hideyoshi to oversee the transition from his regency to that of his son Hideyori).
text_ai_base: In 1592 and again in 1597, Toyotomi Hideyoshi sought to invade China by way of Korea, deploying an army of 160,000 peasants and samurai. For more details, see Hideyoshi's invasions of Korea, known as Chōsen-seibatsu. Leveraging their expertise with the arquebus and their extensive experience from the Sengoku period, Japanese samurai made significant advances across much of Korea. Katō Kiyomasa pushed into Orangkai territory (modern-day Manchuria) bordering Korea to the northeast. However, he withdrew after facing counterattacks from the Jurchens, realizing he had advanced too far ahead of the main Japanese force. Among the notable samurai generals were Katō Kiyomasa, Konishi Yukinaga, and Shimazu Yoshihiro. Leading 7,000 samurai, Yoshihiro, known as Oni-Shimazu ("Shimazu ogre"), defeated a significantly larger force of allied Ming and Korean troops at the Battle of Sacheon in 1598, near the end of the campaigns. Despite the Japanese army's superiority on land, both military expeditions ultimately failed for several reasons. These included the Korean navy's dominance, led by Admiral Yi Sun-shin, who disrupted Japanese supply lines, the deployment of substantial Ming forces to aid Korea, local guerrilla actions, and the Japanese commanders' misjudgment of Korean resistance. While the first 1592 campaign saw unprepared Korean land defenses overwhelmed by experienced Japanese troops, the second 1597 campaign met far stronger Korean and Ming resistance, aided by continued naval superiority, limiting Japanese gains to southeastern Korea. The campaigns' end was hastened by wavering Japanese resolve and ultimately by Hideyoshi's death in late 1598, when the Council of Five Elders, appointed by Hideyoshi to manage the transition of power to his son Hideyori, ordered the withdrawal of all Japanese forces from Korea.
text_ai_humanized: In the late 16th century, specifically in 1592 and again in 1597, Toyotomi Hideyoshi ambitiously aimed to conquer China by way of Korea, dispatching an imposing force of 160,000 consisting of both peasants and samurai warriors. For an in-depth look at these campaigns, you might want to delve into the "Chōsen-seibatsu," the name given to Hideyoshi's invasions of Korea. By utilizing their proficiency with the arquebus gained during the tumultuous Sengoku period, Japanese samurai made notable headway across the Korean Peninsula. One samurai, Katō Kiyomasa, pushed boldly into the territory called Orangkai—what we now know as modern-day Manchuria—on Korea’s northeastern reaches. Yet, his advance was met with resistance. Facing fierce counterattacks from the Jurchens, he found himself overstretched and decided to retreat. Some of the prominent samurai generals in these invasions were Katō Kiyomasa, Konishi Yukinaga, and the formidable Shimazu Yoshihiro. Yoshihiro, who led a force of 7,000 samurai and earned the nickname Oni-Shimazu or "Shimazu ogre," managed an impressive feat by defeating a considerably larger coalition of Ming and Korean troops at the Battle of Sacheon in 1598. This victory occurred as the campaigns were drawing to a close. Despite having superior land forces, the Japanese expeditions met with ultimate failure due to a variety of critical factors. The Korean navy, commanded by the esteemed Admiral Yi Sun-shin, disrupted Japanese supply routes and maintained naval dominance. Additionally, the Ming Dynasty sent substantial reinforcements to aid Korea. Guerrilla warfare led by local fighters and the Japanese commanders’ underestimation of the Korean tenacity further compounded their difficulties. In 1592, the initial campaign saw Japanese troops overpower Korea’s unprepared land defenses, but by the second campaign in 1597, the scenario had changed. Strengthened by formidable Korean and Ming resistance and enduring Korean naval control, Japanese advancements were mostly confined to southeast Korea. The momentum of the invasions dwindled, further hindered by political shifts following Hideyoshi's death in late 1598. It was then, with a changing direction from the leadership of the Council of Five Elders—appointed to oversee the power transition to Hideyoshi's son Hideyori—that the decision was made to pull all Japanese troops back from Korean soil.
