text_human: In southeast Europe agrarian societies first appeared in the 7th millennium BC, attested by one of the earliest farming sites of Europe, discovered in Vashtëmi, southeastern Albania and dating back to 6,500 BC. Anthropomorphic figurines have been found in the Balkans from 6000 BC, and in Central Europe by c. 5800 BC (La Hoguette). Among the earliest cultural complexes of this area are the Sesklo culture in Thessaly, which later expanded in the Balkans giving rise to Starčevo-Körös (Cris), Linearbandkeramik, and Vinča. Through a combination of cultural diffusion and migration of peoples, the Neolithic traditions spread west and northwards to reach northwestern Europe by around 4500 BC. The Vinča culture may have created the earliest system of writing, the Vinča signs, though archaeologist Shan Winn believes they most likely represented pictograms and ideograms rather than a truly developed form of writing. The Cucuteni-Trypillian culture built enormous settlements in Romania, Moldova and Ukraine from 5300 to 2300 BC. The megalithic temple complexes of Ġgantija on the Mediterranean island of Gozo (in the Maltese archipelago) and of Mnajdra (Malta) are notable for their gigantic Neolithic structures, the oldest of which date back to c. 3600 BC. The Hypogeum of Ħal-Saflieni, Paola, Malta, is a subterranean structure excavated c. 2500 BC; originally a sanctuary, it became a necropolis, the only prehistoric underground temple in the world, and showing a degree of artistry in stone sculpture unique in prehistory to the Maltese islands. After 2500 BC, the Maltese Islands were depopulated for several decades until the arrival of a new influx of Bronze Age immigrants, a culture that cremated its dead and introduced smaller megalithic structures called dolmens to Malta. In most cases there are small chambers here, with the cover made of a large slab placed on upright stones. They are claimed to belong to a population certainly different from that which built the previous megalithic temples. It is presumed the population arrived from Sicily because of the similarity of Maltese dolmens to some small constructions found in the largest island of the Mediterranean sea.

Early cultural developments in the region included the Sesklo culture in Thessaly, which expanded into the Balkans and contributed to the formation of the Starčevo-Körös (Cris), Linearbandkeramik, and Vinča cultures. Neolithic traditions, through cultural diffusion and migrations, advanced west and north, reaching northwestern Europe by approximately 4500 BC. The Vinča culture possibly developed its own symbolic system, the Vinča signs, which archaeologist Shan Winn suggests were likely pictograms and ideograms rather than a fully-fledged writing system. The Cucuteni-Trypillian culture constructed large settlements in Romania, Moldova, and Ukraine between 5300 and 2300 BC. Ġgantija on Gozo and Mnajdra in Malta are noted for their vast Neolithic structures, dating back to around 3600 BC. This new population is thought to have come from Sicily, as Maltese dolmens resemble similar structures found on the Mediterranean’s largest island.

One of the continent's earliest known farming sites was established in Vashtëmi, situated in southeastern Albania, dating back to around 6,500 BC. By around 6000 BC, the imaginative artistry of the region was evident as anthropomorphic figurines began to appear in the Balkans, eventually reaching Central Europe's La Hoguette by about 5800 BC. Over in eastern Europe, between 5300 and 2300 BC, the Cucuteni-Trypillian culture set up vast settlements stretching across what are now Romania, Moldova, and Ukraine. Meanwhile, in the Maltese archipelago, remarkable Neolithic structures such as Ġgantija on Gozo and Mnajdra in Malta appeared around 3600 BC. One cannot overlook the Hypogeum of Ħal-Saflieni in Paola, Malta, unearthed circa 2500 BC. Initially serving as a sanctuary before becoming a necropolis, it stands uniquely as the world's only known prehistoric underground temple, exhibiting extraordinary stone sculptures. By the time we reach about 2500 BC, the Maltese Islands experienced depopulation. However, it wasn't long before new Bronze Age settlers arrived. These newcomers brought with them the practice of cremating the dead and constructed smaller megalithic structures known as dolmens. These dolmens, characterized by small chambers capped with large slabs balanced on upright stones, suggest a cultural departure from the builders of earlier megalithic temples. It's speculated that these settlers originated from Sicily, drawn from the resemblance between Maltese dolmens and those found on the Mediterranean's largest island.

text_human: In the spring of 1834, Chopin attended the Lower Rhenish Music Festival in Aix-la-Chapelle with Hiller, and it was there that Chopin met Felix Mendelssohn. After the festival, the three visited Düsseldorf, where Mendelssohn had been appointed musical director. They spent what Mendelssohn described as "a very agreeable day", playing and discussing music at his piano, and met Friedrich Wilhelm Schadow, director of the Academy of Art, and some of his eminent pupils such as Lessing, Bendemann, Hildebrandt and Sohn. In 1835 Chopin went to Carlsbad, where he spent time with his parents; it was the last time he would see them. On his way back to Paris, he met old friends from Warsaw, the Wodzińskis. He had made the acquaintance of their daughter Maria in Poland five years earlier, when she was eleven. This meeting prompted him to stay for two weeks in Dresden, when he had previously intended to return to Paris via Leipzig. The sixteen-year-old girl's portrait of the composer is considered, along with Delacroix's, as among Chopin's best likenesses. In October he finally reached Leipzig, where he met Schumann, Clara Wieck and Felix Mendelssohn, who organised for him a performance of his own oratorio St. Paul, and who considered him "a perfect musician". In July 1836 Chopin travelled to Marienbad and Dresden to be with the Wodziński family, and in September he proposed to Maria, whose mother Countess Wodzińska approved in principle. Chopin went on to Leipzig, where he presented Schumann with his G minor Ballade. At the end of 1836 he sent Maria an album in which his sister Ludwika had inscribed seven of his songs, and his 1835 Nocturne in C-sharp minor, Op. 27, No. 1. The anodyne thanks he received from Maria proved to be the last letter he was to have from her.

text_ai_humanized: As spring warmed the air in 1834, Chopin found himself at the Lower Rhenish Music Festival in Aix-la-Chapelle, accompanied by his friend Hiller. There, he crossed paths with none other than Felix Mendelssohn. After the festival's melodious celebrations came to an end, they—now a trio—journeyed to Düsseldorf. Mendelssohn, who had recently taken up the baton as the city’s musical director, hosted them. He later recalled those hours together fondly, as they spent "a very agreeable day," engulfed in musical conversation and lively piano sessions. During their visit, they also mingled with Friedrich Wilhelm Schadow, the director of the Academy of Art, and were introduced to his promising students: Lessing, Bendemann, Hildebrandt, and Sohn. Fast forward to 1835, and Chopin was off to Carlsbad to see his parents. It was a poignant trip as it turned out to be the final time he would lay eyes on them. On his way back to Paris, destiny intervened when he encountered the Wodziński family, whom he knew from Warsaw. Particularly noteworthy was his reconnection with Maria, whom he had first met half a decade ago when she was just eleven. Spurred by this meeting, Chopin opted to linger in Dresden for two weeks, deviating from his plan to return through Leipzig. Maria, now a blossoming sixteen-year-old, painted a portrait of Chopin that rivaled even Delacroix's in capturing his essence. Eventually, in October, Chopin made it to Leipzig, where he met Robert Schumann, Clara Wieck, and again, Mendelssohn. They attended a performance of Mendelssohn's oratorio, "St. Paul," which left such an impression on them all that Mendelssohn himself praised Chopin as "a perfect musician." By July 1836, Chopin was in Marienbad and Dresden, specifically to spend time with the Wodziński family. That September, he proposed to Maria, with Countess Wodzińska, her mother, giving her nod of approval. Continuing his travels, Chopin reached Leipzig, gifting Schumann his G minor Ballade. As the year wound down, he sent Maria a heartfelt album—decorated with seven songs inscribed by his sister Ludwika—and his 1835 Nocturne in C-sharp minor, Op. 27, No. 1. Alas, the tepid thanks he received from Maria marked the last piece of correspondence she would ever send him.

By July 1836, Chopin was in Marienbad and Dresden, specifically to spend time with the Wodziński family. That September, he proposed to Maria, with Countess Wodzińska, her mother, giving her nod of approval. Continuing his travels, Chopin reached Leipzig, gifting Schumann his G minor Ballade. As the year wound down, he sent Maria a heartfelt album—decorated with seven songs inscribed by his sister Ludwika—and his 1835 Nocturne in C-sharp minor, Op. 27, No. 1. Alas, the tepid thanks he received from Maria marked the last piece of correspondence she would ever send him.

text_human: One of the notable authors of esoteric interpretation prior to the 12th century is Sulami (d. 1021) without whose work the majority of very early Sufi commentaries would not have been preserved. Sulami's major commentary is a book named haqaiq al-tafsir ("Truths of Exegesis") which is a compilation of commentaries of earlier Sufis. From the 11th century onwards several other works appear, including commentaries by Qushayri (d. 1074), Daylami (d. 1193), Shirazi (d. 1209) and Suhrawardi (d. 1234). These works include material from Sulami's books plus the author's contributions. Many works are written in Persian such as the works of Maybudi (d. 1135) kash al-asrar ("the unveiling of the secrets"). Rumi (d. 1273) wrote a vast amount of mystical poetry in his book Mathnawi. Rumi makes heavy use of the Quran in his poetry, a feature that is sometimes omitted in translations of Rumi's work. A large number of Quranic passages can be found in Mathnawi, which some consider a kind of Sufi interpretation of the Quran. Rumi's book is not exceptional for containing citations from and elaboration on the Quran, however, Rumi does mention Quran more frequently. Simnani (d. 1336) wrote two influential works of esoteric exegesis on the Quran. He reconciled notions of God's manifestation through and in the physical world with the sentiments of Sunni Islam. Comprehensive Sufi commentaries appear in the 18th century such as the work of Ismail Hakki Bursevi (d. 1725). His work ruh al-Bayan (the Spirit of Elucidation) is a voluminous exegesis. Written in Arabic, it combines the author's own ideas with those of his predecessors (notably Ibn Arabi and Ghazali), all woven together in Hafiz, a Persian poetry form.

text_human: Some established acts continued to enjoy commercial success, such as Aerosmith, with their number one multi-platinum albums: Get a Grip (1993), which produced four Top 40 singles and became the band's best-selling album worldwide (going on to sell over 10 million copies), and Nine Lives (1997). In 1998, Aerosmith released the number one hit "I Don't Want to Miss a Thing", which remains the only single by a hard rock band to debut at number one. AC/DC produced the double platinum Ballbreaker (1995). Bon Jovi appealed to their hard rock audience with songs such as "Keep the Faith" (1992), but also achieved success in adult contemporary radio, with the Top 10 ballads "Bed of Roses" (1993) and "Always" (1994). Bon Jovi's 1995 album These Days was a bigger hit in Europe than it was in the United States, spawning four Top 10 singles on the UK Singles Chart. Metallica's Load (1996) and ReLoad (1997) each sold in excess of 4 million copies in the US and saw the band develop a more melodic and blues rock sound. As the initial impetus of grunge bands faltered in the middle years of the decade, post-grunge bands emerged. They emulated the attitudes and music of grunge, particularly thick, distorted guitars, but with a more radio-friendly commercially oriented sound that drew more directly on traditional hard rock. Among the most successful acts were the Foo Fighters, Candlebox, Live, Collective Soul, Australia's Silverchair and England's Bush, who all cemented post-grunge as one of the most commercially viable subgenres by the late 1990s. Similarly, some post-Britpop bands that followed in the wake of Oasis, including Feeder and Stereophonics, adopted a hard rock or "pop-metal" sound.

They soared with their chart-topping, multi-platinum albums "Get a Grip" in 1993 and "Nine Lives" in 1997. That first album, "Get a Grip," wasn't just popular—it was a worldwide sensation, selling over 10 million copies and featuring a quartet of Top 40 singles. Then, in '98, they dropped "I Don't Want to Miss a Thing," which has the distinction of being the only single by a hard rock band to debut at number one. Pretty impressive, right? However, their 1995 release "These Days" made a bigger splash overseas, especially in Europe, where it spawned four Top 10 hits on the UK Singles Chart. On the heavier end of the rock spectrum, Metallica underwent a sonic evolution with "Load" in 1996 and "ReLoad" a year later, each exceeding 4 million copies in U.S. sales. Their sound took on more melodic and blues rock influences—a notable shift from their earlier work. As the grunge wave started losing steam around the mid-'90s, new bands ventured into the post-grunge territory. These groups borrowed the raw energy of grunge but polished it for a broader audience. Foo Fighters, Candlebox, Live, Collective Soul, Australia's Silverchair, and England's Bush were some of the key players, ensuring the subgenre's broad appeal by the decade's end. Moreover, the post-Britpop phenomenon took shape, with bands like Feeder and Stereophonics drawing inspiration from Oasis. These bands combined rock's raw edge with pop-metal sensibilities, creating a sound that resonated deeply with audiences looking for something fresh yet familiar.

message.content:
Throughout the 1990s, several iconic bands managed to keep their commercial momentum roaring. Aerosmith, for instance, didn't just rest on their laurels. They soared with their chart-topping, multi-platinum albums "Get a Grip" in 1993 and "Nine Lives" in 1997. That first album, "Get a Grip," wasn't just popular—it was a worldwide sensation, selling over 10 million copies and featuring a quartet of Top 40 singles. Then, in '98, they dropped "I Don't Want to Miss a Thing," which has the distinction of being the only single by a hard rock band to debut at number one. Pretty impressive, right?

Meanwhile, AC/DC proved their staying power with "Ballbreaker" in 1995, which hit double platinum—a testament to their relentless rock energy. Bon Jovi, on the other hand, continued to captivate the hard rock audience with "Keep the Faith" in 1992, while also making waves on adult contemporary radio. Tracks like "Bed of Roses" in 1993 and "Always" in 1994 found their way into the Top 10 ballad lists. However, their 1995 release "These Days" made a bigger splash overseas, especially in Europe, where it spawned four Top 10 hits on the UK Singles Chart.

On the heavier end of the rock spectrum, Metallica underwent a sonic evolution with "Load" in 1996 and "ReLoad" a year later, each exceeding 4 million copies in U.S. sales. Their sound took on more melodic and blues rock influences—a notable shift from their earlier work. As the grunge wave started losing steam around the mid-'90s, new bands ventured into the post-grunge territory. These groups borrowed the raw energy of grunge but polished it for a broader audience. Foo Fighters, Candlebox, Live, Collective Soul, Australia's Silverchair, and England's Bush were some of the key players, ensuring the subgenre's broad appeal by the decade's end.

Moreover, the post-Britpop phenomenon took shape, with bands like Feeder and Stereophonics drawing inspiration from Oasis. These bands combined rock's raw edge with pop-metal sensibilities, creating a sound that resonated deeply with audiences looking for something fresh yet familiar.

text_human: In response to the early-to-mid-17th century "continental rationalism" John Locke (1632–1704) proposed in An Essay Concerning Human Understanding (1689) a very influential view wherein the only knowledge humans can have is a posteriori, i.e., based upon experience. Locke is famously attributed with holding the proposition that the human mind is a tabula rasa, a "blank tablet", in Locke's words "white paper", on which the experiences derived from sense impressions as a person's life proceeds are written. There are two sources of our ideas: sensation and reflection. In both cases, a distinction is made between simple and complex ideas. The former are unanalysable, and are broken down into primary and secondary qualities. Primary qualities are essential for the object in question to be what it is. Without specific primary qualities, an object would not be what it is. For example, an apple is an apple because of the arrangement of its atomic structure. If an apple was structured differently, it would cease to be an apple. Secondary qualities are the sensory information we can perceive from its primary qualities. For example, an apple can be perceived in various colours, sizes, and textures but it is still identified as an apple. Therefore, its primary qualities dictate what the object essentially is, while its secondary qualities define its attributes. Complex ideas combine simple ones, and divide into substances, modes, and relations. According to Locke, our knowledge of things is a perception of ideas that are in accordance or discordance with each other, which is very different from the quest for certainty of Descartes.
text_ai_base: John Locke (1632–1704), in his work An Essay Concerning Human Understanding (1689), introduced a significant theory in response to the 17th-century "continental rationalism." He argued that the only knowledge humans possess is a posteriori, acquired through experience. Locke famously described the human mind as a tabula rasa, or a "blank slate"—what he called "white paper"—on which experiences from sense impressions are inscribed throughout a person's life. According to Locke, ideas arise from two sources: sensation and reflection. He further distinguished these ideas into simple and complex categories. Simple ideas are indivisible and consist of primary and secondary qualities. Primary qualities are essential to an object's identity; for instance, the atomic structure of an apple makes it an apple—if altered, it would cease to be an apple. Secondary qualities, on the other hand, are the sensory perceptions derived from primary qualities, such as the apple's color, size, and texture, although it remains identifiable as an apple. Complex ideas are aggregates of simple ones and are classified into substances, modes, and relations. Locke asserted that our understanding is based on the perception of ideas in agreement or disagreement with one another, contrasting with Descartes’ pursuit of certainty.
text_ai_humanized: John Locke, born in 1632 and departing this world in 1704, carved a unique niche in philosophical thought with his 1689 work, *An Essay Concerning Human Understanding*. In a time swayed by the "continental rationalism" of the 17th century, Locke bravely put forth a theory that would challenge established norms. He claimed that all human knowledge springs from experience, a concept known as a posteriori. In Locke’s view, our minds start as a tabula rasa, or "blank slate"—he even called it "white paper"—upon which the impressions from our senses write our life's stories. Delving deeper, Locke pinpointed two sources from which ideas originates: sensation and reflection. He didn’t stop there; he categorized these ideas further into simple and complex constructs. Simple ideas, which cannot be broken down further, are associated with primary and secondary qualities. The primary qualities are intrinsic to an object—they’re what keep an apple an apple, owing to its atomic structure; any change here and it’s no longer the same fruit. Secondary qualities, in contrast, arise from our sensory encounters with the object, like the apple’s vivid color or its firm texture, which remain constants even if our perceptions differ. When simple ideas come together, they form complex ideas, which Locke grouped into substances, modes, and relations. Intriguingly, he argued that understanding is forged through the recognition of ideas’ agreements or disagreements, providing a stark counterpoint to Descartes’ relentless quest for certainty. Locke’s contributions remind us that knowledge isn’t just acquired; it’s built brick by brick from the experiences life graciously—or sometimes reluctantly—offers.

Delving deeper, Locke pinpointed two sources from which ideas originates: sensation and reflection. He didn’t stop there; he categorized these ideas further into simple and complex constructs. Simple ideas, which cannot be broken down further, are associated with primary and secondary qualities. The primary qualities are intrinsic to an object—they’re what keep an apple an apple, owing to its atomic structure; any change here and it’s no longer the same fruit. Secondary qualities, in contrast, arise from our sensory encounters with the object, like the apple’s vivid color or its firm texture, which remain constants even if our perceptions differ.

When simple ideas come together, they form complex ideas, which Locke grouped into substances, modes, and relations. Intriguingly, he argued that understanding is forged through the recognition of ideas’ agreements or disagreements, providing a stark counterpoint to Descartes’ relentless quest for certainty. Locke’s contributions remind us that knowledge isn’t just acquired; it’s built brick by brick from the experiences life graciously—or sometimes reluctantly—offers.

text_human: Stanley Schachter formulated his theory on the earlier work of a Spanish physician, Gregorio Marañón, who injected patients with epinephrine and subsequently asked them how they felt. Interestingly, Marañón found that most of these patients felt something but in the absence of an actual emotion-evoking stimulus, the patients were unable to interpret their physiological arousal as an experienced emotion. Schachter did agree that physiological reactions played a big role in emotions. He suggested that physiological reactions contributed to emotional experience by facilitating a focused cognitive appraisal of a given physiologically arousing event and that this appraisal was what defined the subjective emotional experience. Emotions were thus a result of two-stage process: general physiological arousal, and experience of emotion. For example, the physiological arousal, heart pounding, in a response to an evoking stimulus, the sight of a bear in the kitchen. The brain then quickly scans the area, to explain the pounding, and notices the bear. Consequently, the brain interprets the pounding heart as being the result of fearing the bear. With his student, Jerome Singer, Schachter demonstrated that subjects can have different emotional reactions despite being placed into the same physiological state with an injection of epinephrine. Subjects were observed to express either anger or amusement depending on whether another person in the situation (a confederate) displayed that emotion. Hence, the combination of the appraisal of the situation (cognitive) and the participants' reception of adrenaline or a placebo together determined the response. This experiment has been criticized in Jesse Prinz's (2004) Gut Reactions.
text_ai_base: Stanley Schachter developed his theory based on earlier work by Spanish physician Gregorio Marañón, who studied patients injected with epinephrine. Marañón observed that although patients experienced physiological arousal, without an actual emotion-triggering event, they couldn’t interpret this arousal as a specific emotion. Schachter agreed that physiological reactions are important in emotions, proposing that they contribute to emotional experiences by prompting a targeted cognitive evaluation of the situation causing the arousal. According to him, emotions arise from a two-step process: general physiological arousal followed by the experience of emotion. For instance, if your heart starts pounding at the sight of a bear in your kitchen, your brain attributes this reaction to fear of the bear. Schachter, along with his student Jerome Singer, demonstrated that despite being in identical physiological states induced by epinephrine, participants showed different emotional responses, such as anger or amusement, depending on a confederate’s emotional behavior in the same situation. Therefore, it’s the combination of cognitive appraisal and physiological arousal that determines emotional response. This experiment has been critiqued in Jesse Prinz's 2004 work "Gut Reactions."
text_ai_humanized: Stanley Schachter's theory finds its roots in the intriguing experiments conducted by Gregorio Marañón, a Spanish physician. Marañón observed patients who had been injected with epinephrine. Curiously, even as these individuals experienced bodily arousal, the absence of a genuine emotional impetus left them unable to label what they were feeling as a distinct emotion. Schachter picked up on this idea, recognizing that while physiological reactions are undeniably critical to our emotional experiences, they do not paint the whole picture. He suggested that these reactions serve as a cue for our brains to conduct a more nuanced situational assessment, discerning the underlying cause of our heightened physiological state. Schachter proposed a dual-stage process for emotions: initially, there's a wave of physiological arousal, which is then interpreted as a specific emotion through mental appraisal. Imagine spotting a bear in your kitchen — your heart races, a telltale sign of fear, as your brain connects the dots between the pounding heart and the imminent danger. Working with his student Jerome Singer, Schachter ran experiments where subjects, all in a similarly aroused state due to epinephrine, displayed varied emotions such as anger or amusement. The twist? These emotions mirrored the behavior of a confederate displaying those feelings. Thus, it’s this interplay between how we evaluate our circumstances and our physical state that shapes our emotional experiences. This theory didn't escape scrutiny, though. In 2004, Jesse Prinz offered a critique in his work "Gut Reactions." While the nuances still spark debate, Schachter’s ideas undeniably contributed significantly to our understanding of emotions, blending physiological and cognitive elements in a way that few had considered before.

text_human: England's first permanent settlement in the Americas was founded in 1607 in Jamestown, led by Captain John Smith and managed by the Virginia Company. Bermuda was settled and claimed by England as a result of the 1609 shipwreck there of the Virginia Company's flagship, and in 1615 was turned over to the newly formed Somers Isles Company. The Virginia Company's charter was revoked in 1624 and direct control of Virginia was assumed by the crown, thereby founding the Colony of Virginia. The London and Bristol Company was created in 1610 with the aim of creating a permanent settlement on Newfoundland, but was largely unsuccessful. In 1620, Plymouth was founded as a haven for puritan religious separatists, later known as the Pilgrims. Fleeing from religious persecution would become the motive of many English would-be colonists to risk the arduous trans-Atlantic voyage: Maryland was founded as a haven for Roman Catholics (1634), Rhode Island (1636) as a colony tolerant of all religions and Connecticut (1639) for Congregationalists. The Province of Carolina was founded in 1663. With the surrender of Fort Amsterdam in 1664, England gained control of the Dutch colony of New Netherland, renaming it New York. This was formalised in negotiations following the Second Anglo-Dutch War, in exchange for Suriname. In 1681, the colony of Pennsylvania was founded by William Penn. The American colonies were less financially successful than those of the Caribbean, but had large areas of good agricultural land and attracted far larger numbers of English emigrants who preferred their temperate climates.

text_human: A standard adult football match consists of two periods of 45 minutes each, known as halves. Each half runs continuously, meaning that the clock is not stopped when the ball is out of play. There is usually a 15-minute half-time break between halves. The end of the match is known as full-time. The referee is the official timekeeper for the match, and may make an allowance for time lost through substitutions, injured players requiring attention, or other stoppages. This added time is called additional time in FIFA documents, but is most commonly referred to as stoppage time or injury time, while loss time can also be used as a synonym. The duration of stoppage time is at the sole discretion of the referee. The referee alone signals the end of the match. In matches where a fourth official is appointed, toward the end of the half the referee signals how many minutes of stoppage time he intends to add. The fourth official then informs the players and spectators by holding up a board showing this number. The signalled stoppage time may be further extended by the referee. Added time was introduced because of an incident which happened in 1891 during a match between Stoke and Aston Villa. Trailing 1–0 and with just two minutes remaining, Stoke were awarded a penalty. Villa's goalkeeper kicked the ball out of the ground, and by the time the ball had been recovered, the 90 minutes had elapsed and the game was over. The same law also states that the duration of either half is extended until the penalty kick to be taken or retaken is completed, thus no game shall end with a penalty to be taken.

The referee serves as the official timekeeper and can adjust for time lost due to substitutions, injuries, or other stoppages. This allowance is commonly referred to as stoppage time or injury time, also known as additional time or loss time. How much stoppage time is added is determined solely by the referee, who is the only person who can signal the end of the match. In games with a fourth official, near the end of each half, the referee indicates the amount of stoppage time to be added. The fourth official then shows this number to players and spectators using a board. The referee may further extend the signaled stoppage time. This concept of added time originated from an 1891 incident during a match between Stoke and Aston Villa. Leading 1–0 with only two minutes left, Stoke earned a penalty. However, Villa's goalkeeper kicked the ball out of the ground, and by the time it was retrieved, the 90 minutes had passed, ending the match. The rules also require that if a penalty kick is awarded before the end of a half, the game extends until the kick is taken or retaken, ensuring a match never ends with a pending penalty kick.

text_human: Franklin S. Harris was appointed the university's president in 1921. He was the first BYU president to have a doctoral degree. Harris made several important changes to the school, reorganizing it into a true university, whereas before, its organization had remnants of the Academy days. At the beginning of his tenure, the school was not officially recognized as a university by any accreditation organization. By the end of his term, the school was accredited under all major accrediting organizations at the time. He was eventually replaced by Howard S. McDonald, who received his doctorate from the University of California. When he first received the position, the Second World War had just ended, and thousands of students were flooding into BYU. By the end of his stay, the school had grown nearly five times to an enrollment of 5,440 students. The university did not have the facilities to handle such a large influx, so he bought part of an Air Force Base in Ogden, Utah and rebuilt it to house some of the students. The next president, Ernest L. Wilkinson, also oversaw a period of intense growth, as the school adopted an accelerated building program. Wilkinson was responsible for the building of over eighty structures on the campus, many of which still stand. During his tenure, the student body increased six times, making BYU the largest private school at the time. The quality of the students also increased, leading to higher educational standards at the school. Finally, Wilkinson reorganized the LDS Church units on campus, with ten stakes and over 100 wards being added during his administration.

text_human: Forbes magazine began reporting on Beyoncé's earnings in 2008, calculating that the $80 million earned between June 2007 to June 2008, for her music, tour, films and clothing line made her the world's best-paid music personality at the time, above Madonna and Celine Dion. They placed her fourth on the Celebrity 100 list in 2009 and ninth on the "Most Powerful Women in the World" list in 2010. The following year, Forbes placed her eighth on the "Best-Paid Celebrities Under 30" list, having earned $35 million in the past year for her clothing line and endorsement deals. In 2012, Forbes placed Beyoncé at number 16 on the Celebrity 100 list, twelve places lower than three years ago yet still having earned $40 million in the past year for her album 4, clothing line and endorsement deals. In the same year, Beyoncé and Jay Z placed at number one on the "World's Highest-Paid Celebrity Couples", for collectively earning $78 million. The couple made it into the previous year's Guinness World Records as the "highest-earning power couple" for collectively earning $122 million in 2009. For the years 2009 to 2011, Beyoncé earned an average of $70 million per year, and earned $40 million in 2012. In 2013, Beyoncé's endorsements of Pepsi and H&M made her and Jay Z the world's first billion dollar couple in the music industry. That year, Beyoncé was published as the fourth most-powerful celebrity in the Forbes rankings. MTV estimated that by the end of 2014, Beyoncé would become the highest-paid black musician in history; she succeeded to do so in April 2014. In June 2014, Beyoncé ranked at #1 on the Forbes Celebrity 100 list, earning an estimated $115 million throughout June 2013 – June 2014. This in turn was the first time she had topped the Celebrity 100 list as well as being her highest yearly earnings to date. As of May 2015, her net worth is estimated to be $250 million.

text_human: More commonly, in cases where there are three or more parties, no one party is likely to gain power alone, and parties work with each other to form coalition governments. This has been an emerging trend in the politics of the Republic of Ireland since the 1980s and is almost always the case in Germany on national and state level, and in most constituencies at the communal level. Furthermore, since the forming of the Republic of Iceland there has never been a government not led by a coalition (usually of the Independence Party and one other (often the Social Democratic Alliance). A similar situation exists in the Republic of Ireland; since 1989, no one party has held power on its own. Since then, numerous coalition governments have been formed. These coalitions have been exclusively led by one of either Fianna Fáil or Fine Gael. Political change is often easier with a coalition government than in one-party or two-party dominant systems.[dubious – discuss] If factions in a two-party system are in fundamental disagreement on policy goals, or even principles, they can be slow to make policy changes, which appears to be the case now in the U.S. with power split between Democrats and Republicans. Still coalition governments struggle, sometimes for years, to change policy and often fail altogether, post World War II France and Italy being prime examples. When one party in a two-party system controls all elective branches, however, policy changes can be both swift and significant. Democrats Woodrow Wilson, Franklin Roosevelt and Lyndon Johnson were beneficiaries of such fortuitous circumstances, as were Republicans as far removed in time as Abraham Lincoln and Ronald Reagan. Barack Obama briefly had such an advantage between 2009 and 2011.
text_ai_base: In political systems with three or more parties, it's common for no single party to gain power independently. This leads parties to collaborate and form coalition governments. This trend has been notable in the Republic of Ireland since the 1980s and is a consistent occurrence in Germany at both national and state levels, as well as in most local constituencies. Since its establishment, the Republic of Iceland has never seen a non-coalition government, typically led by the Independence Party and another party, often the Social Democratic Alliance. A similar scenario exists in the Republic of Ireland, where no party has governed alone since 1989, resulting in numerous coalition governments, primarily led by either Fianna Fáil or Fine Gael. Coalition governments can often facilitate political change more effectively than one-party or two-party systems. In a two-party system, if there are fundamental disagreements on policy or principles, adjustments can be slow, as seen in the U.S. with Democrats and Republicans currently sharing power. However, coalition governments can also struggle for years to implement changes and may fail, as seen in post-World War II France and Italy. When one party in a two-party system controls all branches of government, policy changes can occur rapidly and significantly. This was the case for Democrats like Woodrow Wilson, Franklin Roosevelt, and Lyndon Johnson, as well as Republicans such as Abraham Lincoln and Ronald Reagan. Barack Obama also briefly benefited from such circumstances between 2009 and 2011.

An entrenched two-party system may hit a stalemate when ideological rifts emerge, as seen in the current American political scene with Democrats and Republicans entwined in power struggles. Yet, coalitions aren't without their woes; implementing reforms can be a drawn-out affair, occasionally ending in failure, as evidenced by the ordeals of post-war France and Italy. On the flip side, when a single party tightens its grip over all government branches, sweeping policy shifts can happen in a blink. Historical examples abound—Democrats under figures like Woodrow Wilson, Franklin Roosevelt, and Lyndon Johnson, and Republicans such as Abraham Lincoln and Ronald Reagan, executed significant changes. Barack Obama experienced a brief spell of similar control between 2009 and 2011.

text_human: The early and mid-1980s saw economic trouble for Libya; from 1982 to 1986, the country's annual oil revenues dropped from $21 billion to $5.4 billion. Focusing on irrigation projects, 1983 saw construction start on "Gaddafi's Pet Project", the Great Man-Made River; although designed to be finished by the end of the decade, it remained incomplete at the start of the 21st century. Military spending increased, while other administrative budgets were cut back. Libya had long supported the FROLINAT militia in neighbouring Chad, and in December 1980, re-invaded Chad at the request of the Frolinat-controlled GUNT government to aid in the civil war; in January 1981, Gaddafi suggested a political merger. The Organisation of African Unity (OAU) rejected this, and called for a Libyan withdrawal, which came about in November 1981. The civil war resumed, and so Libya sent troops back in, clashing with French forces who supported the southern Chadian forces. Many African nations had tired of Libya's policies of interference in foreign affairs; by 1980, nine African states had cut off diplomatic relations with Libya, while in 1982 the OAU cancelled its scheduled conference in Tripoli in order to prevent Gaddafi gaining chairmanship. Proposing political unity with Morocco, in August 1984, Gaddafi and Moroccan monarch Hassan II signed the Oujda Treaty, forming the Arab-African Union; such a union was considered surprising due to the strong political differences and longstanding enmity that existed between the two governments. Relations remained strained, particularly due to Morocco's friendly relations with the U.S. and Israel; in August 1986, Hassan abolished the union. Domestic threats continued to plague Gaddafi; in May 1984, his Bab al-Azizia home was unsuccessfully attacked by a joint NFSL–Muslim Brotherhood militia, and in the aftermath 5000 dissidents were arrested.

Though intended to be completed by the end of the decade, the project remained unfinished as the 21st century began. While military spending increased, other government budgets were reduced. Meanwhile, domestic threats persisted against Gaddafi; in May 1984, his Bab al-Azizia residence was attacked by a joint militia of NFSL and Muslim Brotherhood, but the assault failed, leading to the arrest of 5000 dissidents thereafter.

Often dubbed "Gaddafi's Pet Project," this grand irrigation effort was meant to reach completion by the decade's close, yet it remained unfinished as the new century dawned. On the military front, expenditures rose even as other parts of the government budget were trimmed down significantly. The attack missed its mark, resulting in the arrest of 5,000 dissidents in the aftermath. Such is the historical complexity of this era for Libya, marked by political gambits and regional wranglings, all set against a backdrop of economic trials.

text_human: Since the construction of its oldest buildings, the university's physical plant has grown substantially. Over the years 29 residence halls have been built to accommodate students and each has been constructed with its own chapel. Many academic building were added together with a system of libraries, the most prominent of which is the Theodore Hesburgh Library, built in 1963 and today containing almost 4 million books. Since 2004, several buildings have been added, including the DeBartolo Performing Arts Center, the Guglielmino Complex, and the Jordan Hall of Science. Additionally, a new residence for men, Duncan Hall, was begun on March 8, 2007, and began accepting residents for the Fall 2008 semester. Ryan Hall was completed and began housing undergraduate women in the fall of 2009. A new engineering building, Stinson-Remick Hall, a new combination Center for Social Concerns/Institute for Church Life building, Geddes Hall, and a law school addition have recently been completed as well. Additionally the new hockey arena opened in the fall of 2011. The Stayer Center for Executive Education, which houses the Mendoza College of Business Executive Education Department opened in March 2013 just South of the Mendoza College of Business building. Because of its long athletic tradition, the university features also many building dedicated to sport. The most famous is Notre Dame Stadium, home of the Fighting Irish football team; it has been renovated several times and today it can hold more than 80 thousand people. Prominent venues include also the Edmund P. Joyce Center, with indoor basketball and volleyball courts, and the Compton Family Ice Arena, a two-rink facility dedicated to hockey. Also, there are many outdoor fields, as the Frank Eck Stadium for baseball.

Over the years, 29 residence halls have been built, each with its own chapel to accommodate students. Numerous academic buildings have been added, along with a system of libraries. The most notable of these is the Theodore Hesburgh Library, established in 1963, which now houses nearly 4 million books. Since 2004, several new buildings have been added, including the DeBartolo Performing Arts Center, the Guglielmino Complex, and the Jordan Hall of Science. A new men's residence, Duncan Hall, began construction on March 8, 2007, and opened for residents in the Fall semester of 2008. Ryan Hall was completed in 2009 and started housing undergraduate women that fall. Recent additions also include the Stinson-Remick Hall for engineering, Geddes Hall, which serves as the Center for Social Concerns/Institute for Church Life, and a law school extension. Additionally, the new hockey arena opened in the fall of 2011. The Stayer Center for Executive Education, part of the Mendoza College of Business, opened in March 2013 just south of the main business building. The university's strong athletic tradition is reflected in its many sports facilities. The most famous is Notre Dame Stadium, home to the Fighting Irish football team, which has been renovated several times and now seats over 80,000 people. Other prominent venues include the Edmund P. Joyce Center, featuring indoor basketball and volleyball courts, and the Compton Family Ice Arena, a two-rink hockey facility. Outdoor sports facilities include the Frank Eck Stadium for baseball.

text_human: Following the Ulm Campaign, French forces managed to capture Vienna in November. The fall of Vienna provided the French a huge bounty as they captured 100,000 muskets, 500 cannons, and the intact bridges across the Danube. At this critical juncture, both Tsar Alexander I and Holy Roman Emperor Francis II decided to engage Napoleon in battle, despite reservations from some of their subordinates. Napoleon sent his army north in pursuit of the Allies, but then ordered his forces to retreat so that he could feign a grave weakness. Desperate to lure the Allies into battle, Napoleon gave every indication in the days preceding the engagement that the French army was in a pitiful state, even abandoning the dominant Pratzen Heights near the village of Austerlitz. At the Battle of Austerlitz, in Moravia on 2 December, he deployed the French army below the Pratzen Heights and deliberately weakened his right flank, enticing the Allies to launch a major assault there in the hopes of rolling up the whole French line. A forced march from Vienna by Marshal Davout and his III Corps plugged the gap left by Napoleon just in time. Meanwhile, the heavy Allied deployment against the French right weakened their center on the Pratzen Heights, which was viciously attacked by the IV Corps of Marshal Soult. With the Allied center demolished, the French swept through both enemy flanks and sent the Allies fleeing chaotically, capturing thousands of prisoners in the process. The battle is often seen as a tactical masterpiece because of the near-perfect execution of a calibrated but dangerous plan — of the same stature as Cannae, the celebrated triumph by Hannibal some 2000 years before.

text_human: Carolingian art was produced for a small group of figures around the court, and the monasteries and churches they supported. It was dominated by efforts to regain the dignity and classicism of imperial Roman and Byzantine art, but was also influenced by the Insular art of the British Isles. Insular art integrated the energy of Irish Celtic and Anglo-Saxon Germanic styles of ornament with Mediterranean forms such as the book, and established many characteristics of art for the rest of the medieval period. Surviving religious works from the Early Middle Ages are mostly illuminated manuscripts and carved ivories, originally made for metalwork that has since been melted down. Objects in precious metals were the most prestigious form of art, but almost all are lost except for a few crosses such as the Cross of Lothair, several reliquaries, and finds such as the Anglo-Saxon burial at Sutton Hoo and the hoards of Gourdon from Merovingian France, Guarrazar from Visigothic Spain and Nagyszentmiklós near Byzantine territory. There are survivals from the large brooches in fibula or penannular form that were a key piece of personal adornment for elites, including the Irish Tara Brooch. Highly decorated books were mostly Gospel Books and these have survived in larger numbers, including the Insular Book of Kells, the Book of Lindisfarne, and the imperial Codex Aureus of St. Emmeram, which is one of the few to retain its "treasure binding" of gold encrusted with jewels. Charlemagne's court seems to have been responsible for the acceptance of figurative monumental sculpture in Christian art, and by the end of the period near life-sized figures such as the Gero Cross were common in important churches.
text_ai_base: Carolingian art emerged among a select group at the court and within the monasteries and churches they funded. This art sought to revive the dignity and classical style of imperial Roman and Byzantine traditions, while also incorporating elements from Insular art of the British Isles. Insular art combined the dynamic ornamentation of Irish Celtic and Anglo-Saxon Germanic styles with Mediterranean formats, like the book, setting lasting trends for medieval art. Most religious artifacts from the Early Middle Ages are illuminated manuscripts and carved ivories, originally part of metalworks that have largely been melted down. Though objects in precious metals were considered the pinnacle of artistic creation, few survive today. Notable exceptions include several crosses like the Cross of Lothair, various reliquaries, and discoveries such as the Anglo-Saxon burial at Sutton Hoo, along with hoards from Gourdon in Merovingian France, Guarrazar in Visigothic Spain, and Nagyszentmiklós near Byzantine areas. Among the surviving items are large brooches for elite personal adornment, such as the Irish Tara Brooch. Lavishly decorated books, mainly Gospel Books, have survived in notable numbers, including the Book of Kells, the Book of Lindisfarne, and the Codex Aureus of St. Emmeram, which retains its jewel-encrusted "treasure binding." Charlemagne's court played a crucial role in introducing figurative monumental sculpture to Christian art, leading to life-sized figures, like the Gero Cross, becoming common in major churches by the period's end.
text_ai_humanized: Amidst the grandeur of Charlemagne’s court and the spiritual sanctuaries they endowed, Carolingian art made its distinct mark. It strove to bring back the noble and classical flair reminiscent of imperial Roman and Byzantine aesthetics, all the while weaving in the vibrant, intricate designs characteristic of Insular art from the British Isles. This Insular style adeptly merged the spirited ornamentation of Irish Celtic and Anglo-Saxon Germanic roots with the formal structures of Mediterranean traditions, such as the book format, setting enduring benchmarks for medieval art that followed. Interestingly, the Early Middle Ages produced religious artifacts primarily in the form of illuminated manuscripts and intricately carved ivory pieces. These were intended as companions to now-lost metalworks, which have mostly vanished—rescued by the smelter’s heat over time. Craftsmen adored working with precious metals, viewing them as the zenith of artistic achievement; unfortunately, only a few remarkable pieces remain. Among these are the Cross of Lothair, an array of reliquaries, and significant archaeological finds like the Anglo-Saxon burial treasures at Sutton Hoo. Hoards unearthed in diverse locations—Gourdon in Merovingian France, Guarrazar in Visigothic Spain, and near Byzantine influences in Nagyszentmiklós—also tell tales of glittering pasts. Personal adornment for the elite included grand brooches, with the renowned Irish Tara Brooch standing as a testament to such lavish taste. Books, especially Gospel Books, did fare better with time, surviving in notable quantities. Some have become legendary: the Book of Kells, the Book of Lindisfarne, and the Codex Aureus of St. Emmeram, the latter still boasting its exquisite, jewel-adorned "treasure binding." The court of Charlemagne, a crucible of artistic innovation, introduced monumental figurative sculpture into the Christian artistic canon. This influence soon became evident as life-sized figures, like the striking Gero Cross, began appearing in major churches, heralding a new norm by the end of the era.

text_human: The Guangxu Emperor died on November 14, 1908, and on November 15, 1908, Cixi also died. Rumors held that she or Yuan Shikai ordered trusted eunuchs to poison the Guangxu Emperor, and an autopsy conducted nearly a century later confirmed lethal levels of arsenic in his corpse. Puyi, the oldest son of Zaifeng, Prince Chun, and nephew to the childless Guangxu Emperor, was appointed successor at the age of two, leaving Zaifeng with the regency. This was followed by the dismissal of General Yuan Shikai from his former positions of power. In April 1911 Zaifeng created a cabinet in which there were two vice-premiers. Nonetheless, this cabinet was also known by contemporaries as "The Royal Cabinet" because among the thirteen cabinet members, five were members of the imperial family or Aisin Gioro relatives. This brought a wide range of negative opinions from senior officials like Zhang Zhidong. The Wuchang Uprising of October 10, 1911, led to the creation of a new central government, the Republic of China, in Nanjing with Sun Yat-sen as its provisional head. Many provinces soon began "separating" from Qing control. Seeing a desperate situation unfold, the Qing government brought Yuan Shikai back to military power. He took control of his Beiyang Army to crush the revolution in Wuhan at the Battle of Yangxia. After taking the position of Prime Minister and creating his own cabinet, Yuan Shikai went as far as to ask for the removal of Zaifeng from the regency. This removal later proceeded with directions from Empress Dowager Longyu.

Rumors alleged that she or Yuan Shikai had trusted eunuchs poison the Guangxu Emperor, a suspicion confirmed nearly a century later when an autopsy detected lethal arsenic levels in his body. Puyi, the eldest son of Zaifeng, Prince Chun, and the childless Guangxu Emperor's nephew, was named successor at age two, placing Zaifeng in charge as regent. Subsequently, General Yuan Shikai was dismissed from his previous positions of influence. In April 1911, Zaifeng set up a cabinet featuring two vice-premiers, but contemporary critics dubbed it "The Royal Cabinet" due to its composition: five out of thirteen members hailed from the imperial family or were Aisin Gioro relatives. This elicited significant disapproval from senior officials like Zhang Zhidong. The Wuchang Uprising on October 10, 1911, led to the founding of the Republic of China in Nanjing, with Sun Yat-sen as its provisional leader. Many provinces soon began to break away from Qing control. Facing a worsening crisis, the Qing government restored Yuan Shikai to military command. He deployed his Beiyang Army to suppress the revolution at the Battle of Yangxia in Wuhan. After becoming Prime Minister and forming his own cabinet, Yuan Shikai sought the removal of Zaifeng from the regency, which was eventually carried out under Empress Dowager Longyu's orders.
text_ai_humanized: On November 14, 1908, the Guangxu Emperor passed away, and just a day later, the formidable Empress Dowager Cixi followed suit. Whispers soon circulated that the emperor’s demise was orchestrated by Cixi or perhaps Yuan Shikai, with the deed done by trusted eunuchs and involving poison. These suspicions weren’t merely idle gossip—as nearly a hundred years later, scientific examination indeed revealed lethal arsenic in Guangxu's remains. The succession of the crown found an unexpected heir in the two-year-old Puyi, who happened to be both the nephew of the childless Guangxu Emperor and the eldest son of Zaifeng, Prince Chun. With Puyi too young to rule, Zaifeng stepped into the role of regent. This change simultaneously edged General Yuan Shikai out of his influential posts. By April 1911, Zaifeng had formed a cabinet, but it wasn’t without its controversies. Critics wasted no time dubbing it "The Royal Cabinet," pointing out disdainfully that five of the thirteen members were either direct imperial family members or Aisin Gioro kin, much to the chagrin of senior officials, Zhang Zhidong being a notable detractor. Then came the pivotal Wuchang Uprising on October 10, 1911, a spark that led to the birth of the Republic of China in Nanjing, with Sun Yat-sen stepping up as provisional head. In the wake of this upheaval, province after province began slipping out from under Qing control. In a desperate bid to stabilize the unraveling empire, the Qing dynasty called Yuan Shikai back into military power. His Beiyang Army was dispatched to quash the revolution at the Battle of Yangxia in Wuhan. Climbing to the position of Prime Minister, Yuan Shikai set about shaping his own cabinet. Yet, he had his sights set on greater changes—particularly the removal of Zaifeng from the regency, a move that the Emperor's widow, Empress Dowager Longyu, eventually sanctioned.

These suspicions weren’t merely idle gossip—as nearly a hundred years later, scientific examination indeed revealed lethal arsenic in Guangxu's remains.

The succession of the crown found an unexpected heir in the two-year-old Puyi, who happened to be both the nephew of the childless Guangxu Emperor and the eldest son of Zaifeng, Prince Chun. With Puyi too young to rule, Zaifeng stepped into the role of regent. This change simultaneously edged General Yuan Shikai out of his influential posts.

By April 1911, Zaifeng had formed a cabinet, but it wasn’t without its controversies. Critics wasted no time dubbing it "The Royal Cabinet," pointing out disdainfully that five of the thirteen members were either direct imperial family members or Aisin Gioro kin, much to the chagrin of senior officials, Zhang Zhidong being a notable detractor.

Then came the pivotal Wuchang Uprising on October 10, 1911, a spark that led to the birth of the Republic of China in Nanjing, with Sun Yat-sen stepping up as provisional head. In the wake of this upheaval, province after province began slipping out from under Qing control. In a desperate bid to stabilize the unraveling empire, the Qing dynasty called Yuan Shikai back into military power. His Beiyang Army was dispatched to quash the revolution at the Battle of Yangxia in Wuhan. Climbing to the position of Prime Minister, Yuan Shikai set about shaping his own cabinet. Yet, he had his sights set on greater changes—particularly the removal of Zaifeng from the regency, a move that the Emperor's widow, Empress Dowager Longyu, eventually sanctioned.

text_human: The torch was lit at a park outside at AT&T Park at about 1:17 pm PDT (20:17 UTC), briefly held aloft by American and Chinese Olympic officials. The relay descended into confusion as the first runner in the elaborately planned relay disappeared into a warehouse on a waterfront pier where it stayed for a half-an-hour. There were clashes between thousands of pro-China demonstrators, many of whom said they were bused in by the Chinese Consulate and other pro-China groups, and both pro-Tibet and Darfur protesters. The non-Chinese demonstrators were reported to have been swamped and trailed by angry crowds. Around 2 pm PDT (21:00 UTC), the torch resurfaced about 3 km (1.9 mi) away from the stadium along Van Ness Avenue, a heavily trafficked thoroughfare that was not on official route plans. Television reports showed the flame flanked by motorcycles and uniformed police officers. Two torchbearers carried the flame running slowly behind a truck and surrounded by Olympic security guards. During the torch relay, two torchbearers, Andrew Michael who uses a wheelchair and is the Vice President for Sustainable Development for the Bay Area Council and Director of Partnerships For Change, and an environmental advocate, Majora Carter, managed to display Tibetan flags in protest, resulting in their ejection from the relay. The closing ceremony at Justin Herman Plaza was canceled due to the presence of large numbers of protesters at the site. The torch run ended with a final stretch through San Francisco's Marina district and was then moved by bus to San Francisco International Airport for a makeshift closing ceremony at the terminal, from which the free media was excluded. San Jose Mercury News described the "deceiving" event as "a game of Where's Waldo, played against the landscape of a lovely city." International Olympic Committee President Jacques Rogge said the San Francisco relay had "fortunately" avoided much of the disruptions that marred the legs in London and Paris, but "was, however, not the joyous party that we had wished it to be."

text_ai_humanized: At about 1:17 pm PDT (20:17 UTC), an unexpected scene played out just outside AT&T Park. The torch, clutched by American and Chinese Olympic officials, set the stage for what should have been a seamless relay. Yet, in a twist that could rival a film plot, the initial runner vanished into a waterfront warehouse for nearly 30 minutes, leaving onlookers bewildered. Meanwhile, amidst this chaos, throngs of spirited demonstrators clashed. Pro-China protesters, allegedly organized by the Chinese Consulate, vociferously squared off against supporters of Tibet and Darfur. The latter were soon overwhelmed by irate crowds. Then, around 2 pm PDT (21:00 UTC), the torch made an unexpected reappearance on Van Ness Avenue, roughly 3 kilometers (1.9 miles) from its original path. This unplanned detour was a surprise twist for many. TV cameras captured the flame being closely escorted by motorcycles and heavy police presence. In the midst of this, two torchbearers caught the eye—Andrew Michael, who was participating in his wheelchair, and Majora Carter, an environmental advocate. Both raised Tibetan flags, making a powerful yet brief statement before being whisked away from the event. The day’s unpredictability didn’t end there—San Francisco’s Justin Herman Plaza was supposed to host the relay’s grand finale, but the growing number of demonstrators led to its cancellation. Instead, the relay wound through the Marina district, capped off by a hurried bus ride to San Francisco International Airport. Here, an impromptu closing ceremony took place behind closed doors at the terminal, far from the gaze of free media. The San Jose Mercury News didn’t hold back, likening this convoluted affair to "a game of Where’s Waldo played against the backdrop of a lovely city." In his remarks, Jacques Rogge, the IOC President, acknowledged that San Francisco had managed to dodge some of the more severe disruptions that marked the relays in London and Paris. However, he lamented that it was "not the joyous celebration we had hoped for."

text_human: A true predator can commonly be known as one that kills and eats another living thing. Whereas other types of predator all harm their prey in some way, this form kills them. Predators may hunt actively for prey in pursuit predation, or sit and wait for prey to approach within striking distance, as in ambush predators. Some predators kill large prey and dismember or chew it prior to eating it, such as a jaguar or a human; others may eat their (usually much smaller) prey whole, as does a bottlenose dolphin swallowing a fish, or a snake, duck or stork swallowing a frog. Some animals that kill both large and small prey for their size (domestic cats and dogs are prime examples) may do either depending upon the circumstances; either would devour a large insect whole but dismember a rabbit. Some predation entails venom that subdues a prey creature before the predator ingests the prey by killing, which the box jellyfish does, or disabling it, found in the behavior of the cone shell. In some cases, the venom, as in rattlesnakes and some spiders, contributes to the digestion of the prey item even before the predator begins eating. In other cases, the prey organism may die in the mouth or digestive system of the predator. Baleen whales, for example, eat millions of microscopic plankton at once, the prey being broken down well after entering the whale. Seed predation and egg predation are other forms of true predation, as seeds and eggs represent potential organisms. Predators of this classification need not eat prey entirely. For example, some predators cannot digest bones, while others can. Some may eat only part of an organism, as in grazing (see below), but still consistently cause its direct death.
text_ai_base: A true predator is commonly defined as an organism that kills and consumes another living being. While all predators harm their prey in some way, true predators are distinctive in that they kill their prey. Predators may actively pursue prey, known as pursuit predation, or they may use ambush tactics, waiting for prey to wander within reach. Some predators, like jaguars and humans, kill large prey and break it apart or chew it before consuming. Others, such as bottlenose dolphins, snakes, ducks, or storks, swallow their often smaller prey whole. Domestic cats and dogs, which hunt both large and small prey relative to their size, may consume a large insect whole but dismember a rabbit. Certain predators use venom to subdue prey, either killing it, as box jellyfish do, or disabling it, like cone shells. In some predators, such as rattlesnakes and certain spiders, the venom aids in digesting the prey even before they begin feeding. Additionally, some prey may die within the predator’s mouth or digestive system, such as when baleen whales consume vast quantities of plankton, breaking down the prey after ingestion. True predation also includes seed and egg predation, as seeds and eggs represent potential organisms. Not all predators consume every part of their prey; for instance, some cannot digest bones, while others do. Some predators might consume only part of an organism, as in the case of grazing, yet still directly cause the organism's death.

Venom enters the scene as another fascinating tool in the predator's arsenal. Box jellyfish employ it to kill outright, while cone shells use venom to disable, ensuring their prey remains manageable. Rattlesnakes and certain spiders even use it to pre-digest, starting the meal well before it reaches their mouths. Then there's the gentle giant approach—baleen whales, for instance, gobble up vast quantities of plankton, their prey meeting demise within the whale's massive digestive system. text_human: In December, Beyoncé along with a variety of other celebrities teamed up and produced a video campaign for "Demand A Plan", a bipartisan effort by a group of 950 US mayors and others designed to influence the federal government into rethinking its gun control laws, following the Sandy Hook Elementary School shooting. Beyoncé became an ambassador for the 2012 World Humanitarian Day campaign donating her song "I Was Here" and its music video, shot in the UN, to the campaign. In 2013, it was announced that Beyoncé would work with Salma Hayek and Frida Giannini on a Gucci "Chime for Change" campaign that aims to spread female empowerment. The campaign, which aired on February 28, was set to her new music. A concert for the cause took place on June 1, 2013 in London and included other acts like Ellie Goulding, Florence and the Machine, and Rita Ora. In advance of the concert, she appeared in a campaign video released on 15 May 2013, where she, along with Cameron Diaz, John Legend and Kylie Minogue, described inspiration from their mothers, while a number of other artists celebrated personal inspiration from other women, leading to a call for submission of photos of women of viewers' inspiration from which a selection was shown at the concert. Beyoncé said about her mother Tina Knowles that her gift was "finding the best qualities in every human being." With help of the crowdfunding platform Catapult, visitors of the concert could choose between several projects promoting education of women and girls. Beyoncé is also taking part in "Miss a Meal", a food-donation campaign, and supporting Goodwill charity through online charity auctions at Charitybuzz that support job creation throughout Europe and the U.S.

text_human: Jefferson and James Madison's conceptions of separation have long been debated. Jefferson refused to issue Proclamations of Thanksgiving sent to him by Congress during his presidency, though he did issue a Thanksgiving and Prayer proclamation as Governor of Virginia. Madison issued four religious proclamations while President, but vetoed two bills on the grounds they violated the first amendment. On the other hand, both Jefferson and Madison attended religious services at the Capitol. Years before the ratification of the Constitution, Madison contended "Because if Religion be exempt from the authority of the Society at large, still less can it be subject to that of the Legislative Body." After retiring from the presidency, Madison wrote of "total separation of the church from the state." " "Strongly guarded as is the separation between Religion & Govt in the Constitution of the United States," Madison wrote, and he declared, "practical distinction between Religion and Civil Government is essential to the purity of both, and as guaranteed by the Constitution of the United States." In a letter to Edward Livingston Madison further expanded, "We are teaching the world the great truth that Govts. do better without Kings & Nobles than with them. The merit will be doubled by the other lesson that Religion flourishes in greater purity, without than with the aid of Govt." Madison's original draft of the Bill of Rights had included provisions binding the States, as well as the Federal Government, from an establishment of religion, but the House did not pass them.[citation needed]
text_ai_base: The separation of church and state as conceived by Jefferson and James Madison has been a topic of debate for many years. During his presidency, Jefferson declined to issue Thanksgiving proclamations requested by Congress, despite having issued one as Governor of Virginia. In contrast, Madison, as President, issued four religious proclamations but vetoed two bills, arguing they violated the First Amendment. Both Jefferson and Madison also attended religious services at the Capitol. Before the Constitution was ratified, Madison argued that if religion is beyond the authority of society, it should be even more so beyond that of the legislature. After his presidency, Madison advocated for a "total separation of church and state." He wrote about the strong separation between religion and government in the U.S. Constitution and stated that maintaining a practical distinction between religion and civil government is crucial to preserving the integrity of both. In a letter to Edward Livingston, Madison elaborated, "We are teaching the world that governments function better without kings and nobles. This lesson will be further enhanced by proving that religion thrives more purely without government support." Madison's original draft of the Bill of Rights included provisions to prevent states, as well as the federal government, from establishing religion, but these were not passed by the House.
text_ai_humanized: The debate over the separation of church and state, a principle championed by Thomas Jefferson and James Madison, has sparked much discussion over the years. Interestingly, despite issuing a Thanksgiving proclamation during his time as Governor of Virginia, President Jefferson refused to issue similar proclamations when urged by Congress. Madison, on the other hand, took a slightly different path during his presidency by issuing four religious proclamations; yet, he made it clear where he stood by vetoing two bills, citing that they infringed upon the First Amendment. Both historical figures, despite these actions, were known to attend religious services held at the Capitol. Before the ratification of the Constitution, Madison was firm in his belief: if religion was to remain outside the bounds of societal control, it certainly should stand beyond legislative authority. Post-presidency, he became an even stronger advocate for the "total separation of church and state." Madison emphasized, in various writings, the importance of keeping religion and government in separate spheres, asserting this distinction was key to preserving the integrity of each. In correspondence with Edward Livingston, Madison eloquently noted, "We are teaching the world that governments can operate effectively without kings and nobles—a lesson that’s only reinforced by demonstrating that religion flourishes when not entwined with government support." It's worth mentioning that in his initial draft of the Bill of Rights, Madison included amendments aimed at preventing both federal and state governments from establishing a state religion. However, these particular amendments didn’t make it through the House. Madison and Jefferson’s actions and writings laid foundational ideas that continue to influence how we interpret the interaction between church and state today.

message.content:
The debate over the separation of church and state, a principle championed by Thomas Jefferson and James Madison, has sparked much discussion over the years. Interestingly, despite issuing a Thanksgiving proclamation during his time as Governor of Virginia, President Jefferson refused to issue similar proclamations when urged by Congress. Madison, on the other hand, took a slightly different path during his presidency by issuing four religious proclamations; yet, he made it clear where he stood by vetoing two bills, citing that they infringed upon the First Amendment. Both historical figures, despite these actions, were known to attend religious services held at the Capitol.

Before the ratification of the Constitution, Madison was firm in his belief: if religion was to remain outside the bounds of societal control, it certainly should stand beyond legislative authority. Post-presidency, he became an even stronger advocate for the "total separation of church and state." Madison emphasized, in various writings, the importance of keeping religion and government in separate spheres, asserting this distinction was key to preserving the integrity of each. 

In correspondence with Edward Livingston, Madison eloquently noted, "We are teaching the world that governments can operate effectively without kings and nobles—a lesson that’s only reinforced by demonstrating that religion flourishes when not entwined with government support." It's worth mentioning that in his initial draft of the Bill of Rights, Madison included amendments aimed at preventing both federal and state governments from establishing a state religion. However, these particular amendments didn’t make it through the House. 

Madison and Jefferson’s actions and writings laid foundational ideas that continue to influence how we interpret the interaction between church and state today.

text_human: John treated the interdict as "the equivalent of a papal declaration of war". He responded by attempting to punish Innocent personally and to drive a wedge between those English clergy that might support him and those allying themselves firmly with the authorities in Rome. John seized the lands of those clergy unwilling to conduct services, as well as those estates linked to Innocent himself; he arrested the illicit concubines that many clerics kept during the period, only releasing them after the payment of fines; he seized the lands of members of the church who had fled England, and he promised protection for those clergy willing to remain loyal to him. In many cases, individual institutions were able to negotiate terms for managing their own properties and keeping the produce of their estates. By 1209 the situation showed no signs of resolution, and Innocent threatened to excommunicate John if he did not acquiesce to Langton's appointment. When this threat failed, Innocent excommunicated the king in November 1209. Although theoretically a significant blow to John's legitimacy, this did not appear to greatly worry the king. Two of John's close allies, Emperor Otto IV and Count Raymond VI of Toulouse, had already suffered the same punishment themselves, and the significance of excommunication had been somewhat devalued. John simply tightened his existing measures and accrued significant sums from the income of vacant sees and abbeys: one 1213 estimate, for example, suggested the church had lost an estimated 100,000 marks (equivalent to £66,666 at the time) to John. Official figures suggest that around 14% of annual income from the English church was being appropriated by John each year.

He detained the concubines, which many clerics maintained, releasing them only after imposing fines. Additionally, he seized properties of church members who fled England and promised protection to clergy who remained loyal to him. Some institutions managed to negotiate terms to oversee their properties and retain their estate yields. By 1209, the deadlock persisted, prompting Innocent to threaten John's excommunication unless he accepted Langton's appointment. This threat having no effect, Innocent excommunicated John in November 1209. While theoretically a serious blow to John's legitimacy, it did not seem to trouble the king much. In 1213, estimates suggested the church had lost around 100,000 marks (equivalent to £66,666 at the time) to John. Official records indicate that John appropriated roughly 14% of the annual income from the English church each year.

Undeterred, John ramped up his efforts, drawing significant wealth from unoccupied churches and abbeys.
