Later, South Korea's Prosecutor's Office, National Police Agency, Ministry of Foreign Affairs, and National Intelligence Service jointly announced they would deport all participating Chinese students. China defended the students' actions.
text_ai_humanized: In the bustling city of Seoul, known for hosting the famed 1988 Summer Olympics, an event unfolded on April 27 that few will forget. With intent written across their faces, designated torchbearers Choi Seung-kook and Park Won-sun decided not to participate, taking a stand against the Chinese government’s policies in Tibet by boycotting the occasion. The city braced itself with over 8,000 riot police securing the 24-kilometer stretch beginning at Olympic Park, a remnant of the ‘88 Games. The day was anything but peaceful. Clashes marred the torch relay, with rocks, bottles, and punches flying between Chinese students and opposing protesters. Amid the chaos, a North Korean defector, desperate to highlight the plight of North Korean refugees at the hands of China, tried to set himself ablaze. Dousing himself in gasoline, his protest was cut short by quick-acting police who whisked him away. Meanwhile, other attempts to disrupt the relay fizzled out without note. At the starting line, the sparks of a larger confrontation ignited. About 500 Chinese supporters squared off against a smaller, determined group of 50 protesters, who brought along a bold message: “Free North Korean refugees in China.” Stones and bottles sliced through the air, prompting swift intervention by roughly 2,500 police officers. Five arrests followed, including a Chinese student caught in the act of rock-throwing. The journey of the torch, lasting a tense 4.5 hours, was shadowed by legions of Chinese participants chanting, "Go China, go Olympics!" Yet, the event’s conclusion unraveled into violence, with what Korean media described as a "lynching" of dissenters by Chinese students. The altercations turned severe enough to send a police officer to the hospital. Just days later, on April 29, Justice Secretary Kim Kyung Han assured the prime minister of swift justice for all involved. In a decisive move, South Korea’s Prosecutor's Office, alongside the National Police Agency, Ministry of Foreign Affairs, and National Intelligence Service, announced plans to deport all the Chinese students who took part. China, however, defended its students' actions, setting the stage for ongoing diplomatic tensions.

text_human: Democratic Party candidates were consistently elected to local office, increasing the city's ties to the South and its dominant party. In 1861, Mayor Fernando Wood called on the aldermen to declare independence from Albany and the United States after the South seceded, but his proposal was not acted on. Anger at new military conscription laws during the American Civil War (1861–1865), which spared wealthier men who could afford to pay a $300 (equivalent to $5,766 in 2016) commutation fee to hire a substitute, led to the Draft Riots of 1863, whose most visible participants were ethnic Irish working class. The situation deteriorated into attacks on New York's elite, followed by attacks on black New Yorkers and their property after fierce competition for a decade between Irish immigrants and blacks for work. Rioters burned the Colored Orphan Asylum to the ground, but more than 200 children escaped harm due to efforts of the New York City Police Department, which was mainly made up of Irish immigrants. According to historian James M. McPherson (2001), at least 120 people were killed. In all, eleven black men were lynched over five days, and the riots forced hundreds of blacks to flee the city for Williamsburg, Brooklyn, as well as New Jersey; the black population in Manhattan fell below 10,000 by 1865, which it had last been in 1820. The white working class had established dominance. Violence by longshoremen against black men was especially fierce in the docks area. It was one of the worst incidents of civil unrest in American history.
text_ai_base: Democratic Party candidates consistently secured local office positions, strengthening the city's connection to the South and its leading political party. In 1861, Mayor Fernando Wood urged the aldermen to declare independence from Albany and the United States after the South seceded, but his idea was not pursued. New military conscription laws during the American Civil War (1861–1865) incited anger, as these laws exempted wealthier men who could pay a $300 fee (equivalent to $5,766 in 2016) to hire substitutes. This resentment led to the 1863 Draft Riots, predominantly involving ethnic Irish working class men. The violence escalated to assaults on New York's elite, and later targeted black New Yorkers and their property due to intense competition for jobs over the previous decade between Irish immigrants and blacks. Rioters torched the Colored Orphan Asylum, but more than 200 children escaped unharmed thanks to efforts by the New York City Police Department, primarily composed of Irish immigrants. Historian James M. McPherson (2001) estimated that at least 120 people were killed. In total, eleven black men were lynched over five days, prompting hundreds of blacks to flee to Williamsburg, Brooklyn, and New Jersey; by 1865, Manhattan’s black population had fallen below 10,000, a level unseen since 1820, marking the rise of white working class dominance. Longshoremen's violence against black men was particularly brutal in the docks area, marking one of the most severe incidents of civil unrest in American history.
text_ai_humanized: In a city where the Democratic Party's stronghold on local offices seemed unshakeable, the political landscape of the mid-1800s was vividly tied to Southern allegiances. Back in 1861, amidst the turbulence of secession, Mayor Fernando Wood floated the rather audacious idea of New York City breaking away from both Albany and the larger United States. His proposal, however, was shelved, met with little more than raised eyebrows. As the American Civil War churned on from 1861 to 1865, it brought with it the highly controversial new military draft laws. These laws sparked outrage among the working class due to a loophole favoring the wealthier citizens; those who could afford it paid $300—no small sum, roughly $5,766 in today's terms—to avoid conscription by sending a substitute in their place. The resulting fury came to a head in 1863 with the eruption of the Draft Riots, predominantly instigated by ethnic Irish men from the working class. The chaos spiraled violently beyond mere dissent. Rioters lashed out first at the city’s elite, but then shockingly turned their aggression towards black New Yorkers. Over preceding years, fierce job competition had already bred tension between Irish immigrants and black residents, boiling over during these riots. In a shocking act of brutality, the rioters set fire to the Colored Orphan Asylum. Fortunately, quick action by the New York City Police Department, mostly staffed by Irish immigrants themselves, ensured that over 200 children managed to escape the flames unharmed. According to historian James M. McPherson's 2001 estimates, the toll of this human tragedy included at least 120 deaths. During the five-day spree of violence, eleven black men fell victim to lynch mobs, pushing hundreds more to seek refuge in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, and across the river in New Jersey. By the war's end in 1865, the black population in Manhattan had plummeted to fewer than 10,000 residents, a stark drop not seen since 1820, and symbolized the white working class's grim ascendance. Particularly horrific were the assaults at the docks, where longshoremen vented their vicious fury on black men, shaping one of the darker chapters of civil unrest in the annals of American history.

The resulting fury came to a head in 1863 with the eruption of the Draft Riots, predominantly instigated by ethnic Irish men from the working class. 

The chaos spiraled violently beyond mere dissent. Rioters lashed out first at the city’s elite, but then shockingly turned their aggression towards black New Yorkers. According to historian James M. McPherson's 2001 estimates, the toll of this human tragedy included at least 120 deaths. text_human: France: The torch relay leg in Paris, held on April 7, began on the first level of the Eiffel Tower and finished at the Stade Charléty. The relay was initially supposed to cover 28 km, but it was shortened at the demand of Chinese officials following widespread protests by pro-Tibet and human rights activists, who repeatedly attempted to disrupt, hinder or halt the procession. A scheduled ceremony at the town hall was cancelled at the request of the Chinese authorities, and, also at the request of Chinese authorities, the torch finished the relay by bus instead of being carried by athletes. Paris City officials had announced plans to greet the Olympic flame with peaceful protest when the torch was to reach the French capital. The city government attached a banner reading "Paris defends human rights throughout the world" to the City Hall, in an attempt to promote values "of all humanity and of human rights." Members from Reporters Without Borders turned out in large numbers to protest. An estimated 3,000 French police protected the Olympic torch relay as it departed from the Eiffel Tower and criss-crossed Paris amid threat of protests. Widespread pro-Tibet protests, including an attempt by more than one demonstrator to extinguish the flame with water or fire extinguishers, prompted relay authorities to put out the flame five times (according to the police authorities in Paris) and load the torch onto a bus, at the demand of Chinese officials. This was later denied by the Chinese Ministry of Foreign Affairs, despite video footage broadcast by French television network France 2 which showed Chinese flame attendants extinguishing the torch. Backup flames are with the relay at all times to relight the torch. French judoka and torchbearer David Douillet expressed his annoyance at the Chinese flame attendants who extinguished the torch which he was about to hand over to Teddy Riner: "I understand they're afraid of everything, but this is just annoying. They extinguished the flame despite the fact that there was no risk, and they could see it and they knew it. I don't know why they did it."

A ceremony at the town hall was canceled at the Chinese authorities' request, and the torch concluded its journey by bus rather than with athletes running. Paris city officials had planned peaceful protests upon the torch's arrival, displaying a banner at City Hall declaring, "Paris defends human rights throughout the world," to advocate for global human rights values. Members of Reporters Without Borders joined the large protest turnout. Approximately 3,000 French police officers guarded the torch as it traversed Paris amidst protest threats. Backup flames are always available to relight the torch. French judoka and torchbearer David Douillet voiced his frustration when Chinese attendants extinguished the torch as he was about to pass it to Teddy Riner: "I understand they're afraid of everything, but this is just annoying. They extinguished the flame, although there was no risk, and they were aware of it. I don't know why they did it."
text_ai_humanized: On the brisk morning of April 7, Paris became the stage for a dramatic leg of the torch relay, starting majestically from the first tier of the iconic Eiffel Tower and planned to conclude at Stade Charléty. However, the route, originally set to stretch 28 kilometers, faced abrupt modifications. Chinese officials intervened to shorten it, spurred by a storm of protests from fervent supporters of Tibet and advocates for human rights seeking to interrupt the event. Adding to the tension, a ceremonial event slated for the town hall had to be scrapped, again at the behest of Chinese authorities. Instead of athletes gracefully carrying the flame to its final destination, the torch ended its journey on a bus. Despite the changes, Paris city officials intended to stage peaceful demonstrations, draping a banner across City Hall with the empowering words: "Paris defends human rights throughout the world." Their goal was to underscore universal values tied to human rights. Interestingly, Reporters Without Borders members mingled with the sizeable crowd of demonstrators. With about 3,000 French police officers standing vigilant, the torch meandered through Paris amidst looming protest threats. The city witnessed fervent pro-Tibet demonstrations, with activists attempting to douse the flame using water or extinguishers, which resulted in the torch being extinguished—as confirmed by Paris police—five times. In response, the relay authorities placed it on a bus, an act pushed by Chinese officials yet paradoxically denied by the Chinese Ministry of Foreign Affairs, even as France 2 aired footage of the flame being extinguished by Chinese attendants. But fret not, as backup flames—always on standby—ensured the torch could be reignited. David Douillet, a French judoka and torchbearer, couldn't hide his dissatisfaction when the flame was snuffed out just as he prepared to hand it off to Teddy Riner. Voicing his dismay, Douillet remarked, "I understand they're afraid of everything, but this is just annoying. They extinguished the flame, although there was no risk, and they were aware of it. I don't know why they did it." His words captured the oddity of the moment, emphasizing the perplexing shifts that clouded an event meant to unify.

On the brisk morning of April 7, Paris became the stage for a dramatic leg of the torch relay, starting majestically from the first tier of the iconic Eiffel Tower and planned to conclude at Stade Charléty. However, the route, originally set to stretch 28 kilometers, faced abrupt modifications. Chinese officials intervened to shorten it, spurred by a storm of protests from fervent supporters of Tibet and advocates for human rights seeking to interrupt the event.

Adding to the tension, a ceremonial event slated for the town hall had to be scrapped, again at the behest of Chinese authorities. Instead of athletes gracefully carrying the flame to its final destination, the torch ended its journey on a bus. Despite the changes, Paris city officials intended to stage peaceful demonstrations, draping a banner across City Hall with the empowering words: "Paris defends human rights throughout the world." Their goal was to underscore universal values tied to human rights.

Interestingly, Reporters Without Borders members mingled with the sizeable crowd of demonstrators. With about 3,000 French police officers standing vigilant, the torch meandered through Paris amidst looming protest threats. The city witnessed fervent pro-Tibet demonstrations, with activists attempting to douse the flame using water or extinguishers, which resulted in the torch being extinguished—as confirmed by Paris police—five times. In response, the relay authorities placed it on a bus, an act pushed by Chinese officials yet paradoxically denied by the Chinese Ministry of Foreign Affairs, even as France 2 aired footage of the flame being extinguished by Chinese attendants.

But fret not, as backup flames—always on standby—ensured the torch could be reignited. David Douillet, a French judoka and torchbearer, couldn't hide his dissatisfaction when the flame was snuffed out just as he prepared to hand it off to Teddy Riner. Voicing his dismay, Douillet remarked, "I understand they're afraid of everything, but this is just annoying. They extinguished the flame, although there was no risk, and they were aware of it. I don't know why they did it." His words captured the oddity of the moment, emphasizing the perplexing shifts that clouded an event meant to unify.

text_human: Israel's Supreme Court is at the head of the court system in the State of Israel. It is the highest judicial instance. The Supreme Court sits in Jerusalem. The area of its jurisdiction is the entire State. A ruling of the Supreme Court is binding upon every court, other than the Supreme Court itself. The Israeli supreme court is both an appellate court and the high court of justice. As an appellate court, the Supreme Court considers cases on appeal (both criminal and civil) on judgments and other decisions of the District Courts. It also considers appeals on judicial and quasi-judicial decisions of various kinds, such as matters relating to the legality of Knesset elections and disciplinary rulings of the Bar Association. As the High Court of Justice (Hebrew: Beit Mishpat Gavoha Le'Zedek בית משפט גבוה לצדק; also known by its initials as Bagatz בג"ץ), the Supreme Court rules as a court of first instance, primarily in matters regarding the legality of decisions of State authorities: Government decisions, those of local authorities and other bodies and persons performing public functions under the law, and direct challenges to the constitutionality of laws enacted by the Knesset. The court has broad discretionary authority to rule on matters in which it considers it necessary to grant relief in the interests of justice, and which are not within the jurisdiction of another court or tribunal. The High Court of Justice grants relief through orders such as injunction, mandamus and Habeas Corpus, as well as through declaratory judgments. The Supreme Court can also sit at a further hearing on its own judgment. In a matter on which the Supreme Court has ruled - whether as a court of appeals or as the High Court of Justice - with a panel of three or more justices, it may rule at a further hearing with a panel of a larger number of justices. A further hearing may be held if the Supreme Court makes a ruling inconsistent with a previous ruling or if the Court deems that the importance, difficulty or novelty of a ruling of the Court justifies such hearing. The Supreme Court also holds the unique power of being able to order "trial de novo" (a retrial).
text_ai_base: Israel's Supreme Court stands at the apex of the country's judicial system, serving as the highest court in the nation. Located in Jerusalem, its jurisdiction encompasses the entire State of Israel. Its rulings are binding on all other courts, except itself. The Supreme Court functions as both an appellate court and the High Court of Justice. As an appellate court, it handles appeals concerning decisions from District Courts in both criminal and civil cases, and reviews various legal and quasi-legal decisions, including those related to Knesset elections and disciplinary actions by the Bar Association. As the High Court of Justice (Hebrew: Beit Mishpat Gavoha Le'Zedek בית משפט גבוה לצדק; commonly referred to by its initials, Bagatz בג"ץ), it serves as a court of first instance, addressing the legality of actions taken by state authorities, government, local authorities, and others performing public duties. It also hears direct challenges to the constitutionality of laws passed by the Knesset. The court possesses wide discretionary power to intervene in matters requiring justice when no other court or tribunal has jurisdiction. The High Court of Justice provides relief through orders like injunctions, mandamus, and Habeas Corpus, along with declaratory judgments. The Supreme Court can also conduct a further hearing on its previous rulings. If a decision, whether rendered as an appellate court or as the High Court of Justice, is made by a panel of three or more justices, a further hearing may be convened with an expanded panel. Such a hearing is warranted if the ruling conflicts with prior decisions or if its importance, complexity, or novelty demands reevaluation. Additionally, the Supreme Court has the exceptional authority to order a "trial de novo" (a retrial).
text_ai_humanized: Nestled in the heart of Jerusalem, Israel’s Supreme Court stands as the pinnacle of the country’s judicial hierarchy. Charged with the ultimate judicial authority, it exercises a binding influence over all other courts—except itself. This esteemed institution functions multifacetedly, serving both as the nation’s appellate court and as the High Court of Justice. When acting in its appellate capacity, the Supreme Court reviews appeals against decisions handed down by District Courts in cases both criminal and civil. Beyond this, it tackles an array of legal and quasi-legal disputes, such as contentious Knesset election issues and disciplinary matters involving the Bar Association. Meanwhile, under its guise as the High Court of Justice, known in Hebrew as Beit Mishpat Gavoha Le'Zedek (בית משפט גבוה לצדק) and often referred to by its shorthand, Bagatz (בג"ץ), it wears another critical hat. Here, it is the court of first instance, scrutinizing the legality of actions undertaken by state authorities, local government, and others engaged in public service, even weighing in on the constitutionality of Knesset-passed laws. The court's wide-reaching discretionary power frequently allows it to wade into matters demanding justice where no other legal body can tread. Remedies proffered by the High Court include, but aren’t limited to, injunctions, mandamus, writs of habeas corpus, and declaratory judgments. Intriguingly, it possesses the capacity to revisit its own verdicts. If a ruling emerges from a panel of three or more justices, further hearings are possible, often with a larger bench. This occurs particularly when a decision contradicts earlier rulings or when the resolution is deemed significant, complex, or unprecedented in nature. Adding another layer to its exceptional powers, the Supreme Court holds the rare authority to mandate a "trial de novo," essentially initiating a retrial. This robust system underscores the Court's pivotal role in shaping Israeli law and protecting its democratic fabric.

text_human: In addition to the classical restaurants, Paris has several other kinds of traditional eating places. The café arrived in Paris in the 17th century, when the beverage was first brought from Turkey, and by the 18th century Parisian cafés were centres of the city's political and cultural life. The Cafe Procope on the Left Bank dates from this period. In the 20th century, the cafés of the Left Bank, especially Café de la Rotonde and Le Dôme Café in Montparnasse and Café de Flore and Les Deux Magots on Boulevard Saint Germain, all still in business, were important meeting places for painters, writers and philosophers. A bistro is a type of eating place loosely defined as a neighbourhood restaurant with a modest decor and prices and a regular clientele and a congenial atmosphere. Its name is said to have come in 1814 from the Russian soldiers who occupied the city; "bistro" means "quickly" in Russian, and they wanted their meals served rapidly so they could get back their encampment. Real bistros are increasingly rare in Paris, due to rising costs, competition from cheaper ethnic restaurants, and different eating habits of Parisian diners. A brasserie originally was a tavern located next to a brewery, which served beer and food at any hour. Beginning with the Paris Exposition of 1867; it became a popular kind of restaurant which featured beer and other beverages served by young women in the national costume associated with the beverage, particular German costumes for beer. Now brasseries, like cafés, serve food and drinks throughout the day.

text_human: Chapter XI deals with evidence from biogeography, starting with the observation that differences in flora and fauna from separate regions cannot be explained by environmental differences alone; South America, Africa, and Australia all have regions with similar climates at similar latitudes, but those regions have very different plants and animals. The species found in one area of a continent are more closely allied with species found in other regions of that same continent than to species found on other continents. Darwin noted that barriers to migration played an important role in the differences between the species of different regions. The coastal sea life of the Atlantic and Pacific sides of Central America had almost no species in common even though the Isthmus of Panama was only a few miles wide. His explanation was a combination of migration and descent with modification. He went on to say: "On this principle of inheritance with modification, we can understand how it is that sections of genera, whole genera, and even families are confined to the same areas, as is so commonly and notoriously the case." Darwin explained how a volcanic island formed a few hundred miles from a continent might be colonised by a few species from that continent. These species would become modified over time, but would still be related to species found on the continent, and Darwin observed that this was a common pattern. Darwin discussed ways that species could be dispersed across oceans to colonise islands, many of which he had investigated experimentally.
text_ai_base: Chapter XI explores biogeographical evidence, beginning with the observation that differences in flora and fauna across regions cannot be solely attributed to environmental factors. Within a continent, species tend to be more closely related to those in different areas of the same continent rather than to species on other continents. Darwin highlighted the significant role that migration barriers play in the unique species of various regions. For instance, the coastal marine life on the Atlantic and Pacific sides of Central America had almost no species in common, despite being divided by the narrow Isthmus of Panama. He explained these differences through the concepts of migration and descent with modification, stating: "On this principle of inheritance with modification, we can understand how sections of genera, entire genera, and even families are confined to the same areas, as is so often observed." Darwin further explained that a volcanic island emerging a few hundred miles from a continent could be colonized by a few species from that continent. These species would evolve over time but remain related to their continental counterparts, a pattern he frequently noted. Additionally, Darwin explored various methods of how species might disperse across oceans to colonize islands, many of which he investigated experimentally.
text_ai_humanized: Chapter XI delves into the intriguing question of how plant and animal species vary so dramatically across different regions, a puzzle not resolved simply by looking at the environment. Even when climates and latitudes are strikingly similar, as with South America, Africa, and Australia, the natural inhabitants are startlingly distinct. Interestingly, within any one continent, species are more closely related to each other than to those on other continents. Darwin, pondering this phenomenon, emphasized the profound impact of migratory barriers on the distinctiveness of regional species. A fascinating case in point is the coastal marine populations on either side of the Isthmus of Panama. Although they are separated by only a narrow strip of land, the Atlantic and Pacific marine ecosystems have little overlap in species. To unravel this mystery, Darwin proposed the concepts of migration and descent with modification. He mused, "On this principle of inheritance with modification, we can understand how sections of genera, entire genera, and even families are confined to the same areas, as is so often observed." Darwin added some thought-provoking scenarios, such as a volcanic island emerging a few hundred miles from a continent. This new island might soon be colonized by a handful of wandering species from the continent, which, over time, would evolve yet still resemble their mainland relatives—a pattern he found repeated in nature. Moreover, he engaged in some experimental exploration into how species could travel vast oceanic expanses to colonize islands, demonstrating the diverse ways in which life finds a foothold in seemingly isolated places. It’s clear that these reflections on biogeography highlight the complex and fascinating patterns of life that exist on our planet, continually shaping Darwin’s groundbreaking insights into the mechanisms of evolution.

text_human: The College Dropout was eventually issued by Roc-A-Fella in February 2004, shooting to number two on the Billboard 200 as his debut single, "Through the Wire" peaked at number fifteen on the Billboard Hot 100 chart for five weeks. "Slow Jamz", his second single featuring Twista and Jamie Foxx, became an even bigger success: it became the three musicians' first number one hit. The College Dropout received near-universal critical acclaim from contemporary music critics, was voted the top album of the year by two major music publications, and has consistently been ranked among the great hip-hop works and debut albums by artists. "Jesus Walks", the album's fourth single, perhaps exposed West to a wider audience; the song's subject matter concerns faith and Christianity. The song nevertheless reached the top 20 of the Billboard pop charts, despite industry executives' predictions that a song containing such blatant declarations of faith would never make it to radio. The College Dropout would eventually be certified triple platinum in the US, and garnered West 10 Grammy nominations, including Album of the Year, and Best Rap Album (which it received). During this period, West also founded GOOD Music, a record label and management company that would go on to house affiliate artists and producers, such as No I.D. and John Legend. At the time, the focal point of West's production style was the use of sped-up vocal samples from soul records. However, partly because of the acclaim of The College Dropout, such sampling had been much copied by others; with that overuse, and also because West felt he had become too dependent on the technique, he decided to find a new sound.

text_human: These different explorations of 'identity' demonstrate how difficult a concept it is to pin down. Since identity is a virtual thing, it is impossible to define it empirically. Discussions of identity use the term with different meanings, from fundamental and abiding sameness, to fluidity, contingency, negotiated and so on. Brubaker and Cooper note a tendency in many scholars to confuse identity as a category of practice and as a category of analysis (Brubaker & Cooper 2000, p. 5). Indeed, many scholars demonstrate a tendency to follow their own preconceptions of identity, following more or less the frameworks listed above, rather than taking into account the mechanisms by which the concept is crystallised as reality. In this environment, some analysts, such as Brubaker and Cooper, have suggested doing away with the concept completely (Brubaker & Cooper 2000, p. 1). Others, by contrast, have sought to introduce alternative concepts in an attempt to capture the dynamic and fluid qualities of human social self-expression. Hall (1992, 1996), for example, suggests treating identity as a process, to take into account the reality of diverse and ever-changing social experience. Some scholars have introduced the idea of identification, whereby identity is perceived as made up of different components that are 'identified' and interpreted by individuals. The construction of an individual sense of self is achieved by personal choices regarding who and what to associate with. Such approaches are liberating in their recognition of the role of the individual in social interaction and the construction of identity.
text_ai_base: Explorations of 'identity' reveal the concept's complexity and elusive nature. Being virtual, identity cannot be empirically defined. The term 'identity' carries various meanings in discussions, ranging from stable sameness to changeable, contingent aspects subject to negotiation. Brubaker and Cooper highlight that many scholars often blur the lines between viewing identity as a practical category and an analytical one (Brubaker & Cooper 2000, p. 5). Indeed, researchers frequently rely on their preconceived notions of identity, adhering to established frameworks, rather than focusing on how identity manifests in reality. In this context, some analysts, including Brubaker and Cooper, propose abandoning the concept altogether (Brubaker & Cooper 2000, p. 1). Conversely, others suggest alternative ideas to better capture the dynamic and fluid nature of human social expression. Hall (1992, 1996), for instance, advocates understanding identity as a process to reflect diverse and evolving social experiences. Additionally, some scholars present the notion of identification, where identity comprises various elements 'identified' and interpreted by individuals. This personal construction of self is influenced by choices about affiliations and associations. These approaches are empowering, recognizing the individual's role in social interactions and identity formation.
text_ai_humanized: When pondering 'identity,' one finds it to be a concept both beguiling and hard to pin down. It's intangible—something you can't quite wrap your fingers around and slap a definitive label on. The term itself is a chameleon, shifting in discussions from a sense of unwavering consistency to aspects that are adaptable and subject to ongoing negotiation. Brubaker and Cooper shine a light on the tendency of scholars to muddle the waters between using identity as a practical concept versus an analytical tool (2000, p. 5). Remarkably, researchers often cling to preconceived notions, sticking to tried-and-true frameworks instead of examining how identity truly unfolds in the real world. There’s a camp, including Brubaker and Cooper themselves, who provocatively suggest we might be better off ditching the identity concept altogether (2000, p. 1). Yet, others propose fresh paradigms to capture the swirling, unpredictable dance of human social expression. Hall, a thought leader in the field (1992, 1996), champions perceiving identity as a dynamic process, one that accommodates the myriad nuances of social experiences as they evolve. Moreover, some scholars pivot towards 'identification,' focusing on how identity is pieced together from elements individuals recognize and interpret personally. It's about how we craft our sense of self through deliberate choices regarding our affiliations and connections. This perspective is intrinsically empowering, acknowledging the individual’s pivotal role in sculpting their social interactions and identity. It suggests a canvas on which we paint our lives, aware of the colors we choose and the strokes we make—a fascinating interplay where the personal intertwines with the social fabric.

text_human: In 1681, in partial repayment of a debt, Charles II of England granted William Penn a charter for what would become the Pennsylvania colony. Despite the royal charter, Penn bought the land from the local Lenape to be on good terms with the Native Americans and ensure peace for his colony. Penn made a treaty of friendship with Lenape chief Tammany under an elm tree at Shackamaxon, in what is now the city's Fishtown section. Penn named the city Philadelphia, which is Greek for brotherly love (from philos, "love" or "friendship", and adelphos, "brother"). As a Quaker, Penn had experienced religious persecution and wanted his colony to be a place where anyone could worship freely. This tolerance, far more than afforded by most other colonies, led to better relations with the local Native tribes and fostered Philadelphia's rapid growth into America's most important city. Penn planned a city on the Delaware River to serve as a port and place for government. Hoping that Philadelphia would become more like an English rural town instead of a city, Penn laid out roads on a grid plan to keep houses and businesses spread far apart, with areas for gardens and orchards. The city's inhabitants did not follow Penn's plans, as they crowded by the Delaware River, the port, and subdivided and resold their lots. Before Penn left Philadelphia for the last time, he issued the Charter of 1701 establishing it as a city. It became an important trading center, poor at first, but with tolerable living conditions by the 1750s. Benjamin Franklin, a leading citizen, helped improve city services and founded new ones, such as fire protection, a library, and one of the American colonies' first hospitals.

He forged a friendship treaty with Lenape chief Tammany under an elm tree at Shackamaxon, now part of the Fishtown section of the city. Penn named the city Philadelphia, deriving its name from the Greek term for brotherly love—combining "philos" (love or friendship) and "adelphos" (brother). As a Quaker who had faced religious persecution, Penn envisioned his colony as an oasis of religious freedom. This level of tolerance, surpassing most other colonies, improved relations with local Native tribes and spurred Philadelphia's rapid growth into a vital American city. Penn planned the city on the Delaware River as both a port and administrative hub. He aspired for Philadelphia to resemble an English rural town rather than a bustling city, designing roads on a grid to allow space between homes and businesses for gardens and orchards. However, the inhabitants clustered near the Delaware River and the port, subdividing and reselling their lots contrary to his plans. Before departing Philadelphia for the final time, Penn granted the Charter of 1701 which officially established it as a city. Initially poor, it developed into a significant trading center with modest living conditions by the 1750s. Prominent resident Benjamin Franklin significantly enhanced the city by improving services and founding new ones, including fire protection, a library, and one of the colonies' first hospitals.

Underscoring his intentions, Penn met Lenape chief Tammany under an elm tree at Shackamaxon, now in the vibrant Fishtown area, sealing a friendship treaty. When it came to naming the city, Penn drew inspiration from Greek, choosing 'Philadelphia', roughly translating to 'brotherly love', with roots traced to "philos" (love or friendship) and "adelphos" (brother). He greatly improved services and founded new ventures, such as fire protection, a library, and one of the nation's earliest hospitals. Franklin’s contributions undoubtedly propelled Philadelphia forward in ways few could have anticipated at the time.

text_human: There is usually an indication for a specific identification of an infectious agent only when such identification can aid in the treatment or prevention of the disease, or to advance knowledge of the course of an illness prior to the development of effective therapeutic or preventative measures. For example, in the early 1980s, prior to the appearance of AZT for the treatment of AIDS, the course of the disease was closely followed by monitoring the composition of patient blood samples, even though the outcome would not offer the patient any further treatment options. In part, these studies on the appearance of HIV in specific communities permitted the advancement of hypotheses as to the route of transmission of the virus. By understanding how the disease was transmitted, resources could be targeted to the communities at greatest risk in campaigns aimed at reducing the number of new infections. The specific serological diagnostic identification, and later genotypic or molecular identification, of HIV also enabled the development of hypotheses as to the temporal and geographical origins of the virus, as well as a myriad of other hypothesis. The development of molecular diagnostic tools have enabled physicians and researchers to monitor the efficacy of treatment with anti-retroviral drugs. Molecular diagnostics are now commonly used to identify HIV in healthy people long before the onset of illness and have been used to demonstrate the existence of people who are genetically resistant to HIV infection. Thus, while there still is no cure for AIDS, there is great therapeutic and predictive benefit to identifying the virus and monitoring the virus levels within the blood of infected individuals, both for the patient and for the community at large.
text_ai_base: Identification of an infectious agent is typically pursued when it can aid in disease treatment or prevention, or advance understanding of the illness before effective therapies or preventatives are developed. For instance, in the early 1980s, prior to AZT's introduction for AIDS treatment, the disease's progression was tracked by analyzing patient blood samples, even though this provided no immediate treatment options. These studies helped form hypotheses regarding HIV's transmission routes in specific communities. Understanding transmission allowed resources to be directed at communities most at risk, aiming to reduce new infections. Diagnostic methods, initially serological and later genotypic or molecular, facilitated hypotheses about the virus's temporal and geographical origins and many other aspects. Molecular diagnostics have enabled physicians and researchers to assess the efficacy of anti-retroviral therapy. These tools are now routinely used to identify HIV in healthy individuals well before symptoms appear and to study genetic resistance to the infection. Although a cure for AIDS remains elusive, identifying and monitoring HIV offers significant therapeutic and predictive benefits for both individual patients and communities.
text_ai_humanized: Pinning down the identity of an infectious agent is often crucial when it can steer treatment strategies or boost disease prevention efforts. Gaining such understanding is indispensable, especially before viable therapies or preventive measures have been crafted. Take the case from the early 1980s—well before AZT hit the scene for treating AIDS. Back then, patient blood samples were meticulously analyzed to track the disease’s progression, even when immediate treatments were nonexistent. This analysis was not just an exercise in futility; rather, it laid the groundwork for forming conjectures about how HIV spread among certain groups. By untangling these transmission paths, efforts could be strategically aimed at the communities in greatest peril, curbing the spread effectively. Initially, diagnostic approaches were serological. As time marched on, they evolved into genotypic and molecular methods. These advanced diagnostics unearthed insights into the virus’s history—its origins across time and geography—alongside a host of other angles. Practically speaking, molecular diagnostics have crucially empowered doctors and researchers alike to gauge how well anti-retroviral therapies are working. Nowadays, identifying HIV in otherwise healthy individuals long before symptoms erupt—and studying their genetic resilience to the virus—has become second nature. Though curing AIDS stubbornly remains a distant goal, tracking and understanding HIV has undeniably delivered substantial therapeutic and predictive virtues, both on personal and community levels.

Pinning down the identity of an infectious agent is often crucial when it can steer treatment strategies or boost disease prevention efforts. Gaining such understanding is indispensable, especially before viable therapies or preventive measures have been crafted. Take the case from the early 1980s—well before AZT hit the scene for treating AIDS. Back then, patient blood samples were meticulously analyzed to track the disease’s progression, even when immediate treatments were nonexistent. This analysis was not just an exercise in futility; rather, it laid the groundwork for forming conjectures about how HIV spread among certain groups. By untangling these transmission paths, efforts could be strategically aimed at the communities in greatest peril, curbing the spread effectively.

These advanced diagnostics unearthed insights into the virus’s history—its origins across time and geography—alongside a host of other angles. Nowadays, identifying HIV in otherwise healthy individuals long before symptoms erupt—and studying their genetic resilience to the virus—has become second nature. text_human: In June 2013, West and television personality Kim Kardashian announced the birth of their first child, North. In October 2013, the couple announced their engagement to widespread media attention. November 2013, West stated that he was beginning work on his next studio album, hoping to release it by mid-2014, with production by Rick Rubin and Q-Tip. In December 2013, Adidas announced the beginning of an official apparel collaboration with West, to be premiered the following year. In May 2014, West and Kardashian were married in a private ceremony in Florence, Italy, with a variety of artists and celebrities in attendance. West released a single, "Only One", featuring Paul McCartney, on December 31, 2014. "FourFiveSeconds", a single jointly produced with Rihanna and McCartney, was released in January 2015. West also appeared on the Saturday Night Live 40th Anniversary Special, where he premiered a new song entitled "Wolves", featuring Sia Furler and fellow Chicago rapper, Vic Mensa. In February 2015, West premiered his clothing collaboration with Adidas, entitled Yeezy Season 1, to generally positive reviews. This would include West's Yeezy Boost sneakers. In March 2015, West released the single "All Day" featuring Theophilus London, Allan Kingdom and Paul McCartney. West performed the song at the 2015 BRIT Awards with a number of US rappers and UK grime MC's including: Skepta, Wiley, Novelist, Fekky, Krept & Konan, Stormzy, Allan Kingdom, Theophilus London and Vic Mensa. He would premiere the second iteration of his clothing line, Yeezy Season 2, in September 2015 at New York Fashion Week.

text_human: The mandolin has been used extensively in the traditional music of England and Scotland for generations. Simon Mayor is a prominent British player who has produced six solo albums, instructional books and DVDs, as well as recordings with his mandolin quartet the Mandolinquents. The instrument has also found its way into British rock music. The mandolin was played by Mike Oldfield (and introduced by Vivian Stanshall) on Oldfield's album Tubular Bells, as well as on a number of his subsequent albums (particularly prominently on Hergest Ridge (1974) and Ommadawn (1975)). It was used extensively by the British folk-rock band Lindisfarne, who featured two members on the instrument, Ray Jackson and Simon Cowe, and whose "Fog on the Tyne" was the biggest selling UK album of 1971-1972. The instrument was also used extensively in the UK folk revival of the 1960s and 1970s with bands such as Fairport Convention and Steeleye Span taking it on as the lead instrument in many of their songs. Maggie May by Rod Stewart, which hit No. 1 on both the British charts and the Billboard Hot 100, also featured Jackson's playing. It has also been used by other British rock musicians. Led Zeppelin's bassist John Paul Jones is an accomplished mandolin player and has recorded numerous songs on mandolin including Going to California and That's the Way; the mandolin part on The Battle of Evermore is played by Jimmy Page, who composed the song. Other Led Zeppelin songs featuring mandolin are Hey Hey What Can I Do, and Black Country Woman. Pete Townshend of The Who played mandolin on the track Mike Post Theme, along with many other tracks on Endless Wire. McGuinness Flint, for whom Graham Lyle played the mandolin on their most successful single, When I'm Dead And Gone, is another example. Lyle was also briefly a member of Ronnie Lane's Slim Chance, and played mandolin on their hit How Come. One of the more prominent early mandolin players in popular music was Robin Williamson in The Incredible String Band. Ian Anderson of Jethro Tull is a highly accomplished mandolin player (beautiful track Pussy Willow), as is his guitarist Martin Barre. The popular song Please Please Please Let Me Get What I Want by The Smiths featured a mandolin solo played by Johnny Marr. More recently, the Glasgow-based band Sons and Daughters featured the mandolin, played by Ailidh Lennon, on tracks such as Fight, Start to End, and Medicine. British folk-punk icons the Levellers also regularly use the mandolin in their songs. Current bands are also beginning to use the Mandolin and its unique sound - such as South London's Indigo Moss who use it throughout their recordings and live gigs. The mandolin has also featured in the playing of Matthew Bellamy in the rock band Muse.

Oldfield continued this trend in subsequent works like "Hergest Ridge" (1974) and "Ommadawn" (1975). The British folk-rock scene also heartily embraced the mandolin, with bands like Lindisfarne using it to craft their signature sound. Ray Jackson and Simon Cowe propelled the instrument to the forefront, driving their album "Fog on the Tyne" to the top of UK charts between 1971 and 1972. The folk revival of the 1960s and '70s saw other influential names such as Fairport Convention and Steeleye Span eagerly adopting the mandolin's unique tones. Notably, Rod Stewart’s "Maggie May," which captivated listeners across the UK, showcased Jackson’s deft mandolin work. In the realm of rock, several British music legends have deftly wielded the mandolin. John Paul Jones of Led Zeppelin displayed his prowess in "Going to California" and "That's the Way," while Jimmy Page famously strummed for "The Battle of Evermore." Other tracks like "Hey Hey What Can I Do" and "Black Country Woman" prominently feature the instrument, further embedding it into the Led Zeppelin tapestry. Then there’s Pete Townshend of The Who, who added mandolin textures to "Mike Post Theme" as well as "Endless Wire." Delving further into this instrumental lineage, McGuinness Flint's Graham Lyle handled the mandolin on "When I'm Dead And Gone" and lent his talents to Ronnie Lane’s Slim Chance with the track "How Come." Robin Williamson, of The Incredible String Band, stands out as an early pioneer in integrating the mandolin into popular music. Meanwhile, Ian Anderson and Martin Barre of Jethro Tull demonstrated their mastery on songs like "Pussy Willow." The mandolin has also found a home in the shimmering soundscapes of The Smiths, specifically in Johnny Marr’s haunting solo on "Please Please Please Let Me Get What I Want." Similarly, Glasgow's Sons and Daughters feature Ailidh Lennon’s mandolin in tracks such as "Fight," "Start to End," and "Medicine." Folk-punk outfits like the Levellers continue to weave its sound into their tunes, while newcomers such as Indigo Moss from South London breathe fresh life into its use in their live performances and studio sessions. Even Matthew Bellamy of Muse has tapped into the mandolin’s distinctive qualities, adding yet another layer to its rich history.

text_human: The fourth Digimon series, which began airing on April 7, 2002, radically departs from the previous three by focusing on a new and very different kind of evolution, Spirit Evolution, in which the human characters use their D-Tectors (this series' Digivice) to transform themselves into special Digimon called Legendary Warriors, detracting from the customary formula of having digital partners. After receiving unusual phone messages from Ophanimon (one of the three ruling Digimon alongside Seraphimon and Cherubimon) Takuya Kanbara, Koji Minamoto, Junpei Shibayama, Zoe Orimoto, Tommy Himi, and Koichi Kimura go to a subway station and take a train to the Digital World. Summoned by Ophanimon, the Digidestined realize that they must find the ten legendary spirits and stop the forces of Cherubimon from physically destroying the Digital World. After finding the ten spirits of the Legendary Warriors and defeating Mercurymon, Grumblemon, Ranamon, and Arbormon, they finally end up fighting Cherubimon hoping to foil his effort to dominate the Digital World. After the defeat of Cherubimon, the Digidestined find they must face an even greater challenge as they try to stop the Royal Knights—Dynasmon and Crusadermon—from destroying the Digital World and using the collected data to revive the original ruler of the Digital World: the tyrannical Lucemon. Ultimately the Digidestined fail in preventing Lucemon from reawakening but they do manage to prevent him from escaping into the Real World. In the final battle, all of the legendary spirits the digidestined have collected thus far merge and create Susanoomon. With this new form, the digidestined are able to effectively defeat Lucemon and save the Digital World. In general, Frontier has a much lighter tone than that of Tamers, yet remains darker than Adventure and Adventure 02.

text_ai_humanized: The fourth installment of the Digimon saga, which premiered on April 7, 2002, took audiences by surprise with its fresh twist on Digivolution. Unlike earlier series where kids teamed up with Digimon, this time around, the characters could actually become Legendary Warriors themselves, thanks to their D-Tectors—the show's uniquely designed Digivices. Spurred on by mysterious phone messages from Ophanimon, one of the key Digimon rulers alongside Seraphimon and Cherubimon, the curious band of youngsters—Takuya Kanbara, Koji Minamoto, Junpei Shibayama, Zoe Orimoto, Tommy Himi, and Koichi Kimura—embarked on a fantastical journey to the Digital World, departing via subway train of all things. Summoned by Ophanimon, they were tasked with finding the ten legendary spirits, their only hope against Cherubimon's malevolent plans. The path was fraught with battles against formidable opponents like Mercurymon, Grumblemon, Ranamon, and Arbormon. But the real challenge awaited them in the face-off with Cherubimon, a showdown crucial for the fate of the Digital World. However, their struggle was far from over. Enter the Royal Knights—Dynasmon and Crusadermon—whose sinister mission was to obliterate the Digital World to revive its ancient ruler, Lucemon. Despite their best efforts, Lucemon still managed to come back; they had to pull all the stops to prevent him from breaking into the Real World. In a final showdown bursting with tension, all the spirits combined to form Susanoomon, the ultimate force needed to vanquish Lucemon, thereby saving the Digital World in the nick of time. Digimon Frontier, as it's called, carried on the tradition of a lighter narrative tone compared to the more intense Tamers, yet it retained a darker edge than Adventure or Adventure 02. It's a story infused with adventure and suspense, underscored by themes of friendship and courage.

text_human: The political turmoil continued. John began to explore an alliance with the French king Philip II, freshly returned from the crusade. John hoped to acquire Normandy, Anjou and the other lands in France held by Richard in exchange for allying himself with Philip. John was persuaded not to pursue an alliance by his mother. Longchamp, who had left England after Walter's intervention, now returned, and argued that he had been wrongly removed as justiciar. John intervened, suppressing Longchamp's claims in return for promises of support from the royal administration, including a reaffirmation of his position as heir to the throne. When Richard still did not return from the crusade, John began to assert that his brother was dead or otherwise permanently lost. Richard had in fact been captured en route to England by the Duke of Austria and was handed over to Emperor Henry VI, who held him for ransom. John seized the opportunity and went to Paris, where he formed an alliance with Philip. He agreed to set aside his wife, Isabella of Gloucester, and marry Philip's sister, Alys, in exchange for Philip's support. Fighting broke out in England between forces loyal to Richard and those being gathered by John. John's military position was weak and he agreed to a truce; in early 1194 the king finally returned to England, and John's remaining forces surrendered. John retreated to Normandy, where Richard finally found him later that year. Richard declared that his younger brother – despite being 27 years old – was merely "a child who has had evil counsellors" and forgave him, but removed his lands with the exception of Ireland.

Yet, he did exact his dues, stripping John of his lands—save for Ireland, holding back just enough to remind him of the consequences of overreach.

text_human: A predator's effect on its prey species is hard to see in the short-term. However, if observed over a longer period of time, it is seen that the population of a predator will correlationally rise and fall with the population of its prey in a cycle similar to the boom and bust cycle of economics. If a predator overhunts its prey, the prey population will lower to numbers that are too scarce for the predators to find. This will cause the predator population to dip, decreasing the predation pressure on the prey population. The decrease in predators will allow the small number of prey left to slowly increase their population to somewhere around their previous abundance, which will allow the predator population to increase in response to the greater availability of resources. If a predator hunts its prey species to numbers too low to sustain the population in the short term, they can cause not only the extinction or extirpation of the prey but also the extinction of their own species, a phenomenon known as coextinction. This is a risk that wildlife conservationists encounter when introducing predators to prey that have not coevolved with the same or similar predators. This possibility depends largely on how well and how fast the prey species is able to adapt to the introduced predator. One way that this risk can be avoided is if the predator finds an alternative prey species or if an alternative prey species is introduced (something that ecologists and environmentalists try to avoid whenever possible). An alternative prey species would help to lift some of the predation pressure from the initial prey species, giving the population a chance to recover, however it does not guarantee that the initial prey species will be able to recover as the initial prey population may have been hunted to below sustainable numbers or to complete extinction.
text_ai_base: Observing the short-term effects of a predator on its prey species can be difficult. However, over a longer period, one can see that predator and prey populations rise and fall in a cycle akin to the economic boom and bust cycle. If predators overhunt, the prey population may decline to levels too scarce for predators to find, leading to a decline in the predator population and easing pressure on the prey. This reduction in predators allows the few remaining prey to slowly rebuild their numbers, eventually restoring their previous abundance, which in turn supports a rebound in the predator population as resources become more available. If predators drive prey species to critically low numbers, this can result in both the prey's extinction and the predators'—a phenomenon known as coextinction. Wildlife conservationists face this risk when introducing predators to environments where prey species have not coevolved with similar predators. The extent of this risk depends on the prey's ability to adapt quickly to the new predator. One way to mitigate this risk is by providing an alternative prey species, though ecologists typically avoid this strategy. An alternative prey can reduce predatory pressure on the original prey, giving them a chance to recover. However, it doesn't ensure recovery if the initial prey population has been hunted to unsustainable levels or extinction.
text_ai_humanized: Trying to track the immediate impacts a predator has on its prey isn't easy. But over time, you'll notice a rhythm, much like the ups and downs of an economic cycle. When predators get a bit too enthusiastic with their hunting, the prey numbers start thinning out, making it tough for predators to find food. As a result, predator numbers dip as well, taking some of the hunting pressure off the prey. Eventually, this lull enables the beleaguered prey to slowly regroup, repopulating until they reach thriving numbers again. This renewal, in turn, supports a resurgence in the predator population as their food becomes more abundant. Now, things can get dicey if predators push prey populations to dangerously low levels. There's a risk here of coextinction—where both the prey and their hunters might vanish for good. Wildlife conservationists must tread carefully when introducing predators into areas where native prey have no experience dealing with them. This risk hinges on how quickly the prey can adapt to this new threat. One potential solution, albeit controversial, is to provide an alternative prey for predators. This strategy can alleviate some of the pressure on the original prey, allowing them a chance at recovery. Yet, it's no silver bullet. If the prey numbers have already fallen below sustainable levels, introducing another food source doesn't necessarily spell recovery, and extinction might still rear its head.

Trying to track the immediate impacts a predator has on its prey isn't easy. But over time, you'll notice a rhythm, much like the ups and downs of an economic cycle. When predators get a bit too enthusiastic with their hunting, the prey numbers start thinning out, making it tough for predators to find food. As a result, predator numbers dip as well, taking some of the hunting pressure off the prey. Eventually, this lull enables the beleaguered prey to slowly regroup, repopulating until they reach thriving numbers again. This renewal, in turn, supports a resurgence in the predator population as their food becomes more abundant.

Now, things can get dicey if predators push prey populations to dangerously low levels. There's a risk here of coextinction—where both the prey and their hunters might vanish for good. Wildlife conservationists must tread carefully when introducing predators into areas where native prey have no experience dealing with them. This risk hinges on how quickly the prey can adapt to this new threat.

One potential solution, albeit controversial, is to provide an alternative prey for predators. This strategy can alleviate some of the pressure on the original prey, allowing them a chance at recovery. Yet, it's no silver bullet. If the prey numbers have already fallen below sustainable levels, introducing another food source doesn't necessarily spell recovery, and extinction might still rear its head.

"It may not be revolutionary, but the Super Slim PS3 is the same impressive machine in a much smaller package. text_human: Sound could be stored in either analog or digital format and in a variety of surround sound formats; NTSC discs could carry two analog audio tracks, plus two uncompressed PCM digital audio tracks, which were (EFM, CIRC, 16-bit and 44.056 kHz sample rate). PAL discs could carry one pair of audio tracks, either analog or digital and the digital tracks on a PAL disc were 16-bit 44.1 kHz as on a CD; in the UK, the term "LaserVision" is used to refer to discs with analog sound, while "LaserDisc" is used for those with digital audio. The digital sound signal in both formats are EFM-encoded as in CD. Dolby Digital (also called AC-3) and DTS—which are now common on DVD titles—first became available on LaserDisc, and Star Wars: Episode I – The Phantom Menace (1999) which was released on LaserDisc in Japan, is among the first home video releases ever to include 6.1 channel Dolby Digital EX Surround. Unlike DVDs, which carry Dolby Digital audio in digital form, LaserDiscs store Dolby Digital in a frequency modulated form within a track normally used for analog audio. Extracting Dolby Digital from a LaserDisc required a player equipped with a special "AC-3 RF" output and an external demodulator in addition to an AC-3 decoder. The demodulator was necessary to convert the 2.88 MHz modulated AC-3 information on the disc into a 384 kbit/s signal that the decoder could handle. DTS audio, when available on a disc, replaced the digital audio tracks; hearing DTS sound required only an S/PDIF compliant digital connection to a DTS decoder.

text_ai_humanized: Sound storage has had its fair share of evolution, accommodating both analog and digital formats, along with various surround sound setups. For instance, NTSC discs were capable of storing two analog audio tracks and a pair of uncompressed PCM digital audio tracks. These tracks were encoded using EFM and CIRC, with a 16-bit depth and a somewhat unusual 44.056 kHz sample rate. Meanwhile, PAL discs could manage just one set of audio tracks, be they analog or digital, with digital tracks pretty much matching CD specifications at a 16-bit 44.1 kHz rate. In the UK, the terminology is telling—what with "LaserVision" being the chosen label for discs bearing analog audio, in contrast to "LaserDisc," which indicates digital sound. Both, however, utilize EFM encoding for their digital audio tracks, mirroring the technology employed in CDs. LaserDiscs were actually pioneers of sorts, introducing Dolby Digital (also known as AC-3) and DTS, which later became staples in DVD technology. A case in point is the Japanese release of *Star Wars: Episode I – The Phantom Menace* in 1999, which was among the initial home video offerings to feature 6.1 channel Dolby Digital EX Surround. Now, here's an interesting tidbit: Unlike DVDs, which host Dolby Digital audio in a clean digital format, LaserDiscs carried it in a frequency modulated state on what was typically an analog audio track. Retrieving this Dolby Digital content from a LaserDisc wasn't straightforward; it required a player with a special "AC-3 RF" output, an external demodulator, and of course, an AC-3 decoder. The demodulator was indispensable, tasked with transforming the 2.88 MHz modulated AC-3 data from the disc into a 384 kbit/s signal digestible by the decoder. As for DTS audio, whenever it appeared on a disc, it would supplant the digital audio tracks. This switch made life slightly easier, only necessitating an S/PDIF-compliant digital connection to a DTS decoder for proper playback. So, while modern conveniences abound, the LaserDisc certainly showcased some early sophistication in home audio systems.

text_human: The result was a sequence of innovative but unpopular financial measures.[nb 10] John levied scutage payments eleven times in his seventeen years as king, as compared to eleven times in total during the reign of the preceding three monarchs. In many cases these were levied in the absence of any actual military campaign, which ran counter to the original idea that scutage was an alternative to actual military service. John maximised his right to demand relief payments when estates and castles were inherited, sometimes charging enormous sums, beyond barons' abilities to pay. Building on the successful sale of sheriff appointments in 1194, John initiated a new round of appointments, with the new incumbents making back their investment through increased fines and penalties, particularly in the forests. Another innovation of Richard's, increased charges levied on widows who wished to remain single, was expanded under John. John continued to sell charters for new towns, including the planned town of Liverpool, and charters were sold for markets across the kingdom and in Gascony.[nb 11] The king introduced new taxes and extended existing ones. The Jews, who held a vulnerable position in medieval England, protected only by the king, were subject to huge taxes; £44,000 was extracted from the community by the tallage of 1210; much of it was passed on to the Christian debtors of Jewish moneylenders.[nb 12] John created a new tax on income and movable goods in 1207 – effectively a version of a modern income tax – that produced £60,000; he created a new set of import and export duties payable directly to the crown. John found that these measures enabled him to raise further resources through the confiscation of the lands of barons who could not pay or refused to pay.
text_ai_base: John implemented a series of innovative yet unpopular financial policies. He imposed scutage payments eleven times during his seventeen-year reign, whereas the previous three monarchs combined did so eleven times in total. Often, these taxes were collected without any military campaign in place, contradicting the original purpose of scutage as an alternative to military service. John leveraged his right to demand relief payments when estates and castles were inherited, sometimes imposing exorbitant fees that exceeded the barons' ability to pay. Building on the successful sale of sheriff appointments in 1194, John initiated a new round of appointments, with appointees recouping their investment through increased fines and penalties, especially in forest areas. A practice originally expanded under Richard, increasing fees charged to widows wishing to remain unmarried, was further developed by John. He continued selling charters for new towns, including the planned town of Liverpool, and for markets throughout the kingdom and in Gascony. The king introduced new taxes and expanded existing ones, placing heavy taxes on the Jewish community, who were vulnerable in medieval England and protected solely by the king. In 1210, £44,000 was extracted from them; much of this burden was transferred to Christian debtors of Jewish lenders. In 1207, John introduced a new tax on income and movable goods—essentially a precursor to modern income tax—yielding £60,000 and established a new set of import and export duties payable directly to the crown. These measures allowed John to further raise resources by confiscating lands from barons who could not pay or refused to do so.
text_ai_humanized: In a bid to enforce a slew of financial measures that were nothing if not bold—or perhaps brazen—John introduced policies that rubbed many the wrong way. During his seventeen-year rule, he imposed scutage payments eleven times. For context, that's as often as his three predecessors managed together. These payments were frequently demanded even when no military campaign was underway, a clear departure from scutage's original intent as a substitute for joining the king's army. Beyond this, John took full advantage of his authority to demand relief payments when estates or castles were inherited. These charges frequently reached astronomical levels, straining the resources of barons who could scarcely meet them. After a precedent by Richard, John resumed selling sheriff positions, allowing those who bought them to cover their costs by ramping up fines and penalties, especially in the expansive forest regions. Notorious, too, was his expansion of fees for widows who wished to avoid remarriage, something he saw no reason to scale back. The king also continued to sell charters for new towns—Liverpool being one notable plan—and for markets not just in England but also in its territory of Gascony. Vital to his strategy of royal income was the introduction of fresh taxes. The Jewish community was particularly targeted, being heavily taxed—protected solely, somewhat ironically, by the king himself in an otherwise unforgiving society. In 1210, the staggering sum of £44,000 was extracted from the Jewish populace, indirectly pressuring Christian debtors into paying their Jewish creditors, who bore the initial burden. A key innovation of John's was a 1207 levy on income and movable goods—a sort of precursory income tax—which pulled in £60,000 and was supplemented by newly minted import and export duties, all heading straight into royal coffers. The king, seeking ever more resources, was unafraid to seize lands from barons who could either not pay these ambitious demands or opted to refuse outright.
