In a bid to enforce a slew of financial measures that were nothing if not bold—or perhaps brazen—John introduced policies that rubbed many the wrong way. During his seventeen-year rule, he imposed scutage payments eleven times. For context, that's as often as his three predecessors managed together. These payments were frequently demanded even when no military campaign was underway, a clear departure from scutage's original intent as a substitute for joining the king's army.

Beyond this, John took full advantage of his authority to demand relief payments when estates or castles were inherited. These charges frequently reached astronomical levels, straining the resources of barons who could scarcely meet them. After a precedent by Richard, John resumed selling sheriff positions, allowing those who bought them to cover their costs by ramping up fines and penalties, especially in the expansive forest regions.

Notorious, too, was his expansion of fees for widows who wished to avoid remarriage, something he saw no reason to scale back. The king also continued to sell charters for new towns—Liverpool being one notable plan—and for markets not just in England but also in its territory of Gascony. Vital to his strategy of royal income was the introduction of fresh taxes. The Jewish community was particularly targeted, being heavily taxed—protected solely, somewhat ironically, by the king himself in an otherwise unforgiving society. In 1210, the staggering sum of £44,000 was extracted from the Jewish populace, indirectly pressuring Christian debtors into paying their Jewish creditors, who bore the initial burden.

A key innovation of John's was a 1207 levy on income and movable goods—a sort of precursory income tax—which pulled in £60,000 and was supplemented by newly minted import and export duties, all heading straight into royal coffers. The king, seeking ever more resources, was unafraid to seize lands from barons who could either not pay these ambitious demands or opted to refuse outright.

text_human: Egocentrism in adolescents forms a self-conscious desire to feel important in their peer groups and enjoy social acceptance. Unlike the conflicting aspects of self-concept, identity represents a coherent sense of self stable across circumstances and including past experiences and future goals. Everyone has a self-concept, whereas Erik Erikson argued that not everyone fully achieves identity. Erikson's theory of stages of development includes the identity crisis in which adolescents must explore different possibilities and integrate different parts of themselves before committing to their beliefs. He described the resolution of this process as a stage of "identity achievement" but also stressed that the identity challenge "is never fully resolved once and for all at one point in time". Adolescents begin by defining themselves based on their crowd membership. "Clothes help teens explore new identities, separate from parents, and bond with peers." Fashion has played a major role when it comes to teenagers "finding their selves"; Fashion is always evolving, which corresponds with the evolution of change in the personality of teenagers. Adolescents attempt to define their identity by consciously styling themselves in different manners to find what best suits them. Trial and error in matching both their perceived image and the image others respond to and see, allows for the adolescent to grasp an understanding of who they are Just as fashion is evolving to influence adolescents so is the media. "Modern life takes place amidst a never-ending barrage of flesh on screens, pages, and billboards." This barrage consciously or subconsciously registers into the mind causing issues with self-image a factor that contributes to an adolescence sense of identity. Researcher James Marcia developed the current method for testing an individual's progress along these stages. His questions are divided into three categories: occupation, ideology, and interpersonal relationships. Answers are scored based on extent to which the individual has explored and the degree to which he has made commitments. The result is classification of the individual into a) identity diffusion in which all children begin, b) Identity Foreclosure in which commitments are made without the exploration of alternatives, c) Moratorium, or the process of exploration, or d) Identity Achievement in which Moratorium has occurred and resulted in commitments.
text_ai_base: Egocentrism in adolescents manifests as a self-conscious desire to feel important within their peer groups and gain social acceptance. While self-concept can encompass conflicting aspects, identity offers a coherent sense of self that remains stable across various situations, integrating past experiences and future goals. Erik Erikson proposed that everyone develops a self-concept, but not everyone fully achieves a clear identity. According to Erikson's stages of development, adolescents experience an identity crisis where they must explore various possibilities and unify different facets of themselves before settling on their beliefs. He described successful resolution of this crisis as reaching "identity achievement" but emphasized that the challenge of identity "is never fully resolved once and for all at one point in time." Adolescents initially define themselves by their associations within peer groups. Fashion plays a critical role in teenagers "finding themselves" by helping them explore new identities, differentiate from parents, and connect with peers. As fashion continually evolves, it reflects corresponding changes in adolescent personalities. Through experimenting with different styles to align their self-image with the perceptions of others, adolescents gain insight into their identities. Just as fashion evolves to influence adolescents, so does media exposure. "Modern life unfolds amidst an unending stream of images on screens, pages, and billboards," which affects self-image and, consequently, an adolescent’s sense of identity. Researcher James Marcia developed a method for assessing progress through these stages, using questions in categories like occupation, ideology, and interpersonal relationships. Responses are assessed based on exploration depth and level of commitment, classifying individuals as: a) identity diffusion, which is the initial state for all children, b) identity foreclosure, where commitments are made without exploring alternatives, c) moratorium, which involves exploration, or d) identity achievement, where exploration leads to commitments.
text_ai_humanized: Adolescents often find themselves caught up in a whirlwind of egocentrism, driven by a deep-seated desire to feel important and accepted within their social circles. The way they perceive themselves, their self-concept, might have conflicting elements, but identity offers a more coherent and stable sense of self, one that seamlessly weaves together past experiences with future aspirations. This idea was elegantly laid out by Erik Erikson, who argued that all individuals develop some level of self-concept, yet not everyone attains a fully articulated sense of identity. Now, this search for identity becomes particularly intense during the teenage years, when adolescents navigate an "identity crisis." At this stage, they are urged to explore who they are, piece together different parts of themselves, and figure out what they believe in. Erikson discussed "identity achievement" as the successful resolution of this ordeal, though he cautioned that understanding oneself is a continuous process, never truly finished. Initially, teens tend to define themselves based on their connections with peers. Here, fashion steps into the limelight—imperative to teenagers as they embark on their quest to "find themselves." Through the evolving trends, they may distance themselves from parental norms while fostering bonds with friends. And as fashion transforms, so do the personalities of adolescents, as each new style provides an opportunity for self-discovery. By dabbling in various looks to match how they'd like to be seen by others, young people start piecing together a clearer picture of who they are. But it’s not just about clothes—television screens, glossy magazines, and billboards all form a never-ending stream of images, each potentially altering a teen's self-image and thus their identity. In tandem with fashion, these media influences have profound impacts on how youngsters perceive themselves. James Marcia, a notable researcher, devised a way to quantify progress within these developmental stages. Through questions targeting areas like career aspirations, personal beliefs, and social interactions, individuals reveal how deeply they’ve explored their options and the extent of their commitments. Based on this, Marcia identified four identity statuses: identity diffusion—where many begin, that ambiguous stage devoid of clear commitments; identity foreclosure—jumping to decisions without considering alternatives; moratorium—the active phase of exploration; and ultimately, identity achievement—finding commitments through thoughtful exploration. In essence, each adolescent's journey through identity formation is unique, shaped by those fleeting fashion fads and omnipresent media messages, interwoven with their social interactions—a complex tapestry of self-discovery.

Through questions targeting areas like career aspirations, personal beliefs, and social interactions, individuals reveal how deeply they’ve explored their options and the extent of their commitments. Based on this, Marcia identified four identity statuses: identity diffusion—where many begin, that ambiguous stage devoid of clear commitments; identity foreclosure—jumping to decisions without considering alternatives; moratorium—the active phase of exploration; and ultimately, identity achievement—finding commitments through thoughtful exploration.

In essence, each adolescent's journey through identity formation is unique, shaped by those fleeting fashion fads and omnipresent media messages, interwoven with their social interactions—a complex tapestry of self-discovery.

text_human: While medieval pageants and festivals such as Corpus Christi were church-sanctioned, Carnival was also a manifestation of medieval folk culture. Many local Carnival customs are claimed to derive from local pre-Christian rituals, such as elaborate rites involving masked figures in the Swabian–Alemannic Fastnacht. However, evidence is insufficient to establish a direct origin from Saturnalia or other ancient festivals. No complete accounts of Saturnalia survive and the shared features of feasting, role reversals, temporary social equality, masks and permitted rule-breaking do not necessarily constitute a coherent festival or link these festivals. These similarities may represent a reservoir of cultural resources that can embody multiple meanings and functions. For example, Easter begins with the resurrection of Jesus, followed by a liminal period and ends with rebirth. Carnival reverses this as King Carnival comes to life, a liminal period follows before his death. Both feasts are calculated by the lunar calendar. Both Jesus and King Carnival may be seen as expiatory figures who make a gift to the people with their deaths. In the case of Jesus, the gift is eternal life in heaven and in the case of King Carnival, the acknowledgement that death is a necessary part of the cycle of life. Besides Christian anti-Judaism, the commonalities between church and Carnival rituals and imagery suggest a common root. Christ's passion is itself grotesque: Since early Christianity Christ is figured as the victim of summary judgement, is tortured and executed by Romans before a Jewish mob ("His blood is on us and on our children!" Matthew 27:24–25). Holy Week processions in Spain include crowds who vociferously insult the figure of Jesus. Irreverence, parody, degradation and laughter at a tragicomic effigy God can be seen as intensifications of the sacred order. In 1466, the Catholic Church under Pope Paul II revieved customs of the Saturnalia carnival: Jews were forced to race naked through the streets of the city of Rome. “Before they were to run, the Jews were richly fed, so as to make the race more difficult for them and at the same time more amusing for spectators. They ran… amid Rome’s taunting shrieks and peals of laughter, while the Holy Father stood upon a richly ornamented balcony and laughed heartily”, an eyewitness reports.

message.content:
In medieval times, the church gave its blessing to pageants and festivals like Corpus Christi, while Carnival was more of a grassroots celebration, thriving in the realm of medieval folk culture. Local Carnival traditions often trace their lineage to pre-Christian rites; take the intricate masked celebrations of the Swabian–Alemannic Fastnacht, for instance. Yet, the supposed roots in ancient festivals such as Saturnalia remain speculative, with little hard evidence to back a direct connection. Sure, both Saturnalia and Carnival featured feasting, masks, and role reversals, but these common threads don't weave a singular, unified origin story. It's more plausible that they draw from a broader cultural tapestry rich with varied meanings and uses.

Take Easter, with its narrative commencing with Jesus's resurrection, moving through a transitional phase, and blossoming in rebirth. Carnival, on the flip side, kicks off with the rise of King Carnival, wades through its own transition, only to conclude with his demise. Both follow the lunar calendar's rhythm, and both Jesus and King Carnival symbolize figures of sacrifice—Jesus offering eternal life, King Carnival teaching acceptance of death's inevitability. Beyond any Christian anti-Judaic themes, the church and Carnival rituals betray shared foundations. The passion of Christ is, in some aspects, starkly grotesque; early Christian texts cast Christ as a hastily judged, tortured, and crucified figure, suffering at the hands of Romans while a Jewish crowd appears to accept responsibility ("His blood is on us and on our children!" Matthew 27:24–25). Spanish Holy Week processions add another layer, where the figure of Jesus is verbally assaulted by onlookers. This mockery, irreverence, and laughter targeting a tragicomic effigy amplify the sacred order's distortions.

Flash forward to 1466, when Pope Paul II decided to revive Saturnalia's carnival customs by imposing a race on the Jewish community—naked through Rome's streets, no less. An observer reported that the Jews were generously fed before the event, making the race all the more challenging and entertaining for the spectators, with the Pope himself chuckling from his lavishly adorned balcony.

text_human: Libya's economy witnessed increasing privatization; although rejecting the socialist policies of nationalized industry advocated in The Green Book, government figures asserted that they were forging "people's socialism" rather than capitalism. Gaddafi welcomed these reforms, calling for wide-scale privatization in a March 2003 speech. In 2003, the oil industry was largely sold to private corporations, and by 2004, there was $40 billion of direct foreign investment in Libya, a sixfold rise over 2003. Sectors of Libya's population reacted against these reforms with public demonstrations, and in March 2006, revolutionary hard-liners took control of the GPC cabinet; although scaling back the pace of the changes, they did not halt them. In 2010, plans were announced that would have seen half the Libyan economy privatized over the following decade. While there was no accompanying political liberalization, with Gaddafi retaining predominant control, in March 2010, the government devolved further powers to the municipal councils. Rising numbers of reformist technocrats attained positions in the country's governance; best known was Gaddafi's son and heir apparent Saif al-Islam Gaddafi, who was openly critical of Libya's human rights record. He led a group who proposed the drafting of the new constitution, although it was never adopted, and in October 2009 was appointed to head the PSLC. Involved in encouraging tourism, Saif founded several privately run media channels in 2008, but after criticising the government they were nationalised in 2009. In October 2010, Gaddafi apologized to African leaders on behalf of Arab nations for their involvement in the African slave trade.

text_ai_humanized: Libya's economy witnessed a sweeping shift toward privatization, deviating from the socialist policies enshrined in The Green Book, which had previously endorsed nationalized industries. Even as the government abandoned these socialist ideals, officials insisted they were crafting a version of "people's socialism" rather than embracing full-fledged capitalism. In a notable move, Gaddafi lent his support to these changes, passionately advocating for extensive privatization during his speech in March 2003. That year marked a significant turning point as major portions of the oil industry were transferred to private companies, and by 2004, Libya had managed to pull in a staggering $40 billion in direct foreign investment—an amount six times larger than the previous year. Yet, not everyone welcomed these changes with open arms. In March 2006, revolutionary hard-liners made their way into the GPC cabinet, determined to halt the rapid pace of reform. While they succeeded in slowing things down a bit, they couldn't entirely derail the process. Fast forward to 2010, the government boldly announced plans to privatize half of Libya's economy over the coming decade. All this economic reshuffling happened without much political liberalization, as Gaddafi retained a tight grip on power. Nonetheless, March 2010 saw a slight shift when the government delegated more authority to municipal councils. Reformist technocrats gained a foothold during these times. Among them was Saif al-Islam Gaddafi, Gaddafi’s son, who wasn't shy about criticizing Libya’s less-than-stellar human rights record. Saif took charge of pushing for a new constitution, although these efforts never bore fruit. Notably, in October 2009, he ascended to leadership of the PSLC. In his bid to revitalize the country's image, Saif promoted tourism and founded a host of private media outlets in 2008. Strangely enough, these channels later fell under national control in 2009 after Saif openly criticized the government. And then, in a move that might have surprised observers, Gaddafi issued an apology to African leaders in October 2010, acknowledging the Arab nations' involvement in the African slave trade—a gesture that left lingering questions about its long-term impact on regional relations.

message.content:
Libya's economy witnessed a sweeping shift toward privatization, deviating from the socialist policies enshrined in The Green Book, which had previously endorsed nationalized industries. Even as the government abandoned these socialist ideals, officials insisted they were crafting a version of "people's socialism" rather than embracing full-fledged capitalism. In a notable move, Gaddafi lent his support to these changes, passionately advocating for extensive privatization during his speech in March 2003. That year marked a significant turning point as major portions of the oil industry were transferred to private companies, and by 2004, Libya had managed to pull in a staggering $40 billion in direct foreign investment—an amount six times larger than the previous year.

Yet, not everyone welcomed these changes with open arms. In March 2006, revolutionary hard-liners made their way into the GPC cabinet, determined to halt the rapid pace of reform. While they succeeded in slowing things down a bit, they couldn't entirely derail the process. Fast forward to 2010, the government boldly announced plans to privatize half of Libya's economy over the coming decade. All this economic reshuffling happened without much political liberalization, as Gaddafi retained a tight grip on power. Nonetheless, March 2010 saw a slight shift when the government delegated more authority to municipal councils.

Reformist technocrats gained a foothold during these times. Among them was Saif al-Islam Gaddafi, Gaddafi’s son, who wasn't shy about criticizing Libya’s less-than-stellar human rights record. Saif took charge of pushing for a new constitution, although these efforts never bore fruit. Notably, in October 2009, he ascended to leadership of the PSLC. In his bid to revitalize the country's image, Saif promoted tourism and founded a host of private media outlets in 2008. Strangely enough, these channels later fell under national control in 2009 after Saif openly criticized the government.

And then, in a move that might have surprised observers, Gaddafi issued an apology to African leaders in October 2010, acknowledging the Arab nations' involvement in the African slave trade—a gesture that left lingering questions about its long-term impact on regional relations.

text_human: Israelites enjoyed political independence twice in ancient history, first during the periods of the Biblical judges followed by the United Monarchy.[disputed – discuss] After the fall of the United Monarchy the land was divided into Israel and Judah. The term Jew originated from the Roman "Judean" and denoted someone from the southern kingdom of Judah. The shift of ethnonym from "Israelites" to "Jews" (inhabitant of Judah), although not contained in the Torah, is made explicit in the Book of Esther (4th century BCE), a book in the Ketuvim, the third section of the Jewish Tanakh. In 587 BC Nebuchadnezzar II, King of the Neo-Babylonian Empire, besieged Jerusalem, destroyed the First Temple, and deported the most prominent citizens of Judah. In 586 BC, Judah itself ceased to be an independent kingdom, and its remaining Jews were left stateless. The Babylonian exile ended in 539 BCE when the Achaemenid Empire conquered Babylon and Cyrus the Great allowed the exiled Jews to return to Yehud and rebuild their Temple. The Second Temple was completed in 515 BCE. Yehud province was a peaceful part of the Achaemenid Empire until the fall of the Empire in c. 333 BCE to Alexander the Great. Jews were also politically independent during the Hasmonean dynasty spanning from 140 to 37 BCE and to some degree under the Herodian dynasty from 37 BCE to 6 CE. Since the destruction of the Second Temple in 70 CE, most Jews have lived in diaspora. As an ethnic minority in every country in which they live (except Israel), they have frequently experienced persecution throughout history, resulting in a population that has fluctuated both in numbers and distribution over the centuries.[citation needed]
text_ai_base: The Israelites experienced political independence twice in ancient history: first during the period of the Biblical judges, and later under the United Monarchy. After the fall of this monarchy, the land was split into two kingdoms: Israel and Judah. The term "Jew" originates from "Judean," a Roman word for someone from the southern kingdom of Judah. The ethnonym shift from "Israelites" to "Jews" is not mentioned in the Torah but is made clear in the Book of Esther, a text from the Ketuvim section of the Jewish Tanakh, written in the 4th century BCE. In 587 BCE, Nebuchadnezzar II, the King of the Neo-Babylonian Empire, besieged Jerusalem, destroyed the First Temple, and deported Judah's prominent citizens. By 586 BCE, Judah was no longer an independent kingdom, leaving its Jews stateless. The Babylonian exile ended in 539 BCE when the Achaemenid Empire conquered Babylon, and Cyrus the Great permitted the exiled Jews to return to Yehud and rebuild their Temple. The Second Temple was completed in 515 BCE. Yehud remained a peaceful part of the Achaemenid Empire until approximately 333 BCE when Alexander the Great conquered the region. Jews regained political independence during the Hasmonean dynasty from 140 to 37 BCE, and to some extent under the Herodian dynasty from 37 BCE to 6 CE. Since the Second Temple's destruction in 70 CE, most Jews have lived in the diaspora. As an ethnic minority worldwide (except in Israel), they have often faced persecution, leading to fluctuating populations and distribution over the centuries.
text_ai_humanized: Throughout ancient history, the Israelites tasted political independence twice, initially under the rule of the Biblical judges and later during the era of the United Monarchy. Following the collapse of this monarchy, the territory split into two separate kingdoms: Israel in the north and Judah in the south. Interestingly, the term "Jew" stems from "Judean," the Roman identifier for someone hailing from the southern dominion of Judah. This evolution from "Israelites" to "Jews" is not explicitly chronicled in the Torah but surfaces clearly in the Book of Esther, belonging to the Ketuvim section of the Jewish Tanakh, crafted around the 4th century BCE. In the grim year of 587 BCE, Nebuchadnezzar II, the formidable ruler of the Neo-Babylonian Empire, laid siege to Jerusalem. He wreaked havoc by demolishing the First Temple and deporting Judah's elite citizenry. By the stroke of 586 BCE, Judah stood without independence, leaving its Jewish populace stateless in a matter of months. Fast forward to 539 BCE, Cyrus the Great of the Achaemenid Empire conquered Babylon, permitting the exiled Jews to return to Yehud and begin reconstructing their cherished Temple. They eventually completed the Second Temple by 515 BCE, setting Yehud on a peaceful course within the Achaemenid sphere until about 333 BCE, when Alexander the Great seized the region, bringing another twist in history. Political autonomy later surfaced briefly during the years of the Hasmonean dynasty from 140 to 37 BCE, and somewhat during the Herodian dynasty from 37 BCE to 6 CE. Since the heart-wrenching destruction of the Second Temple in 70 CE, Jews largely dispersed into what is now known as the diaspora. Living chiefly as an ethnic minority across the globe—Israel being the notable exception—they've often been targets of persecution, which has caused shifts in their population and distribution with the tides of time.

message.content:
Throughout ancient history, the Israelites tasted political independence twice, initially under the rule of the Biblical judges and later during the era of the United Monarchy. Following the collapse of this monarchy, the territory split into two separate kingdoms: Israel in the north and Judah in the south. Interestingly, the term "Jew" stems from "Judean," the Roman identifier for someone hailing from the southern dominion of Judah. This evolution from "Israelites" to "Jews" is not explicitly chronicled in the Torah but surfaces clearly in the Book of Esther, belonging to the Ketuvim section of the Jewish Tanakh, crafted around the 4th century BCE.

In the grim year of 587 BCE, Nebuchadnezzar II, the formidable ruler of the Neo-Babylonian Empire, laid siege to Jerusalem. He wreaked havoc by demolishing the First Temple and deporting Judah's elite citizenry. By the stroke of 586 BCE, Judah stood without independence, leaving its Jewish populace stateless in a matter of months. Fast forward to 539 BCE, Cyrus the Great of the Achaemenid Empire conquered Babylon, permitting the exiled Jews to return to Yehud and begin reconstructing their cherished Temple. They eventually completed the Second Temple by 515 BCE, setting Yehud on a peaceful course within the Achaemenid sphere until about 333 BCE, when Alexander the Great seized the region, bringing another twist in history.

Political autonomy later surfaced briefly during the years of the Hasmonean dynasty from 140 to 37 BCE, and somewhat during the Herodian dynasty from 37 BCE to 6 CE. Since the heart-wrenching destruction of the Second Temple in 70 CE, Jews largely dispersed into what is now known as the diaspora. Living chiefly as an ethnic minority across the globe—Israel being the notable exception—they've often been targets of persecution, which has caused shifts in their population and distribution with the tides of time.

text_human: From his diagrams of a small number of particles interacting in spacetime, Feynman could then model all of physics in terms of the spins of those particles and the range of coupling of the fundamental forces. Feynman attempted an explanation of the strong interactions governing nucleons scattering called the parton model. The parton model emerged as a complement to the quark model developed by his Caltech colleague Murray Gell-Mann. The relationship between the two models was murky; Gell-Mann referred to Feynman's partons derisively as "put-ons". In the mid-1960s, physicists believed that quarks were just a bookkeeping device for symmetry numbers, not real particles, as the statistics of the Omega-minus particle, if it were interpreted as three identical strange quarks bound together, seemed impossible if quarks were real. The Stanford linear accelerator deep inelastic scattering experiments of the late 1960s showed, analogously to Ernest Rutherford's experiment of scattering alpha particles on gold nuclei in 1911, that nucleons (protons and neutrons) contained point-like particles that scattered electrons. It was natural to identify these with quarks, but Feynman's parton model attempted to interpret the experimental data in a way that did not introduce additional hypotheses. For example, the data showed that some 45% of the energy momentum was carried by electrically-neutral particles in the nucleon. These electrically-neutral particles are now seen to be the gluons that carry the forces between the quarks and carry also the three-valued color quantum number that solves the Omega-minus problem. Feynman did not dispute the quark model; for example, when the fifth quark was discovered in 1977, Feynman immediately pointed out to his students that the discovery implied the existence of a sixth quark, which was discovered in the decade after his death.
text_ai_base: Using diagrams to illustrate the interaction of a few particles in spacetime, Feynman developed models for all of physics based on the spins of these particles and the range of coupling among fundamental forces. He proposed the parton model to explain strong interactions in nucleon scattering, complementing the quark model advanced by his Caltech colleague, Murray Gell-Mann. The connection between the two models was unclear, with Gell-Mann mockingly calling Feynman's partons "put-ons." During the mid-1960s, many physicists considered quarks mere tools for tracking symmetry, not actual particles. This skepticism arose because the Omega-minus particle, if viewed as a bound state of three identical strange quarks, seemed theoretically impossible. However, experiments at the Stanford linear accelerator in the late 1960s, similar to Rutherford's 1911 alpha particle gold nucleus scattering, revealed that nucleons had point-like particles scattering electrons. These were naturally identified as quarks, yet Feynman's parton model aimed to interpret the findings without new hypotheses. The data indicated that about 45% of the energy momentum was carried by electrically-neutral particles within the nucleon. Today, we recognize these particles as gluons, which mediate forces between quarks and carry a three-valued color charge that resolves the Omega-minus issue. Although Feynman didn't reject the quark model, he acknowledged its implications; for instance, upon the discovery of the fifth quark in 1977, he told his students it suggested a sixth quark, which was indeed discovered a decade after his passing.
text_ai_humanized: Richard Feynman, with his knack for simplifying the complex, used diagrams to map out how particles dance and interact within spacetime. He created models that encapsulated the entirety of physics by focusing on the particles' spins and the extent to which fundamental forces interlink. Feynman's ingenuity didn't stop there; he also devised the parton model to better understand strong interactions during nucleon scattering. This theory ran parallel to the quark model, developed by Murray Gell-Mann, who worked alongside Feynman at Caltech. Despite their shared workplace, Gell-Mann wasn't entirely convinced by the parton model, even jokingly dubbing Feynman's partons as "put-ons." In the 1960s, many physicists saw quarks more as theoretical constructs to maintain symmetry rather than tangible entities. The Omega-minus particle, supposed to be made of three identical strange quarks, posed theoretical challenges that fueled this skepticism. But the late 1960s brought experiments at Stanford's linear accelerator that turned the tide. Much like Rutherford's famous 1911 experiments with alpha particles and gold foil, these studies showed that nucleons contained point-like particles causing electrons to scatter. These particles, as it turned out, aligned with what we'd come to know as quarks, although Feynman didn't jump to conclusions; his parton model sought to make sense of the observations without leaping to new hypotheses. The experiments provided striking evidence: approximately 45% of the nucleon's energy and momentum originated from electrically-neutral particles. These have since been identified as gluons, which carry a unique three-valued color charge. This elegantly solved the Omega-minus anomaly. Though Feynman didn't outright dismiss the quark model, he recognized its wider implications. For instance, when a fifth quark emerged in 1977, he predicted to his students that a sixth was lurking in the shadows—a prediction confirmed a decade after his death. Feynman's foresight yet again underscored his profound understanding and pioneering spirit in the realm of particle physics.

Richard Feynman, with his knack for simplifying the complex, used diagrams to map out how particles dance and interact within spacetime. He created models that encapsulated the entirety of physics by focusing on the particles' spins and the extent to which fundamental forces interlink. Feynman's ingenuity didn't stop there; he also devised the parton model to better understand strong interactions during nucleon scattering. This theory ran parallel to the quark model, developed by Murray Gell-Mann, who worked alongside Feynman at Caltech. Despite their shared workplace, Gell-Mann wasn't entirely convinced by the parton model, even jokingly dubbing Feynman's partons as "put-ons." 

In the 1960s, many physicists saw quarks more as theoretical constructs to maintain symmetry rather than tangible entities. The Omega-minus particle, supposed to be made of three identical strange quarks, posed theoretical challenges that fueled this skepticism. But the late 1960s brought experiments at Stanford's linear accelerator that turned the tide. Much like Rutherford's famous 1911 experiments with alpha particles and gold foil, these studies showed that nucleons contained point-like particles causing electrons to scatter. These particles, as it turned out, aligned with what we'd come to know as quarks, although Feynman didn't jump to conclusions; his parton model sought to make sense of the observations without leaping to new hypotheses.

The experiments provided striking evidence: approximately 45% of the nucleon's energy and momentum originated from electrically-neutral particles. These have since been identified as gluons, which carry a unique three-valued color charge. This elegantly solved the Omega-minus anomaly. Though Feynman didn't outright dismiss the quark model, he recognized its wider implications. For instance, when a fifth quark emerged in 1977, he predicted to his students that a sixth was lurking in the shadows—a prediction confirmed a decade after his death. Feynman's foresight yet again underscored his profound understanding and pioneering spirit in the realm of particle physics.

text_human: By August 1805, Napoleon had realized that the strategic situation had changed fundamentally. Facing a potential invasion from his continental enemies, he decided to strike first and turned his army's sights from the English Channel to the Rhine. His basic objective was to destroy the isolated Austrian armies in Southern Germany before their Russian allies could arrive. On 25 September, after great secrecy and feverish marching, 200,000 French troops began to cross the Rhine on a front of 260 km (160 mi). Austrian commander Karl Mack had gathered the greater part of the Austrian army at the fortress of Ulm in Swabia. Napoleon swung his forces to the southeast and the Grande Armée performed an elaborate wheeling movement that outflanked the Austrian positions. The Ulm Maneuver completely surprised General Mack, who belatedly understood that his army had been cut off. After some minor engagements that culminated in the Battle of Ulm, Mack finally surrendered after realizing that there was no way to break out of the French encirclement. For just 2000 French casualties, Napoleon had managed to capture a total of 60,000 Austrian soldiers through his army's rapid marching. The Ulm Campaign is generally regarded as a strategic masterpiece and was influential in the development of the Schlieffen Plan in the late 19th century. For the French, this spectacular victory on land was soured by the decisive victory that the Royal Navy attained at the Battle of Trafalgar on 21 October. After Trafalgar, Britain had total domination of the seas for the duration of the Napoleonic Wars.

Facing the threat of invasion from his continental adversaries, he opted for a preemptive strike and redirected his army's focus from the English Channel to the Rhine. His primary goal was to defeat the isolated Austrian forces in Southern Germany before their Russian allies could intervene. On September 25, under great secrecy and with intense marching, 200,000 French troops began crossing the Rhine along a 260 km (160 mi) front. Austrian commander Karl Mack had concentrated most of the Austrian army at Ulm fortress in Swabia. Napoleon maneuvered his forces southeast, executing a complex wheeling movement that outflanked the Austrian positions. This Ulm Maneuver completely caught General Mack off guard, and he realized too late that his army was surrounded. Following several minor skirmishes, which culminated in the Battle of Ulm, Mack surrendered upon recognizing the impossibility of breaking through the French encirclement. With only 2,000 French casualties, Napoleon captured 60,000 Austrian soldiers, owing to the swift marching of his army. The Ulm Campaign is widely seen as a strategic masterpiece and influenced the development of the Schlieffen Plan in the late 19th century. However, for the French, this impressive victory on land was overshadowed by the Royal Navy's decisive triumph at the Battle of Trafalgar on October 21. After Trafalgar, Britain maintained total command of the seas throughout the Napoleonic Wars.
text_ai_humanized: By the late summer of 1805, Napoleon found himself facing a markedly altered strategic landscape. With continental threats looming ominously, he made a calculated decision to shift focus away from the English Channel and target the Rhine. His main objective? To tackle the Austrian forces isolated in Southern Germany before Russia could step in and bolster them. In a move cloaked in secrecy, 200,000 French soldiers embarked on a grueling march, crossing the Rhine between September 25 and the days that followed—a vast front stretching 260 kilometers (or 160 miles, if you prefer). General Karl Mack of Austria had, intriguingly or perhaps naively, gathered the majority of his troops at the Ulm fortress in Swabia. Unperturbed, Napoleon orchestrated a daring southeast maneuver, executing a complex wheeling tactic that adeptly bypassed Austrian defenses. This Ulm Maneuver, a textbook example of military cunning, completely took Mack by surprise, leaving him with the grim realization that his forces were enveloped. What ensued were a series of minor clashes, culminating in the Battle of Ulm. Faced with the stark reality of entrapment and unable to break free, Mack capitulated, handing over 60,000 men to Napoleon, who suffered only 2,000 casualties in the process. Regarded as a strategic masterstroke, the Ulm Campaign profoundly influenced the Schlieffen Plan devised later in the 19th century. Yet, for the French, this significant triumph on land was somewhat eclipsed. If we hop over to the seas—in contrast to Napoleon's brilliant land tactics—the Royal Navy scored a definitive victory at the Battle of Trafalgar on October 21. This defeat meant that Britain firmly held dominion over the waves for the remainder of the Napoleonic conflicts, marking an indelible shift in naval power.

message.content:
By the late summer of 1805, Napoleon found himself facing a markedly altered strategic landscape. With continental threats looming ominously, he made a calculated decision to shift focus away from the English Channel and target the Rhine. His main objective? To tackle the Austrian forces isolated in Southern Germany before Russia could step in and bolster them. In a move cloaked in secrecy, 200,000 French soldiers embarked on a grueling march, crossing the Rhine between September 25 and the days that followed—a vast front stretching 260 kilometers (or 160 miles, if you prefer). 

General Karl Mack of Austria had, intriguingly or perhaps naively, gathered the majority of his troops at the Ulm fortress in Swabia. Unperturbed, Napoleon orchestrated a daring southeast maneuver, executing a complex wheeling tactic that adeptly bypassed Austrian defenses. This Ulm Maneuver, a textbook example of military cunning, completely took Mack by surprise, leaving him with the grim realization that his forces were enveloped. What ensued were a series of minor clashes, culminating in the Battle of Ulm. Faced with the stark reality of entrapment and unable to break free, Mack capitulated, handing over 60,000 men to Napoleon, who suffered only 2,000 casualties in the process. 

Regarded as a strategic masterstroke, the Ulm Campaign profoundly influenced the Schlieffen Plan devised later in the 19th century. Yet, for the French, this significant triumph on land was somewhat eclipsed. If we hop over to the seas—in contrast to Napoleon's brilliant land tactics—the Royal Navy scored a definitive victory at the Battle of Trafalgar on October 21. This defeat meant that Britain firmly held dominion over the waves for the remainder of the Napoleonic conflicts, marking an indelible shift in naval power.

text_human: But in the mid-18th century, during the French Enlightenment, a more ideological use of the term had come into use. In 1765, the author of an anonymous article in a French Enlightenment periodical spoke of "The general love of humanity ... a virtue hitherto quite nameless among us, and which we will venture to call 'humanism', for the time has come to create a word for such a beautiful and necessary thing". The latter part of the 18th and the early 19th centuries saw the creation of numerous grass-roots "philanthropic" and benevolent societies dedicated to human betterment and the spreading of knowledge (some Christian, some not). After the French Revolution, the idea that human virtue could be created by human reason alone independently from traditional religious institutions, attributed by opponents of the Revolution to Enlightenment philosophes such as Rousseau, was violently attacked by influential religious and political conservatives, such as Edmund Burke and Joseph de Maistre, as a deification or idolatry of humanity. Humanism began to acquire a negative sense. The Oxford English Dictionary records the use of the word "humanism" by an English clergyman in 1812 to indicate those who believe in the "mere humanity" (as opposed to the divine nature) of Christ, i.e., Unitarians and Deists. In this polarised atmosphere, in which established ecclesiastical bodies tended to circle the wagons and reflexively oppose political and social reforms like extending the franchise, universal schooling, and the like, liberal reformers and radicals embraced the idea of Humanism as an alternative religion of humanity. The anarchist Proudhon (best known for declaring that "property is theft") used the word "humanism" to describe a "culte, déification de l’humanité" ("worship, deification of humanity") and Ernest Renan in L’avenir de la science: pensées de 1848 ("The Future of Knowledge: Thoughts on 1848") (1848–49), states: "It is my deep conviction that pure humanism will be the religion of the future, that is, the cult of all that pertains to humanity—all of life, sanctified and raised to the level of a moral value."

An anonymous author in a 1765 French Enlightenment periodical spoke of "The general love of humanity ... a virtue hitherto quite nameless among us, and which we will venture to call 'humanism,' for the time has come to create a word for such a beautiful and necessary thing." In the latter part of the 18th century and the early 19th century, numerous grassroots philanthropic and benevolent societies emerged, focused on human betterment and spreading knowledge, some with Christian values and others without. After the French Revolution, the notion that human virtue could be cultivated solely through human reason, independent of traditional religious institutions, was championed by Enlightenment thinkers like Rousseau. This idea faced fierce criticism from influential religious and political conservatives, such as Edmund Burke and Joseph de Maistre, who saw it as a form of deification or idolization of humanity. As a result, humanism started to acquire a negative connotation. In 1812, an English clergyman used the word "humanism" to describe those who believe in the "mere humanity" of Christ, referring to Unitarians and Deists, as opposed to His divine nature. In this polarized climate, where established ecclesiastical bodies often opposed political and social reforms like extending the franchise and universal schooling, liberal reformers and radicals embraced Humanism as a new religion centered around humanity. The anarchist Proudhon, famous for his claim that "property is theft," used "humanism" to describe a "cult, deification of humanity," while Ernest Renan, in his work "L’avenir de la science: pensées de 1848" ("The Future of Knowledge: Thoughts on 1848"), asserted: "It is my deep conviction that pure humanism will be the religion of the future, that is, the cult of all that relates to humanity—sanctifying and elevating all aspects of life to the level of a moral value."
text_ai_humanized: In the bustling intellectual atmosphere of the mid-18th century French Enlightenment, a curious shift occurred around the concept of "humanism." Originally introduced with a deeper ideological slant, the term was given life by an anonymous writer in a 1765 periodical. They mused on a "general love of humanity," dubbing it "humanism," as if to christen this previously unnamed virtue with a fitting designation for something so vital and beautiful. As the latter half of the century gave way to the early 19th, a multitude of philanthropic and benevolent societies began springing up. Their purpose? The betterment of mankind and the dissemination of knowledge—some rooted in Christian doctrines, others decidedly secular. The upheaval of the French Revolution brought forth a radical notion: human virtue could grow through reason, completely apart from the influence of religious institutions. This idea found champions among Enlightenment figures, including the notable Rousseau. Yet, it wasn't without its detractors. Criticism thundered from the pens of religious and political conservatives like Edmund Burke and Joseph de Maistre, who perceived these ideas as akin to idolizing humanity itself. Consequently, humanism began to accumulate a somewhat negative reputation. Then, in 1812, an English clergyman wielded "humanism" to label those who held to the "mere humanity" of Christ—refuting His divinity—a description targeted at Unitarians and Deists. This was, to say the least, a time of polarization. Ecclesiastical authorities frequently clashed with reformers over issues like extending voting rights and establishing universal education. Within this charged climate, liberal reformers and radicals saw Humanism as not just a movement but a burgeoning religion founded on the essence of humanity. Proudhon, an anarchist with a flair for provocation, famously argued that "property is theft," and referred to humanism as a form of worship or the "deification of humanity." Similarly, Ernest Renan, in his contemplative work "L’avenir de la science: pensées de 1848" ("The Future of Knowledge: Thoughts on 1848"), proposed with profound conviction that pure humanism might serve as the religion of the future, elevating all facets related to humanity to the exalted level of moral value.

text_human: Statistically speaking, cable-borne elevators are extremely safe. Their safety record is unsurpassed by any other vehicle system. In 1998, it was estimated that approximately eight millionths of one percent (1 in 12 million) of elevator rides result in an anomaly, and the vast majority of these were minor things such as the doors failing to open. Of the 20 to 30 elevator-related deaths each year, most of them are maintenance-related — for example, technicians leaning too far into the shaft or getting caught between moving parts, and most of the rest are attributed to other kinds of accidents, such as people stepping blindly through doors that open into empty shafts or being strangled by scarves caught in the doors. In fact, prior to the September 11th terrorist attacks, the only known free-fall incident in a modern cable-borne elevator happened in 1945 when a B-25 bomber struck the Empire State Building in fog, severing the cables of an elevator cab, which fell from the 75th floor all the way to the bottom of the building, seriously injuring (though not killing) the sole occupant — the elevator operator. However, there was an incident in 2007 at a Seattle children's hospital, where a ThyssenKrupp ISIS machine-room-less elevator free-fell until the safety brakes were engaged. This was due to a flaw in the design where the cables were connected at one common point, and the kevlar ropes had a tendency to overheat and cause slipping (or, in this case, a free-fall). While it is possible (though extraordinarily unlikely) for an elevator's cable to snap, all elevators in the modern era have been fitted with several safety devices which prevent the elevator from simply free-falling and crashing. An elevator cab is typically borne by 2 to 6 (up to 12 or more in high rise installations) hoist cables or belts, each of which is capable on its own of supporting the full load of the elevator plus twenty-five percent more weight. In addition, there is a device which detects whether the elevator is descending faster than its maximum designed speed; if this happens, the device causes copper (or silicon nitride in high rise installations) brake shoes to clamp down along the vertical rails in the shaft, stopping the elevator quickly, but not so abruptly as to cause injury. This device is called the governor, and was invented by Elisha Graves Otis. In addition, a oil/hydraulic or spring or polyurethane or telescopic oil/hydraulic buffer or a combination (depending on the travel height and travel speed) is installed at the bottom of the shaft (or in the bottom of the cab and sometimes also in the top of the cab or shaft) to somewhat cushion any impact. However, In Thailand, in November 2012, a woman was killed in free falling elevator, in what was reported as the "first legally recognised death caused by a falling lift".

In 1998, it was estimated that only about one in 12 million elevator rides resulted in an issue, often minor, such as doors failing to open. Of the 20 to 30 elevator-related deaths annually, most involve maintenance accidents, such as technicians leaning too far into the shaft or being caught in moving parts. Others involve accidents like individuals stepping into open shafts or being strangled by scarves caught in doors. Before the September 11 attacks, the only known modern free-fall incident occurred in 1945 when a B-25 bomber crashed into the Empire State Building, causing an elevator car to fall from the 75th floor. The single occupant, the operator, was seriously injured but survived. In 2007, a ThyssenKrupp ISIS elevator at a Seattle children's hospital experienced a free-fall until safety brakes engaged due to a design flaw where cables connected at a single point caused overheating and slippage. While rare, a cable snap is possible. However, modern elevators are equipped with numerous safety devices to prevent free-falling. Elevators are typically supported by 2 to 6 hoist cables or belts (up to 12 or more in high-rise buildings), each capable of holding more than the elevator's full load. A device called the governor, invented by Elisha Graves Otis, detects if an elevator descends too quickly and activates brake shoes to clamp down on the shaft's vertical rails, effectively stopping the elevator without causing injury. Additional safety features, like oil/hydraulic buffers or springs, are installed to cushion impacts at shaft bottoms. Nonetheless, in November 2012, a woman in Thailand was tragically killed in a free-falling elevator, marking the first legally recognized death caused by a falling lift.
text_ai_humanized: When it comes to safety, cable-driven elevators are in a league of their own, outstripping other modes of transport. Back in 1998, the chances of encountering any issue during an elevator ride—typically something minor like malfunctioning doors—were pegged at roughly one in 12 million. Yet, among the 20 to 30 elevator-related fatalities reported each year, most incidents involved maintenance workers. Too often, these tragic events happen when technicians lean precariously into elevator shafts or become entangled in moving components. Occasionally, individuals step into open shafts, or, in bizarre scenarios, people have been strangled by scarves caught in doors. A notorious incident predates the September 11 attacks: In 1945, a B-25 bomber crashed into the Empire State Building, sending an elevator plummeting from the 75th floor. Despite the terrifying drop, the lone operator inside survived, albeit with serious injuries. Fast-forward to 2007, when a ThyssenKrupp ISIS elevator in a Seattle children's hospital experienced a dramatic free-fall before safety brakes kicked in, triggered by a design flaw that led cables to overheat and slip. Though rare, cable snaps can happen. However, the sophisticated safeguards of today’s elevators make free-falls practically impossible. Typically, elevators hang by 2 to 6 robust hoist cables or belts, and for high-rise structures, this number can climb to 12 or more. Each of these cables can support the entire load of an elevator. The key player here is the governor, brainchild of Elisha Graves Otis. It acts like an astute sentry, detecting any unsanctioned speed during a descent and deploying brake shoes to grip the shaft’s vertical rails—the elevator stops without jarring riders. Extra layers of safety, such as oil/hydraulic buffers or springs at the shaft's base, soften any impacts. Despite these advanced precautions, in November 2012, a woman suffered a fatal fall in Thailand, marking the first legally acknowledged death linked directly to a falling lift.

text_human: Valencia is a bilingual city: Valencian and Spanish are the two official languages. Spanish is official in all of Spain, whereas Valencian is official in the Valencian Country, as well as in Catalonia and the Balearic Islands, where it receives the name of Catalan. Despite the differentiated denomination, the distinct dialectal traits and political tension between Catalonia and the Valencian Country, Catalan and Valencian are mutually intelligible and are considered two varieties of the same language. Valencian has been historically repressed in favour of Spanish. The effects have been more noticeable in the city proper, whereas the language has remained active in the rural and metropolitan areas. After the Castille-Aragon unification, a Spanish-speaking elite established itself in the city. In more recent history, the establishment of Franco's military and administrative apparatus in Valencia further excluded Valencian from public life. Valencian recovered its official status, prestige and use in education after the transition to democracy in 1978. However, due to industrialisation in recent decades, Valencia has attracted immigration from other regions in Spain, and hence there is also a demographic factor for its declining social use. Due to a combination of these reasons, Valencia has become the bastion of anti-Catalan blaverism, which celebrates Valencian as merely folkloric, but rejects the existing standard which was adapted from Catalan orthography. Spanish is currently the predominant language in the city proper but, thanks to the education system, most Valencians have basic knowledge of both Spanish and Valencian, and either can be used in the city. Valencia is therefore the second biggest Catalan-speaking city after Barcelona. Institutional buildings and streets are named in Valencian. The city is also home to many pro-Valencian political and civil organisations. Furthermore, education entirely in Valencian is offered in more than 70 state-owned schools in the city, as well as by the University of Valencia across all disciplines.
text_ai_base: Valencia is a bilingual city where both Valencian and Spanish are official languages. Spanish holds official status across Spain, while Valencian is recognized in the Valencian Community, Catalonia, and the Balearic Islands, where it is known as Catalan. Despite their different names, dialectal traits, and political tensions between Catalonia and the Valencian Community, Catalan and Valencian are mutually intelligible and considered dialects of the same language. Historically, Valencian has been suppressed in favor of Spanish, especially in the city itself, although it remains active in rural and suburban areas. After the unification of Castile and Aragon, a Spanish-speaking elite settled in Valencia. In the more recent past, Franco's regime further marginalized Valencian in public life. The language regained its official status, prestige, and educational use after Spain's transition to democracy in 1978. Yet, industrialization has led to increased immigration from other Spanish regions, contributing to the decline in Valencian's social usage. These factors have made Valencia a hub of anti-Catalan blaverism, which sees Valencian as merely folkloric and rejects the Catalan-based standard orthography. Spanish is now the dominant language in the city proper, but due to the education system, most Valencians have a basic grasp of both languages, and either can be used around the city. Consequently, Valencia is the second largest Catalan-speaking city after Barcelona. Valencian is used for naming streets and institutional buildings, and the city hosts many pro-Valencian political and civil groups. Additionally, over 70 public schools in Valencia offer education entirely in Valencian, as does the University of Valencia across various disciplines.
text_ai_humanized: Valencia is a city where the echoes of dual languages resonate in daily life: both Valencian and Spanish have earned their stripes as official languages here. While Spanish is the recognized official tongue throughout Spain, Valencian holds sway in the Valencian Community, Catalonia, and the Balearic Islands, though in the latter regions, it's called Catalan. Political frictions aside, Valencian and Catalan, with their varied dialects, remain quite intelligible to one another, viewed largely as dialects of the same linguistic tradition. Going back in time, you'll find that Valencian wasn't always welcomed with open arms. Historically, it's seen its fair share of suppression in favor of Spanish, especially notable in urban Valencia. The twist came during the unification of Castile and Aragon, bringing a Spanish-speaking elite that nested itself comfortably in the city. Fast forward to the era of Franco, and the marginalization of Valencian deepened further, overshadowing the language in public spheres. Then came 1978—a pivotal year as Spain moved towards democracy. Valencian reclaimed its rightful place, regaining its official status along with newfound prestige and a spot in the educational system. Yet, as Valencia embraced industrialization, waves of immigration flooded in from other Spanish regions, slowly eroding the social fabric that was once vibrant with Valencian. This flowed into the rise of anti-Catalan blaverism, a movement that views Valencian as mere folklore, choosing to dismiss the standard orthography rooted in Catalan traditions. Today, Spanish commands the forefront in Valencia itself, with Valencians often toggling between the two languages thanks to bilingual education. It’s intriguing to note that Valencia stands as the second largest Catalan-speaking city right behind Barcelona. In a testament to Valencian's enduring presence, streets and institutional buildings proudly display their names in the Valencian tongue, and the city is home to numerous political and civil groups championing Valencian causes. Education plays its part too, with over 70 public schools dedicated to teaching in Valencian, alongside the University of Valencia offering a wide array of disciplines in the language. The city’s vibrant mix of languages paints a complex picture, capturing its dynamic social and cultural landscape.

text_human: Israel has a school life expectancy of 15.5 years and a literacy rate of 97.1% according to the United Nations. The State Education Law, passed in 1953, established five types of schools: state secular, state religious, ultra orthodox, communal settlement schools, and Arab schools. The public secular is the largest school group, and is attended by the majority of Jewish and non-Arab pupils in Israel. Most Arabs send their children to schools where Arabic is the language of instruction. Education is compulsory in Israel for children between the ages of three and eighteen. Schooling is divided into three tiers – primary school (grades 1–6), middle school (grades 7–9), and high school (grades 10–12) – culminating with Bagrut matriculation exams. Proficiency in core subjects such as mathematics, the Hebrew language, Hebrew and general literature, the English language, history, Biblical scripture and civics is necessary to receive a Bagrut certificate. In Arab, Christian and Druze schools, the exam on Biblical studies is replaced by an exam on Muslim, Christian or Druze heritage. Christian Arabs are one of the most educated groups in Israel. Maariv have describe the Christian Arabs sectors as "the most successful in education system", since Christian Arabs fared the best in terms of education in comparison to any other group receiving an education in Israel. Israeli children from Russian-speaking families have a higher bagrut pass rate at high-school level. Although amongst immigrant children born in the FSU, the bagrut pass rate is highest amongst those families from Western FSU states of Russia, Ukraine, Belarus and Moldova (at 62.6%), and lower amongst those from Central Asian and Caucasian FSU states. In 2003, over half of all Israeli twelfth graders earned a matriculation certificate.

text_human: Knowledge, for Popper, was objective, both in the sense that it is objectively true (or truthlike), and also in the sense that knowledge has an ontological status (i.e., knowledge as object) independent of the knowing subject (Objective Knowledge: An Evolutionary Approach, 1972). He proposed three worlds: World One, being the physical world, or physical states; World Two, being the world of mind, or mental states, ideas, and perceptions; and World Three, being the body of human knowledge expressed in its manifold forms, or the products of the second world made manifest in the materials of the first world (i.e., books, papers, paintings, symphonies, and all the products of the human mind). World Three, he argued, was the product of individual human beings in exactly the same sense that an animal path is the product of individual animals, and that, as such, has an existence and evolution independent of any individual knowing subjects. The influence of World Three, in his view, on the individual human mind (World Two) is at least as strong as the influence of World One. In other words, the knowledge held by a given individual mind owes at least as much to the total accumulated wealth of human knowledge, made manifest, as to the world of direct experience. As such, the growth of human knowledge could be said to be a function of the independent evolution of World Three. Many contemporary philosophers, such as Daniel Dennett, have not embraced Popper's Three World conjecture, due mostly, it seems, to its resemblance to mind-body dualism.
text_ai_base: For Popper, knowledge was objective in two ways: it was considered objectively true or truthlike, and it had a separate ontological status, existing independently of the knowing subject ("Objective Knowledge: An Evolutionary Approach," 1972). He identified three distinct worlds: World One, the physical world comprising physical states; World Two, the mental world, encompassing ideas, perceptions, and mental states; and World Three, which is the vast body of human knowledge manifested through the creations derived from World Two, materialized in the artifacts of World One, such as books, paintings, or symphonies. Popper argued that World Three, much like animal paths are the results of the actions of individual animals, is the product of human activity and evolves independently of individual minds. He believed that World Three impacts the human mind (World Two) as strongly as the physical world (World One) does. Thus, an individual's knowledge is influenced significantly by the accumulation of human knowledge as much as by direct experience. Consequently, the evolution of human knowledge depends on the independent development of World Three. Despite Popper’s insights, many modern philosophers, like Daniel Dennett, have not accepted his Three Worlds theory, largely due to its similarities to mind-body dualism.
text_ai_humanized: In Popper's view, knowledge stands objective in two principal ways: firstly, as being objectively true or resembling truth, and secondly, due to its independent ontological status, separate from the person who knows it (“Objective Knowledge: An Evolutionary Approach,” 1972). He framed this concept through his idea of three distinct worlds. There's World One, which is the physical realm filled with material states; World Two, the domain of our minds, filled with thoughts, perceptions, and mental conditions; and finally, World Three, representing the vast collection of human knowledge. This third world, birthed by the discoveries and creativity of the human mind, is tangible through the creations of World One—think paintings, novels, or music. Popper saw World Three as a product of human endeavor, akin to how trails are carved out by animals traversing the land. Interestingly, he believed it developed quite apart from individual minds and could influence human thought (World Two) just as intensely as the physical environment (World One) does. In this way, what we know is shaped not only by our personal experiences but also heavily by the accumulated wisdom of humanity. This notion suggests that the progression of our understanding leans on the independent growth of World Three. However, many contemporary philosophers, including Daniel Dennett, haven’t fully embraced Popper’s Three Worlds concept, possibly because of its echoes of mind-body dualism, a perspective that tends to stir debate.

text_human: The Space Race was a 20th-century competition between two Cold War rivals, the Soviet Union (USSR) and the United States (US), for supremacy in spaceflight capability. It had its origins in the missile-based nuclear arms race between the two nations that occurred following World War II, enabled by captured German rocket technology and personnel. The technological superiority required for such supremacy was seen as necessary for national security, and symbolic of ideological superiority. The Space Race spawned pioneering efforts to launch artificial satellites, unmanned space probes of the Moon, Venus, and Mars, and human spaceflight in low Earth orbit and to the Moon. The competition began on August 2, 1955, when the Soviet Union responded to the US announcement four days earlier of intent to launch artificial satellites for the International Geophysical Year, by declaring they would also launch a satellite "in the near future". The Soviet Union beat the US to this, with the October 4, 1957 orbiting of Sputnik 1, and later beat the US to the first human in space, Yuri Gagarin, on April 12, 1961. The Space Race peaked with the July 20, 1969 US landing of the first humans on the Moon with Apollo 11. The USSR tried but failed manned lunar missions, and eventually cancelled them and concentrated on Earth orbital space stations. A period of détente followed with the April 1972 agreement on a co-operative Apollo–Soyuz Test Project, resulting in the July 1975 rendezvous in Earth orbit of a US astronaut crew with a Soviet cosmonaut crew.
text_ai_base: The Space Race was a mid-20th-century competition between Cold War adversaries, the Soviet Union (USSR) and the United States (US), to achieve superior spaceflight capabilities. It evolved from the missile-based nuclear arms race that emerged after World War II, fueled by captured German rocket technology and expertise. Technological dominance in space was viewed as crucial for national security and an indicator of ideological supremacy. The race prompted innovative attempts to launch artificial satellites, send unmanned probes to the Moon, Venus, and Mars, and achieve human spaceflight in low Earth orbit and to the Moon. The rivalry began on August 2, 1955, when the Soviet Union announced their intent to launch a satellite, in response to the US declaring its plans to do the same for the International Geophysical Year just four days earlier. The Soviets outpaced the US by launching Sputnik 1 on October 4, 1957, and later sent the first human, Yuri Gagarin, into space on April 12, 1961. The Space Race reached its zenith with the US Apollo 11 mission, landing the first humans on the Moon on July 20, 1969. The USSR attempted but abandoned manned lunar missions, shifting focus to Earth orbital space stations. A period of détente ensued, highlighted by the April 1972 agreement for the cooperative Apollo–Soyuz Test Project, culminating in a joint mission in July 1975 where US astronauts met Soviet cosmonauts in Earth orbit.
text_ai_humanized: In the mid-20th century, the Space Race unfolded as an intense contest between two Cold War giants: the Soviet Union and the United States. At its heart was the ambition to surpass each other in spaceflight prowess. This rivalry was, in many ways, a natural offshoot of the missile-centric nuclear arms race that gained momentum after World War II. Both nations eagerly tapped into technology and know-how inherited from captured German rocket scientists. In a world where national security and ideological dominance rested on highly visible achievements, making strides beyond Earth's atmosphere became indispensable. The competition energized efforts to launch satellites, send probes hurtling toward celestial bodies like the Moon, Venus, and Mars, and master human spaceflight in orbit and beyond. Things kicked off in earnest on August 2, 1955, when the Soviet Union declared its intention to launch a satellite—a swift reaction to the United States' announcement of similar plans just days earlier, aligned with the upcoming International Geophysical Year. Dramatically, the Soviet Union took an early lead by deploying Sputnik 1 into orbit on October 4, 1957. They continued their trailblazing progress by sending Yuri Gagarin, the first human in space, soaring above Earth on April 12, 1961. The climactic highlight arrived with the US Apollo 11 mission, where on July 20, 1969, humanity first set foot on the Moon's dusty surface. Meanwhile, the USSR, despite initial intentions, never managed a manned lunar landing and instead shifted its focus to establishing space stations in Earth's orbit. As the fervor of direct competition eased, a new phase of cooperation began. This détente was symbolized by the Apollo-Soyuz Test Project, agreed upon in April 1972, and brought to life by a groundbreaking joint mission in July 1975, where American astronauts shook hands with Soviet cosmonauts, floating together in the vastness above our planet.

text_human: From 1877 to 1878, the area suffered a rash of stagecoach robberies. Most notable, however, were the two holdups committed by masked road-agent William Whitney Brazelton. Brazelton held up two stages in the summer of 1878 near Point of Mountain Station approximately 17 mi (27 km) northwest of Tucson. John Clum, of Tombstone, Arizona fame was one of the passengers. Brazelton was eventually tracked down and killed on Monday August 19, 1878, in a mesquite bosque along the Santa Cruz River 3 miles (5 km) south of Tucson by Pima County Sheriff Charles A. Shibell and his citizen's posse. Brazelton had been suspected of highway robbery not only in the Tucson area, but also in the Prescott region and Silver City, New Mexico area as well. Brazelton's crimes prompted John J. Valentine, Sr. of Wells, Fargo & Co. to send special agent and future Pima County sheriff Bob Paul to investigate. Fort Lowell, then east of Tucson, was established to help protect settlers from Apache attacks. In 1882, Frank Stilwell was implicated in the murder of Morgan Earp by Cowboy Pete Spence's wife, Marietta, at the coroner's inquest on Morgan Earp's shooting. The coroner's jury concluded that Spence, Stilwell, Frederick Bode, and Florentino "Indian Charlie" Cruz were the prime suspects in the assassination of Morgan Earp. :250 Deputy U.S. Marshal Wyatt Earp gathered a few trusted friends and accompanied Virgil Earp and his family as they traveled to Benson for a train ride to California. They found Stilwell lying in wait for Virgil in the Tucson station and killed him on the tracks. After killing Stilwell, Wyatt deputized others and rode on a vendetta, killing three more cowboys over the next few days before leaving the state.

In 1882, Frank Stilwell became a suspect in the murder of Morgan Earp after Cowboy Pete Spence's wife, Marietta, implicated him during a coroner's inquest. The jurors concluded that Spence, Stilwell, Frederick Bode, and Florentino "Indian Charlie" Cruz were the main suspects in Morgan Earp's assassination. Deputy U.S. Marshal Wyatt Earp, accompanied by trusted allies, escorted his brother Virgil and family to Benson on their way to catch a train to California. They discovered Stilwell lying in wait for Virgil at the Tucson station and killed him on the tracks. Following Stilwell's death, Wyatt deputized others and pursued a vendetta, killing three more cowboys over the next few days before leaving the state.
text_ai_humanized: Between 1877 and 1878, the region became notorious for a spate of stagecoach robberies. Perhaps the most infamous of these were the two hold-ups orchestrated by the elusive bandit, William Whitney Brazelton. One hot summer day in 1878, Brazelton made his move, intercepting two stagecoaches near Point of Mountain Station, roughly 17 miles northwest of Tucson. Notably, among the passengers was John Clum, renowned for his future exploits in Tombstone, Arizona. Brazelton did not enjoy freedom for much longer. On Monday, August 19, 1878, his criminal escapades came to a violent end. Pima County Sheriff Charles A. Shibell, along with his posse, tracked him down to a mesquite grove along the Santa Cruz River, about 3 miles south of Tucson, and put an end to his reign of terror. Brazelton had been a suspect in a string of other highway robberies, not only in Tucson but stretching as far as Prescott and Silver City, New Mexico. These crimes were serious enough that John J. Valentine, Sr. from Wells, Fargo & Co. dispatched Bob Paul, a special agent who would later become Pima County sheriff, to delve into the matter. Around the same era, tensions and violence continued in different quarters. Fort Lowell had been set up to shield settlers from Apache raids east of Tucson. And by 1882, another dramatic chapter unfolded when Frank Stilwell found himself a suspect in the murder of Morgan Earp. This happened after Cowboy Pete Spence's wife, Marietta, offered startling testimony at a coroner's inquest. The jurors, convinced by the evidence, pointed fingers at Spence, Stilwell, Frederick Bode, and Florentino "Indian Charlie" Cruz as the chief suspects behind Earp's assassination. The intrigue didn’t end there. Deputy U.S. Marshal Wyatt Earp, determined to protect his kin, traveled with trusted comrades to escort his wounded brother Virgil, alongside his family, to Benson, from where they were to catch a train to California. It's here that events took an unexpected and lethal turn. They found Stilwell lurking with ill intent at the Tucson railway station, where Wyatt and his men finished him off on the tracks. This wasn't the end of the saga. Following Stilwell’s demise, Wyatt Earp, driven by vengeance, swore in new deputies and went on a whirlwind of retribution, dispatching three more cowboys over the span of a few days before he finally vanished from Arizona's tumultuous landscape.
