text_human: The opening years of the 1980s saw a number of changes in personnel and direction of established hard rock acts, including the deaths of Bon Scott, the lead singer of AC/DC, and John Bonham, drummer with Led Zeppelin. Whereas Zeppelin broke up almost immediately afterwards, AC/DC pressed on, recording the album Back in Black (1980) with their new lead singer, Brian Johnson. It became the fifth-highest-selling album of all time in the US and the second-highest-selling album in the world. Black Sabbath had split with original singer Ozzy Osbourne in 1979 and replaced him with Ronnie James Dio, formerly of Rainbow, giving the band a new sound and a period of creativity and popularity beginning with Heaven and Hell (1980). Osbourne embarked on a solo career with Blizzard of Ozz (1980), featuring American guitarist Randy Rhoads. Some bands, such as Queen, moved away from their hard rock roots and more towards pop rock, while others, including Rush with Moving Pictures (1981), began to return to a hard rock sound. The creation of thrash metal, which mixed heavy metal with elements of hardcore punk from about 1982, particularly by Metallica, Anthrax, Megadeth and Slayer, helped to create extreme metal and further remove the style from hard rock, although a number of these bands or their members would continue to record some songs closer to a hard rock sound. Kiss moved away from their hard rock roots toward pop metal: firstly removing their makeup in 1983 for their Lick It Up album, and then adopting the visual and sound of glam metal for their 1984 release, Animalize, both of which marked a return to commercial success. Pat Benatar was one of the first women to achieve commercial success in hard rock, with three successive Top 5 albums between 1980 and 1982.
text_ai_base: In the early 1980s, the hard rock scene experienced significant shifts in both personnel and direction. Notably, Bon Scott, AC/DC's lead singer, and John Bonham, Led Zeppelin's drummer, both passed away. Following Bonham's death, Led Zeppelin disbanded. Conversely, AC/DC continued forward, recruiting Brian Johnson as their new lead singer and releasing the album "Back in Black" (1980). This album became immensely successful, ranking as the fifth highest-selling in the U.S. and the second worldwide. Meanwhile, Black Sabbath replaced their original vocalist, Ozzy Osbourne, with Ronnie James Dio from Rainbow. This change heralded a new era of creativity and popularity for the band, starting with the "Heaven and Hell" album (1980). Osbourne launched his solo career with "Blizzard of Ozz" (1980), showcasing American guitarist Randy Rhoads. Some bands, like Queen, shifted from their hard rock beginnings to a pop rock sound, while others, such as Rush with "Moving Pictures" (1981), revisited their hard rock roots. Around 1982, thrash metal emerged, blending heavy metal with hardcore punk, led by bands like Metallica, Anthrax, Megadeth, and Slayer. This new genre solidified extreme metal's identity, further distancing it from traditional hard rock, although many of these bands continued to record tracks with a hard rock influence. Kiss transitioned from hard rock to pop metal, starting with their makeup-free album "Lick It Up" in 1983, and embraced glam metal with "Animalize" in 1984, reviving their commercial success. Additionally, Pat Benatar broke new ground for women in hard rock with three consecutive Top 5 albums between 1980 and 1982.
text_ai_humanized: In the tumultuous early years of the 1980s, the hard rock scene underwent striking transformations, both in personnel and musical direction. A sense of profound change was palpable following the tragic deaths of Bon Scott, the iconic voice of AC/DC, and John Bonham, the legendary drummer of Led Zeppelin. With Bonham's passing, Led Zeppelin chose to disband, closing a significant chapter in rock history. AC/DC, however, forged ahead by bringing Brian Johnson into the fold as their new frontman. Their resilience paid off with the release of the blockbuster album "Back in Black" (1980), which soared to astonishing commercial success, becoming the fifth highest-seller in the U.S. and the second worldwide. Meanwhile, Black Sabbath underwent a notable transformation of its own. Ronnie James Dio, formerly of Rainbow, stepped in to replace Ozzy Osbourne as Sabbath's lead vocalist. This era marked a creative resurgence for the band, ushered in by the release of "Heaven and Hell" (1980). As for Osbourne, he embarked on a solo venture and released "Blizzard of Ozz" (1980), spotlighting the remarkable talents of American guitarist Randy Rhoads. Interestingly, some bands took unexpected musical courses: Queen ventured away from hard rock into pop rock territory, while Rush dove back into their hard rock essence with the celebrated "Moving Pictures" (1981). It was around 1982 that thrash metal emerged—a ferocious fusion of heavy metal and hardcore punk—helmed by bands like Metallica, Anthrax, Megadeth, and Slayer. This genre crystallized extreme metal's identity, inching away from traditional hard rock, yet undeniably influenced by it. The band Kiss decided to innovate, shedding their hallmark makeup to flirt with pop metal sounds in "Lick It Up" (1983) before fully embracing glam metal with "Animalize" in 1984, a move that reenergized their commercial appeal. Amidst these changes, Pat Benatar carved a notable niche for women in hard rock, releasing three Top 5 albums in succession between 1980 and 1982, thereby shifting the landscape of the era.

message.content:
In the tumultuous early years of the 1980s, the hard rock scene underwent striking transformations, both in personnel and musical direction. A sense of profound change was palpable following the tragic deaths of Bon Scott, the iconic voice of AC/DC, and John Bonham, the legendary drummer of Led Zeppelin. With Bonham's passing, Led Zeppelin chose to disband, closing a significant chapter in rock history. AC/DC, however, forged ahead by bringing Brian Johnson into the fold as their new frontman. Their resilience paid off with the release of the blockbuster album "Back in Black" (1980), which soared to astonishing commercial success, becoming the fifth highest-seller in the U.S. and the second worldwide.

Meanwhile, Black Sabbath underwent a notable transformation of its own. Ronnie James Dio, formerly of Rainbow, stepped in to replace Ozzy Osbourne as Sabbath's lead vocalist. This era marked a creative resurgence for the band, ushered in by the release of "Heaven and Hell" (1980). As for Osbourne, he embarked on a solo venture and released "Blizzard of Ozz" (1980), spotlighting the remarkable talents of American guitarist Randy Rhoads.

Interestingly, some bands took unexpected musical courses: Queen ventured away from hard rock into pop rock territory, while Rush dove back into their hard rock essence with the celebrated "Moving Pictures" (1981). It was around 1982 that thrash metal emerged—a ferocious fusion of heavy metal and hardcore punk—helmed by bands like Metallica, Anthrax, Megadeth, and Slayer. This genre crystallized extreme metal's identity, inching away from traditional hard rock, yet undeniably influenced by it.

The band Kiss decided to innovate, shedding their hallmark makeup to flirt with pop metal sounds in "Lick It Up" (1983) before fully embracing glam metal with "Animalize" in 1984, a move that reenergized their commercial appeal. Amidst these changes, Pat Benatar carved a notable niche for women in hard rock, releasing three Top 5 albums in succession between 1980 and 1982, thereby shifting the landscape of the era.

text_human: Intel had tried unsuccessfully to push Apple to migrate the Macintosh platform to Intel chips. Apple concluded that Intel's CISC (Complex Instruction Set Computer) architecture ultimately would not be able to compete against RISC (Reduced Instruction Set Computer) processors. While the Motorola 68040 offered the same features as the Intel 80486 and could on a clock-for-clock basis significantly outperform the Intel chip, the 486 had the ability to be clocked significantly faster without suffering from overheating problems, especially the clock-doubled i486DX2 which ran the CPU logic at twice the external bus speed, giving such equipped IBM compatible systems a significant performance lead over their Macintosh equivalents. Apple's product design and engineering didn't help matters as they restricted the use of the '040 to their expensive Quadras for a time while the 486 was readily available to OEMs as well as enthusiasts who put together their own machines. In late 1991, as the higher-end Macintosh desktop lineup transitioned to the '040, Apple was unable to offer the '040 in their top-of-the-line PowerBooks until early 1994 with the PowerBook 500 series, several years after the first 486-powered IBM compatible laptops hit the market which cost Apple considerable sales. In 1993 Intel rolled out the Pentium processors as the successor to the 486, while the Motorola 68050 was never released, leaving the Macintosh platform a generation behind IBM compatibles in the latest CPU technology. In 1994, Apple abandoned Motorola CPUs for the RISC PowerPC architecture developed by the AIM alliance of Apple Computer, IBM, and Motorola. The Power Macintosh line, the first to use the new chips, proved to be highly successful, with over a million PowerPC units sold in nine months. However, in the long run, spurning Intel for the PowerPC was a mistake as the commoditization of Intel-architecture chips meant Apple couldn't compete on price against "the Dells of the world".
text_ai_base: Intel made multiple attempts to persuade Apple to transition the Macintosh platform to its chips, but Apple resisted. Apple decided that Intel's CISC (Complex Instruction Set Computer) architecture wouldn't effectively compete with RISC (Reduced Instruction Set Computer) processors. Although the Motorola 68040 offered similar functionality to the Intel 80486 and could outperform it at equal clock speeds, the 486 could run at much higher clock speeds without overheating, particularly the i486DX2, which operated at twice the external bus speed. As a result, IBM-compatible systems had a notable performance edge over their Macintosh counterparts. Apple's decision to limit the Motorola 68040 to their high-priced Quadra models initially, while the 486 was widely available for OEMs and hobbyists, further compounded the issue. By late 1991, even as the more advanced Macintosh desktops began using the 68040, Apple couldn't offer it in their top-tier PowerBooks until the PowerBook 500 series launched in early 1994, leaving them lagging behind IBM-compatible laptops that began using the 486 years earlier—a factor that hurt Apple's sales substantially. In 1993, Intel introduced the Pentium processors to replace the 486, while the Motorola 68050 was never released, putting Macintosh a generation behind in CPU technology compared to IBM compatibles. In 1994, Apple decided to switch from Motorola CPUs to the RISC PowerPC architecture developed through the AIM alliance with Apple, IBM, and Motorola. The Power Macintosh series, utilizing these new chips, achieved great success, selling over a million units in nine months. Despite this initial success, the decision to bypass Intel for PowerPC ultimately proved misguided, as Intel-based chips became standardized, leaving Apple unable to compete on pricing with companies like Dell.
text_ai_humanized: Intel made numerous overtures to Apple, hoping to convince them to switch the Macintosh platform over to Intel's processors. However, Apple turned those proposals down, doubting whether Intel’s CISC architecture could hold its ground against RISC processors. While the Motorola 68040 offered functionality akin to the Intel 80486 and even outperformed it at identical clock speeds, the 486 could achieve much higher clock speeds without the risk of overheating—especially models like the i486DX2, which could double the external bus speed without breaking a sweat. Consequently, systems compatible with IBM boasted a clear advantage over their Macintosh counterparts. Adding to Apple's woes, their decision to confine the Motorola 68040 to only the pricier Quadra models, while the 486 spread insidiously through OEM channels and hobbyist circles, left them further disadvantaged. By the closing months of 1991, even as the more advanced Macintosh desktops started using the 68040, Apple's top-tier PowerBooks were still stuck without it. They didn't arrive until the PowerBook 500 series came around in early 1994, by which time IBM-compatible laptops had adopted the 486 years earlier—a major setback that significantly blunted Apple's sales momentum. Fast forward to 1993: Intel unveiled their new Pentium processors as successors to the 486, while Motorola’s 68050 remained in the realm of the never-released, further widening the gap between Macintosh and IBM in terms of CPU technology. By 1994, Apple switched gears, moving away from Motorola’s chips in favor of the RISC PowerPC architecture—a result of the AIM alliance between Apple, IBM, and Motorola. The Power Macintosh series, featuring these new processors, hit a home run initially, moving over a million units in just nine months. This triumph, however, masked a strategic blunder; choosing PowerPC over Intel ultimately hamstrung Apple. Intel chips, becoming an industry staple, enabled rivals like Dell to outstrip Apple on price points, a crucial disadvantage in the competitive computer market.

message.content:
Intel made numerous overtures to Apple, hoping to convince them to switch the Macintosh platform over to Intel's processors. However, Apple turned those proposals down, doubting whether Intel’s CISC architecture could hold its ground against RISC processors. While the Motorola 68040 offered functionality akin to the Intel 80486 and even outperformed it at identical clock speeds, the 486 could achieve much higher clock speeds without the risk of overheating—especially models like the i486DX2, which could double the external bus speed without breaking a sweat. Consequently, systems compatible with IBM boasted a clear advantage over their Macintosh counterparts.

Adding to Apple's woes, their decision to confine the Motorola 68040 to only the pricier Quadra models, while the 486 spread insidiously through OEM channels and hobbyist circles, left them further disadvantaged. By the closing months of 1991, even as the more advanced Macintosh desktops started using the 68040, Apple's top-tier PowerBooks were still stuck without it. They didn't arrive until the PowerBook 500 series came around in early 1994, by which time IBM-compatible laptops had adopted the 486 years earlier—a major setback that significantly blunted Apple's sales momentum.

Fast forward to 1993: Intel unveiled their new Pentium processors as successors to the 486, while Motorola’s 68050 remained in the realm of the never-released, further widening the gap between Macintosh and IBM in terms of CPU technology. By 1994, Apple switched gears, moving away from Motorola’s chips in favor of the RISC PowerPC architecture—a result of the AIM alliance between Apple, IBM, and Motorola. The Power Macintosh series, featuring these new processors, hit a home run initially, moving over a million units in just nine months. This triumph, however, masked a strategic blunder; choosing PowerPC over Intel ultimately hamstrung Apple. Intel chips, becoming an industry staple, enabled rivals like Dell to outstrip Apple on price points, a crucial disadvantage in the competitive computer market.

text_human: Other historians find incongruity in the proposition that the very place where the vast number of the scholars that influenced the scientific revolution received their education should also be the place that inhibits their research and the advancement of science. In fact, more than 80% of the European scientists between 1450–1650 included in the Dictionary of Scientific Biography were university trained, of which approximately 45% held university posts. It was the case that the academic foundations remaining from the Middle Ages were stable, and they did provide for an environment that fostered considerable growth and development. There was considerable reluctance on the part of universities to relinquish the symmetry and comprehensiveness provided by the Aristotelian system, which was effective as a coherent system for understanding and interpreting the world. However, university professors still utilized some autonomy, at least in the sciences, to choose epistemological foundations and methods. For instance, Melanchthon and his disciples at University of Wittenberg were instrumental for integrating Copernican mathematical constructs into astronomical debate and instruction. Another example was the short-lived but fairly rapid adoption of Cartesian epistemology and methodology in European universities, and the debates surrounding that adoption, which led to more mechanistic approaches to scientific problems as well as demonstrated an openness to change. There are many examples which belie the commonly perceived intransigence of universities. Although universities may have been slow to accept new sciences and methodologies as they emerged, when they did accept new ideas it helped to convey legitimacy and respectability, and supported the scientific changes through providing a stable environment for instruction and material resources.
text_ai_base: Some historians find it puzzling that the very institutions where scholars of the scientific revolution were educated could also be seen as hindering scientific progress. Interestingly, more than 80% of the European scientists from 1450 to 1650, as listed in the Dictionary of Scientific Biography, were trained at universities, and about 45% held positions there. The universities, rooted in medieval traditions, offered a stable environment that supported significant growth and development. Although there was hesitance to abandon the comprehensive and symmetrical Aristotelian system, which effectively explained the world, university professors in the sciences were allowed some independence in choosing their methods and foundational ideas. For example, Melanchthon and his followers at the University of Wittenberg played a key role in incorporating Copernican mathematical models into astronomical discussions and teaching. Similarly, the relatively quick acceptance of Cartesian thought at European universities, along with the ensuing debates, illustrated an openness to change and ushered in more mechanistic approaches to scientific inquiries. These examples challenge the notion that universities were resistant to change. While universities may have initially been slow to embrace new sciences and methodologies, they ultimately provided legitimacy and respectability to these ideas, supporting scientific advancements by offering a stable setting for teaching and resources.

Even though there was a tendency to cling to the well-structured Aristotelian worldview—which had long explained earthly phenomena with elegance—science professors had some leeway in choosing their teaching methods and fundamental principles. Take, for instance, Melanchthon and his cohort at the University of Wittenberg, who made remarkable strides by weaving Copernican mathematical models into their astronomy curriculum. By the same token, the relatively swift embrace of Cartesian thought—inspired debates and all—showed a willingness among European universities to evolve and explore more mechanistic scientific approaches. Such instances cast doubt on the caricature of universities as bastions of resistance to change. Even though they were sometimes slow to warm to new scientific ideas and methodologies, these institutions ended up lending legitimacy and respectability to emerging theories and provided a nurturing ground for groundbreaking work, thanks to their teaching resources and stable settings.

text_human: Regarding the timing of German rapprochement, many historians agree that the dismissal of Maxim Litvinov, whose Jewish ethnicity was viewed unfavorably by Nazi Germany, removed an obstacle to negotiations with Germany. Stalin immediately directed Molotov to "purge the ministry of Jews." Given Litvinov's prior attempts to create an anti-fascist coalition, association with the doctrine of collective security with France and Britain, and pro-Western orientation by the standards of the Kremlin, his dismissal indicated the existence of a Soviet option of rapprochement with Germany.[f] Likewise, Molotov's appointment served as a signal to Germany that the USSR was open to offers. The dismissal also signaled to France and Britain the existence of a potential negotiation option with Germany. One British official wrote that Litvinov's disappearance also meant the loss of an admirable technician or shock-absorber, while Molotov's "modus operandi" was "more truly Bolshevik than diplomatic or cosmopolitan." Carr argued that the Soviet Union's replacement of Foreign Minister Litvinov with Molotov on May 3, 1939 indicated not an irrevocable shift towards alignment with Germany, but rather was Stalin's way of engaging in hard bargaining with the British and the French by appointing a proverbial hard man, namely Molotov, to the Foreign Commissariat. Historian Albert Resis stated that the Litvinov dismissal gave the Soviets freedom to pursue faster-paced German negotiations, but that they did not abandon British–French talks. Derek Watson argued that Molotov could get the best deal with Britain and France because he was not encumbered with the baggage of collective security and could negotiate with Germany. Geoffrey Roberts argued that Litvinov's dismissal helped the Soviets with British–French talks, because Litvinov doubted or maybe even opposed such discussions.
text_ai_base: Historians often agree that Maxim Litvinov's dismissal played a crucial role in facilitating negotiations between Germany and the Soviet Union. Litvinov's Jewish ethnicity was considered unfavorable by Nazi Germany, and his removal reduced barriers to diplomacy. Stalin swiftly instructed Molotov to "purge the ministry of Jews." Litvinov had previously tried to form an anti-fascist coalition and was closely associated with collective security arrangements with France and Britain. His pro-Western stance by Kremlin standards signaled a possible Soviet shift towards rapprochement with Germany. Molotov's appointment was intended as a clear signal to Germany that the USSR was open to dialogue. Simultaneously, Litvinov's dismissal communicated to France and Britain that the USSR might negotiate with Germany. A British official noted that Litvinov's exit marked the loss of a skilled negotiator, while Molotov's approach was "more truly Bolshevik than diplomatic or cosmopolitan." Carr argued that replacing Litvinov with Molotov on May 3, 1939 was not an irreversible alignment with Germany, but rather Stalin's strategy to engage in tough negotiations with Britain and France by appointing Molotov, known for his firmness, to the Foreign Commissariat. Historian Albert Resis believed that Litvinov's dismissal freed the Soviets to pursue quicker negotiations with Germany, while maintaining talks with Britain and France. Derek Watson supported the idea that Molotov could secure the best deal with Britain and France since he was free from the constraints of collective security and able to engage with Germany. Geoffrey Roberts contended that Litvinov's dismissal furthered Soviet discussions with Britain and France, as Litvinov had doubts or even opposed such negotiations.
text_ai_humanized: According to a consensus among historians, the removal of Maxim Litvinov was a pivotal moment that cleared the way for diplomatic discussions between Germany and the Soviet Union. As Litvinov was of Jewish descent, this fact made him unfavorable to Nazi Germany, leading Stalin to quickly instruct Molotov to "purge the ministry of Jews." Litvinov had diligently pushed for anti-fascist alliances and was notably aligned with collective security measures involving France and Britain. In the eyes of the Kremlin, his Western-leaning approach indicated a potential Soviet shift toward German rapprochement. The entrance of Molotov was intended to signal clearly to Germany that the USSR was open for dialogue while simultaneously hinting to France and Britain that negotiating with Germany was on the table. A British official commented that losing Litvinov meant letting go of a skilled negotiator, and noted Molotov's style as "more truly Bolshevik than diplomatic or cosmopolitan," perhaps with a touch of irony. Carr suggested that the May 3, 1939 decision to replace Litvinov with Molotov didn't instantly align the Soviet Union with Germany. Rather, it was a calculated move by Stalin to engage robustly with Britain and France, leveraging Molotov's renowned decisiveness in foreign affairs. Historian Albert Resis posited that removing Litvinov liberated the Soviets to speed up negotiations with Germany, without discarding dialogues with Britain and France. Derek Watson echoed the sentiment, asserting that Molotov's lack of attachment to collective security allowed him to negotiate with Germany while pursuing favorable terms with Britain and France. Geoffrey Roberts reinforced the notion that ousting Litvinov bolstered Soviet conversations with Britain and France, given Litvinov’s skepticism or outright resistance to such negotiations. In the kaleidoscope of international diplomacy at that time, these moves were anything but straightforward, reflecting a complex web of strategies and ideological balancing acts.

text_human: The Mughals were perhaps the richest single dynasty to have ever existed. During the Mughal era, the dominant political forces consisted of the Mughal Empire and its tributaries and, later on, the rising successor states – including the Maratha Empire – which fought an increasingly weak Mughal dynasty. The Mughals, while often employing brutal tactics to subjugate their empire, had a policy of integration with Indian culture, which is what made them successful where the short-lived Sultanates of Delhi had failed. This period marked vast social change in the subcontinent as the Hindu majority were ruled over by the Mughal emperors, most of whom showed religious tolerance, liberally patronising Hindu culture. The famous emperor Akbar, who was the grandson of Babar, tried to establish a good relationship with the Hindus. However, later emperors such as Aurangazeb tried to establish complete Muslim dominance, and as a result several historical temples were destroyed during this period and taxes imposed on non-Muslims. Akbar declared "Amari" or non-killing of animals in the holy days of Jainism. He rolled back the jizya tax for non-Muslims. The Mughal emperors married local royalty, allied themselves with local maharajas, and attempted to fuse their Turko-Persian culture with ancient Indian styles, creating a unique Indo-Saracenic architecture. It was the erosion of this tradition coupled with increased brutality and centralization that played a large part in the dynasty's downfall after Aurangzeb, who unlike previous emperors, imposed relatively non-pluralistic policies on the general population, which often inflamed the majority Hindu population.
text_ai_base: The Mughal dynasty is considered one of the wealthiest in history. During their rule, the Mughal Empire and its tributaries were the dominant political forces, although eventually they faced challenges from emerging successor states like the Maratha Empire, which contested the progressively weakening Mughal dynasty. Despite their often brutal methods of control, the Mughals succeeded by integrating with Indian culture—a strategy that distinguished them from the short-lived Sultanates of Delhi. This era saw significant social changes as the Hindu majority came under the rule of Mughal emperors, who mostly displayed religious tolerance and actively supported Hindu culture. Akbar, the notable emperor and grandson of Babar, aimed to foster good relations with Hindus. In contrast, later emperors like Aurangzeb pursued complete Muslim dominance, leading to the destruction of historic temples and the imposition of taxes on non-Muslims. Akbar had introduced "Amari," banning animal killings on holy Jain days, and abolished the jizya tax on non-Muslims. Mughal emperors often married into local royalty, allied with regional maharajas, and blended their Turko-Persian culture with ancient Indian styles, giving rise to unique Indo-Saracenic architecture. The erosion of these traditions, alongside increasing brutality and centralization, contributed significantly to the dynasty’s decline after Aurangzeb, whose policies departed from his predecessors' pluralism, provoking unrest among the predominantly Hindu population.
text_ai_humanized: The Mughal dynasty, renowned for its immense wealth, held sway over a vast empire that once dominated India. Unlike the fleeting Sultanates of Delhi, the Mughals left a mark by integrating into Indian society, even as they exercised harsh control at times. During this era, the Hindu majority lived under Mughal rule, which was generally characterized by a policy of religious tolerance. Most emperors, particularly Akbar—grandson of Babar—endeavored to nurture positive relationships with Hindus. An advocate for cultural harmony, Akbar took noteworthy actions, such as instituting "Amari" to ban animal slaughter on holy Jain days and eliminating the jizya, a tax levied on non-Muslims. However, contrasting sharply with Akbar’s inclusivity, Emperor Aurangzeb sought to impose Islamic supremacy, infamously demolishing significant temples and reinstating taxes on non-Muslims. Marriages between Mughal emperors and local royals formed political alliances and a unique blend of Turko-Persian and Indian traditions—manifested vividly in Indo-Saracenic architecture—illustrated their cultural assimilation. Yet, as time passed, the dynasty's deviation from its pluralistic roots, coupled with increased autocracy and harsher measures, accelerated its downfall. Aurangzeb’s rigid policies, veering away from those of his forerunners, sparked unrest among the predominantly Hindu populace, contributing to the dynasty’s ultimate decline.

text_human: Medieval Cholas rose to prominence during the middle of the 9th century C.E. and established the greatest empire South India had seen. They successfully united the South India under their rule and through their naval strength extended their influence in the Southeast Asian countries such as Srivijaya. Under Rajaraja Chola I and his successors Rajendra Chola I, Rajadhiraja Chola, Virarajendra Chola and Kulothunga Chola I the dynasty became a military, economic and cultural power in South Asia and South-East Asia. Rajendra Chola I's navies went even further, occupying the sea coasts from Burma to Vietnam, the Andaman and Nicobar Islands, the Lakshadweep (Laccadive) islands, Sumatra, and the Malay Peninsula in Southeast Asia and the Pegu islands. The power of the new empire was proclaimed to the eastern world by the expedition to the Ganges which Rajendra Chola I undertook and by the occupation of cities of the maritime empire of Srivijaya in Southeast Asia, as well as by the repeated embassies to China. They dominated the political affairs of Sri Lanka for over two centuries through repeated invasions and occupation. They also had continuing trade contacts with the Arabs in the west and with the Chinese empire in the east. Rajaraja Chola I and his equally distinguished son Rajendra Chola I gave political unity to the whole of Southern India and established the Chola Empire as a respected sea power. Under the Cholas, the South India reached new heights of excellence in art, religion and literature. In all of these spheres, the Chola period marked the culmination of movements that had begun in an earlier age under the Pallavas. Monumental architecture in the form of majestic temples and sculpture in stone and bronze reached a finesse never before achieved in India.

Rajendra Chola I's fleets sailed far, establishing control along sea coasts from Burma to Vietnam, the Andaman and Nicobar Islands, the Lakshadweep islands, Sumatra, and the Malay Peninsula. The empire's might was showcased through Rajendra Chola I's expedition to the Ganges, the occupation of cities within Srivijaya, and multiple embassies to China. Their monumental temples and exquisite stone and bronze sculptures set new standards of excellence in India.

This dynasty, led by notable rulers like Rajaraja Chola I and his successors—Rajendra Chola I, Rajadhiraja Chola, Virarajendra Chola, and Kulothunga Chola I—grew into a formidable military, economic, and cultural powerhouse across the Indian Ocean expanse. The Chola Empire's grandeur was no more evident than in Rajendra Chola I's bold northern foray to the Ganges and his occupation of key Srivijayan cities, not to mention the frequent diplomatic missions to China—an impressive feat itself. Their sway over Sri Lankan politics was undeniable, with the Cholas keeping their grip tight through invasions and a long-lasting occupation that spanned over two centuries. This epoch was a golden age for South Indian culture, setting unmatched standards in art, religion, and literature. Monumental temple architecture and masterful stone and bronze sculptures from this era continue to resonate, marking the Chola period as a cultural zenith, a thrilling continuation of artistic advances first kindled by the earlier Pallavas.

text_human: On 20 June 1794, Burke received a vote of thanks from the Commons for his services in the Hastings Trial and he immediately resigned his seat, being replaced by his son Richard. A tragic blow fell upon Burke with the loss of Richard in August 1794, to whom he was tenderly attached, and in whom he saw signs of promise, which were not patent to others and which, in fact, appear to have been non-existent (though this view may have rather reflected the fact that Richard Burke had worked successfully in the early battle for Catholic emancipation). King George III, whose favour he had gained by his attitude on the French Revolution, wished to create him Earl of Beaconsfield, but the death of his son deprived the opportunity of such an honour and all its attractions, so the only award he would accept was a pension of £2,500. Even this modest reward was attacked by the Duke of Bedford and the Earl of Lauderdale, to whom Burke replied in his Letter to a Noble Lord (1796): "It cannot at this time be too often repeated; line upon line; precept upon precept; until it comes into the currency of a proverb, To innovate is not to reform". He argued that he was rewarded on merit, but the Duke of Bedford received his rewards from inheritance alone, his ancestor being the original pensioner: "Mine was from a mild and benevolent sovereign; his from Henry the Eighth". Burke also hinted at what would happen to such people if their revolutionary ideas were implemented, and included a description of the British constitution:
text_ai_base: On June 20, 1794, Burke was honored with a vote of thanks from the Commons for his role in the Hastings Trial. He then resigned, with his son Richard taking his place. Sadly, in August 1794, Burke suffered a devastating loss with Richard’s passing. Burke was deeply attached to his son and saw great potential in him, which was not apparent to others, although Richard had played a successful part in the early fight for Catholic emancipation. King George III, appreciating Burke’s stance on the French Revolution, wanted to make him Earl of Beaconsfield. However, the possibility of this honor diminished with Richard’s death, leaving Burke only willing to accept a £2,500 pension. The pension became the target of criticism from the Duke of Bedford and Earl of Lauderdale, prompting Burke’s well-known retort in his "Letter to a Noble Lord" (1796): "It cannot at this time be too often repeated; line upon line; precept upon precept; until it comes into the currency of a proverb, To innovate is not to reform." Burke insisted he was awarded based on merit, while the Duke of Bedford's rewards came solely from inheritance, highlighting that Burke's compensation was granted by a kind sovereign and Bedford’s ancestor from Henry VIII. Burke also hinted at the consequences if their radical ideas were realized, providing an insightful view of the British constitution.
text_ai_humanized: Back on June 20, 1794, Edmund Burke received a heartfelt vote of appreciation from the Commons, acknowledging his contributions to the Hastings Trial. Following this commendation, he decided to resign, passing the torch to his son Richard. Tragically, the flame of hope was extinguished in August that year when Richard passed away—a blow to Burke, who harbored great hopes for his son, envisioning a future others failed to see. Richard had already shown promise, notably in the campaign for Catholic emancipation. Meanwhile, in the courtly corridors, King George III—valuing Burke's views on the French Revolution—considered conferring upon him the title of Earl of Beaconsfield. Yet, with Richard's untimely death, Burke's ambitions shifted; ultimately, he agreed to a pension of £2,500 instead. This pension soon stirred some controversy. The Duke of Bedford, alongside the Earl of Lauderdale, criticized this monetary award, prompting Burke to pen one of his sharpest and memorable rejoinders in "Letter to a Noble Lord" (1796). Burke fired back with biting eloquence, "It cannot at this time be too often repeated; line upon line; precept upon precept; until it comes into the currency of a proverb, To innovate is not to reform." That phrase is one for the ages! Burke argued his pension was well-earned through his contributions, unlike the Duke of Bedford, whose fortune was handed down courtesy of inheritance. His sharp comparison noted that while his pension was granted by a benevolent monarch, Bedford’s wealth had roots far back with Henry VIII. Further, Burke hinted at the dangers lurking within their radical visions, offering a thoughtful reflection on the delicate fabric of the British constitution.

This pension soon stirred some controversy. The Duke of Bedford, alongside the Earl of Lauderdale, criticized this monetary award, prompting Burke to pen one of his sharpest and memorable rejoinders in "Letter to a Noble Lord" (1796). Burke fired back with biting eloquence, "It cannot at this time be too often repeated; line upon line; precept upon precept; until it comes into the currency of a proverb, To innovate is not to reform." His sharp comparison noted that while his pension was granted by a benevolent monarch, Bedford’s wealth had roots far back with Henry VIII. text_human: The deeper ancestral demography of Bermuda's population has been obscured by the ethnic homogenisation of the last four centuries. There is effectively no ethnic distinction between black and white Bermudians, other than those characterising recent immigrant communities. In the 17th century, this was not so. For the first hundred years of settlement, white Protestants of English heritage were the distinct majority, with white minorities of Irish (the native language of many of whom can be assumed to have been Gaelic) and Scots sent to Bermuda after the English invasions of their homelands that followed the English Civil War. Non-white minorities included Spanish-speaking, free (indentured) blacks from the West Indies, black chattel slaves primarily captured from Spanish and Portuguese ships by Bermudian privateers, and Native Americans, primarily from the Algonquian and other tribes of the Atlantic seaboard, but possibly from as far away as Mexico. By the 19th century, the white ethnically-English Bermudians had lost their numerical advantage. Despite the banning of the importation of Irish, and the repeated attempts to force free blacks to emigrate and the owners of black slaves to export them, the merging of the various minority groups, along with some of the white English, had resulted in a new demographic group, "coloured" (which term, in Bermuda, referred to anyone not wholly of European ancestry) Bermudians, gaining a slight majority. Any child born before or since then to one coloured and one white parent has been added to the coloured statistic. Most of those historically described as "coloured" are today described as "black", or "of African heritage", which obscures their non-African heritage (those previously described as "coloured" who were not of African ancestry had been very few, though the numbers of South Asians, particularly, is now growing. The number of persons born in Asian countries doubled between the 2000 and the 2010 censuses), blacks have remained in the majority, with new white immigration from Portugal, Britain and elsewhere countered by black immigration from the West Indies.
text_ai_base: The complex ancestral history of Bermuda's population has been obscured over the last four centuries due to ethnic homogenization. Today, there is virtually no ethnic distinction between black and white Bermudians, apart from those reflected in recent immigrant communities. However, this was not the case in the 17th century. During the first hundred years of settlement, the majority consisted of white Protestants with English heritage, accompanied by smaller groups of Irish, who likely spoke Gaelic, and Scots, sent to Bermuda following English invasions after the English Civil War. Non-white minorities included Spanish-speaking free (indentured) blacks from the West Indies, black slaves typically captured from Spanish and Portuguese ships by Bermudian privateers, and Native Americans from tribes along the Atlantic seaboard, and possibly as far as Mexico. By the 19th century, the white, ethnically English Bermudians had lost their numerical dominance. Although laws were enacted to ban Irish importation and efforts were made to force free blacks to emigrate and export black slaves, the blending of various minority groups, including some white English, led to the emergence of a new demographic termed "coloured." In Bermuda, "coloured" referred to anyone not wholly of European ancestry, forming a slight majority. Children born to one coloured and one white parent were categorized as coloured. Most individuals historically labeled as "coloured" are now described as "black" or "of African heritage," which largely masks their non-African ancestry. Individuals previously identified as "coloured" without African roots were few, though numbers of South Asians are now rising, evidenced by the doubling of those born in Asian countries between the 2000 and 2010 censuses. Although blacks have remained the majority, this demographic has been balanced by new white immigration from Portugal, Britain, and other regions, countered by black immigration from the West Indies.
text_ai_humanized: Over the last four hundred years, Bermuda's rich tapestry of ancestral history has been somewhat lost in an ongoing process of ethnic homogenization. Nowadays, black and white Bermudians exhibit little ethnic distinction, except for those connected to the more recent immigrant waves. This wasn't always true, especially if we journey back to the 17th century, where the island was largely populated by white Protestants bearing English roots. Alongside them were smaller groups of Irish, likely conversing in Gaelic, and Scots who arrived after the unsettling English Civil War brought invasions. Non-white minorities present at the time included free blacks who spoke Spanish and were indentured from the West Indies, enslaved blacks captured from Spanish and Portuguese vessels by bold Bermudian privateers, and Native Americans from tribes positioned along the Atlantic seaboard—some possibly tracing back to Mexico. Come the 19th century, those whites of English descent saw their numerical hold slip away. Even as laws were passed preventing the importation of the Irish and attempts were made to encourage free blacks to leave and export enslaved blacks, various minority groups began to blend. This melting pot yielded a demographic named "coloured," referring to individuals not entirely of European lineage, a category that grew to become the slight majority. Children born to a coloured parent and a white parent fell under the coloured designation. Nowadays, individuals once classified as "coloured" are more frequently identified as "black" or "of African heritage," a label that often conceals their non-African lineage. Except for a few, those previously described as coloured but lacking African roots were sparse. Yet, interestingly, South Asian numbers have been climbing, apparent from the doubling of births in Asian countries between the 2000 and 2010 censuses. Despite blacks continuing to hold the majority, this demographic equilibrium has been swayed by new white immigrants arriving from places like Portugal, Britain, and beyond, set against black immigration from the West Indies.

Non-white minorities present at the time included free blacks who spoke Spanish and were indentured from the West Indies, enslaved blacks captured from Spanish and Portuguese vessels by bold Bermudian privateers, and Native Americans from tribes positioned along the Atlantic seaboard—some possibly tracing back to Mexico.

Come the 19th century, those whites of English descent saw their numerical hold slip away. This melting pot yielded a demographic named "coloured," referring to individuals not entirely of European lineage, a category that grew to become the slight majority. Children born to a coloured parent and a white parent fell under the coloured designation. Nowadays, individuals once classified as "coloured" are more frequently identified as "black" or "of African heritage," a label that often conceals their non-African lineage. Except for a few, those previously described as coloured but lacking African roots were sparse. Yet, interestingly, South Asian numbers have been climbing, apparent from the doubling of births in Asian countries between the 2000 and 2010 censuses.

Despite blacks continuing to hold the majority, this demographic equilibrium has been swayed by new white immigrants arriving from places like Portugal, Britain, and beyond, set against black immigration from the West Indies.

text_human: To prevent the risk of out-of-phase supplies mixing, sections of line fed from different feeder stations must be kept strictly isolated. This is achieved by Neutral Sections (also known as Phase Breaks), usually provided at feeder stations and midway between them although, typically, only half are in use at any time, the others being provided to allow a feeder station to be shut down and power provided from adjacent feeder stations. Neutral Sections usually consist of an earthed section of wire which is separated from the live wires on either side by insulating material, typically ceramic beads, designed so that the pantograph will smoothly run from one section to the other. The earthed section prevents an arc being drawn from one live section to the other, as the voltage difference may be higher than the normal system voltage if the live sections are on different phases and the protective circuit breakers may not be able to safely interrupt the considerable current that would flow. To prevent the risk of an arc being drawn across from one section of wire to earth, when passing through the neutral section, the train must be coasting and the circuit breakers must be open. In many cases, this is done manually by the drivers. To help them, a warning board is provided just before both the neutral section and an advance warning some distance before. A further board is then provided after the neutral section to tell drivers to re-close the circuit breaker, although drivers must not do this until the rear pantograph has passed this board. In the UK, a system known as Automatic Power Control (APC) automatically opens and closes the circuit breaker, this being achieved by using sets of permanent magnets alongside the track communicating with a detector on the train. The only action needed by the driver is to shut off power and coast and therefore warning boards are still provided at and on the approach to neutral sections.
text_ai_base: To prevent the risk of out-of-phase supplies mixing, sections of rail fed from different feeder stations must remain thoroughly isolated. This is accomplished through Neutral Sections, also called Phase Breaks, which are typically located at feeder stations and halfway between them. Normally, only half of these sections are active, allowing another feeder station to be shut down as power is supplied from nearby feeder stations. Neutral Sections consist of an earthed section of wire separated from live wires on either side by insulating materials, such as ceramic beads, enabling the pantograph to transition smoothly between sections. The grounded section prevents arcing between live sections due to potentially high voltage differences when live sections exist on separate phases. Protective circuit breakers might struggle to safely handle the significant current that could occur. To avoid drawing an arc from one wire section to the ground while passing through the neutral section, trains must coast with circuit breakers open. This is often done manually by drivers, who are aided by a warning board placed before the neutral section and an advance warning board some distance ahead. Another board follows the neutral section, instructing drivers to close the circuit breaker, but only after the rear pantograph has passed it. In the UK, an Automatic Power Control (APC) system manages the opening and closing of circuit breakers automatically using sets of permanent magnets along the track that interact with a detector on the train. Despite this automation, drivers must still cut off power and coast, so warning boards remain in place near neutral sections and along their approach.
text_ai_humanized: To stave off the risks from mixing out-of-phase power supplies, segments of the railway fed from various feeder stations need to be distinctly segregated. This separation is managed through what are known as Neutral Sections, or Phase Breaks, nestled at feeder stations and midway between them. Typically, only half of these sections are engaged to allow one feeder station to be deactivated, ensuring power continuity from adjacent stations. Neutral Sections are made up of a grounded wire stretch, flanked on both sides by live wires, separated by insulating materials like ceramic beads. These beads help the pantograph transition smoothly from one section to another. The grounded part helps avert arcing due to high voltage disparities when live portions of the track operate on separate phases. Protective circuit breakers might find it tough to manage the hefty currents that could ensue during such transitions. To prevent the train from inadvertently drawing an arc from the live wire section to the ground when navigating the neutral section, it's vital for trains to coast with their circuit breakers open. Drivers often manage this manually, guided by a warning board posted before they reach the neutral section and a preliminary warning sign some distance beforehand. Following the neutral section, another board directs drivers to close the circuit breaker, but only once the rear pantograph has successfully passed. Those trusty old warning boards remain crucial near neutral sections and their approaches—seeming a bit redundant in the wake of technology, but a necessary safety measure nonetheless.

text_human: Fearing the worst, the Romans began a major mobilization, all but pulling out of recently pacified Spain and Gaul. They even established a major garrison in Sicily in case the Seleucids ever got to Italy. This fear was shared by Rome's Greek allies, who had largely ignored Rome in the years after the Second Macedonian War, but now followed Rome again for the first time since that war. A major Roman-Greek force was mobilized under the command of the great hero of the Second Punic War, Scipio Africanus, and set out for Greece, beginning the Roman-Syrian War. After initial fighting that revealed serious Seleucid weaknesses, the Seleucids tried to turn the Roman strength against them at the Battle of Thermopylae (as they believed the 300 Spartans had done centuries earlier). Like the Spartans, the Seleucids lost the battle, and were forced to evacuate Greece. The Romans pursued the Seleucids by crossing the Hellespont, which marked the first time a Roman army had ever entered Asia. The decisive engagement was fought at the Battle of Magnesia, resulting in a complete Roman victory. The Seleucids sued for peace, and Rome forced them to give up their recent Greek conquests. Although they still controlled a great deal of territory, this defeat marked the decline of their empire, as they were to begin facing increasingly aggressive subjects in the east (the Parthians) and the west (the Greeks). Their empire disintegrated into a rump over the course of the next century, when it was eclipsed by Pontus. Following Magnesia, Rome again withdrew from Greece, assuming (or hoping) that the lack of a major Greek power would ensure a stable peace. In fact, it did the opposite.

This fear resonated with Rome's Greek allies, who had mostly distanced themselves from Rome after the Second Macedonian War but now re-aligned with Rome for the first time since then. Over the next century, their empire dwindled, overshadowed by Pontus. They didn't hesitate to set up a formidable garrison in Sicily, just in case the Seleucid forces made their way to Italian shores. This concern was shared by Rome's Greek allies. Although these allies had mostly kept their distance since the Second Macedonian War, they now found themselves rejoining forces with Rome against a common threat. A formidable alliance was forged under the command of Scipio Africanus, famed for his triumph in the Second Punic War, as he led a powerful Roman-Greek army into Greece. With this, the Roman-Syrian War commenced. In the early encounters, the Seleucids' vulnerabilities were laid bare. In an attempt to mimic the legendary Spartan stand at Thermopylae, the Seleucids tried to hold their ground, but like the Spartans before them, they were ultimately overpowered and driven out of Greece. The determined Romans didn't stop there. They pursued the fleeing Seleucids across the Hellespont, marking the moment when Roman forces stepped foot in Asia for the first time. The confrontation peaked at the decisive Battle of Magnesia. Here, the Seleucids suffered an overwhelming defeat, leading them to sue for peace and abandon their Greek acquisitions. Although the Seleucid Empire still retained vast lands, the sting of this loss was a turning point. With aggressive threats looming from the Parthians in the east and the Greeks in the west, their empire began its decline. Over the ensuing century, their influence waned, eventually overshadowed by the rise of Pontus. Following the victory at Magnesia, Rome retreated from Greece, perhaps convinced or simply optimistic that peace would endure in the absence of a dominating Greek power. Ironically, this withdrawal didn't usher in the tranquil era they had hoped for.

In a swirl of apprehension, the Romans took bold action, almost pulling back from their newly settled territories in Spain and Gaul. They didn't hesitate to set up a formidable garrison in Sicily, just in case the Seleucid forces made their way to Italian shores. This concern was shared by Rome's Greek allies. Although these allies had mostly kept their distance since the Second Macedonian War, they now found themselves rejoining forces with Rome against a common threat.

A formidable alliance was forged under the command of Scipio Africanus, famed for his triumph in the Second Punic War, as he led a powerful Roman-Greek army into Greece. With this, the Roman-Syrian War commenced. In the early encounters, the Seleucids' vulnerabilities were laid bare. In an attempt to mimic the legendary Spartan stand at Thermopylae, the Seleucids tried to hold their ground, but like the Spartans before them, they were ultimately overpowered and driven out of Greece.

The determined Romans didn't stop there. They pursued the fleeing Seleucids across the Hellespont, marking the moment when Roman forces stepped foot in Asia for the first time. The confrontation peaked at the decisive Battle of Magnesia. Here, the Seleucids suffered an overwhelming defeat, leading them to sue for peace and abandon their Greek acquisitions. Although the Seleucid Empire still retained vast lands, the sting of this loss was a turning point. With aggressive threats looming from the Parthians in the east and the Greeks in the west, their empire began its decline. Over the ensuing century, their influence waned, eventually overshadowed by the rise of Pontus.

Following the victory at Magnesia, Rome retreated from Greece, perhaps convinced or simply optimistic that peace would endure in the absence of a dominating Greek power. Ironically, this withdrawal didn't usher in the tranquil era they had hoped for.

text_human: Since re-establishing independence, Estonia has styled itself as the gateway between East and West and aggressively pursued economic reform and integration with the West. Estonia's market reforms put it among the economic leaders in the former COMECON area.[citation needed] In 1994, based on the economic theories of Milton Friedman, Estonia became one of the first countries to adopt a flat tax, with a uniform rate of 26% regardless of personal income. In January 2005, the personal income tax rate was reduced to 24%. Another reduction to 23% followed in January 2006. The income tax rate was decreased to 21% by January 2008. The Government of Estonia finalised the design of Estonian euro coins in late 2004, and adopted the euro as the country's currency on 1 January 2011, later than planned due to continued high inflation. A Land Value Tax is levied which is used to fund local municipalities. It is a state level tax, however 100% of the revenue is used to fund Local Councils. The rate is set by the Local Council within the limits of 0.1–2.5%. It is one of the most important sources of funding for municipalities. The Land Value Tax is levied on the value of the land only with improvements and buildings not considered. Very few exemptions are considered on the land value tax and even public institutions are subject to the tax. The tax has contributed to a high rate (~90%) of owner-occupied residences within Estonia, compared to a rate of 67.4% in the United States.

The rate was lowered to 24% in January 2005, to 23% in January 2006, and further reduced to 21% by January 2008. Estonia finalized its euro coin designs in late 2004 and adopted the euro as its currency on January 1, 2011, a delay caused by persistently high inflation. Estonia also levies a Land Value Tax to fund local municipalities, setting the rate at the state level but allocating 100% of the revenue to local councils. The local council determines the tax rate within a range of 0.1–2.5%. This tax, based solely on land value without considering buildings, is among the most critical funding sources for municipalities. There are minimal exemptions, and even public institutions must pay the tax. Consequently, Estonia boasts a high rate of owner-occupied homes at about 90%, significantly higher than the 67.4% in the United States.
text_ai_humanized: Since Estonia regained its independence, the nation has emerged as a pivotal bridge between East and West, eagerly embracing economic reforms and aligning itself with Western countries. Notably, Estonia's market reforms have placed it at the forefront among former COMECON nations. Back in 1994, drawing inspiration from Milton Friedman's economic principles, the country introduced a flat tax system. Initially, the rate was pegged at 26% for personal income, irrespective of what individuals earned, but it didn't stop there. Estonia progressively lowered the tax rate over the years: dropping to 24% in January 2005, then to 23% in January 2006, and ultimately reaching 21% by January 2008. The journey to euro adoption was marked by a few bumps, notably a persistent inflation issue that delayed the process. Nonetheless, Estonia finalized its euro coin designs by the latter part of 2004 and welcomed the euro as its official currency on January 1, 2011. Another key aspect of Estonia’s fiscal policy is the Land Value Tax, which serves as a financial backbone for local municipalities. Set at the state level, the tax generates revenue that is wholly allocated to local councils, which have the discretion to adjust the tax rate within a band of 0.1% to 2.5%. What's fascinating is that this tax is determined purely based on land value; buildings don't come into play here, making it pivotal for municipal funding. With few exemptions, and even public institutions shouldering their tax responsibilities, Estonia achieves a noteworthy level of homeownership. A whopping 90% of homes are owner-occupied—quite the leap compared to the 67.4% in the United States. This robust homeownership rate stands as a testament to the unique and efficient fiscal strategies Estonia employs.

text_human: In 1718, at the behest of either Rector Samuel Andrew or the colony's Governor Gurdon Saltonstall, Cotton Mather contacted a successful businessman named Elihu Yale, who lived in Wales but had been born in Boston and whose father, David, had been one of the original settlers in New Haven, to ask him for financial help in constructing a new building for the college. Through the persuasion of Jeremiah Dummer, Yale, who had made a fortune through trade while living in Madras as a representative of the East India Company, donated nine bales of goods, which were sold for more than £560, a substantial sum at the time. Cotton Mather suggested that the school change its name to Yale College. Meanwhile, a Harvard graduate working in England convinced some 180 prominent intellectuals that they should donate books to Yale. The 1714 shipment of 500 books represented the best of modern English literature, science, philosophy and theology. It had a profound effect on intellectuals at Yale. Undergraduate Jonathan Edwards discovered John Locke's works and developed his original theology known as the "new divinity." In 1722 the Rector and six of his friends, who had a study group to discuss the new ideas, announced that they had given up Calvinism, become Arminians, and joined the Church of England. They were ordained in England and returned to the colonies as missionaries for the Anglican faith. Thomas Clapp became president in 1745, and struggled to return the college to Calvinist orthodoxy; but he did not close the library. Other students found Deist books in the library.

Persuaded by Jeremiah Dummer, Yale, who had accumulated wealth through trade during his stay in Madras with the East India Company, contributed nine bales of goods. This shift led them to join the Church of England, where they were ordained. Upon their return, they served as Anglican missionaries. Then came 1745, when Thomas Clapp assumed the presidency, endeavoring to steer the college back to Calvinist orthodoxy. Interestingly, he kept the library's doors wide open, inadvertently providing students access to Deist literature—hardly a mundane tale!

In 1718, Cotton Mather made a significant move with a little nudge from either Rector Samuel Andrew or Governor Gurdon Saltonstall. He penned a letter to Elihu Yale, a successful businessman residing in Wales who was born in Boston to David Yale, one of New Haven's pioneering settlers. Mather's mission? To secure Yale's financial support for a new college edifice. Yale, having amassed substantial wealth through trade in Madras with the East India Company, was eventually persuaded by Jeremiah Dummer to make a generous gift. His contribution consisted of nine bales of goods that ultimately fetched over £560—a hefty sum for that era. In gratitude for Yale's lavish donation, Mather suggested the college be named in his honor: Yale College.

Meanwhile, over in England, a Harvard graduate rallied approximately 180 esteemed intellectuals to donate books to the budding college. This remarkable shipment arrived in 1714, packing around 500 volumes that showcased the cream of contemporary English literature, science, philosophy, and theology. The impact on Yale's scholarly environment was profound, to say the least. Among those influenced was undergraduate Jonathan Edwards, whose encounter with John Locke's writings gave rise to his "new divinity" theology.

Fast forward to 1722, when the Rector and six associates, having thoughtfully examined these novel ideas, took a bold step away from Calvinism to embrace Arminianism. This shift led them to join the Church of England, where they were ordained. Upon their return, they served as Anglican missionaries. Then came 1745, when Thomas Clapp assumed the presidency, endeavoring to steer the college back to Calvinist orthodoxy. Interestingly, he kept the library's doors wide open, inadvertently providing students access to Deist literature—hardly a mundane tale!

text_human: Darwin was hard at work on his "big book" on Natural Selection, when on 18 June 1858 he received a parcel from Wallace, who stayed on the Maluku Islands (Ternate and Gilolo). It enclosed twenty pages describing an evolutionary mechanism, a response to Darwin's recent encouragement, with a request to send it on to Lyell if Darwin thought it worthwhile. The mechanism was similar to Darwin's own theory. Darwin wrote to Lyell that "your words have come true with a vengeance, ... forestalled" and he would "of course, at once write and offer to send [it] to any journal" that Wallace chose, adding that "all my originality, whatever it may amount to, will be smashed". Lyell and Hooker agreed that a joint publication putting together Wallace's pages with extracts from Darwin's 1844 Essay and his 1857 letter to Gray should be presented at the Linnean Society, and on 1 July 1858, the papers entitled On the Tendency of Species to form Varieties; and on the Perpetuation of Varieties and Species by Natural Means of Selection, by Wallace and Darwin respectively, were read out but drew little reaction. While Darwin considered Wallace's idea to be identical to his concept of natural selection, historians have pointed out differences. Darwin described natural selection as being analogous to the artificial selection practised by animal breeders, and emphasised competition between individuals; Wallace drew no comparison to selective breeding, and focused on ecological pressures that kept different varieties adapted to local conditions. Some historians have suggested that Wallace was actually discussing group selection rather than selection acting on individual variation.

This mechanism was strikingly similar to Darwin’s own theory. In a letter to Lyell, Darwin remarked that "your words have come true with a vengeance, ... forestalled," and stated he would "of course, at once write and offer to send [it] to any journal" Wallace preferred, adding that "all my originality, whatever it may amount to, will be smashed." Lyell and Hooker proposed a joint presentation, combining Wallace's pages with excerpts from Darwin's 1844 Essay and his 1857 letter to Gray, to be submitted to the Linnean Society. On 1 July 1858, the papers titled On the Tendency of Species to form Varieties; and on the Perpetuation of Varieties and Species by Natural Means of Selection, by Wallace and Darwin respectively, were read aloud but received little reaction. Although Darwin viewed Wallace's idea as identical to his own concept of natural selection, historians have noted differences. Darwin likened natural selection to artificial selection practiced by animal breeders, emphasizing individual competition. In contrast, Wallace did not draw comparisons to selective breeding and focused on ecological pressures that maintained varieties adapted to local environments. Some historians suggest Wallace may have been addressing group selection rather than individual variation.
text_ai_humanized: During the mid-19th century, as Charles Darwin labored over his extensive work on Natural Selection, something unexpected arrived on his doorstep. On June 18, 1858, a parcel from Alfred Russel Wallace, then based in the remote Maluku Islands, landed in Darwin’s hands. Wallace's packet contained a succinct, twenty-page outline of an evolutionary theory, echoing Darwin’s own, sparked by Darwin's earlier encouragement to openly share findings. Wallace also requested that the document be sent to the esteemed Sir Charles Lyell if it held any merit in Darwin’s eyes. Upon reading it, Darwin was struck by the uncanny resemblance to his own conclusions and confessed in a letter to Lyell that Wallace had, “with a vengeance,” anticipated his theory. “All my originality, whatever it may amount to, will be smashed,” Darwin admitted, though he gracefully offered to submit Wallace's work to any journal Wallace chose. Lyell, alongside Joseph Dalton Hooker, suggested a simultaneous presentation of findings, merging Wallace's manuscript with extracts from Darwin's own unpublished 1844 Essay and a 1857 letter he had penned to Asa Gray. This collaboration was to be showcased to the Linnean Society in London. On July 1, 1858, joint papers titled "On the Tendency of Species to form Varieties; and on the Perpetuation of Varieties and Species by Natural Means of Selection" were read for the society. Strangely, despite the groundbreaking content, the reception was minimal—perhaps the assembly had yet to grasp the depth of what was proposed. While Darwin saw a mirror of his ideas in Wallace’s paper, later historians detected nuances in their perspectives. Darwin’s vision of natural selection drew parallels to the practice of artificial selection, where breeders meticulously chose desirable traits, underscoring fierce individual competition. Wallace, on the other hand, leaned towards the ecological side of things, highlighting environmental pressures that preserved local adaptations. There’s even a whisper among some scholars that Wallace’s focus might have leaned towards group selection rather than strictly individual variation. Curious how interpretations can diverge, isn't it?

text_human: The interface of Windows 8 has been the subject of mixed reaction. Bright wrote that its system of hot corners and edge swiping "wasn't very obvious" due to the lack of instructions provided by the operating system on the functions accessed through the user interface, even by the video tutorial added on the RTM release (which only instructed users to point at corners of the screen or swipe from its sides). Despite this "stumbling block", Bright said that Windows 8's interface worked well in some places, but began to feel incoherent when switching between the "Metro" and desktop environments, sometimes through inconsistent means. Tom Warren of The Verge wrote that the new interface was "as stunning as it is surprising", contributing to an "incredibly personal" experience once it is customized by the user, but had a steep learning curve, and was awkward to use with a keyboard and mouse. He noted that while forcing all users to use the new touch-oriented interface was a risky move for Microsoft as a whole, it was necessary in order to push development of apps for the Windows Store. Others, such as Adrian Kingsley-Hughes from ZDNet, considered the interface to be "clumsy and impractical" due to its inconsistent design (going as far as considering it "two operating systems unceremoniously bolted together"), and concluded that "Windows 8 wasn't born out of a need or demand; it was born out of a desire on Microsoft's part to exert its will on the PC industry and decide to shape it in a direction—touch and tablets -- that allows it to compete against, and remain relevant in the face of Apple's iPad."

This tutorial only suggested that users point at screen corners or swipe its sides. Despite this challenge, Bright mentioned that the interface worked well in certain aspects but became incoherent when transitioning between the "Metro" and desktop environments, sometimes using inconsistent methods. Tom Warren of The Verge described the new interface as "stunning" and "surprising," noting that it created a "personal" experience once customized by users, though he acknowledged its steep learning curve and awkwardness when used with a keyboard and mouse. Warren highlighted that while compelling all users to adopt the touch-focused interface was a risky strategy for Microsoft, it was essential for driving app development for the Windows Store. Conversely, Adrian Kingsley-Hughes from ZDNet criticized the interface as "clumsy and impractical" due to its inconsistent design, likening it to "two operating systems unceremoniously bolted together." He argued that "Windows 8 wasn't born out of necessity or demand; it was Microsoft's attempt to shape the PC industry toward touch and tablets, allowing competition against Apple's iPad and ensuring relevance."
text_ai_humanized: Not everyone was sold on the interface of Windows 8 when it debuted, with critics expressing a range of opinions. Bright pointed out a glaring issue: the reliance on hot corners and edge-swiping wasn’t exactly intuitive. The operating system lacked clear instructions on how to access its functions, even though a video tutorial was part of the RTM release. The tutorial merely hinted that users might want to try pointing at screen corners or giving the sides a swipe. Despite these challenges, Bright conceded that the interface had its bright spots. Yet, when users had to juggle between the "Metro" style and the traditional desktop, things tended to fall apart. The methods were inconsistent and sometimes downright confusing. On the other hand, Tom Warren over at The Verge had mixed feelings too. He found the new look "stunning" and "surprising." Once users got the hang of personalizing it, the interface became almost enchanting, he said. But the process wasn’t without its hurdles. Warren mentioned the learning curve was pretty steep, particularly awkward is an understatement when used with a keyboard and mouse. He noted that pushing all users toward a touch-centric design was a bold gamble for Microsoft. They aimed to spur app growth on the Windows Store this way, despite the gamble's risky nature. Adrian Kingsley-Hughes of ZDNet didn't mince words, offering a scathing critique. He called the interface "clumsy and impractical," tearing into its uneven design. The whole thing, he felt, was like "two operating systems unceremoniously bolted together.” In his view, Windows 8 wasn't a response to any market demand or necessity. It was, rather, Microsoft's bid to nudge the PC market into touch and tablets, keep up with the iPad craze, and stay relevant in a changing tech landscape.

text_human: In September 2012 at the Tokyo Game Show, Sony announced that a new, slimmer PS3 redesign (CECH-4000) was due for release in late 2012 and that it would be available with either a 250 GB or 500 GB hard drive. Three versions Super Slim model were revealed: one with a 500 GB hard drive, a second with a 250 GB hard drive which is not available in PAL regions, and a third with a 12 GB flash storage that was only available in PAL regions. The storage of 12 GB model is upgradable with an official standalone 250 GB hard drive. A vertical stand was also released for the model. In the United Kingdom, the 500 GB model was released on September 28, 2012; and the 12 GB model was released on October 12, 2012. In the United States, the PS3 Super Slim was first released as a bundled console. The 250 GB was model was bundled with Game of the Year edition of Uncharted 3: Drake's Deception and released on September 25, 2012; and the 500 GB model was bundled with Assassin's Creed III and released on October 30, 2012. In Japan, the black colored Super Slim model was released on October 4, 2012; and the white colored Super Slim model was released on November 22, 2012. The Super Slim model is 20 percent smaller and 25 percent lighter than the Slim model and features a manual sliding disc cover instead of a motorized slot-loading disc cover of the Slim model. The white colored Super Slim model was released in the United States on January 27, 2013 as part of the Instant Game Collection Bundle. The Garnet Red and Azurite Blue colored models were launched in Japan on February 28, 2013. The Garnet Red version was released in North America on March 12, 2013 as part of the God of War: Ascension bundle with 500 GB storage and contained God of War: Ascension as well as the God of War Saga. The Azurite Blue model was released as a GameStop exclusive with 250GB storage.
