In September 2012, amid the buzz of the Tokyo Game Show, Sony unveiled a sleeker iteration of the PS3, the CECH-4000 model, with plans to roll it out later that year. Dubbed the Super Slim, this new version could be chosen with a hard drive of either 250 GB or 500 GB. Intriguingly, Sony presented three distinct configurations: a 500 GB option, a 250 GB model not appearing in PAL regions, and a 12 GB flash storage edition exclusively for PAL geographies—this last one capable of upgrading via an official 250 GB hard drive.

Sony also released a vertical stand specifically for this model, a small but thoughtful accessory. The UK saw the 500 GB unit available on September 28, 2012, while the 12 GB version followed shortly behind on October 12, 2012. Across the pond in the US, the Super Slim initially made its entry through bundled packages: the 250 GB variant alongside Uncharted 3: Drake’s Deception on September 25, and later, the 500 GB model with Assassin’s Creed III on October 30.

Japan wasn’t left out either. By October 4, 2012, the black Super Slim hit shelves, with its white counterpart appearing on November 22. Notably smaller and lighter—20% smaller and 25% lighter than its predecessor—the Super Slim introduced a manual sliding disc cover, a departure from the Slim’s motorized design.

Fast forward to January 27, 2013, the US received the white Super Slim as part of the Instant Game Collection Bundle. Japan again had its share of exclusivity with the Garnet Red and Azurite Blue models, launching on February 28, 2013. North America didn’t lag far behind; on March 12, 2013, the Garnet Red model became available as part of the God of War: Ascension bundle, featuring generous 500 GB storage and including the God of War Saga. For those in search of the Azurite Blue variant, it was exclusively stocked at GameStop, equipped with 250 GB storage.

text_human: In the wake of the racially-motivated" church shooting in Charleston, South Carolina, Yale was under criticism again in the summer of 2015 for Calhoun College, one of 12 residential colleges, which was named after John C. Calhoun, a slave-owner and strong slavery supporter in the nineteenth century. In July 2015 students signed a petition calling for the name change. They argued in the petition that—while Calhoun was respected in the 19th century as an "extraordinary American statesman"—he was "one of the most prolific defenders of slavery and white supremacy" in the history of the United States. In August 2015 Yale President Peter Salovey addressed the Freshman Class of 2019 in which he responded to the racial tensions but explained why the college would not be renamed. He described Calhoun as a "a notable political theorist, a vice president to two different U.S. presidents, a secretary of war and of state, and a congressman and senator representing South Carolina." He acknowledged that Calhoun also "believed that the highest forms of civilization depend on involuntary servitude. Not only that, but he also believed that the races he thought to be inferior, black people in particular, ought to be subjected to it for the sake of their own best interests." Racial tensions increased in the fall of 2015 centering on comments by Nicholas A. Christakis and his wife Erika regarding freedom of speech. In April 2016 Salovey announced that "despite decades of vigorous alumni and student protests," Calhoun's name will remain on the Yale residential college explaining that it is preferable for Yale students to live in Calhoun's "shadow" so they will be "better prepared to rise to the challenges of the present and the future." He claimed that if they removed Calhoun's name, it would "obscure" his "legacy of slavery rather than addressing it." "Yale is part of that history" and "We cannot erase American history, but we can confront it, teach it and learn from it." One change that will be issued is the title of “master” for faculty members who serve as residential college leaders will be renamed to “head of college” due to its connotation of slavery.

Named after John C. Calhoun, a 19th-century slave owner and staunch supporter of slavery, the college’s name drew controversy. In July 2015, students signed a petition demanding a name change, asserting that despite Calhoun's recognition as an "extraordinary American statesman" during his time, he was "one of the most prolific defenders of slavery and white supremacy" in U.S. history. In August 2015, Yale President Peter Salovey addressed these racial tensions while speaking to the Freshman Class of 2019. He explained why the college would retain its name, citing Calhoun as a "notable political theorist" and highlighting his roles as vice president to two U.S. presidents, a secretary of war and state, and a congressman and senator for South Carolina. Salovey admitted Calhoun believed civilization depended on involuntary servitude and held that black people, whom he deemed inferior, should be subjected to slavery for their own benefit. Racial tensions escalated in fall 2015 following comments by Nicholas A. Christakis and his wife Erika on free speech. He reasoned that Yale students should experience Calhoun's "shadow" to be "better equipped to face modern and future challenges." Removing Calhoun's name, Salovey argued, would "obscure” his “legacy of slavery rather than confronting it," adding, "Yale is part of that history," and "We cannot erase American history, but we can confront, teach, and learn from it." As a related change, the title "master" for faculty leading residential colleges will be changed to "head of college" due to its slavery-related connotation.
text_ai_humanized: In the wake of the tragic racially motivated church shooting in Charleston, South Carolina, during the summer of 2015, Yale found itself in the spotlight once more, grappling with controversy surrounding Calhoun College. This particular residential college, named after John C. Calhoun—a 19th-century figure notorious for his ardent support of slavery—came under scrutiny. By July, a wave of students organized a petition urging the university to reconsider the name, pointing out the stark contradiction: although Calhoun was a lauded "extraordinary American statesman" in his day, he was undeniably one of history's staunchest advocates for slavery and white supremacy in the United States. Fast forward to August 2015, when Yale President Peter Salovey addressed these surfacing racial tensions during a talk with the incoming Freshman Class of 2019. He laid out his stance on why the institution planned to keep the college's name unchanged. Salovey acknowledged Calhoun's significant political roles—among them, vice president to two presidents of the United States, as well as his positions as secretary of war and state, and terms as both congressman and senator from South Carolina. However, he wasn't blind to the darker aspects of Calhoun's legacy—admitting that Calhoun firmly believed that societal progress hinged on the continuance of forced servitude, guided by a deeply flawed belief in the inferiority of black people who, he argued, should be enslaved for their supposed 'benefit.' Later, in the fall of 2015, tensions simmered further following comments on free speech made by Nicholas A. Christakis and his wife, Erika. Despite an ongoing clamor from students and alumni alike, in April 2016, Salovey reiterated the decision to keep the name. He argued that confronting Calhoun's "shadow" equips students with the tools to tackle contemporary and future societal hurdles. Removing the name, in his view, would "obscure" the dialogue on slavery's legacy rather than address it head-on. He added, "Yale is part of that history, and while we can’t undo the past, we can confront and learn from it." As an additional step towards sensitivity, Yale announced a modification of titles by changing "master" to "head of college," acknowledging the term's ties to slavery.

text_human: The Feinberg School of Medicine (previously the Northwestern University Medical School) has produced a number of notable graduates, including Mary Harris Thompson, Class of 1870, ad eundem, first female surgeon in Chicago, first female surgeon at Cook County Hospital, and founder of the Mary Thomson Hospital, Roswell Park, Class of 1876, prominent surgeon for whom the Roswell Park Cancer Institute in Buffalo, New York, is named, Daniel Hale Williams, Class of 1883, performed the first successful American open heart surgery; only black charter member of the American College of Surgeons, Charles Horace Mayo, Class of 1888, co-founder of Mayo Clinic, Carlos Montezuma, Class of 1889, one of the first Native Americans to receive a Doctor of Medicine degree from any school, and founder of the Society of American Indians, Howard T. Ricketts, Class of 1897, who discovered bacteria of the genus Rickettsia, and identified the cause and methods of transmission of rocky mountain spotted fever, Allen B. Kanavel, Class of 1899, founder, regent, and president of the American College of Surgeons, internationally recognized as founder of modern hand and peripheral nerve surgery, Robert F. Furchgott, Class of 1940, received a Lasker Award in 1996 and the 1998 Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine for his co-discovery of nitric oxide, Thomas E. Starzl, Class of 1952, performed the first successful liver transplant in 1967 and received the National Medal of Science in 2004 and a Lasker Award in 2012, Joseph P. Kerwin, first physician in space, flew on three skylab missions and later served as director of Space and Life Sciences at NASA, C. Richard Schlegel, Class of 1972, developed the dominant patent for a vaccine against human papillomavirus (administered as Gardasil) to prevent cervical cancer, David J. Skorton, Class of 1974, a noted cardiologist became president of Cornell University in 2006, and Andrew E. Senyei, Class of 1979, inventor, venture capitalist, and entrepreneur, founder of biotech and genetics companies, and a university trustee.
text_ai_base: The Feinberg School of Medicine, formerly known as Northwestern University Medical School, has a legacy of notable graduates. Among them is Mary Harris Thompson, Class of 1870, ad eundem, who became Chicago's first female surgeon, the first female surgeon at Cook County Hospital, and the founder of the Mary Thomson Hospital. Roswell Park, Class of 1876, was a prominent surgeon who lent his name to the Roswell Park Cancer Institute in Buffalo, New York. Daniel Hale Williams, Class of 1883, was a trailblazer who performed the first successful American open-heart surgery and was the only Black charter member of the American College of Surgeons. Charles Horace Mayo, Class of 1888, co-founded the Mayo Clinic. Carlos Montezuma, Class of 1889, was one of the first Native Americans to earn a Doctor of Medicine degree and established the Society of American Indians. Howard T. Ricketts, Class of 1897, discovered the bacteria genus Rickettsia and uncovered the cause and transmission of Rocky Mountain spotted fever. Allen B. Kanavel, Class of 1899, was the founder, regent, and president of the American College of Surgeons, recognized globally as a pioneer in modern hand and peripheral nerve surgery. Nobel laureate Robert F. Furchgott, Class of 1940, won a 1996 Lasker Award and the 1998 Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine for his co-discovery of nitric oxide. Thomas E. Starzl, Class of 1952, made history with the first successful liver transplant in 1967 and earned the National Medal of Science in 2004 and a Lasker Award in 2012. Joseph P. Kerwin, the first physician in space, participated in three Skylab missions and subsequently became director of Space and Life Sciences at NASA. C. Richard Schlegel, Class of 1972, advanced the dominant patent for the HPV vaccine (marketed as Gardasil) to prevent cervical cancer. David J. Skorton, Class of 1974, was a distinguished cardiologist who became president of Cornell University in 2006. Andrew E. Senyei, Class of 1979, is known as an inventor, venture capitalist, and entrepreneur, founding several biotech and genetics companies and serving as a university trustee.
text_ai_humanized: Feinberg School of Medicine, which you might recognize from its earlier days as Northwestern University Medical School, boasts an impressive roster of alumni. Take Mary Harris Thompson, for instance—she graduated as part of the Class of 1870 and made her mark as Chicago's pioneering female surgeon, evident in her groundbreaking roles at Cook County Hospital and in establishing the Mary Thomson Hospital. Another notable name is Roswell Park from the Class of 1876, a leading figure in surgery whose legacy flourishes through the Roswell Park Cancer Institute in Buffalo, New York. Then there's Daniel Hale Williams, a trailblazer from the Class of 1883, celebrated for conducting America's first successful open-heart surgery. He was also the sole Black founding member of the American College of Surgeons, a significant achievement given the era. The Mayo Clinic traces its roots to Charles Horace Mayo, an alumnus of 1888, whose influence in medicine is widely acknowledged. In a different vein, Carlos Montezuma of the Class of 1889 stands out for being among the first Native Americans to earn a Doctor of Medicine degree and for founding the Society of American Indians, a significant stride toward representation. As a detective of sorts, Howard T. Ricketts from the Class of 1897 made groundbreaking discoveries on Rocky Mountain spotted fever, including its bacterial cause and transmission. Turning to the world of surgery, Allen B. Kanavel, Class of 1899, gained international recognition for his pioneering work in hand and peripheral nerve surgery and played key roles as founder, regent, and president of the American College of Surgeons. Nobel laureate status wasn’t out of reach for Robert F. Furchgott, Class of 1940, whose research won him the 1996 Lasker Award and the 1998 Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine due to his critical findings on nitric oxide. Thomas E. Starzl, a distinguished member of the Class of 1952, transformed medicine with the first successful liver transplant in 1967. His contributions earned him the National Medal of Science in 2004 and another Lasker Award in 2012—a true testament to his impact. Meanwhile, soaring into the cosmos, Joseph P. Kerwin became the first physician in space, participating in three Skylab missions before guiding Space and Life Sciences at NASA. Returning to Earth, C. Richard Schlegel of the Class of 1972 advanced the main patent for the HPV vaccine, known commercially as Gardasil, providing essential prevention against cervical cancer. A few years later, David J. Skorton, Class of 1974, transitioned from his esteemed cardiologist career to take the helm as Cornell University's president in 2006. Finally, Andrew E. Senyei, Class of 1979, embraced innovation, launching multiple biotech and genetics companies, all while serving as a dedicated university trustee.

text_human: Boundaries can be inclusive or exclusive depending on how they are perceived by other people. An exclusive boundary arises, for example, when a person adopts a marker that imposes restrictions on the behaviour of others. An inclusive boundary is created, by contrast, by the use of a marker with which other people are ready and able to associate. At the same time, however, an inclusive boundary will also impose restrictions on the people it has included by limiting their inclusion within other boundaries. An example of this is the use of a particular language by a newcomer in a room full of people speaking various languages. Some people may understand the language used by this person while others may not. Those who do not understand it might take the newcomer's use of this particular language merely as a neutral sign of identity. But they might also perceive it as imposing an exclusive boundary that is meant to mark them off from her. On the other hand, those who do understand the newcomer's language could take it as an inclusive boundary, through which the newcomer associates herself with them to the exclusion of the other people present. Equally, however, it is possible that people who do understand the newcomer but who also speak another language may not want to speak the newcomer's language and so see her marker as an imposition and a negative boundary. It is possible that the newcomer is either aware or unaware of this, depending on whether she herself knows other languages or is conscious of the plurilingual quality of the people there and is respectful of it or not.
text_ai_base: Boundaries can be seen as either inclusive or exclusive, depending on how others perceive them. An exclusive boundary is created when someone adopts a marker that restricts the behavior of others. Conversely, an inclusive boundary forms when a marker allows others to easily associate with it. However, inclusive boundaries also impose restrictions by limiting individuals to one group, thereby excluding them from others. For instance, if a newcomer in a multilingual room chooses to speak a particular language, some may understand it, while others may not. Those who don't understand might view this choice simply as a neutral identity marker or as an exclusive boundary that separates them from the newcomer. Conversely, those who do understand the language might see it as an inclusive boundary, connecting them with the newcomer while excluding others. However, even among those who understand the language, some may prefer not to use it, viewing the newcomer's choice as an unwelcome imposition. The newcomer might be aware or unaware of these dynamics, depending on whether she knows other languages or understands and respects the multilingual nature of the group.
text_ai_humanized: Boundaries walk a fine line—sometimes inviting in, other times shutting out—guided by perception. When an individual adopts a specific marker, it sets the groundwork for an exclusive boundary, dictating the actions or affiliations of others. On the flip side, an inclusive boundary emerges from markers that encourage connection and commonality. But here's a twist: these inclusive boundaries can still pigeonhole a person, confining them to a certain circle while barring entrée to others. Imagine stepping into a multilingual gathering. Opting to converse in one language means some will follow along seamlessly, while others might find themselves adrift. To those lost in translation, this choice could feel like a mere label or perhaps, more divisively, an exclusive boundary—a wall that separates them from the speaker. Yet, to those in the know, it’s an inclusive beacon, forging bonds with the newcomer but inevitably sidelining those outside the linguistic loop. And even among the conversationally included, preferences vary—some might balk at the language choice, perceiving it as overbearing. The newcomer, carving her path in this social labyrinth, might or might not grasp these subtleties, contingent on her linguistic repertoire and sensitivity to the group’s diverse dynamics.

text_human: In October 2014, the trial of six senior staff and journalists at The Sun newspaper began. All six were charged with conspiring to commit misconduct in a public office. They included The Sun's head of news Chris Pharo, who faced six charges, while ex-managing editor Graham Dudman and ex-Sun deputy news editor Ben O'Driscoll were accused of four charges each. Thames Valley district reporter Jamie Pyatt and picture editor John Edwards were charged with three counts each, while ex-reporter John Troup was accused of two counts. The trial related to illegal payments allegedly made to public officials, with prosecutors saying the men conspired to pay officials from 2002–11, including police, prison officers and soldiers. They were accused of buying confidential information about the Royal Family, public figures and prison inmates. They all denied the charges. On 16 January 2015, Troup and Edwards were cleared by the jury of all charges against them. The jury also partially cleared O'Driscoll and Dudman but continued deliberating over other counts faced by them, as well as the charges against Pharo and Pyatt. On 21 January 2015, the jury told the court that it was unable to reach unanimous verdicts on any of the outstanding charges and was told by the judge, Richard Marks, that he would accept majority verdicts. Shortly afterwards, one of the jurors sent a note to the judge and was discharged. The judge told the remaining 11 jurors that their colleague had been "feeling unwell and feeling under a great deal of pressure and stress from the situation you are in", and that under the circumstances he was prepared to accept majority verdicts of "11 to zero or 10 to 1". On 22 January 2015, the jury was discharged after failing to reach verdicts on the outstanding charges. The Crown Prosecution Service (CPS) announced that it would seek a retrial.

Thames Valley district reporter Jamie Pyatt and picture editor John Edwards were charged with three counts, while ex-reporter John Troup was accused of two counts. The trial centered on illegal payments allegedly made to public officials, with prosecutors claiming the group conspired to pay officials, including police, prison officers, and soldiers, from 2002 to 2011 to buy confidential information about the Royal Family, public figures, and prison inmates. All the accused denied the charges. On January 16, 2015, Troup and Edwards were acquitted by the jury. The jury partially cleared O'Driscoll and Dudman but continued deliberating on other charges against them, as well as those against Pharo and Pyatt. On January 21, the jury informed the court they couldn't reach unanimous verdicts on the remaining charges. Judge Richard Marks said he would accept majority verdicts shortly after one juror was discharged for health reasons. The judge informed the remaining 11 jurors that he would accept verdicts of "11 to zero or 10 to 1." On January 22, the jury was discharged after failing to reach verdicts on the outstanding charges, and the Crown Prosecution Service (CPS) announced plans to seek a retrial.

Alongside him were Graham Dudman, the former managing editor, and Ben O'Driscoll, the ex-deputy news editor, each dealing with four charges on their plate. Jamie Pyatt, reporting from Thames Valley, and picture editor John Edwards faced three while ex-reporter John Troup grappled with two. The crux of the trial revolved around allegations that these individuals orchestrated illegal payments to public officials—police officers, prison staff, and soldiers—spanning from 2002 to 2011. On January 22, without reaching conclusions on lingering charges, the jury was let go. Subsequently, the Crown Prosecution Service (CPS) declared intentions for a retrial, leaving the case's resolution hanging in the balance.

text_human: Intense media interest in the opinions and private lives of the royal family during the 1980s led to a series of sensational stories in the press, not all of which were entirely true. As Kelvin MacKenzie, editor of The Sun, told his staff: "Give me a Sunday for Monday splash on the Royals. Don't worry if it's not true—so long as there's not too much of a fuss about it afterwards." Newspaper editor Donald Trelford wrote in The Observer of 21 September 1986: "The royal soap opera has now reached such a pitch of public interest that the boundary between fact and fiction has been lost sight of ... it is not just that some papers don't check their facts or accept denials: they don't care if the stories are true or not." It was reported, most notably in The Sunday Times of 20 July 1986, that the Queen was worried that Margaret Thatcher's economic policies fostered social divisions and was alarmed by high unemployment, a series of riots, the violence of a miners' strike, and Thatcher's refusal to apply sanctions against the apartheid regime in South Africa. The sources of the rumours included royal aide Michael Shea and Commonwealth Secretary-General Shridath Ramphal, but Shea claimed his remarks were taken out of context and embellished by speculation. Thatcher reputedly said the Queen would vote for the Social Democratic Party—Thatcher's political opponents. Thatcher's biographer John Campbell claimed "the report was a piece of journalistic mischief-making". Belying reports of acrimony between them, Thatcher later conveyed her personal admiration for the Queen, and the Queen gave two honours in her personal gift—membership in the Order of Merit and the Order of the Garter—to Thatcher after her replacement as prime minister by John Major. Former Canadian Prime Minister Brian Mulroney said Elizabeth was a "behind the scenes force" in ending apartheid.
text_ai_base: During the 1980s, intense media fascination with the opinions and private lives of the royal family led to numerous sensationalized press stories, many of which were less than truthful. Kelvin MacKenzie, then editor of The Sun, famously instructed his team: "Give me a Sunday for Monday splash on the Royals. Don't worry if it's not true—so long as there's not too much fuss about it afterwards." On September 21, 1986, newspaper editor Donald Trelford commented in The Observer: "The royal soap opera has now reached such a pitch of public interest that the boundary between fact and fiction has been lost ... not only do some papers avoid fact-checking or dismiss denials: they don’t care if the stories are true or not." A notable report in The Sunday Times on July 20, 1986, claimed that the Queen was concerned about Margaret Thatcher's economic policies, which she feared encouraged social divisions. The report also mentioned her alarm over high unemployment, civil unrest, violent miners' strikes, and Thatcher's refusal to enforce sanctions against apartheid in South Africa. These rumors were reportedly sourced from royal aide Michael Shea and Commonwealth Secretary-General Shridath Ramphal, though Shea insisted his comments were taken out of context and exaggerated. Thatcher was rumored to have claimed that the Queen would vote for her political rivals, the Social Democratic Party. According to Thatcher's biographer, John Campbell, "the report was a piece of journalistic mischief-making." Contrary to reports of tension between Thatcher and the Queen, Thatcher later expressed her personal admiration for the monarch. The Queen, in turn, awarded Thatcher two prestigious honors—membership in the Order of Merit and the Order of the Garter—after she was succeeded by John Major as prime minister. Former Canadian Prime Minister Brian Mulroney described Elizabeth as a "behind the scenes force" in the abolition of apartheid.
text_ai_humanized: Back in the flashy days of the 1980s, the media couldn't seem to resist poking its nose into the royal family's affairs, often blurring the lines between truth and theater. Kelvin MacKenzie, who helmed The Sun at the time, candidly urged his staff, "Bring me a juicy Royals story for Monday’s front page. Accuracy? No problem, just keep a lid on any backlash." This was a period when sensational stories, especially about the monarchy, were churned out like hotcakes. Take September 21, 1986, for instance, when newspaper bigwig Donald Trelford, in The Observer, bluntly pointed out, "The royal saga has morphed into a spectacle where fact and fiction intermingle freely... some newspapers hardly pause for fact-checking, dismissing any denials with ease. Truth? Not the priority.” Fast forward a smidge to July 20, 1986, and The Sunday Times was boldly reporting that Queen Elizabeth had expressed concerns over Margaret Thatcher's economic tactics, worries fuelled by fears of deepening societal rifts. Adding fire to the gossip, the article highlighted the Queen's unease about skyrocketing unemployment, chaotic miners' strikes, mounting civil unrest, and Thatcher’s reluctance to penalize apartheid in South Africa. Allegedly, royal aide Michael Shea and Commonwealth Secretary-General Shridath Ramphal were the informants, though Shea later argued his words were twisted and exaggerated. Thatcher herself was rumored to have thought the Queen would throw her political weight behind the Social Democratic Party, her opposition, with John Campbell, Thatcher's biographer, dismissing the report as "a crafty bit of journalistic mischief." Yet, any tales of frostiness between Thatcher and the Queen seem overblown. Thatcher would go on to speak warmly of the Queen, whom she admired greatly. In an interesting twist, when Thatcher exited office, the Queen honored her with coveted memberships in the Order of Merit and the Order of the Garter. On a broader stage, former Canadian Prime Minister Brian Mulroney depicted Elizabeth as a subtle yet significant player in toppling apartheid. A reminder, perhaps, that what's whispered behind palace walls might not entirely match the hype seen in the headlines.

text_human: Many insects possess very sensitive and, or specialized organs of perception. Some insects such as bees can perceive ultraviolet wavelengths, or detect polarized light, while the antennae of male moths can detect the pheromones of female moths over distances of many kilometers. The yellow paper wasp (Polistes versicolor) is known for its wagging movements as a form of communication within the colony; it can waggle with a frequency of 10.6±2.1 Hz (n=190). These wagging movements can signal the arrival of new material into the nest and aggression between workers can be used to stimulate others to increase foraging expeditions. There is a pronounced tendency for there to be a trade-off between visual acuity and chemical or tactile acuity, such that most insects with well-developed eyes have reduced or simple antennae, and vice versa. There are a variety of different mechanisms by which insects perceive sound, while the patterns are not universal, insects can generally hear sound if they can produce it. Different insect species can have varying hearing, though most insects can hear only a narrow range of frequencies related to the frequency of the sounds they can produce. Mosquitoes have been found to hear up to 2 kHz., and some grasshoppers can hear up to 50 kHz. Certain predatory and parasitic insects can detect the characteristic sounds made by their prey or hosts, respectively. For instance, some nocturnal moths can perceive the ultrasonic emissions of bats, which helps them avoid predation.:87–94 Insects that feed on blood have special sensory structures that can detect infrared emissions, and use them to home in on their hosts.

text_ai_humanized: In the curious world of insects, their sensory organs are nothing short of remarkable and highly specialized. Take bees, for example; they boast the ability to perceive ultraviolet light as well as detect polarized light, revealing a visual perception quite distinct from ours. Then there are male moths, which rely on their incredibly sensitive antennae to pick up on female moths' pheromones from kilometers away—a feat straight out of nature’s playbook. Meanwhile, in the world of the yellow paper wasp, or *Polistes versicolor*, communication within the colony is a lively affair. These wasps employ unique wagging movements at a tempo of 10.6±2.1 Hz (observed in a study with 190 samples). These wagging signals are not mere dance moves; they actually signify that new materials have arrived at the nest. It’s fascinating how aggressive interactions among the workers stimulate a more vigorous foraging response. When it comes to the trade-offs insects face, it's typically between seeing and sensing through chemical or tactile means. Insects with keen eyesight often exhibit simpler antennae, while those with less developed eyes compensate with highly attuned olfactory or tactile senses. Hearing is another realm where insects show diversity, employing different mechanisms that aren’t as universally shared across species. Most insects hear within ranges connected to sounds they themselves produce. To illustrate, mosquitoes, interestingly enough, can hear up to 2 kHz. In contrast, some types of grasshoppers can tune into frequencies as high as 50 kHz. Certain predators and parasitic insects sharpen their hunting skills by recognizing the particular sounds made by their prey or hosts. Consider those nocturnal moths able to pick up on ultrasonic signals from bats; this adaptation gives them a crucial edge in evading these stealthy night predators. Moreover, insects that feast on blood have developed the ability to detect infrared emissions from their potential hosts, an evolutionary adaptation ensuring they don't miss a meal. It’s quite astonishing how these small creatures navigate their world with such meticulous sensory systems.

text_human: The initial military maneuvers began in September 1806. In a notable letter to Marshal Soult detailing the plan for the campaign, Napoleon described the essential features of Napoleonic warfare and introduced the phrase le bataillon-carré ('square battalion'). In the bataillon-carré system, the various corps of the Grande Armée would march uniformly together in close supporting distance. If any single corps was attacked, the others could quickly spring into action and arrive to help. Napoleon invaded Prussia with 180,000 troops, rapidly marching on the right bank of the River Saale. As in previous campaigns, his fundamental objective was to destroy one opponent before reinforcements from another could tip the balance of the war. Upon learning the whereabouts of the Prussian army, the French swung westwards and crossed the Saale with overwhelming force. At the twin battles of Jena and Auerstedt, fought on 14 October, the French convincingly defeated the Prussians and inflicted heavy casualties. With several major commanders dead or incapacitated, the Prussian king proved incapable of effectively commanding the army, which began to quickly disintegrate. In a vaunted pursuit that epitomized the "peak of Napoleonic warfare," according to historian Richard Brooks, the French managed to capture 140,000 soldiers, over 2,000 cannons and hundreds of ammunition wagons, all in a single month. Historian David Chandler wrote of the Prussian forces: "Never has the morale of any army been more completely shattered." Despite their overwhelming defeat, the Prussians refused to negotiate with the French until the Russians had an opportunity to enter the fight.

Napoleon, in a significant correspondence to Marshal Soult, laid out his campaign tactics and unveiled the revolutionary concept known as le bataillon-carré, or the 'square battalion'. This approach had the regiments of the Grande Armée advancing in unison, sticking close enough to offer mutual support. This arrangement meant that if one corps faced attack, the others could quickly rush to assist, creating a formidable defense. With a massive force of 180,000 troops, Napoleon spearheaded an invasion into Prussia, advancing swiftly along the right bank of the River Saale. True to his typical strategy, he aimed to crush one opponent decisively before another could have the chance to intervene and upset the balance. The French, upon pinpointing the location of the Prussian forces, made a strategic shift to the west and crossed the Saale with formidable power. This led to the decisive twin victories at Jena and Auerstedt on October 14, where the Prussian forces suffered heavy losses. With key leaders either killed or incapacitated, the Prussian king found himself struggling to muster leadership over a rapidly disintegrating army. Rather than surrender immediately, the Prussians chose to linger until Russia could potentially enter the fray against the French. The situation clearly underlined the complex interplay of military might and the pursuit of strategic advantages in Napoleonic warfare.

text_human: As a boy, Schwarzenegger played several sports, heavily influenced by his father. He picked up his first barbell in 1960, when his soccer coach took his team to a local gym. At the age of 14, he chose bodybuilding over soccer as a career. Schwarzenegger has responded to a question asking if he was 13 when he started weightlifting: "I actually started weight training when I was 15, but I'd been participating in sports, like soccer, for years, so I felt that although I was slim, I was well-developed, at least enough so that I could start going to the gym and start Olympic lifting." However, his official website biography claims: "At 14, he started an intensive training program with Dan Farmer, studied psychology at 15 (to learn more about the power of mind over body) and at 17, officially started his competitive career." During a speech in 2001, he said, "My own plan formed when I was 14 years old. My father had wanted me to be a police officer like he was. My mother wanted me to go to trade school." Schwarzenegger took to visiting a gym in Graz, where he also frequented the local movie theaters to see bodybuilding idols such as Reg Park, Steve Reeves, and Johnny Weissmuller on the big screen. When Reeves died in 2000, Schwarzenegger fondly remembered him: "As a teenager, I grew up with Steve Reeves. His remarkable accomplishments allowed me a sense of what was possible, when others around me didn't always understand my dreams. Steve Reeves has been part of everything I've ever been fortunate enough to achieve." In 1961, Schwarzenegger met former Mr. Austria Kurt Marnul, who invited him to train at the gym in Graz. He was so dedicated as a youngster that he broke into the local gym on weekends, when it was usually closed, so that he could train. "It would make me sick to miss a workout... I knew I couldn't look at myself in the mirror the next morning if I didn't do it." When Schwarzenegger was asked about his first movie experience as a boy, he replied: "I was very young, but I remember my father taking me to the Austrian theaters and seeing some newsreels. The first real movie I saw, that I distinctly remember, was a John Wayne movie."

Some might confuse the timeline of his training; when queried about starting weights at 13, Arnold unequivocally refuted it, enlightening: "I only got into weight training at 15. But before that, I was very much involved in other sports, particularly soccer. Even though I was slim, my physical development allowed me to dive into gym workouts and Olympic lifting." Interestingly enough, his official biography provides slightly different nuances: "At 14, Arnold embarked on intensive training with Dan Farmer. My dad’s dream was for me to become a police officer like him, and my mom envisioned trade school in my future." Graz’s gym became a haunt for him, as did local cinemas where he unapologetically absorbed the allure of bodybuilding titans like Reg Park, Steve Reeves, and Johnny Weissmuller. Steve Reeves, in particular, left an indelible mark on young Schwarzenegger. In 2000, with fondness, Arnold reflected: "Steve Reeves was a beacon of inspiration during my teenage years. The feats he accomplished opened my eyes to possibilities beyond my immediate world—possibilities that others failed to see. The influence of Reeves permeates all my successes." In 1961, fate introduced Arnold to former Mr. Austria, Kurt Marnul. Marnul, recognizing Arnold’s zeal, invited him to train in Graz. Schwarzenegger showcased unparalleled commitment; he famously broke into the gym on weekends, driven by his unwavering desire to keep training. "Missing a workout? It felt like a sickness. The thought alone made it hard to face myself in the mirror," he confessed. As a nod to the cinematic magic of his youth, Arnold mused on his earliest movie memory: "Dad would take me to Austrian theaters where newsreels played, but the first proper film—one that stood out—was a John Wayne flick."

text_human: The phenomenalist phase of post-Humean empiricism ended by the 1940s, for by that time it had become obvious that statements about physical things could not be translated into statements about actual and possible sense data. If a physical object statement is to be translatable into a sense-data statement, the former must be at least deducible from the latter. But it came to be realized that there is no finite set of statements about actual and possible sense-data from which we can deduce even a single physical-object statement. Remember that the translating or paraphrasing statement must be couched in terms of normal observers in normal conditions of observation. There is, however, no finite set of statements that are couched in purely sensory terms and can express the satisfaction of the condition of the presence of a normal observer. According to phenomenalism, to say that a normal observer is present is to make the hypothetical statement that were a doctor to inspect the observer, the observer would appear to the doctor to be normal. But, of course, the doctor himself must be a normal observer. If we are to specify this doctor's normality in sensory terms, we must make reference to a second doctor who, when inspecting the sense organs of the first doctor, would himself have to have the sense data a normal observer has when inspecting the sense organs of a subject who is a normal observer. And if we are to specify in sensory terms that the second doctor is a normal observer, we must refer to a third doctor, and so on (also see the third man).
text_ai_base: By the 1940s, the phenomenalist phase of post-Humean empiricism had concluded. It became clear that statements about physical objects could not be converted into statements about actual and possible sensory data. For a statement about physical objects to be translatable into one about sensory data, it must be at least deducible from the latter. However, it was realized that we cannot derive even a single statement about physical objects from any finite set of statements describing actual and possible sensory data. Remember that these translating or paraphrasing statements must involve normal observers in typical conditions. Yet, no finite set of purely sensory statements can satisfy the requirement of having a normal observer present. According to phenomenalism, claiming the presence of a normal observer is akin to hypothetically stating that if a doctor were to examine the observer, they would find the observer normal. However, this doctor must also be a normal observer. To specify the doctor's normality in sensory terms, we would need a second doctor, who would have to experience the usual sensory data when examining the first doctor's sensory organs. To further specify the second doctor as a normal observer using sensory terms, we must refer to a third doctor, continuing the cycle indefinitely (see also the third man problem).
text_ai_humanized: By the time the 1940s rolled around, the phenomenalist phase of post-Humean empiricism had run its course. People began to understand that translating statements about physical objects into those about sensory data was not feasible. For such a translation to work, you'd expect a statement about a physical object to at least be deducible from sensory data. But the kicker was that even with all our actual and possible sensory data, we couldn't derive a single statement about physical objects. Now, this idea of translation requires that the sensory statements account for normal observers under usual conditions. But here's where things get tricky: no finite set of sensory statements can guarantee the presence of a normal observer. In phenomenalism's world, affirming a normal observer's presence almost suggests that, hypothetically, if a doctor examined our observer, they'd label them normal. This hypothetical doctor, however, also needs to be a normal observer. To confirm the doctor's normality via sensory terms, you'd find yourself needing a second doctor, who then must experience typical sensory data when checking the first doctor's senses. And so the story goes on—this second doctor needs validation from a third, continuing in an endless loop (bringing to mind the notorious third man problem). It becomes clear that we're stuck in a perpetual chase for normalcy and confirmation, never quite reaching a solid ground of conclusion.

text_human: Although the doctrine of Mary's Immaculate Conception appears only later among Latin (and particularly Frankish) theologians, it became ever more manifest among Byzantine theologians reliant on Gregory Nazianzen's Mariology in the Medieval or Byzantine East. Although hymnographers and scholars, like the Emperor Justinian I, were accustomed to call Mary "prepurified" in their poetic and credal statements, the first point of departure for more fully commenting on Nazianzen's meaning occurs in Sophronius of Jerusalem. In other places Sophronius explains that the Theotokos was already immaculate, when she was "purified" at the Annunciation and goes so far as to note that John the Baptist is literally "holier than all 'Men' born of woman" since Mary's surpassing holiness signifies that she was holier than even John after his sanctification in utero. Sophronius' teaching is augmented and incorporated by St. John Damascene (d. 749/750). John, besides many passages wherein he extolls the Theotokos for her purification at the Annunciation, grants her the unique honor of "purifying the waters of baptism by touching them." This honor was most famously and firstly attributed to Christ, especially in the legacy of Nazianzen. As such, Nazianzen's assertion of parallel holiness between the prepurified Mary and purified Jesus of the New Testament is made even more explicit in Damascene in his discourse on Mary's holiness to also imitate Christ's baptism at the Jordan. The Damascene's hymnongraphy and De fide Orthodoxa explicitly use Mary's "pre purification" as a key to understanding her absolute holiness and unsullied human nature. In fact, Damascene (along with Nazianzen) serves as the source for nearly all subsequent promotion of Mary's complete holiness from her Conception by the "all pure seed" of Joachim and the womb "wider than heaven" of St. Ann.
text_ai_base: The doctrine of Mary's Immaculate Conception emerged later among Latin theologians, especially the Franks, but found clearer expression among Byzantine theologians with roots in Gregory Nazianzen's Mariology during the Medieval Byzantine era. Poets and scholars, including Emperor Justinian I, often referred to Mary as "prepurified" in their writings and creeds. Sophronius of Jerusalem offered a pivotal interpretation of Nazianzen's ideas, explaining that Mary was already immaculate at the time of the Annunciation. He even suggested that John the Baptist was "holier than all 'Men' born of woman," acknowledging that Mary's extraordinary holiness eclipsed even John's, who was sanctified in utero. Sophronius' teachings were further developed by St. John Damascene (d. 749/750), who praised Mary for her purification at the Annunciation and uniquely recognized her role in "purifying the waters of baptism by touching them," an honor traditionally reserved for Christ, according to Nazianzen's legacy. Damascene elaborated on the parallel holiness between Mary's prepurification and Jesus' purification in the New Testament, likening her holiness at the Annunciation to Christ's baptism at the Jordan. His hymns and the work "De fide Orthodoxa" utilized Mary's "pre purification" to emphasize her unparalleled holiness and pure human nature. Damascene, along with Nazianzen, influenced nearly all later depictions of Mary's complete holiness, stemming from her conception by the "all pure seed" of Joachim and the womb of St. Ann, which is metaphorically described as "wider than heaven."

However, Byzantine theologians made significant strides in articulating this doctrine, drawing inspiration from the Mariological insights of Gregory Nazianzen during the medieval Byzantine period. Take, for instance, how poets and intellectuals—Emperor Justinian I being a notable example—frequently dubbed Mary as "prepurified" in their writings and creeds. In a key development, Sophronius of Jerusalem expanded upon Nazianzen's perspectives. He put forth the notion that Mary was already immaculate at the moment of the Annunciation. This interpretation, Sophronius argued, even placed Mary's exceptional sanctity above that of John the Baptist—a figure traditionally believed to be sanctified while still in his mother's womb. He posited that John was "holier than all 'Men' born of woman," yet Mary's unique holiness surpassed even this. Building on these ideas, St. John Damascene (d. 749/750) provided further depth. text_human: United States of America: The torch relay's North American leg occurred in San Francisco, California on April 9. On the day of the relay officials diverted the torch run to an unannounced route. The start was at McCovey Cove, where Norman Bellingham of the U.S. Olympic Committee gave the torch to the first torchbearer, Chinese 1992 Olympic champion swimmer Lin Li. The planned closing ceremony at Justin Herman Plaza was cancelled and instead, a ceremony was held at San Francisco International Airport, where the torch was to leave for Buenos Aires. The route changes allowed the run to avoid large numbers of China supporters and protesters against China. As people found out there would be no closing ceremony at Justin Herman Plaza, there were angry reactions. One demonstrator was quoted as saying that the route changes were an effort to "thwart any organized protest that had been planned." San Francisco Board of Supervisors President Aaron Peskin, a critic of Mayor Gavin Newsom, said that it was a "cynical plan to please the Bush State Department and the Chinese government because of the incredible influence of money." Newsom, on the other hand, said he felt it was in "everyone's best interest" and that he believed people had been "afforded the right to protest and support the torch" despite the route changes. Peter Ueberroth, head of the U.S. Olympic Committee, praised the route changes, saying, "The city of San Francisco, from a global perspective, will be applauded." People who saw the torch were surprised and cheered as shown from live video of CBS and NBC. The cost to the city for hosting the event was reported to be USD $726,400, nearly half of which has been recovered by private fundraising. Mayor Gavin Newsom said that "exponential" costs associated with mass arrests were avoided by his decision to change the route in consultation with police chief Heather Fong.

text_human: The current Mac product family uses Intel x86-64 processors. Apple introduced an emulator during the transition from PowerPC chips (called Rosetta), much as it did during the transition from Motorola 68000 architecture a decade earlier. The Macintosh is the only mainstream computer platform to have successfully transitioned to a new CPU architecture, and has done so twice. All current Mac models ship with at least 8 GB of RAM as standard other than the 1.4 GHz Mac Mini, MacBook Pro (without Retina Display), and MacBook Air. Current Mac computers use ATI Radeon or nVidia GeForce graphics cards as well as Intel graphics built into the main CPU. All current Macs (except for the MacBook Pro without Retina Display) do not ship with an optical media drive that includes a dual-function DVD/CD burner. Apple refers to this as a SuperDrive. Current Macs include two standard data transfer ports: USB and Thunderbolt (except for the MacBook (2015 version), which only has a USB-C port and headphone port). MacBook Pro, iMac, MacBook Air, and Mac Mini computers now also feature the "Thunderbolt" port, which Apple says can transfer data at speeds up to 10 gigabits per second. USB was introduced in the 1998 iMac G3 and is ubiquitous today, while FireWire is mainly reserved for high-performance devices such as hard drives or video cameras. Starting with the then-new iMac G5, released in October 2005, Apple started to include built-in iSight cameras on appropriate models, and a media center interface called Front Row that can be operated by an Apple Remote or keyboard for accessing media stored on the computer. Front Row has been discontinued as of 2011, however, and the Apple Remote is no longer bundled with new Macs.

It was a neat feature, controllable via an Apple Remote or through the keyboard, perfect for perusing media stored on the system. Though Front Row vanished in 2011, leaving no trace, and the trusty Apple Remote has also been put out to pasture, the spirit of innovation continues to thrive in today's Macs.

text_human: As anticipated by Nimitz, the Japanese fleet arrived off Midway on 4 June and was spotted by PBY patrol aircraft. Nagumo executed a first strike against Midway, while Fletcher launched his aircraft, bound for Nagumo's carriers. At 09:20 the first U.S. carrier aircraft arrived, TBD Devastator torpedo bombers from Hornet, but their attacks were poorly coordinated and ineffectual; thanks in part to faulty aerial torpedoes, they failed to score a single hit and all 15 were wiped out by defending Zero fighters. At 09:35, 15 additional TBDs from Enterprise attacked in which 14 were lost, again with no hits. Thus far, Fletcher's attacks had been disorganized and seemingly ineffectual, but they succeeded in drawing Nagumo's defensive fighters down to sea level where they expended much of their fuel and ammunition repulsing the two waves of torpedo bombers. As a result, when U.S. dive bombers arrived at high altitude, the Zeros were poorly positioned to defend. To make matters worse, Nagumo's four carriers had drifted out of formation in their efforts to avoid torpedoes, reducing the concentration of their anti-aircraft fire. Nagumo's indecision had also created confusion aboard his carriers. Alerted to the need of a second strike on Midway, but also wary of the need to deal with the American carriers that he now knew were in the vicinity, Nagumo twice changed the arming orders for his aircraft. As a result, the American dive bombers found the Japanese carriers with their decks cluttered with munitions as the crews worked hastily to properly re-arm their air groups.

Consequently, when U.S. dive bombers arrived at high altitude, the Zeros were ill-positioned to defend. Furthermore, Nagumo's four carriers had drifted out of formation while evading torpedoes, diminishing their concentration of anti-aircraft fire. Nagumo's indecision added to the confusion on his carriers as he contemplated a second strike on Midway while being aware of American carriers nearby. text_ai_humanized: As Nimitz had anticipated, on June 4, the Japanese fleet neared Midway, promptly detected by prowling PBY patrol planes. Nagumo wasted no time, launching an assault on Midway, while Fletcher prepped his forces to strike at Nagumo's carriers. At 09:20, the TBD Devastator torpedo bombers from the Hornet pushed forward, yet their attack floundered in a tangle of mismanagement and malfunctioning torpedoes, resulting in no hits. Tragic repeat: all 15 were shot down by the defending Zero fighters. A mere 15 minutes later, the Enterprise sent forth another batch of 15 TBDs; however, their fate mirrored that of the Hornet, with 14 lost and still no successful strikes—bad luck and poor planning seemed to plague Fletcher's squads. Yet, these chaotic jaunts had unwittingly drawn Nagumo's fighter cover downward, expending precious fuel and ammunition on two frustrating waves of torpedo bombers. Thus, when U.S. dive bombers swept in from above, the Zeros were caught off guard, poorly positioned to mount an effective defense. Amidst this chaos, another curse befell Nagumo—his four carriers, in their evasive maneuvers against torpedoes, had scattered from their formation, weakening their combined anti-aircraft defenses. As if disarray weren't enough, Nagumo hesitated, torn between launching a second strike on Midway and confronting the lurking U.S. carriers. He vacillated twice on the arming orders for his planes, leaving them cluttered with munitions just when the dive bombers struck. Perhaps chaos and confusion were the secretly American allies on that day.

text_human: Scotland, meanwhile had remained an independent Kingdom. In 1603, that changed when the King of Scotland inherited the Crown of England, and consequently the Crown of Ireland also. The subsequent 17th century was one of political upheaval, religious division and war. English colonialism in Ireland of the 16th century was extended by large-scale Scottish and English colonies in Ulster. Religious division heightened and the King in England came into conflict with parliament. A prime issue was, inter alia, over his policy of tolerance towards Catholicism. The resulting English Civil War or War of the Three Kingdoms led to a revolutionary republic in England. Ireland, largely Catholic was mainly loyal to the king. Following defeat to the parliaments army, large scale land distributions from loyalist Irish nobility to English commoners in the service of the parliamentary army created the beginnings a new Ascendancy class which over the next hundred years would obliterate the English (Hiberno-Norman) and Gaelic Irish nobility in Ireland. The new ruling class was Protestant and British, whilst the common people were largely Catholic and Irish. This theme would influence Irish politics for centuries to come. When the monarchy was restored in England, the king found it politically impossible to restore all the lands of former land-owners in Ireland. The "Glorious Revolution" of 1688 repeated similar themes: a Catholic king pushing for religious tolerance in opposition to a Protestant parliament in England. The king's army was defeated at the Battle of the Boyne and at the militarily crucial Battle of Aughrim in Ireland. Resistance held out, and a guarantee of religious tolerance was a cornerstone of the Treaty of Limerick. However, in the evolving political climate, the terms of Limerick were superseded, a new monarchy was installed, and the new Irish parliament was packed with the new elite which legislated increasing intolerant Penal Laws, which discommoded both Dissenters and Catholics.
text_ai_base: Scotland remained an independent kingdom until 1603, when the King of Scotland inherited the crowns of both England and Ireland. The following century was marked by political unrest, religious division, and warfare. English colonialism, which began in Ireland in the 16th century, expanded with the establishment of large Scottish and English colonies in Ulster. Tensions rose, especially as the English king's policy of tolerance towards Catholicism clashed with Parliament. This discord led to the English Civil War, also known as the War of the Three Kingdoms, resulting in a revolutionary republic. Although predominantly Catholic Ireland mostly supported the king, defeat by Parliament's army led to significant land redistribution from loyalist Irish nobility to English commoners serving in the parliamentary forces. This shift began the rise of a new "Ascendancy" class that, over the next hundred years, replaced the English (Hiberno-Norman) and Gaelic Irish nobility. This new ruling class, Protestant and British, contrasted with the largely Catholic and Irish populace, influencing Irish politics for centuries. When the English monarchy was restored, the king could not politically restore the lands of former Irish landowners. The "Glorious Revolution" of 1688 echoed these themes, with a Catholic king advocating for religious tolerance against a Protestant Parliament. The king's army was defeated in Ireland at the Battle of the Boyne and the crucial Battle of Aughrim. Despite resistance and a pledge for religious tolerance in the Treaty of Limerick, its terms were later overridden in the shifting political landscape. A new monarchy emerged, and the Irish parliament, now dominated by the new elite, enacted increasingly oppressive Penal Laws affecting both Dissenters and Catholics.
text_ai_humanized: Up until 1603, Scotland stood as an independent realm, maintaining its sovereignty until destiny veered off course when the Scottish king ascended to the throne of both England and Ireland. What followed was a tumultuous century, marred by political turmoil, religious strife, and outright conflict. English colonial ambitions, which had taken root in 16th century Ireland, swelled as the establishment of sprawling Scottish and English settlements in Ulster took shape. These developments fueled rising tensions, primarily due to a clash between the English king's relatively tolerant stance towards Catholicism and Parliament's opposing views. This discord blossomed into the English Civil War—some know it by the more dramatic moniker, the War of the Three Kingdoms—out of which a revolutionary republic emerged. In a twist bitter for many, largely Catholic Ireland, which had mostly aligned with the royal cause, saw its nobility's lands irretrievably altered. Parliament’s victory brought a redistribution of Irish estates to the English commoners, those who had fought to ensure its dominance, and thus a new "Ascendancy" class began to form. This Protestant, British ruling group gradually eclipsed the existing English (Hiberno-Norman) and Gaelic Irish aristocracies, setting a stark socio-political divide against the predominantly Catholic, Irish populace—a dynamic that would shape political fires for countless years ahead. Upon the monarchy's restoration, any hope for returning lands to the vanquished Irish gentry was quashed by the political realities of the time. Fast forward to the "Glorious Revolution" of 1688, echoes of past conflicts resounded as a Catholic king sought to champion religious leniency, only to face a predominantly Protestant Parliament. Defeat followed at battles such as the Boyne and the decisive Aughrim. Despite initial promises made under the Treaty of Limerick to honor religious freedoms, these were swiftly brushed aside amidst shifting tides. A new monarch came to power as the Irish Parliament, solidly influenced by the new elite, enacted harsh Penal Laws that marginalized both Catholics and Dissenters, tightening the noose of control.

These developments fueled rising tensions, primarily due to a clash between the English king's relatively tolerant stance towards Catholicism and Parliament's opposing views. 

This discord blossomed into the English Civil War—some know it by the more dramatic moniker, the War of the Three Kingdoms—out of which a revolutionary republic emerged. In a twist bitter for many, largely Catholic Ireland, which had mostly aligned with the royal cause, saw its nobility's lands irretrievably altered. Parliament’s victory brought a redistribution of Irish estates to the English commoners, those who had fought to ensure its dominance, and thus a new "Ascendancy" class began to form. This Protestant, British ruling group gradually eclipsed the existing English (Hiberno-Norman) and Gaelic Irish aristocracies, setting a stark socio-political divide against the predominantly Catholic, Irish populace—a dynamic that would shape political fires for countless years ahead.

Upon the monarchy's restoration, any hope for returning lands to the vanquished Irish gentry was quashed by the political realities of the time. Fast forward to the "Glorious Revolution" of 1688, echoes of past conflicts resounded as a Catholic king sought to champion religious leniency, only to face a predominantly Protestant Parliament. Defeat followed at battles such as the Boyne and the decisive Aughrim. Despite initial promises made under the Treaty of Limerick to honor religious freedoms, these were swiftly brushed aside amidst shifting tides. text_human: Different phases of digestion take place including: the cephalic phase , gastric phase, and intestinal phase. The cephalic phase occurs at the sight, thought and smell of food, which stimulate the cerebral cortex. Taste and smell stimuli are sent to the hypothalamus and medulla oblongata. After this it is routed through the vagus nerve and release of acetylcholine. Gastric secretion at this phase rises to 40% of maximum rate. Acidity in the stomach is not buffered by food at this point and thus acts to inhibit parietal (secretes acid) and G cell (secretes gastrin) activity via D cell secretion of somatostatin. The gastric phase takes 3 to 4 hours. It is stimulated by distension of the stomach, presence of food in stomach and decrease in pH. Distention activates long and myenteric reflexes. This activates the release of acetylcholine, which stimulates the release of more gastric juices. As protein enters the stomach, it binds to hydrogen ions, which raises the pH of the stomach. Inhibition of gastrin and gastric acid secretion is lifted. This triggers G cells to release gastrin, which in turn stimulates parietal cells to secrete gastric acid. Gastric acid is about 0.5% hydrochloric acid (HCl), which lowers the pH to the desired pH of 1-3. Acid release is also triggered by acetylcholine and histamine. The intestinal phase has two parts, the excitatory and the inhibitory. Partially digested food fills the duodenum. This triggers intestinal gastrin to be released. Enterogastric reflex inhibits vagal nuclei, activating sympathetic fibers causing the pyloric sphincter to tighten to prevent more food from entering, and inhibits local reflexes.
text_ai_base: Digestion occurs in different phases: the cephalic, gastric, and intestinal phases. The cephalic phase begins with the sight, thought, and smell of food, which stimulate the cerebral cortex. These stimuli are sent to the hypothalamus and medulla oblongata, then routed through the vagus nerve, leading to the release of acetylcholine. During this phase, gastric secretion reaches 40% of its maximum rate. Since the acidity in the stomach isn't buffered by food, it inhibits the activity of parietal cells (which secrete acid) and G cells (which secrete gastrin) via D cell secretion of somatostatin. The gastric phase lasts 3 to 4 hours and is triggered by the stomach's distension, the presence of food, and decreased pH. Distention activates long and myenteric reflexes, releasing acetylcholine and stimulating more gastric juice production. As proteins enter the stomach, they bind with hydrogen ions, increasing the pH and lifting the inhibition on gastrin and gastric acid secretion. This causes G cells to release gastrin, prompting parietal cells to secrete gastric acid, which consists of about 0.5% hydrochloric acid (HCl), lowering the pH to 1-3. Acetylcholine and histamine also trigger acid release. The intestinal phase has two parts: excitatory and inhibitory. Partially digested food enters the duodenum, triggering the release of intestinal gastrin. The enterogastric reflex inhibits the vagal nuclei, activates sympathetic fibers which tighten the pyloric sphincter to prevent more food from entering, and inhibits local reflexes.

The journey kicks off with the cephalic phase, ignited by merely seeing, smelling, or even thinking about food. This stirs the cerebral cortex into action, cascading signals down to the hypothalamus and medulla oblongata. From here, these cues take a detour via the vagus nerve, ultimately releasing acetylcholine. Interestingly, at this stage, gastric secretions ramp up to about 40% of their peak potential. However, because there's no food to buffer the stomach's acidity, the excess acid production gets curbed. The parietal and G cells, responsible respectively for acid and gastrin secretion, are put on pause thanks to somatostatin from the D cells. Moving on, the gastric phase stretches over 3 to 4 hours. It kicks in as the stomach swells with food—thanks, in part, to both the physical presence and decreased pH. This distension sets off long and myenteric reflexes, releasing more acetylcholine and revving up the production of gastric juices. When proteins mingle with stomach contents, they mop up hydrogen ions. This leads to a rise in pH, lifting the inhibitions on gastrin and acid secretion. Thus, G cells get busy releasing gastrin, nudging parietal cells to churn out gastric acid. This acid, which is about 0.5% hydrochloric acid, plummets the pH to a dramatic 1-3. As partially digested food makes its way into the duodenum, intestinal gastrin gets released. Yet, an intriguing twist occurs here: the enterogastric reflex steps in, casting a dampening effect. It reins in the vagal nuclei, activates sympathetic fibers tightening the pyloric sphincter to block further entry of food, and puts local reflexes to rest. It's a finely tuned ballet of chemical exchanges and reflexive controls, choreographing the digestive process with remarkable precision.

text_human: The late 1980s saw a series of liberalising economic reforms within Libya designed to cope with the decline in oil revenues. In May 1987, Gaddafi announced the start of the "Revolution within a Revolution", which began with reforms to industry and agriculture and saw the re-opening of small business. Restrictions were placed on the activities of the Revolutionary Committees; in March 1988, their role was narrowed by the newly created Ministry for Mass Mobilization and Revolutionary Leadership to restrict their violence and judicial role, while in August 1988 Gaddafi publicly criticised them, asserting that "they deviated, harmed, tortured" and that "the true revolutionary does not practise repression." In March, hundreds of political prisoners were freed, with Gaddafi falsely claiming that there were no further political prisoners in Libya. In June, Libya's government issued the Great Green Charter on Human Rights in the Era of the Masses, in which 27 articles laid out goals, rights and guarantees to improve the situation of human rights in Libya, restricting the use of the death penalty and calling for its eventual abolition. Many of the measures suggested in the charter would be implemented the following year, although others remained inactive. Also in 1989, the government founded the Al-Gaddafi International Prize for Human Rights, to be awarded to figures from the Third World who had struggled against colonialism and imperialism; the first year's winner was South African anti-apartheid activist Nelson Mandela. From 1994 through to 1997, the government initiated cleansing committees to root out corruption, particularly in the economic sector.

The Revolutionary Committees faced restrictions; in March 1988, a new Ministry for Mass Mobilization and Revolutionary Leadership limited their violent and judicial activities. In August 1988, Gaddafi criticized these committees, stating they had "deviated, harmed, tortured" and insisted that "true revolutionaries do not practice repression." That March, hundreds of political prisoners were released, although Gaddafi inaccurately claimed there were none left in Libya. In June, the government published the Great Green Charter on Human Rights in the Era of the Masses, outlining 27 articles to improve human rights, limit the death penalty, and call for its eventual abolition. While some measures in the charter were implemented the following year, others were not. Additionally, in 1989, the government established the Al-Gaddafi International Prize for Human Rights, honoring Third World figures who opposed colonialism and imperialism, with Nelson Mandela as the first recipient. Between 1994 and 1997, the government formed cleansing committees to combat corruption, especially in the economic sector.

Fast forward to the mid-90s, the government deployed cleansing committees between 1994 to 1997, laser-focused on rooting out corruption, particularly that which plagued the economic sector.

text_human: ARC was acquired in 1938 by the Columbia Broadcasting System (CBS, which, in turn, had been formed by the Columbia Phonograph Company, but then sold off). ARC was renamed Columbia Recording Corporation. The Columbia Phonograph Company had international subsidiaries and affiliates such as the Columbia Graphophone Company in the United Kingdom, but they were sold off prior to CBS acquiring American Columbia. RCA Victor Records executive Ted Wallerstein convinced CBS head William S. Paley to buy ARC and Paley made Wallerstein head of the newly acquired record company. The renamed company made Columbia its flagship label with Okeh its subsidiary label while deemphasizing ARC's other labels. This allowed ARC's leased labels Brunswick Records and Vocalion Records to revert to former owner Warner Bros. which sold the labels to Decca Records. Columbia kept the Brunswick catalogue recorded from December 1931 onward which was reissued on the Columbia label as well as the Vocalion label material from the same time period which was reissued on the Okeh label. Wallerstein, who was promoted at the end of 1947 from president to chairman of the record company, restored Columbia's status as a leading record company and spearheaded the successful introduction of the long playing (LP) record before he retired as Columbia's chairman in 1951. James Conkling then became head of Columbia Records. Also in 1951, Columbia severed its ties with the EMI-owned record label of the same name and began a UK distribution deal with Philips Records, whereas Okeh Records continued to be distributed by EMI on the Columbia label.

Consequently, ARC’s leased labels, Brunswick Records and Vocalion Records, reverted to previous owner Warner Bros., who then sold them to Decca Records. Wallerstein, promoted from president to chairman of the record company in late 1947, restored Columbia to prominence and led the successful launch of the long-playing (LP) record before retiring as chairman in 1951. James Conkling subsequently took over as head of Columbia Records. It's worth noting that CBS came into possession of American Columbia after the Columbia Phonograph Company had already divested its international branches, such as the UK-based Columbia Graphophone Company. An interesting twist in this corporate tale is how Ted Wallerstein, an RCA Victor Records executive, managed to convince CBS leader William S. Paley to go ahead with the acquisition. As a result, Wallerstein was appointed to lead the newly minted record company. With Columbia stepping into the spotlight as the principal label under this new lineup, Okeh took a backseat as its subsidiary. Notably, Columbia maintained rights to the Brunswick catalog created from December 1931 onward—these recordings were reintroduced via the Columbia label, and works from Vocalion got a new life under the Okeh banner. Speaking of Wallerstein, his upward trajectory saw him rise from president to chairman of the company by late 1947. Under his leadership, Columbia regained its status as a major player and successfully launched the groundbreaking LP record—quite the achievement—before he retired in 1951, at which point James Conkling stepped in to helm the record company. In a pivotal move that same year, Columbia severed ties with its similarly named label owned by EMI and started a distribution partnership in the UK with Philips Records. Meanwhile, Okeh’s distribution continued under the Columbia label, courtesy of EMI. It's fascinating how these shifts in the music industry's landscape played out during those transformative years, isn't it?

An interesting twist in this corporate tale is how Ted Wallerstein, an RCA Victor Records executive, managed to convince CBS leader William S. Paley to go ahead with the acquisition. As a result, Wallerstein was appointed to lead the newly minted record company.

With Columbia stepping into the spotlight as the principal label under this new lineup, Okeh took a backseat as its subsidiary. Lesser-known labels under ARC were shuffled off, while Brunswick Records and Vocalion Records found their way back to Warner Bros., the previous owner, who later sold them to Decca Records. Notably, Columbia maintained rights to the Brunswick catalog created from December 1931 onward—these recordings were reintroduced via the Columbia label, and works from Vocalion got a new life under the Okeh banner.

Speaking of Wallerstein, his upward trajectory saw him rise from president to chairman of the company by late 1947. Under his leadership, Columbia regained its status as a major player and successfully launched the groundbreaking LP record—quite the achievement—before he retired in 1951, at which point James Conkling stepped in to helm the record company.

In a pivotal move that same year, Columbia severed ties with its similarly named label owned by EMI and started a distribution partnership in the UK with Philips Records. Meanwhile, Okeh’s distribution continued under the Columbia label, courtesy of EMI. It's fascinating how these shifts in the music industry's landscape played out during those transformative years, isn't it?

text_human: The "Bleacher Bums" is a name given to fans, many of whom spend much of the day heckling, who sit in the bleacher section at Wrigley Field. Initially, the group was called "bums" because it referred to a group of fans who were at most games, and since those games were all day games, it was assumed they did not work. Many of those fans were, and are still, students at Chicago area colleges, such as DePaul University, Loyola, Northwestern University, and Illinois-Chicago. A Broadway play, starring Joe Mantegna, Dennis Farina, Dennis Franz, and James Belushi ran for years and was based on a group of Cub fans who frequented the club's games. The group was started in 1967 by dedicated fans Ron Grousl, Tom Nall and "mad bugler" Mike Murphy, who was a sports radio host during mid days on Chicago-based WSCR AM 670 "The Score". Murphy alleges that Grousl started the Wrigley tradition of throwing back opposing teams' home run balls. The current group is headed by Derek Schaul (Derek the Five Dollar Kid). Prior to the 2006 season, they were updated, with new shops and private bar (The Batter's Eye) being added, and Bud Light bought naming rights to the bleacher section, dubbing them the Bud Light Bleachers. Bleachers at Wrigley are general admission, except during the playoffs. The bleachers have been referred to as the "World's Largest Beer Garden." A popular T-shirt (sold inside the park and licensed by the club) which says "Wrigley Bleachers" on the front and the phrase "Shut Up and Drink Your Beer" on the reverse fuels this stereotype.

Many of these fans are, or were, students from Chicago area universities like DePaul, Loyola, Northwestern, and Illinois-Chicago. Before the 2006 season, updates were made with new shops and a private bar, The Batter's Eye, added, and Bud Light secured naming rights, calling it the Bud Light Bleachers. At Wrigley, bleacher seats are generally admission only, except during the playoffs. The bleachers are known as the "World's Largest Beer Garden." A popular T-shirt sold inside the park, licensed by the club, promotes this stereotype with the front saying "Wrigley Bleachers" and the back reading "Shut Up and Drink Your Beer."

These fans, often jesting from the bleacher seats, earned their nickname from their penchant for attending numerous games, many of which were midday fixtures.
