With the approach of the 2006 season, enhancements were introduced, including fresh shopping venues and a swanky private retreat dubbed The Batter's Eye, as part of the bleachers' rebranding. Following a deal with Bud Light, they acquired naming rights, bestowing the new moniker "Bud Light Bleachers." Here, the bleachers are more than just seats—they're a lively hub, famously known as the "World's Largest Beer Garden," especially catching the spotlight during playoff season when seats become a hot commodity. Adding to their playful persona, fans can snag a popular T-shirt within the park, officially sanctioned by the club, with an eye-catching slogan. While the front states "Wrigley Bleachers," the back cheekily advises patrons to "Shut Up and Drink Your Beer," embodying the carefree, jovial spirit of the Chicago bleachers.

text_human: In 1824, the French physicist François Arago formulated the existence of rotating magnetic fields, termed Arago's rotations, which, by manually turning switches on and off, Walter Baily demonstrated in 1879 as in effect the first primitive induction motor. In the 1880s, many inventors were trying to develop workable AC motors because AC's advantages in long-distance high-voltage transmission were counterbalanced by the inability to operate motors on AC. The first alternating-current commutatorless induction motors were independently invented by Galileo Ferraris and Nikola Tesla, a working motor model having been demonstrated by the former in 1885 and by the latter in 1887. In 1888, the Royal Academy of Science of Turin published Ferraris' research detailing the foundations of motor operation while however concluding that "the apparatus based on that principle could not be of any commercial importance as motor." In 1888, Tesla presented his paper A New System for Alternating Current Motors and Transformers to the AIEE that described three patented two-phase four-stator-pole motor types: one with a four-pole rotor forming a non-self-starting reluctance motor, another with a wound rotor forming a self-starting induction motor, and the third a true synchronous motor with separately excited DC supply to rotor winding. One of the patents Tesla filed in 1887, however, also described a shorted-winding-rotor induction motor. George Westinghouse promptly bought Tesla's patents, employed Tesla to develop them, and assigned C. F. Scott to help Tesla, Tesla left for other pursuits in 1889. The constant speed AC induction motor was found not to be suitable for street cars but Westinghouse engineers successfully adapted it to power a mining operation in Telluride, Colorado in 1891. Steadfast in his promotion of three-phase development, Mikhail Dolivo-Dobrovolsky invented the three-phase cage-rotor induction motor in 1889 and the three-limb transformer in 1890. This type of motor is now used for the vast majority of commercial applications. However, he claimed that Tesla's motor was not practical because of two-phase pulsations, which prompted him to persist in his three-phase work. Although Westinghouse achieved its first practical induction motor in 1892 and developed a line of polyphase 60 hertz induction motors in 1893, these early Westinghouse motors were two-phase motors with wound rotors until B. G. Lamme developed a rotating bar winding rotor. The General Electric Company began developing three-phase induction motors in 1891. By 1896, General Electric and Westinghouse signed a cross-licensing agreement for the bar-winding-rotor design, later called the squirrel-cage rotor. Induction motor improvements flowing from these inventions and innovations were such that a 100 horsepower (HP) induction motor currently has the same mounting dimensions as a 7.5 HP motor in 1897.

Back in 1824, a pioneering French physicist named François Arago came up with an intriguing idea about rotating magnetic fields, which we now know as Arago's rotations. This concept was a spark that eventually ignited the creation of a rudimentary induction motor in 1879, thanks in part to Walter Baily's attempts at manually switching it on and off. During the bustling 1880s, inventors eagerly set their sights on developing AC motors. The pressing need for these motors was fueled by AC's advantages in transmitting electricity over long distances and at high voltages, despite the glaring absence of motors capable of utilizing it.

Enter Galileo Ferraris and Nikola Tesla, who, working independently, brought forth the first AC commutatorless induction motors. Ferraris showcased a functional model in 1885, and Tesla followed suit with his in 1887. In 1888, Ferraris shared his research on motor operations with the Royal Academy of Science of Turin, though they were somewhat skeptical about its commercial viability.

Around the same time, Tesla was crafting his own narrative for the AIEE, shedding light on three distinct types of two-phase, four-stator-pole motors. These included a non-self-starting reluctance motor, a self-starting induction motor with a wound rotor, and a synchronous motor with a separately excited DC rotor winding. A patent Tesla filed in 1887 outlined a shorted-winding-rotor induction motor, which caught the astute eye of George Westinghouse. Westinghouse swiftly acquired Tesla’s patents, bringing him on board to further develop them alongside C. F. Scott, though Tesla departed the collaboration in 1889.

Despite the challenges with constant-speed AC induction motors for streetcars, Westinghouse triumphed with powering a mining operation in Telluride, Colorado, by 1891. Meanwhile, steadfast in his belief in three-phase systems, Mikhail Dolivo-Dobrovolsky invented the three-phase cage-rotor induction motor in 1889, followed by the three-limb transformer in 1890, both of which became staples in commercial settings. Dolivo-Dobrovolsky did voice some qualms about the impracticality of two-phase pulsations, but undeterred, Westinghouse rolled out its first practical induction motor in 1892 and a series of polyphase motors by 1893, initially two-phase with wound rotors.

Progress didn’t stop there; B.G. Lamme’s design of the rotating bar winding rotor changed the game. General Electric was also in the race, developing three-phase induction motors by 1891. Come 1896, GE inked a cross-licensing deal with Westinghouse for the bar-winding-rotor design, which we now recognize as the squirrel-cage rotor. These leaps forward in innovation have paved the way for today's 100 HP induction motors to fit into the same mountings as a mere 7.5 HP motor did back in 1897. A bit of perspective, if you will!

text_human: With the help of Charles Stearn, an expert on vacuum pumps, in 1878, Swan developed a method of processing that avoided the early bulb blackening. This received a British Patent in 1880.[dubious – discuss] On 18 December 1878, a lamp using a slender carbon rod was shown at a meeting of the Newcastle Chemical Society, and Swan gave a working demonstration at their meeting on 17 January 1879. It was also shown to 700 who attended a meeting of the Literary and Philosophical Society of Newcastle upon Tyne on 3 February 1879. These lamps used a carbon rod from an arc lamp rather than a slender filament. Thus they had low resistance and required very large conductors to supply the necessary current, so they were not commercially practical, although they did furnish a demonstration of the possibilities of incandescent lighting with relatively high vacuum, a carbon conductor, and platinum lead-in wires. Besides requiring too much current for a central station electric system to be practical, they had a very short lifetime. Swan turned his attention to producing a better carbon filament and the means of attaching its ends. He devised a method of treating cotton to produce 'parchmentised thread' and obtained British Patent 4933 in 1880. From this year he began installing light bulbs in homes and landmarks in England. His house was the first in the world to be lit by a lightbulb and also the first house in the world to be lit by hydroelectric power. In 1878 the home of Lord Armstrong at Cragside was also among the first houses to be lit by electricity. In the early 1880s he had started his company. In 1881, the Savoy Theatre in the City of Westminster, London was lit by Swan incandescent lightbulbs, which was the first theatre, and the first public building in the world, to be lit entirely by electricity.
text_ai_base: In 1878, with the assistance of vacuum pump expert Charles Stearn, Swan developed a method to prevent early bulb blackening, earning a British Patent in 1880. On December 18, 1878, he displayed a lamp with a slender carbon rod at a Newcastle Chemical Society meeting, followed by a working demonstration on January 17, 1879. The lamp was also showcased to 700 visitors at a meeting of the Literary and Philosophical Society of Newcastle upon Tyne on February 3, 1879. These lamps employed a carbon rod typical of arc lamps, rather than a slender filament, resulting in low resistance and requiring large conductors for sufficient current. While not commercially viable, they demonstrated the potential for incandescent lighting using a high vacuum, carbon conductor, and platinum lead-in wires. However, due to the excessive current requirement and short lifespan, Swan shifted focus to improving the carbon filament and its attachment technique. He pioneered a method using cotton to produce 'parchmentised thread' and secured British Patent 4933 in 1880. That year, Swan began to install light bulbs in homes and landmarks across England, including his own house, which became the first in the world lit by a lightbulb and by hydroelectric power. In 1878, Lord Armstrong's home at Cragside was also among the first to be electrified. By the early 1880s, Swan had founded his own company. In 1881, Swan's incandescent lightbulbs illuminated the Savoy Theatre in Westminster, London, marking it as the first theatre, and public building globally, to be exclusively lit by electricity.
text_ai_humanized: Back in 1878, with Charles Stearn, a whiz with vacuum pumps, helping out, Swan came up with a way to stop early bulb blackening. He landed a British Patent for it in 1880. It was December 18, 1878, when Swan first showed off his lamp, which had a thin carbon rod, at a meeting of the Newcastle Chemical Society. Then, a month later on January 17, 1879, he gave a live demonstration. By February 3, 1879, 700 folks gathered at the Literary and Philosophical Society of Newcastle upon Tyne to see these lamps. Now, these weren't just any lamps. They had carbon rods like those in arc lamps—not the slender filament we might think of—meaning they had hefty resistance and gobbled up a lot of current, needing big conductors. Sure, they weren't ready for the store shelf, but Swan's invention neatly showcased incandescent lighting's possibilities with its high vacuum, carbon conductors, and platinum lead-ins. Yet, given the ridiculous amount of current they needed and their short lives, Swan knew he had to fix the filament and how it was attached. He revolutionized this by using cotton to make 'parchmentised thread,' which got him another British Patent, number 4933, in 1880. That same year, he started lighting up homes and landmarks all over England, not skipping his own—now the first in the world with lightbulb and hydroelectric power. Meanwhile, in 1878, Lord Armstrong's Cragside residence was also an early adopter of electricity. Moving onto the early 1880s, Swan kicked off his own company. Come 1881, his incandescent bulbs lit up the Savoy Theatre in Westminster, London, making it the first theatre and public building worldwide to bask solely in electric light. And that was quite a leap for incandescent lighting back then!

Then, a month later on January 17, 1879, he gave a live demonstration. By February 3, 1879, 700 folks gathered at the Literary and Philosophical Society of Newcastle upon Tyne to see these lamps. 

Now, these weren't just any lamps. They had carbon rods like those in arc lamps—not the slender filament we might think of—meaning they had hefty resistance and gobbled up a lot of current, needing big conductors. Sure, they weren't ready for the store shelf, but Swan's invention neatly showcased incandescent lighting's possibilities with its high vacuum, carbon conductors, and platinum lead-ins. Yet, given the ridiculous amount of current they needed and their short lives, Swan knew he had to fix the filament and how it was attached. 

He revolutionized this by using cotton to make 'parchmentised thread,' which got him another British Patent, number 4933, in 1880. That same year, he started lighting up homes and landmarks all over England, not skipping his own—now the first in the world with lightbulb and hydroelectric power. Meanwhile, in 1878, Lord Armstrong's Cragside residence was also an early adopter of electricity.

Moving onto the early 1880s, Swan kicked off his own company. Come 1881, his incandescent bulbs lit up the Savoy Theatre in Westminster, London, making it the first theatre and public building worldwide to bask solely in electric light. And that was quite a leap for incandescent lighting back then!

text_human: The state united behind the Plan of Ayutla and ratified the new constitution in 1855. The state was able to survive through the Reform War with minimal damage due to the large number of liberal political figures. The 1858 conservative movement did not succeed in the state even after the successful military campaign of the conservative Zuloaga with 1,000 men occupied the cities of Chihuahua and Parral. In August 1859, Zuloaga and his forces were defeated by the liberal Orozco and his forces; Orozco soon after deposed the state governor, but had to flee to Durango two months later. In the late 1860s the conservative General Cajen briefly entered the state after his campaign through the state of Jalisco and helped establish conservative politicians and ran out the liberal leaders Jesús González Ortega and José María Patoni. Cajen took possession of the state capital and established himself as governor; he brooked no delay in uniting a large force to combat the liberal forces which he defeated in La Batalla del Gallo. Cajen attained several advantages over the liberals within the state, but soon lost his standing due to a strong resurgence of the liberal forces within the state. The successful liberal leaders José María Patoni of Durango and J.E. Muñoz of Chihuahua quickly strengthened their standing by limiting the political rights of the clergy implementing the presidential decree. The state elected General Luis Terrazas, a liberal leader, as governor; he would continue to fight small battles within the state to suppress conservative uprisings during 1861.

During the Reform War, it endured with little damage, thanks to its many liberal political figures. The 1858 conservative movement failed in the state, even after the conservative leader Zuloaga successfully occupied the cities of Chihuahua and Parral with 1,000 men. In August 1859, Zuloaga and his forces were defeated by the liberal leader Orozco, who then briefly deposed the state governor before fleeing to Durango two months later. In the late 1860s, conservative General Cajen entered the state following his campaign through Jalisco. He helped install conservative politicians and ousted liberal leaders Jesús González Ortega and José María Patoni. Cajen took control of the state capital, declared himself governor, and swiftly assembled a large force, defeating the liberals in La Batalla del Gallo. Despite his initial success, Cajen soon lost power due to a strong liberal resurgence. Liberal leaders José María Patoni of Durango and J.E. Muñoz of Chihuahua regained influence by limiting the clergy's political rights according to a presidential decree. The state elected General Luis Terrazas, a liberal, as governor. He continued to combat small conservative uprisings throughout 1861.
text_ai_humanized: Back in 1855, a wave of support for the Plan of Ayutla swept through the state, leading to a nod of approval for the new constitution. Unlike many regions, the state emerged from the Reform War relatively unscathed, largely due to its strong cadre of liberal politicians. When conservative leader Zuloaga attempted to establish control, he managed to occupy Chihuahua and Parral with his 1,000-strong force, but by 1858, resistance within the state foiled his ambitions. August 1859 saw Zuloaga's forces defeated by the liberal leader Orozco, who briefly took over the governorship. However, Orozco's tenure was short-lived; he fled to Durango just two months later. Fast-forward to the late 1860s, when conservative General Cajen swept into the state following his campaign in Jalisco. He installed conservative allies, displacing liberal figures like Jesús González Ortega and José María Patoni. With swagger, Cajen seized control of the capital, declared himself governor, and wasted no time rallying a sizable army, eventually overpowering liberals in the fierce Battle of the Gallo. Yet, Cajen's triumph quickly unraveled. A powerful liberal resurgence turned the tides against him. Liberal stalwarts, including José María Patoni from Durango and J.E. Muñoz from Chihuahua, clawed back power by curtailing the political clout of the clergy in compliance with a presidential decree. Riding this shift, General Luis Terrazas was elected as the liberal governor. He steadfastly tackled the stubborn conservative insurrections that dotted the landscape throughout 1861, marking a period of liberal consolidation amid turbulent post-war politics.

Back in 1855, a wave of support for the Plan of Ayutla swept through the state, leading to a nod of approval for the new constitution. Unlike many regions, the state emerged from the Reform War relatively unscathed, largely due to its strong cadre of liberal politicians. When conservative leader Zuloaga attempted to establish control, he managed to occupy Chihuahua and Parral with his 1,000-strong force, but by 1858, resistance within the state foiled his ambitions. 

August 1859 saw Zuloaga's forces defeated by the liberal leader Orozco, who briefly took over the governorship. However, Orozco's tenure was short-lived; he fled to Durango just two months later. Fast-forward to the late 1860s, when conservative General Cajen swept into the state following his campaign in Jalisco. He installed conservative allies, displacing liberal figures like Jesús González Ortega and José María Patoni. With swagger, Cajen seized control of the capital, declared himself governor, and wasted no time rallying a sizable army, eventually overpowering liberals in the fierce Battle of the Gallo.

Yet, Cajen's triumph quickly unraveled. A powerful liberal resurgence turned the tides against him. Liberal stalwarts, including José María Patoni from Durango and J.E. Muñoz from Chihuahua, clawed back power by curtailing the political clout of the clergy in compliance with a presidential decree. Riding this shift, General Luis Terrazas was elected as the liberal governor. He steadfastly tackled the stubborn conservative insurrections that dotted the landscape throughout 1861, marking a period of liberal consolidation amid turbulent post-war politics.

text_human: Non-religious Umayyad mosaic works were mainly floor panels which decorated the palaces of the caliphs and other high-ranking officials. They were closely modeled after the mosaics of the Roman country villas, once common in the Eastern Mediterranean. The most superb example can be found in the bath house of Hisham's Palace, Palestine which was made around 744. The main panel depicts a large tree and underneath it a lion attacking a deer (right side) and two deers peacefully grazing (left side). The panel probably represents good and bad governance. Mosaics with classical geometric motifs survived in the bath area of the 8th-century Umayyad palace complex in Anjar, Lebanon. The luxurious desert residence of Al-Walid II in Qasr al-Hallabat (in present-day Jordan) was also decorated with floor mosaics that show a high level of technical skill. The best preserved panel at Hallabat is divided by a Tree of Life flanked by "good" animals on one side and "bad" animals on the other. Among the Hallabat representations are vine scrolls, grapes, pomegranates, oryx, wolves, hares, a leopard, pairs of partridges, fish, bulls, ostriches, rabbits, rams, goats, lions and a snake. At Qastal, near Amman, excavations in 2000 uncovered the earliest known Umayyad mosaics in present-day Jordan, dating probably from the caliphate of Abd al-Malik ibn Marwan (685–705). They cover much of the floor of a finely decorated building that probably served as the palace of a local governor. The Qastal mosaics depict geometrical patterns, trees, animals, fruits and rosettes. Except for the open courtyard, entrance and staircases, the floors of the entire palace were covered in mosaics.

This main panel illustrates a large tree with a lion attacking a deer on the right side, while two deer graze peacefully on the left, likely symbolizing the themes of good versus bad governance. In the 8th-century Umayyad palace complex at Anjar, Lebanon, mosaics featuring classical geometric patterns have been preserved in the bath area. Al-Walid II's luxurious desert residence in Qasr al-Hallabat, now in Jordan, was similarly adorned with highly skilled floor mosaics. The best-preserved panel at Hallabat features a Tree of Life divided among "good" and "bad" animals. The mosaics at Hallabat also include vine scrolls, grapes, pomegranates, oryx, wolves, hares, leopards, pairs of partridges, fish, bulls, ostriches, rabbits, rams, goats, lions, and a snake. Excavations in 2000 at Qastal, near Amman, uncovered the earliest known Umayyad mosaics in modern Jordan, likely dating from 685–705 during Abd al-Malik ibn Marwan's rule. These mosaics, likely part of a local governor's palace, feature geometric patterns, trees, animals, fruits, and rosettes, covering all but the open courtyard, entrance, and staircases.

Among the most stunning of these works lies in the bathhouse at Hisham's Palace in Palestine, crafted around 744 A.D. Venturing into the 8th-century ruins of the Umayyad palace at Anjar, Lebanon, one encounters mosaics that preserve classical geometric designs still visible in the bath areas. Further afield in 2000, archaeologists unearthed the most ancient known Umayyad mosaics at Qastal near Amman, attributed to the rule of Abd al-Malik ibn Marwan between 685–705. These artistic treasures, likely embellishing a local governor's palace, display intricate geometric designs mingled with trees, vibrant fruits, lively animals, and graceful rosettes. Every inch was adorned except for the open courtyard, grand entrances, and staircases. It’s a startlingly vivid time capsule of the artistic dialogues defining the Umayyad era.

text_human: On 13 March, the upper Clyde port of Clydebank near Glasgow was bombed. All but seven of its 12,000 houses were damaged. Many more ports were attacked. Plymouth was attacked five times before the end of the month while Belfast, Hull, and Cardiff were hit. Cardiff was bombed on three nights, Portsmouth centre was devastated by five raids. The rate of civilian housing lost was averaging 40,000 people per week dehoused in September 1940. In March 1941, two raids on Plymouth and London dehoused 148,000 people. Still, while heavily damaged, British ports continued to support war industry and supplies from North America continued to pass through them while the Royal Navy continued to operate in Plymouth, Southampton, and Portsmouth. Plymouth in particular, because of its vulnerable position on the south coast and close proximity to German air bases, was subjected to the heaviest attacks. On 10/11 March, 240 bombers dropped 193 tons of high explosives and 46,000 incendiaries. Many houses and commercial centres were heavily damaged, the electrical supply was knocked out, and five oil tanks and two magazines exploded. Nine days later, two waves of 125 and 170 bombers dropped heavy bombs, including 160 tons of high explosive and 32,000 incendiaries. Much of the city centre was destroyed. Damage was inflicted on the port installations, but many bombs fell on the city itself. On 17 April 346 tons of explosives and 46,000 incendiaries were dropped from 250 bombers led by KG 26. The damage was considerable, and the Germans also used aerial mines. Over 2,000 AAA shells were fired, destroying two Ju 88s. By the end of the air campaign over Britain, only eight percent of the German effort against British ports was made using mines.

Numerous other ports were attacked, with Plymouth suffering five assaults by month's end, while Belfast, Hull, and Cardiff were also targeted. Cardiff endured bombings on three separate nights, and Portsmouth's center was ravaged by five raids. By September 1940, civilian housing loss was at a rate of 40,000 people dehoused per week. In March 1941, two raids on Plymouth and London displaced 148,000 individuals. Despite severe damage, British ports continued supporting war efforts, facilitating supplies from North America, and the Royal Navy maintained operations in Plymouth, Southampton, and Portsmouth. Plymouth, situated vulnerably on the south coast near German air bases, encountered the most intense attacks. On March 10-11, 240 bombers dropped 193 tons of high explosives and 46,000 incendiaries, severely damaging residential and commercial areas and disrupting electricity, with five oil tanks and two magazines detonating. Nine days later, another fierce assault saw two waves of 125 and 170 bombers release 160 tons of high explosives and 32,000 incendiaries, devastating much of the city center and impacting port facilities, although many bombs struck the city itself. On April 17, 250 bombers led by KG 26 dropped 346 tons of explosives and 46,000 incendiaries, causing significant damage and deploying aerial mines. Over 2,000 anti-aircraft shells fired hit two Ju 88 aircraft. By the air campaign's conclusion over Britain, only eight percent of German attacks on British ports employed mines.

text_human: "The first Ottoman Medrese was created in İznik in 1331 and most Ottoman medreses followed the traditions of Sunni Islam." "When an Ottoman sultan established a new medrese, he would invite scholars from the Islamic world—for example, Murad II brought scholars from Persia, such as ʻAlāʼ al-Dīn and Fakhr al-Dīn who helped enhance the reputation of the Ottoman medrese". This reveals that the Islamic world was interconnected in the early modern period as they travelled around to other Islamic states exchanging knowledge. This sense that the Ottoman Empire was becoming modernised through globalization is also recognised by Hamadeh who says: "Change in the eighteenth century as the beginning of a long and unilinear march toward westernisation reflects the two centuries of reformation in sovereign identity." İnalcık also mentions that while scholars from for example Persia travelled to the Ottomans in order to share their knowledge, Ottomans travelled as well to receive education from scholars of these Islamic lands, such as Egypt, Persia and Turkestan. Hence, this reveals that similar to today's modern world, individuals from the early modern society travelled abroad to receive education and share knowledge and that the world was more interconnected than it seems. Also, it reveals how the system of "schooling" was also similar to today's modern world where students travel abroad to different countries for studies. Examples of Ottoman madaris are the ones built by Mehmed the Conqueror. He built eight madaris that were built "on either side of the mosque where there were eight higher madaris for specialised studies and eight lower medreses, which prepared students for these." The fact that they were built around, or near mosques reveals the religious impulses behind madrasa building and it reveals the interconnectedness between institutions of learning and religion. The students who completed their education in the lower medreses became known as danismends. This reveals that similar to the education system today, the Ottomans' educational system involved different kinds of schools attached to different kinds of levels. For example, there were lower madaris and specialised ones, and for one to get into the specialised area meant that he had to complete the classes in the lower one in order to adequately prepare himself for higher learning.
text_ai_base: The first Ottoman Medrese was established in İznik in 1331, and most Ottoman medreses adhered to the traditions of Sunni Islam. When an Ottoman sultan founded a new medrese, he would invite scholars from across the Islamic world. For instance, Murad II brought in scholars from Persia, such as ʻAlāʼ al-Dīn and Fakhr al-Dīn, to enhance the medrese’s reputation. This demonstrates the interconnectedness of the Islamic world during the early modern period, as scholars traveled between Islamic states to exchange knowledge. Hamadeh notes that this globalization indicated the Ottoman Empire's modernization, stating: “Change in the eighteenth century as the beginning of a long and unilinear march toward westernisation reflects the two centuries of reformation in sovereign identity.” İnalcık also mentions that Ottomans traveled abroad to places like Egypt, Persia, and Turkestan to further their education, illustrating the reciprocity of knowledge exchange. Much like today, individuals traveled internationally to learn and share knowledge, suggesting the world was more interconnected than it might appear. This parallels modern systems where students study abroad. An example of Ottoman madaris includes those built by Mehmed the Conqueror, who constructed eight madaris on each side of a mosque—eight for specialized studies and eight for preparatory education. Their proximity to mosques highlights the religious motivations underpinning madrasa construction and the blend of educational and religious institutions. Students who completed their education at the lower medreses were called danismends. Similar to today's educational systems, the Ottoman system comprised various school levels, requiring students to advance from lower to more specialized madaris to prepare for higher learning.
text_ai_humanized: Back in 1331, the first Ottoman medrese sprang up in İznik, setting a precedent for many that followed, each firmly rooted in Sunni Islamic traditions. An Ottoman sultan, when establishing a new medrese, would often extend invitations to scholars from afar. Take Murad II, for example; he brought in intellectual heavyweights from Persia like ʻAlāʼ al-Dīn and Fakhr al-Dīn, bolstering the medrese’s academic standing. This practice illustrates the vibrant exchange within the Islamic world during the early modern era, as scholars crossed borders to share their wisdom. Hamadeh observes that such globalization signals the Ottoman Empire's steps toward modernity, described as an "unilinear march toward westernisation" during two centuries of evolving sovereign identity. Meanwhile, İnalcık highlights the Ottomans' journeys to locales such as Egypt, Persia, and Turkestan for educational pursuits, showcasing a lively reciprocity in knowledge exchange. It’s a thought that resonates with our current global educational exchanges, reminiscent of students who travel abroad for studies today—a testament to how interconnected societies were. One notable example from the Ottoman era is the madrasa complex built by Mehmed the Conqueror; he constructed eight specialized madaris paired with eight preparatory institutions flanking a mosque, underscoring the religious underpinnings of these educational endeavors and how faith intertwined with learning. Graduates from these initial medreses were known as danismends. Much like the educational systems familiar to us, the Ottoman structure required students to progress through various school levels, advancing from foundational training to more specialized fields to ready themselves for higher academic challenges. Isn’t it fascinating how education continues to intertwine with culture and innovation over the centuries?

Meanwhile, İnalcık highlights the Ottomans' journeys to locales such as Egypt, Persia, and Turkestan for educational pursuits, showcasing a lively reciprocity in knowledge exchange. One notable example from the Ottoman era is the madrasa complex built by Mehmed the Conqueror; he constructed eight specialized madaris paired with eight preparatory institutions flanking a mosque, underscoring the religious underpinnings of these educational endeavors and how faith intertwined with learning.

Graduates from these initial medreses were known as danismends. Much like the educational systems familiar to us, the Ottoman structure required students to progress through various school levels, advancing from foundational training to more specialized fields to ready themselves for higher academic challenges. Isn’t it fascinating how education continues to intertwine with culture and innovation over the centuries?

text_human: To extend and consolidate the dynasty's control in Central Asia, the Kangxi Emperor personally led a series of military campaigns against the Dzungars in Outer Mongolia. The Kangxi Emperor was able to successfully expel Galdan's invading forces from these regions, which were then incorporated into the empire. Galdan was eventually killed in the Dzungar–Qing War. In 1683, Qing forces received the surrender of Taiwan from Zheng Keshuang, grandson of Koxinga, who had conquered Taiwan from the Dutch colonists as a base against the Qing. Zheng Keshuang was awarded the title "Duke Haicheng" (海澄公) and was inducted into the Han Chinese Plain Red Banner of the Eight Banners when he moved to Beijing. Several Ming princes had accompanied Koxinga to Taiwan in 1661-1662, including the Prince of Ningjing Zhu Shugui and Prince Zhu Honghuan (朱弘桓), son of Zhu Yihai, where they lived in the Kingdom of Tungning. The Qing sent the 17 Ming princes still living on Taiwan in 1683 back to mainland China where they spent the rest of their lives in exile since their lives were spared from execution. Winning Taiwan freed Kangxi's forces for series of battles over Albazin, the far eastern outpost of the Tsardom of Russia. Zheng's former soldiers on Taiwan like the rattan shield troops were also inducted into the Eight Banners and used by the Qing against Russian Cossacks at Albazin. The 1689 Treaty of Nerchinsk was China's first formal treaty with a European power and kept the border peaceful for the better part of two centuries. After Galdan's death, his followers, as adherents to Tibetan Buddhism, attempted to control the choice of the next Dalai Lama. Kangxi dispatched two armies to Lhasa, the capital of Tibet, and installed a Dalai Lama sympathetic to the Qing.

In a different theater, 1683 marked a strategic victory for Qing forces with the surrender of Taiwan, wrested from Zheng Keshuang, who happened to be Koxinga's grandson. text_human: After the death of the president Benito Juárez in 1872, the first magistracy of the country was occupied by the vice-president Sebastián Lerdo de Tejada, who called for new elections. Two candidates were registered; Lerdo de Tejada and General Porfirio Díaz, one of the heroes of the Battle of Puebla which had taken place on May 5, 1862. Lerdeo de Tejada won the election, but lost popularity after he announced his intent to run for re-election. On March 21, 1876, Don Porfirio Díaz rebelled against President Sebastian Lerdo de Tejada. The Plan of Tuxtepec defended the "No Re-election" principle. On June 2, 1876 the garrisons in the state of Chihuahua surrendered to the authority of General Porfirio Díaz; Governor Antonio Ochoa was arrested until all the Lerdista forces were suppressed throughout the state. Porfirio Díaz then helped Tíras regain the governorship of the state of Chihuahua allowing for the Plan of Tuxtepec to be implemented. The victory of the Plan of Tuxtepec, gave the interim presidency to Jose Maria Iglesias and later, as the only candidate, the General Porfirio Díaz assumed the presidency on May 5, 1877. During the first years of the Porfiriato (Porfirio Díaz Era), the Díaz administration had to combat several attacks from the Lerdista forces and the Apache. A new rebellion led by the Lerdista party was orchestrated from exile in the United States. The Lerdista forces were able to temporarily occupy the city of El Paso del Norte until mid-1877. During 1877 the northern parts of the state suffered through a spell of extreme drought which were responsible for many deaths in El Paso del Norte.
text_ai_base: Following the death of President Benito Juárez in 1872, Vice-President Sebastián Lerdo de Tejada assumed the presidency and called for new elections. The two candidates were Lerdo de Tejada and General Porfirio Díaz, a renowned hero of the Battle of Puebla on May 5, 1862. Lerdo de Tejada won the election but lost favor when he announced plans to seek re-election. On March 21, 1876, Porfirio Díaz launched a rebellion against President Lerdo de Tejada, advocating for the "No Re-election" principle through the Plan of Tuxtepec. On June 2, 1876, the garrisons in Chihuahua state surrendered to Díaz's authority, resulting in the arrest of Governor Antonio Ochoa and the suppression of Lerdista forces across the state. Díaz then supported the reinstatement of Tíras as the governor of Chihuahua, facilitating the implementation of the Plan of Tuxtepec. This victory led to Jose Maria Iglesias briefly holding the interim presidency until Díaz, as the sole candidate, became president on May 5, 1877. In the early years of Díaz's administration, known as the Porfiriato, his government faced attacks from both Lerdista forces and Apache groups. Exiled Lerdistas orchestrated a new rebellion from the United States, temporarily capturing the city of El Paso del Norte until mid-1877. That year, the northern region suffered a severe drought, causing many deaths in El Paso del Norte.
text_ai_humanized: After the death of President Benito Juárez in 1872, Vice-President Sebastián Lerdo de Tejada stepped up to the helm and promptly announced a forthcoming election. Competing for the presidency were Lerdo de Tejada himself and General Porfirio Díaz, celebrated for his heroics during the Battle of Puebla on that memorable day—May 5, 1862. Although Lerdo de Tejada emerged victorious in the elections, his decision to pursue re-election sparked dissatisfaction among many. Thus, on March 21, 1876, Díaz took action by instigating a rebellion against him. This effort championed the "No Re-election" philosophy through what became known as the Plan of Tuxtepec. By June 2 that year, Díaz's influence extended to the garrisons in the state of Chihuahua. They capitulated, leading to the capture of Governor Antonio Ochoa and the dismantling of Lerdista forces. Consequently, Díaz was instrumental in reinstating Tíras as governor, ensuring the Plan of Tuxtepec's ideals were followed. This triumph paved the way for José María Iglesias to step in as interim president for a time, but it wasn't long before Díaz stood unopposed, assuming the presidency on May 5, 1877. The dawn of Díaz's presidency, often referred to as the Porfiriato, was anything but calm. His administration navigated assaults from the remaining Lerdista forces and threats posed by Apache groups. Meanwhile, Lerdistas in exile, from their base in the United States, orchestrated a fresh insurrection, briefly capturing El Paso del Norte until mid-1877. As if political turmoil wasn’t enough, the northern region suffered a harsh drought that year, bringing about a wave of fatalities in El Paso del Norte.

Although Lerdo de Tejada emerged victorious in the elections, his decision to pursue re-election sparked dissatisfaction among many. Thus, on March 21, 1876, Díaz took action by instigating a rebellion against him. This effort championed the "No Re-election" philosophy through what became known as the Plan of Tuxtepec.

By June 2 that year, Díaz's influence extended to the garrisons in the state of Chihuahua. They capitulated, leading to the capture of Governor Antonio Ochoa and the dismantling of Lerdista forces. Consequently, Díaz was instrumental in reinstating Tíras as governor, ensuring the Plan of Tuxtepec's ideals were followed. This triumph paved the way for José María Iglesias to step in as interim president for a time, but it wasn't long before Díaz stood unopposed, assuming the presidency on May 5, 1877.

The dawn of Díaz's presidency, often referred to as the Porfiriato, was anything but calm. His administration navigated assaults from the remaining Lerdista forces and threats posed by Apache groups. Meanwhile, Lerdistas in exile, from their base in the United States, orchestrated a fresh insurrection, briefly capturing El Paso del Norte until mid-1877. As if political turmoil wasn’t enough, the northern region suffered a harsh drought that year, bringing about a wave of fatalities in El Paso del Norte.

text_human: In December 2015, West released a song titled "Facts". He announced in January 2016 on Twitter that SWISH would be released on February 11, after releasing new song "Real Friends" and a snippet of "No More Parties in L.A." with Kendrick Lamar. This also revived the GOOD Fridays initiative in which Kanye releases new singles every Friday. On January 26, 2016, West revealed he had renamed the album from SWISH to Waves, and also announced the premier of his Yeezy Season 3 clothing line at Madison Square Garden. In early 2016, several weeks prior to the release of his new album, West became embroiled in a short-lived social media altercation with rapper Wiz Khalifa on Twitter that eventually involved their mutual ex-partner, Amber Rose, who protested to West's mention of her and Khalifa's child. The feud involved allegations by Rose concerning her sexual relationship with West, and received significant media attention. As of February 2, 2016, West and Khalifa had reconciled. Several days ahead of the album's release, West again changed the title, this time to The Life of Pablo. On February 11, West premiered the album at Madison Square Garden as part of the presentation of his Yeezy Season 3 clothing line. Following the preview, West announced that he would be modifying the track list once more before its release to the public, and further delayed its release to finalize the recording of the track "Waves" at the behest of co-writer Chance the Rapper. He released the album exclusively on Tidal on 14 February 2016 following a performance on SNL.

Kanye took to Twitter to tell the world his upcoming album, originally titled SWISH, was set to hit on February 11. Thus began the rebirth of his GOOD Fridays tradition, where fans were treated to a fresh single every Friday. But wait, the plot thickens. Finally, on February 14, 2016, The Life of Pablo made its debut, but with a twist: it was only available on Tidal, hot on the heels of Kanye’s SNL performance.

text_human: Dorgon's controversial July 1645 edict (the "haircutting order") forced adult Han Chinese men to shave the front of their heads and comb the remaining hair into the queue hairstyle which was worn by Manchu men, on pain of death. The popular description of the order was: "To keep the hair, you lose the head; To keep your head, you cut the hair." To the Manchus, this policy was a test of loyalty and an aid in distinguishing friend from foe. For the Han Chinese, however, it was a humiliating reminder of Qing authority that challenged traditional Confucian values. The Classic of Filial Piety (Xiaojing) held that "a person's body and hair, being gifts from one's parents, are not to be damaged." Under the Ming dynasty, adult men did not cut their hair but instead wore it in the form of a top-knot. The order triggered strong resistance to Qing rule in Jiangnan and massive killing of ethnic Han Chinese. It was Han Chinese defectors who carried out massacres against people refusing to wear the queue.. Li Chengdong, a Han Chinese general who had served the Ming but surrendered to the Qing, ordered his Han troops to carry out three separate massacres in the city of Jiading within a month, resulting in tens of thousands of deaths. At the end of the third massacre, there was hardly any living person left in this city. Jiangyin also held out against about 10,000 Han Chinese Qing troops for 83 days. When the city wall was finally breached on 9 October 1645, the Han Chinese Qing army led by the Han Chinese Ming defector Liu Liangzuo (劉良佐), who had been ordered to "fill the city with corpses before you sheathe your swords," massacred the entire population, killing between 74,000 and 100,000 people. The queue was the only aspect of Manchu culture which the Qing forced on the common Han population. The Qing required people serving as officials to wear Manchu clothing, but allowed non-official Han civilians to continue wearing Hanfu (Han clothing).
text_ai_base: In July 1645, Dorgon issued a contentious edict, known as the "haircutting order," requiring adult Han Chinese men to shave the front of their heads and style the remaining hair into a queue, similar to that worn by Manchu men. Failure to comply meant death. The edict was famously summarized as: "To keep the hair, you lose the head; to keep your head, you cut the hair." For the Manchus, this policy served as a loyalty test and a way to identify allies. However, for the Han Chinese, it was a humiliating symbol of Qing dominance, clashing with traditional Confucian values outlined in the Classic of Filial Piety (Xiaojing), which stated that "a person's body and hair, as gifts from one's parents, should not be harmed." Under the preceding Ming dynasty, men wore their hair in top-knots and did not cut it. The edict sparked fierce resistance to Qing rule in Jiangnan, leading to mass killings of Han Chinese. Ironically, it was Han Chinese defectors who carried out massacres against those refusing the queue. Li Chengdong, a former Ming general who surrendered to the Qing, commanded his troops to perform three separate massacres in Jiading within a month, resulting in tens of thousands of deaths. By the end of the third massacre, scarcely anyone in the city remained alive. Jiangyin resisted the Qing forces for 83 days, but when the city walls fell on October 9, 1645, the Qing army, led by Ming defector Liu Liangzuo (劉良佐), massacred the entire population, killing between 74,000 and 100,000 people, under orders to "fill the city with corpses before you sheathe your swords." The queue was the only element of Manchu culture imposed on the general Han populace. While officials were required to wear Manchu attire, ordinary Han civilians were permitted to continue wearing Hanfu.

text_human: The KU men's basketball team has fielded a team every year since 1898. The Jayhawks are a perennial national contender currently coached by Bill Self. The team has won five national titles, including three NCAA tournament championships in 1952, 1988, and 2008. The basketball program is currently the second winningest program in college basketball history with an overall record of 2,070–806 through the 2011–12 season. The team plays at Allen Fieldhouse. Perhaps its best recognized player was Wilt Chamberlain, who played in the 1950s. Kansas has counted among its coaches Dr. James Naismith (the inventor of basketball and only coach in Kansas history to have a losing record), Basketball Hall of Fame inductee Phog Allen ("the Father of basketball coaching"), Basketball Hall of Fame inductee Roy Williams of the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, and Basketball Hall of Fame inductee and former NBA Champion Detroit Pistons coach Larry Brown. In addition, legendary University of Kentucky coach and Basketball Hall of Fame inductee Adolph Rupp played for KU's 1922 and 1923 Helms National Championship teams, and NCAA Hall of Fame inductee and University of North Carolina Coach Dean Smith played for KU's 1952 NCAA Championship team. Both Rupp and Smith played under Phog Allen. Allen also coached Hall of Fame coaches Dutch Lonborg and Ralph Miller. Allen founded the National Association of Basketball Coaches (NABC), which started what is now the NCAA Tournament. The Tournament began in 1939 under the NABC and the next year was handed off to the newly formed NCAA.

text_human: The Defence Committee—Third Report "Defence Equipment 2009" cites an article from the Financial Times website stating that the Chief of Defence Materiel, General Sir Kevin O’Donoghue, had instructed staff within Defence Equipment and Support (DE&S) through an internal memorandum to reprioritize the approvals process to focus on supporting current operations over the next three years; deterrence related programmes; those that reflect defence obligations both contractual or international; and those where production contracts are already signed. The report also cites concerns over potential cuts in the defence science and technology research budget; implications of inappropriate estimation of Defence Inflation within budgetary processes; underfunding in the Equipment Programme; and a general concern over striking the appropriate balance over a short-term focus (Current Operations) and long-term consequences of failure to invest in the delivery of future UK defence capabilities on future combatants and campaigns. The then Secretary of State for Defence, Bob Ainsworth MP, reinforced this reprioritisation of focus on current operations and had not ruled out "major shifts" in defence spending. In the same article the First Sea Lord and Chief of the Naval Staff, Admiral Sir Mark Stanhope, Royal Navy, acknowledged that there was not enough money within the defence budget and it is preparing itself for tough decisions and the potential for cutbacks. According to figures published by the London Evening Standard the defence budget for 2009 is "more than 10% overspent" (figures cannot be verified) and the paper states that this had caused Gordon Brown to say that the defence spending must be cut. The MoD has been investing in IT to cut costs and improve services for its personnel.

This refocusing emphasizes support for current operations over the next three years, deterrence-related programs, defense obligations that are either contractual or international, and projects with signed production contracts. The report also highlights concerns about potential cuts to the defence science and technology research budget, inaccurate estimates of Defence Inflation impacting budgets, underfunding in the Equipment Programme, and the challenge of balancing short-term focuses on current operations with the need to invest in future UK defense capabilities. Bob Ainsworth MP, the then Secretary of State for Defence, endorsed this shift towards current operations, mentioning that "major shifts" in defense spending were not off the table. Admiral Sir Mark Stanhope, First Sea Lord and Chief of the Naval Staff, acknowledged the insufficient funding in the defense budget, indicating the necessity for tough decisions and possible cutbacks. According to the London Evening Standard, the 2009 defense budget was "more than 10% overspent," though these figures are unverified, prompting Gordon Brown to declare the need for defense spending cuts. To manage costs and enhance services for its personnel, the Ministry of Defence has been investing in IT.

To refocus the process of approval, prioritizing the support of ongoing military operations over the next three years. This shift aims to underline deterrence-related initiatives, fulfill both contractual and international defense commitments, and give precedence to projects already bound by production contracts. It’s worth noting how the London Evening Standard claimed the 2009 defense budget exceeded projections by over 10%, although this figure remains unconfirmed, prompting Gordon Brown to assert the need for expenditure reductions in defense. Meanwhile, the Ministry of Defence is undertaking IT investments to trim costs and boost services for its personnel.

text_human: West's middle-class background, flamboyant fashion sense and outspokenness have additionally set him apart from other rappers. Early in his career, he was among the first rappers to publicly criticize the preponderance of homophobia in hip hop. The sales competition between rapper 50 Cent's Curtis and West's Graduation altered the direction of hip hop and helped pave the way for new rappers who did not follow the hardcore-gangster mold. Rosie Swash of The Guardian viewed the sales competition as a historical moment in hip-hop, because it "highlighted the diverging facets of hip-hop in the last decade; the former was gangsta rap for the noughties, while West was the thinking man's alternative." Rolling Stone credited West with transforming hip hop's mainstream, "establishing a style of introspective yet glossy rap [...]", and called him "as interesting and complicated a pop star as the 2000s produced—a rapper who mastered, upped and moved beyond the hip-hop game, a producer who created a signature sound and then abandoned it to his imitators, a flashy, free-spending sybarite with insightful things to say about college, culture and economics, an egomaniac with more than enough artistic firepower to back it up." His 2008 album 808s & Heartbreak polarized both listeners and critics upon its release, but was commercially successful and impacted hip hop and pop stylistically, as it laid the groundwork for a new wave of artists who generally eschewed typical rap braggadocio for intimate subject matter and introspection, including Frank Ocean, The Weeknd, Drake, Future, Kid Cudi, Childish Gambino, Lil Durk, Chief Keef, and Soulja Boy. According to Ben Detrick of XXL magazine, West effectively led a new wave of artists, including Kid Cudi, Wale, Lupe Fiasco, Kidz in the Hall, and Drake, who lacked the interest or ability to rap about gunplay or drug-dealing.

Rosie Swash of The Guardian regarded this competition as a pivotal moment, highlighting hip hop's divergent trends: gangsta rap for the 2000s versus West's intellectual alternative. Rolling Stone attributed West with transforming mainstream hip hop by creating introspective yet polished rap. They described him as one of the most intriguing and complex pop stars of the 2000s—a rapper who mastered and then transcended the hip hop scene, a producer with a distinctive sound that he left for his imitators, and a flashy yet insightful figure discussing college, culture, and economics. His 2008 album, "808s & Heartbreak," divided listeners and critics but was a commercial success. It had a stylistic impact on hip hop and pop, paving the way for artists like Frank Ocean, The Weeknd, Drake, Future, Kid Cudi, Childish Gambino, Lil Durk, Chief Keef, and Soulja Boy, who favored introspection over traditional rap braggadocio. Ben Detrick of XXL magazine noted that West led a new wave of artists, such as Kid Cudi, Wale, Lupe Fiasco, Kidz in the Hall, and Drake, who were uninterested in or incapable of rapping about gunplay or drug dealing.
text_ai_humanized: Kanye West is a fascinating figure, distinct in the rap world for his middle-class roots, bold fashion choices, and unabashedly vocal persona. Early on, West set himself apart by challenging the homophobia often found in hip hop—a move not many were brave enough to make at the time. When it came to shaking up the music scene, few events were as monumental as the head-to-head sales duel between 50 Cent's "Curtis" and West's "Graduation." This clash reshaped hip hop's future, breaking away from the tough, gangster image and throwing the door open for fresh voices. Rosie Swash of The Guardian viewed this as a crucial turning point, observing how hip hop began to chart two paths: one rooted in gangsta themes and the other led by West's more thoughtful approach. Rolling Stone painted West as a transformative force in mainstream hip hop—a trailblazer who fused introspection with a sleek, polished sound. They saw him as one of the most captivating and multifaceted pop stars of the 2000s, a kind of Renaissance man working within and beyond hip hop's bounds. He was a rapper who not only dominated but also evolved the genre, crafting a signature sound others would soon imitate while addressing topics like academia, culture, and economics with flair. West's 2008 album, "808s & Heartbreak," split opinions among critics and fans alike, yet its commercial triumph was undeniable. This project left an indelible mark on both hip hop and pop, helping to usher in artists like Frank Ocean, The Weeknd, and Drake—figures who preferred introspective themes over the typical boastful rap narratives. According to Ben Detrick of XXL magazine, West became the vanguard of a new artist wave. Folks like Kid Cudi, Wale, Lupe Fiasco, and Drake joined him, steering clear of stories about guns and drugs, either by choice or because it wasn't their style.

text_human: Following the unveiling of Windows 8, Microsoft faced criticism (particularly from free software supporters) for mandating that devices receiving its optional certification for Windows 8 have secure boot enabled by default using a key provided by Microsoft. Concerns were raised that secure boot could prevent or hinder the use of alternate operating systems such as Linux. In a post discussing secure boot on the Building Windows 8 blog, Microsoft developer Tony Mangefeste indicated that vendors would provide means to customize secure boot, stating that "At the end of the day, the customer is in control of their PC. Microsoft's philosophy is to provide customers with the best experience first, and allow them to make decisions themselves." Microsoft's certification guidelines for Windows 8 ultimately revealed that vendors would be required to provide means for users to re-configure or disable secure boot in their device's UEFI firmware. It also revealed that ARM devices (Windows RT) would be required to have secure boot permanently enabled, with no way for users to disable it. However, Tom Warren of The Verge noted that other vendors have implemented similar hardware restrictions on their own ARM-based tablet and smartphone products (including those running Microsoft's own Windows Phone platform), but still argued that Microsoft should "keep a consistent approach across ARM and x86, though, not least because of the number of users who'd love to run Android alongside Windows 8 on their future tablets." No mandate is made regarding the installation of third-party certificates that would enable running alternative programs.

text_human: Many modern specialty matches have been devised, with unique winning conditions. The most common of these is the ladder match. In the basic ladder match, the wrestlers or teams of wrestlers must climb a ladder to obtain a prize that is hoisted above the ring. The key to winning this match is that the wrestler or team of wrestlers must try to incapacitate each other long enough for one wrestler to climb the ladder and secure that prize for their team. As a result, the ladder can be used as a weapon. The prizes include – but are not limited to any given championship belt (the traditional prize), a document granting the winner the right to a future title shot, or any document that matters to the wrestlers involved in the match (such as one granting the winner a cash prize). Another common specialty match is known as the battle royal. In a battle royal, all the wrestlers enter the ring to the point that there are 20-30 wrestlers in the ring at one time. When the match begins, the simple objective is to throw the opponent over the top rope and out of the ring with both feet on the floor in order to eliminate that opponent. The last wrestler standing is declared the winner. A variant on this type of match is the WWE's Royal Rumble where two wrestlers enter the ring to start the match and other wrestlers follow in 90 second intervals (previously 2 minutes) until 30-40 wrestlers have entered the ring. All other rules stay the same. For more match types, see Professional wrestling match types.

All other rules remain the same. For more match types, see Professional wrestling match types.

These days, the sport offers a kaleidoscope of creative formats beyond just these crowd-pleasers.

Victory demands not just athletic skill but also the strategy of incapacitating foes long enough to climb the ladder and grab the prize. The ladder itself often doubles as a weapon in these confrontations. Prizes can range from the classic championship belt and title-shot contracts to meaningful items like cash rewards.

Equally thrilling is the battle royal, where chaos reigns supreme as wrestlers flood the ring, sometimes up to 30 at a time. The objective? To hurl each opponent over the top rope, ensuring both feet touch the ground outside the ring. The last wrestler standing takes the win. This melee has a famous twist in the WWE's Royal Rumble—a spectacle where two wrestlers kick things off, with additional competitors joining the fray at intervals of 90 seconds (though it used to be every two minutes), until a throng of 30 to 40 fills the ring. The fundamental rules don't change, keeping the intensity high as each competitor fights for survival.

Curious about even more match types? These days, the sport offers a kaleidoscope of creative formats beyond just these crowd-pleasers.

text_human: In 633 AD, Rashidun Arabs invaded Iran and conquered it by 651 AD, largely converting Iranian people from their indigenous faiths of Manichaeism and Zoroastrianism to Sunni Islam. Arabic replaced Persian as the official language, while Persian remained the language of both ordinary people and of literature. Iran became a major contributor to the Islamic Golden Age, producing many influential scientists, scholars, artists, and thinkers. Establishment of the Safavid Dynasty in 1501, converted the Iranian people from Sunni Islam to Twelver Shia Islam, and made Twelver Shia Islam the official religion of Iran. Safavid conversion of Iran from Sunnism to Shiism marked one of the most important turning points in Iranian and Muslim history. Starting in 1736 under Nader Shah, Iran reached its greatest territorial extent since the Sassanid Empire, briefly possessing what was arguably the most powerful empire at the time. During the 19th century, Iran irrevocably lost swaths of its territories in the Caucasus which made part of the concept of Iran for centuries, to neighboring Imperial Russia. Popular unrest culminated in the Persian Constitutional Revolution of 1906, which established a constitutional monarchy and the country's first Majles (parliament). Following a coup d'état instigated by the U.K. and the U.S. in 1953, Iran gradually became close allies with the United States and the rest of the West, remained secular, but grew increasingly autocratic. Growing dissent against foreign influence and political repression culminated in the 1979 Revolution, which led to the establishment of an Islamic republic on 1 April 1979.

This led to a significant conversion of Iranians from their indigenous faiths, such as Manichaeism and Zoroastrianism, to Sunni Islam. Arabic became the official language, though Persian persisted as the language of the people and literature. Iran played a crucial role in the Islamic Golden Age, contributing many influential scientists, scholars, artists, and thinkers. Widespread dissatisfaction with foreign influence and political repression fueled the 1979 Revolution, resulting in the establishment of an Islamic republic on April 1, 1979.

Under their rule, a decisive shift from Sunni to Twelver Shia Islam took place, solidifying Shia Islam as the state's religion—a monumental change for both Iran and the broader Muslim world. This period of turmoil fueled the 1906 Persian Constitutional Revolution, culminating in the formation of a constitutional monarchy and Iran's inaugural parliament, known as the Majles. Back in 633 AD, the Rashidun Arabs made their move into Iran, and by 651 AD, they had taken control of the region. This invasion set off a profound shift, with many Iranians leaving behind their traditional faiths like Manichaeism and Zoroastrianism and embracing Sunni Islam. Although Arabic was imposed as the official language, Persian remained vibrant among the people and flourished in literature. Iran's contribution to the Islamic Golden Age was immense, giving the world a wealth of scientists, scholars, and artists.

Fast forward a few centuries to 1501, the rise of the Safavid Dynasty dramatically altered Iran's religious landscape. Under their rule, a decisive shift from Sunni to Twelver Shia Islam took place, solidifying Shia Islam as the state's religion—a monumental change for both Iran and the broader Muslim world. In 1736, under Nader Shah's leadership, Iran expanded its territory to rival the Sassanid Empire, becoming momentarily one of the globe’s mightiest forces.

Come the 19th century, Iran faced significant territorial losses in the Caucasus, a part of its identity for ages, ceded to Imperial Russia. This period of turmoil fueled the 1906 Persian Constitutional Revolution, culminating in the formation of a constitutional monarchy and Iran's inaugural parliament, known as the Majles. However, 1953 saw a dramatic turn of events with a coup d'état, backed secretly by the U.K. and the U.S., steering Iran into a tight alliance with the West. This shift maintained a secular, if increasingly authoritarian, regime.

The growing displeasure over external influence and domestic repression boiled over into the 1979 Revolution. This uprising swept away the old order, leading to the declaration of an Islamic republic on April 1, 1979. This transformation highlighted the deep-seated demand for autonomy and religious governance within the country.

text_human: By far the largest military action in which the United States engaged during this era was the War of 1812. With Britain locked in a major war with Napoleon's France, its policy was to block American shipments to France. The United States sought to remain neutral while pursuing overseas trade. Britain cut the trade and impressed seamen on American ships into the Royal Navy, despite intense protests. Britain supported an Indian insurrection in the American Midwest, with the goal of creating an Indian state there that would block American expansion. The United States finally declared war on the United Kingdom in 1812, the first time the U.S. had officially declared war. Not hopeful of defeating the Royal Navy, the U.S. attacked the British Empire by invading British Canada, hoping to use captured territory as a bargaining chip. The invasion of Canada was a debacle, though concurrent wars with Native Americans on the western front (Tecumseh's War and the Creek War) were more successful. After defeating Napoleon in 1814, Britain sent large veteran armies to invade New York, raid Washington and capture the key control of the Mississippi River at New Orleans. The New York invasion was a fiasco after the much larger British army retreated to Canada. The raiders succeeded in the burning of Washington on 25 August 1814, but were repulsed in their Chesapeake Bay Campaign at the Battle of Baltimore and the British commander killed. The major invasion in Louisiana was stopped by a one-sided military battle that killed the top three British generals and thousands of soldiers. The winners were the commanding general of the Battle of New Orleans, Major General Andrew Jackson, who became president and the Americans who basked in a victory over a much more powerful nation. The peace treaty proved successful, and the U.S. and Britain never again went to war. The losers were the Indians, who never gained the independent territory in the Midwest promised by Britain.
text_ai_base: The largest military engagement involving the United States during this period was the War of 1812. Britain, deeply embroiled in a war against Napoleon's France, aimed to block American trade with France, while the U.S. tried to remain neutral and continue its overseas commerce. Despite strong protests, Britain impeded this trade and forcibly conscripted American sailors into the Royal Navy. Additionally, Britain supported an Indian uprising in the American Midwest, intending to establish an Indian state that would hinder U.S. expansion. Finally, in 1812, the United States declared war on the United Kingdom for the first time, though not expecting to best the Royal Navy. Instead, the U.S. invaded British Canada, hoping to leverage captured territory for negotiation. This invasion was disastrous, although simultaneous conflicts with Native Americans in the west, such as Tecumseh's War and the Creek War, saw more success. Following Napoleon's defeat in 1814, Britain dispatched large veteran forces to invade New York, raid Washington, and seize control of the Mississippi River at New Orleans. The New York campaign ended in failure as the sizable British army retreated to Canada. The British raid successfully burned Washington on August 25, 1814, but they were repelled in the Chesapeake Bay Campaign at the Battle of Baltimore, where their commander was killed. In Louisiana, a decisive battle at New Orleans dealt a crushing blow to Britain, resulting in the deaths of their top three generals and thousands of soldiers. This victory was a defining moment for Major General Andrew Jackson, who later became president, and for Americans celebrated for triumphing over a formidable foe. The peace treaty was effective, and the U.S. and Britain never again went to war. However, the Indians suffered as they did not receive the independent territory in the Midwest promised by Britain.
text_ai_humanized: During the early 19th century, the United States found itself embroiled in its largest military conflict of the era: the War of 1812. At the time, Britain was deeply involved in skirmishes against Napoleon's France, leading it to implement measures to thwart American trade with the French. The U.S. desired neutrality, yearning to continue its overseas commerce unabated, but Britain—a bit stubborn, perhaps—wasn't having it. They not only obstructed this trade but also took the controversial step of forcibly conscripting American sailors into the Royal Navy. If that weren't enough, British efforts to stir an Indian uprising in the American Midwest aimed to establish a state that would put a damper on America’s relentless expansion. Things came to a head in 1812 when the United States, perhaps with more bravado than expectation, declared war on Britain, hoping against hope to stand up to the mighty Royal Navy. With some ambition, the U.S. invaded British Canada to seize territory as a bargaining chip, a strategy that fell flat on its face. However, the concurrent clashes with Native American tribes like the conflicts with Tecumseh and the Creek War showed brighter prospects for the U.S. Meanwhile, with Napoleon's defeat in 1814, Britain sent seasoned veterans to launch a broader offensive, hitting New York, raiding Washington, and trying to seize the strategic Mississippi River at New Orleans. The New York campaign, though packed with potential, fizzled out as British forces withdrew to Canada. Their aggressive raid did result in the torching of Washington on August 25, 1814. Yet, at the Battle of Baltimore, the Chesapeake Bay Campaign ended with the British commander losing his life, and their advance being halted. The showdown in Louisiana at New Orleans was a thunderous moment, dealing Britain a severe defeat, and there Major General Andrew Jackson carved his name into American lore, paving his path to the presidency someday. This American victory, with thousands of British losses including the deaths of key generals, was a celebrated triumph over one of the world's superpowers. After all the dust settled, the peace treaty effectively ensured calm waters as the U.S. and Britain never squared off in war again. Unfortunately, Native Americans found themselves betrayed, as Britain’s promised independent Midwest territory vanished like smoke.

text_human: The university culture developed differently in northern Europe than it did in the south, although the northern (primarily Germany, France and Great Britain) and southern universities (primarily Italy) did have many elements in common. Latin was the language of the university, used for all texts, lectures, disputations and examinations. Professors lectured on the books of Aristotle for logic, natural philosophy, and metaphysics; while Hippocrates, Galen, and Avicenna were used for medicine. Outside of these commonalities, great differences separated north and south, primarily in subject matter. Italian universities focused on law and medicine, while the northern universities focused on the arts and theology. There were distinct differences in the quality of instruction in these areas which were congruent with their focus, so scholars would travel north or south based on their interests and means. There was also a difference in the types of degrees awarded at these universities. English, French and German universities usually awarded bachelor's degrees, with the exception of degrees in theology, for which the doctorate was more common. Italian universities awarded primarily doctorates. The distinction can be attributed to the intent of the degree holder after graduation – in the north the focus tended to be on acquiring teaching positions, while in the south students often went on to professional positions. The structure of northern universities tended to be modeled after the system of faculty governance developed at the University of Paris. Southern universities tended to be patterned after the student-controlled model begun at the University of Bologna. Among the southern universities, a further distinction has been noted between those of northern Italy, which followed the pattern of Bologna as a "self-regulating, independent corporation of scholars" and those of southern Italy and Iberia, which were "founded by royal and imperial charter to serve the needs of government."
text_ai_base: The university culture in northern Europe evolved differently from that in the south, despite sharing many elements, such as the use of Latin for texts, lectures, debates, and exams. Northern universities, primarily in Germany, France, and Great Britain, focused on the arts and theology, while southern universities, notably in Italy, emphasized law and medicine. Instruction quality reflected these focuses, prompting scholars to travel based on their interests and resources. Northern universities often awarded bachelor's degrees, especially outside theology, where doctorates were more common. In contrast, Italian universities primarily conferred doctorates, reflecting career intentions: teaching in the north and professional roles in the south. The governance structures also differed; northern universities followed the faculty-governed model of the University of Paris, whereas southern universities adopted the student-controlled model of the University of Bologna. Additionally, a distinction existed among southern institutions: northern Italian universities, like Bologna, operated as independent scholar corporations, while those in southern Italy and Iberia were established by royal or imperial charters to meet government needs.
text_ai_humanized: While universities across northern Europe and the south shared common foundations, such as the use of Latin for texts, lectures, debates, and exams, they evolved in strikingly different ways. In northern Europe—spanning Germany, France, and Great Britain—academics gravitated towards the arts and theology. In contrast, southern universities, particularly those in Italy, leaned heavily into the study of law and medicine. This regional specialization significantly influenced the quality of instruction, often prompting scholars to trek across borders in pursuit of their academic interests or within the constraints of their financial resources. Bachelor's degrees were frequently awarded in northern universities, except in theology where doctorates predominated. Meanwhile, Italian institutions were more inclined to bestow doctorates, reflecting a different career trajectory: northern graduates aimed for teaching, while those from the south pursued professional careers. As for governance, northern universities tended to emulate the faculty-led model of the University of Paris. Southern institutions, however, were inspired by the student-led approach of the University of Bologna. One could even spot a further division among the southern universities. Those in northern Italy, such as Bologna, functioned as independent scholar corporations. Meanwhile, universities in southern Italy and the Iberian Peninsula were often founded through royal or imperial charters, serving the needs of governmental administrations. This nuanced landscape reveals how geographical, political, and cultural factors intricately wove into the tapestry of medieval higher education—a complex but fascinating evolution.

message.content:

As for governance, northern universities tended to emulate the faculty-led model of the University of Paris. text_human: Vladimir had been prince of Novgorod when his father Sviatoslav I died in 972. He was forced to flee to Scandinavia in 976 after his half-brother Yaropolk had murdered his other brother Oleg and taken control of Rus. In Scandinavia, with the help of his relative Earl Håkon Sigurdsson, ruler of Norway, Vladimir assembled a Viking army and reconquered Novgorod and Kiev from Yaropolk. As Prince of Kiev, Vladimir's most notable achievement was the Christianization of Kievan Rus', a process that began in 988. The Primary Chronicle states that when Vladimir had decided to accept a new faith instead of the traditional idol-worship (paganism) of the Slavs, he sent out some of his most valued advisors and warriors as emissaries to different parts of Europe. They visited the Christians of the Latin Rite, the Jews, and the Muslims before finally arriving in Constantinople. They rejected Islam because, among other things, it prohibited the consumption of alcohol, and Judaism because the god of the Jews had permitted his chosen people to be deprived of their country. They found the ceremonies in the Roman church to be dull. But at Constantinople, they were so astounded by the beauty of the cathedral of Hagia Sophia and the liturgical service held there that they made up their minds there and then about the faith they would like to follow. Upon their arrival home, they convinced Vladimir that the faith of the Byzantine Rite was the best choice of all, upon which Vladimir made a journey to Constantinople and arranged to marry Princess Anna, the sister of Byzantine emperor Basil II.
