Both bands tasted success but disbanded in 2007 and 2008, respectively. Guns N' Roses finally released their long-awaited album *Chinese Democracy* in 2008, but it only achieved platinum status, not matching their earlier success. In contrast, AC/DC's album *Black Ice* (2008) went double platinum. Bon Jovi smoothly transitioned into country music with "Who Says You Can't Go Home," reaching number one on the Hot Country Singles chart in 2006. Their rock/country album *Lost Highway* hit number one in 2007. They returned to their hard rock roots with another number one album, *The Circle*, in 2009.
text_ai_humanized: In the realm of hard rock, a few bands that first roared onto the scene in the '70s and '80s kept their momentum rolling right into the 21st century. Bon Jovi, for instance, scored big with their hit "It's My Life," from the album *Crush* in 2000, which bagged a double platinum status. Meanwhile, that same year, AC/DC rocked the charts with *Stiff Upper Lip*, which also grabbed a platinum certification. Aerosmith took a slightly different path in 2001 with *Just Push Play*, pushing towards a pop sound and reaching number two on the charts, thanks to the Top 10 hit "Jaded." They didn't stop there—three years later, they released *Honkin' on Bobo*, a blues cover album that climbed to number five. Then there's Heart, who achieved the noteworthy feat in 2010 with *Red Velvet Car*, marking their first Top 10 album since the early '90s and establishing them as the only female-led hard rock band to have Top 10 albums in five different decades. Many legendary groups also caught the reunion fever. Van Halen hit the road again twice, first with Sammy Hagar in 2004, and later with David Lee Roth in 2007. The Who, after a pause following John Entwistle’s death in 2002, resumed touring by 2006. Likewise, Black Sabbath reunited with Ozzy Osbourne from 1997 until 2006, later teaming up with Ronnie James Dio from 2006 to 2010. Even Led Zeppelin stirred up nostalgia with their one-off performance in 2007, which sent fans on a trip down memory lane. The early 2000s didn't just see old bands reviving; it was also a time for fresh formations. Supergroups like Audioslave, born of ex-members from Rage Against the Machine and Soundgarden, and Velvet Revolver, which included former Guns N' Roses players, Duff McKagan from Wasted Youth, and Stone Temple Pilots’ Scott Weiland, emerged. Both bands enjoyed their time in the spotlight until splitting up in 2007 and 2008, respectively. Guns N' Roses fans finally got their hands on the long-teased *Chinese Democracy* in 2008, although it only reached platinum status, falling short of their previous heights. In contrast, AC/DC's *Black Ice*, released that same year, achieved double platinum. Bon Jovi, ever adaptable, made a striking transition into country music with "Who Says You Can't Go Home," a track that topped the Hot Country Singles chart in 2006, and then went all the way to number one with their rock/country album *Lost Highway* in 2007. Not to be pigeonholed, they swung back to hard rock with *The Circle*, which also snagged a number one ranking in 2009.

text_human: Under the Capetian dynasty France slowly began to expand its authority over the nobility, growing out of the Île-de-France to exert control over more of the country in the 11th and 12th centuries. They faced a powerful rival in the Dukes of Normandy, who in 1066 under William the Conqueror (duke 1035–1087), conquered England (r. 1066–87) and created a cross-channel empire that lasted, in various forms, throughout the rest of the Middle Ages. Normans also settled in Sicily and southern Italy, when Robert Guiscard (d. 1085) landed there in 1059 and established a duchy that later became the Kingdom of Sicily. Under the Angevin dynasty of Henry II (r. 1154–89) and his son Richard I (r. 1189–99), the kings of England ruled over England and large areas of France,[W] brought to the family by Henry II's marriage to Eleanor of Aquitaine (d. 1204), heiress to much of southern France.[X] Richard's younger brother John (r. 1199–1216) lost Normandy and the rest of the northern French possessions in 1204 to the French King Philip II Augustus (r. 1180–1223). This led to dissension among the English nobility, while John's financial exactions to pay for his unsuccessful attempts to regain Normandy led in 1215 to Magna Carta, a charter that confirmed the rights and privileges of free men in England. Under Henry III (r. 1216–72), John's son, further concessions were made to the nobility, and royal power was diminished. The French monarchy continued to make gains against the nobility during the late 12th and 13th centuries, bringing more territories within the kingdom under their personal rule and centralising the royal administration. Under Louis IX (r. 1226–70), royal prestige rose to new heights as Louis served as a mediator for most of Europe.[Y]
text_ai_base: During the Capetian dynasty, France gradually expanded its authority over the nobility, extending control from the Île-de-France to more regions of the country in the 11th and 12th centuries. The Dukes of Normandy posed a significant challenge, especially after William the Conqueror (duke from 1035 to 1087) invaded England in 1066, establishing a cross-channel empire that persisted in various forms throughout the medieval period. Normans also settled in Sicily and southern Italy after Robert Guiscard (died 1085) arrived in 1059 and set up a duchy that eventually evolved into the Kingdom of Sicily. Under the Angevin dynasty led by Henry II (reigned 1154–89) and his son Richard I (reigned 1189–99), the English kings governed England and large portions of France, a domain expanded by Henry II's marriage to Eleanor of Aquitaine (died 1204), who was the heiress to much of southern France. In 1204, Richard's younger brother John (reigned 1199–1216) lost Normandy and other northern French regions to French King Philip II Augustus (reigned 1180–1223), sparking unrest among English nobility. John's financial demands, aimed at recapturing Normandy, contributed to the Magna Carta in 1215, a charter affirming the rights of free men in England. Under John's son, Henry III (reigned 1216–72), additional concessions reduced royal power further. Meanwhile, the French monarchy continued to strengthen during the late 12th and 13th centuries, bringing more areas under their direct rule and centralizing administrative control. Under Louis IX (reigned 1226–70), royal prestige reached new heights as he acted as a mediator for much of Europe.
text_ai_humanized: Throughout the Capetian dynasty, France slowly asserted itself over its nobility, spreading influence from the Île-de-France outward during the 11th and 12th centuries. But, it wasn’t all smooth sailing—those Dukes of Normandy sure kept them on their toes! Things got especially tangled after William the Conqueror, who ruled as duke from 1035 to 1087, daringly stepped into the fray by invading England in 1066. Talk about shaking things up! His audacity established a kind of realm that stretched across the English Channel in various iterations throughout the medieval era. Meanwhile, way down in Sicily and southern Italy, Normans made their mark too! Robert Guiscard floated over in 1059, and despite his passing in 1085, his legacy lived on, eventually blossoming into the Kingdom of Sicily. The narrative doesn't end there—weave in the Angevin dynasty, spearheaded by Henry II from 1154 to 1189, followed by his son Richard I, reigning from 1189 to 1199. These English monarchs had quite the empire, overseeing territories in England and substantial swaths of France. And the plot thickened further when Henry II tied the knot with Eleanor of Aquitaine, who passed away in 1204—her inheritance encompassed much of southern France, further enlarging their domain. Then we have a misstep; in 1204, Richard's brother, King John, who ruled from 1199 to 1216, misplaced Normandy and several northern French territories to none other than French King Philip II Augustus—his reign spanned from 1180 to 1223. This blunder ruffled feathers among English nobles no end. John's bid to seize Normandy back came with hefty financial demands, sparking unrest and eventually leading to the Magna Carta in 1215, a landmark document affirming the rights of English freemen. As for John’s successor, Henry III, leading until 1272, he found himself granting further concessions, inching toward greater limitations on royal power. On the flip side, French royalty was busy solidifying its grip—strengthening its sway in the late 12th and 13th centuries. King Louis IX, reigning from 1226 to 1270, took royal prestige up several notches. His knack for conflict resolution saw him becoming Europe’s go-to mediator, boosting his standing across borders.

text_human: The men's basketball team has over 1,600 wins, one of only 12 schools who have reached that mark, and have appeared in 28 NCAA tournaments. Former player Austin Carr holds the record for most points scored in a single game of the tournament with 61. Although the team has never won the NCAA Tournament, they were named by the Helms Athletic Foundation as national champions twice. The team has orchestrated a number of upsets of number one ranked teams, the most notable of which was ending UCLA's record 88-game winning streak in 1974. The team has beaten an additional eight number-one teams, and those nine wins rank second, to UCLA's 10, all-time in wins against the top team. The team plays in newly renovated Purcell Pavilion (within the Edmund P. Joyce Center), which reopened for the beginning of the 2009–2010 season. The team is coached by Mike Brey, who, as of the 2014–15 season, his fifteenth at Notre Dame, has achieved a 332-165 record. In 2009 they were invited to the NIT, where they advanced to the semifinals but were beaten by Penn State who went on and beat Baylor in the championship. The 2010–11 team concluded its regular season ranked number seven in the country, with a record of 25–5, Brey's fifth straight 20-win season, and a second-place finish in the Big East. During the 2014-15 season, the team went 32-6 and won the ACC conference tournament, later advancing to the Elite 8, where the Fighting Irish lost on a missed buzzer-beater against then undefeated Kentucky. Led by NBA draft picks Jerian Grant and Pat Connaughton, the Fighting Irish beat the eventual national champion Duke Blue Devils twice during the season. The 32 wins were the most by the Fighting Irish team since 1908-09.

text_human: Though Britain and the empire emerged victorious from the Second World War, the effects of the conflict were profound, both at home and abroad. Much of Europe, a continent that had dominated the world for several centuries, was in ruins, and host to the armies of the United States and the Soviet Union, who now held the balance of global power. Britain was left essentially bankrupt, with insolvency only averted in 1946 after the negotiation of a $US 4.33 billion loan (US$56 billion in 2012) from the United States, the last instalment of which was repaid in 2006. At the same time, anti-colonial movements were on the rise in the colonies of European nations. The situation was complicated further by the increasing Cold War rivalry of the United States and the Soviet Union. In principle, both nations were opposed to European colonialism. In practice, however, American anti-communism prevailed over anti-imperialism, and therefore the United States supported the continued existence of the British Empire to keep Communist expansion in check. The "wind of change" ultimately meant that the British Empire's days were numbered, and on the whole, Britain adopted a policy of peaceful disengagement from its colonies once stable, non-Communist governments were available to transfer power to. This was in contrast to other European powers such as France and Portugal, which waged costly and ultimately unsuccessful wars to keep their empires intact. Between 1945 and 1965, the number of people under British rule outside the UK itself fell from 700 million to five million, three million of whom were in Hong Kong.
text_ai_base: While Britain and its empire emerged victorious from World War II, the aftermath of the conflict had significant impacts both domestically and internationally. Much of Europe, which had dominated the globe for centuries, lay in ruins and was occupied by the armies of the United States and the Soviet Union—new holders of global power. Britain itself faced bankruptcy, narrowly avoiding it in 1946 when the United States agreed to a $4.33 billion loan (equivalent to $56 billion in 2012), with the final repayment made in 2006. Meanwhile, anti-colonial movements gained traction in European colonies, complicated further by the Cold War rivalry between the U.S. and the Soviet Union. Although both superpowers were nominally against colonialism, American anti-communism overshadowed anti-imperialism, leading the U.S. to support the British Empire's continuation to counter Communist growth. Ultimately, the "wind of change" signaled the British Empire's decline, and Britain generally opted for peaceful withdrawal from its colonies once stable, non-Communist governments were established to take over. This approach contrasted with European countries like France and Portugal, which fought costly and ultimately futile wars to maintain their empires. Between 1945 and 1965, those under British rule outside the UK decreased from 700 million to five million, with three million in Hong Kong.
text_ai_humanized: While Britain celebrated victory in World War II, the world around it had drastically changed, leaving significant imprints domestically and across the globe. In echoes of history, Europe—once the titan spread across continents—now lay shattered, its remnants occupied by the newfound powerhouses: the United States and the Soviet Union. These two juggernauts emerged as architects of a new world order. Britain itself teetered dangerously on the brink of financial ruin post-war, narrowly sidestepped thanks to a substantial loan from the U.S., a lifeline stretching to $4.33 billion at the time (which would translate to about $56 billion if you adjust for inflation to 2012). The loan only saw its final repayment in the distant year of 2006. As the dust settled, anti-colonial fervor began to stir within Europe's vast colonies. This upheaval was further tangled in the geopolitical chess game between the U.S. and the Soviet Union—each vying for influence against the backdrop of the Cold War. Despite professed anti-colonial stances, American foreign policy leaned towards backing the British Empire's endurance as a strategic bulwark against communism—a pragmatic choice that arguably put anti-imperialism on the back burner in the face of an expanding Communist threat. The "wind of change," as it was famously dubbed, heralded the twilight of the British Empire. With a cautious eye on stability, Britain generally chose the path of peaceful disengagement from its territories, handing over control once dependable, non-Communist governments stood ready to inherit governance. This peace-oriented transition starkly contrasted with the stubborn resistance seen in nations like France and Portugal, which resisted the tide through costly conflicts that ultimately surrendered to the inevitable. In a mere two decades, from 1945 to 1965, the population under British dominion outside the UK shrank dramatically—from an astounding 700 million down to just five million. Three million of those still counted found themselves in Hong Kong, an emblem of lingering influence amidst considerable contraction.

text_human: The two major types of nonprofit organization are membership and board-only. A membership organization elects the board and has regular meetings and the power to amend the bylaws. A board-only organization typically has a self-selected board, and a membership whose powers are limited to those delegated to it by the board. A board-only organization's bylaws may even state that the organization does not have any membership, although the organization's literature may refer to its donors or service recipients as "members"; examples of such organizations are Fairvote and the National Organization for the Reform of Marijuana Laws. The Model Nonprofit Corporation Act imposes many complexities and requirements on membership decision-making. Accordingly, many organizations, such as Wikimedia, have formed board-only structures. The National Association of Parliamentarians has generated concerns about the implications of this trend for the future of openness, accountability, and understanding of public concerns in nonprofit organizations. Specifically, they note that nonprofit organizations, unlike business corporations, are not subject to market discipline for products and shareholder discipline of their capital; therefore, without membership control of major decisions such as election of the board, there are few inherent safeguards against abuse. A rebuttal to this might be that as nonprofit organizations grow and seek larger donations, the degree of scrutiny increases, including expectations of audited financial statements. A further rebuttal might be that NPOs are constrained, by their choice of legal structure, from financial benefit as far as distribution of profit to its members/directors is concerned. Beware of board-only organizations- review the board members annual income before donating, such as the Clinton Foundation. Board members who decide what percentage of your donations will increase their personal wealth are rampant in abusing this designation of an NPO, and this is why they attempt to avoid audits and use a double bottom line for taxing.
text_ai_base: Nonprofit organizations generally fall into two categories: membership and board-only organizations. In membership organizations, the board is elected by the members, who also hold regular meetings and have the authority to amend the bylaws. In contrast, board-only organizations typically have a self-selected board with members whose powers are limited to what is delegated by the board itself. Some board-only organizations, like Fairvote and the National Organization for the Reform of Marijuana Laws, might state in their bylaws that they do not have a formal membership, even though they may refer to donors or service recipients as "members" in their materials. Due to the complexities and requirements imposed by the Model Nonprofit Corporation Act regarding membership decision-making, many organizations, such as Wikimedia, have opted for a board-only structure. The National Association of Parliamentarians has raised concerns about the potential impact of this trend on the future transparency, accountability, and responsiveness of nonprofit organizations. Unlike business corporations, nonprofits are not governed by market discipline or shareholder oversight, thus without member involvement in critical decisions like board elections, there are few safeguards against misuse. A counterargument suggests that as nonprofits grow and seek larger donations, they face increased scrutiny, including expectations for audited financial statements. Additionally, nonprofits are legally restricted from distributing profits to members or directors, which serves as another check against financial abuse. However, it’s essential to be cautious with board-only organizations; for instance, before donating to organizations like the Clinton Foundation, review the annual income of the board members. Abuse can occur when board members direct donations to increase their personal wealth, and this can lead them to avoid audits and exploit loopholes for tax benefits.
text_ai_humanized: Nonprofit organizations can be broadly classified into two types: membership-oriented and board-only entities. Membership organizations elect their board through member votes, with members actively participating in regular meetings and possessing the authority to alter bylaws. Board-only organizations, on the other hand, typically feature a self-appointing board, restricting member powers to those expressly granted by the board itself. Interestingly, certain board-only organizations, such as Fairvote and the National Organization for the Reform of Marijuana Laws, explicitly mention in their bylaws the absence of formal memberships. However, they might still loosely label their donors or those who receive their services as "members" in various promotional materials. A significant reason many organizations, including Wikimedia, lean toward a board-only framework is to sidestep the intricate requirements for member decision-making laid down by the Model Nonprofit Corporation Act. This trend, however, hasn't gone unnoticed; the National Association of Parliamentarians has expressed considerable concern about its implications for transparency, accountability, and responsiveness within the nonprofit sector. Unlike commercial corporations governed by market forces or shareholder oversight, nonprofits lack those mechanisms to keep the operations in line. Without active member involvement in key decisions like board elections, the risk of governance misuse increases. On the flip side, some argue that as nonprofits expand and pursue larger contributions, they inevitably face heightened scrutiny, potentially including pressure for financial audits. Added to this, legal prohibitions prevent nonprofits from distributing profits to their members or directors, which provides a further check on financial malpractice. Yet, caution remains paramount when dealing with board-only organizations. For example, before contributing to entities like the Clinton Foundation, it's wise to critically evaluate the annual earnings of their board members. Issues arise when board members channel donations for personal enrichment, avoiding audits and manipulating tax loopholes, a situation we certainly want to avoid.

text_human: Marshall Field & Company originated in 1852. It was the premier department store on the main shopping street in the Midwest, State Street in Chicago. Upscale shoppers came by train from throughout the region, patronizing nearby hotels. It grew to become a major chain before converting to the Macy's nameplate on 9 September 2006. Marshall Field's Served as a model for other departments stores in that it had exceptional customer service. Field's also brought with it the now famous Frango mints brand that became so closely identified with Marshall Field's and Chicago from the now defunct Frederick & Nelson Department store. Marshall Field's also had the firsts, among many innovations by Marshall Field's. Field's had the first European buying office, which was located in Manchester, England, and the first bridal registry. The company was the first to introduce the concept of the personal shopper, and that service was provided without charge in every Field's store, until the chain's last days under the Marshall Field's name. It was the first store to offer revolving credit and the first department store to use escalators. Marshall Field's book department in the State Street store was legendary; it pioneered the concept of the "book signing." Moreover, every year at Christmas, Marshall Field's downtown store windows were filled with animated displays as part of the downtown shopping district display; the "theme" window displays became famous for their ingenuity and beauty, and visiting the Marshall Field's windows at Christmas became a tradition for Chicagoans and visitors alike, as popular a local practice as visiting the Walnut Room with its equally famous Christmas tree or meeting "under the clock" on State Street.

The iconic Frango mints, originally from the now-defunct Frederick & Nelson department store, became synonymous with Marshall Field's and Chicago. Throughout its history, Marshall Field’s achieved numerous firsts in retail innovation. It opened the first European buying office in Manchester, England, and pioneered the concept of the bridal registry. Field's introduced personal shoppers, a complimentary service available at every store until the chain's final days under its original name. Marshall Field's also led the way by being the first to offer revolving credit and the first to use escalators in department stores. Its book department in the State Street location was legendary, introducing the "book signing" concept. Every Christmas, the store's downtown windows featured animated displays, gaining fame for their creativity and beauty. Visiting these window displays became a cherished holiday tradition for Chicagoans and tourists, as popular as dining by the Walnut Room's famous Christmas tree or meeting "under the clock" on State Street.

text_human: In 2013, however, a study of Ashkenazi mitochondrial DNA by a team led by Martin B. Richards of the University of Huddersfield in England reached different conclusions, again corroborating the pre-2006 origin hypothesis. Testing was performed on the full 16,600 DNA units composing mitochondrial DNA (the 2006 Behar study had only tested 1,000 units) in all their subjects, and the study found that the four main female Ashkenazi founders had descent lines that were established in Europe 10,000 to 20,000 years in the past while most of the remaining minor founders also have a deep European ancestry. The study states that the great majority of Ashkenazi maternal lineages were not brought from the Near East (i.e., they were non-Israelite), nor were they recruited in the Caucasus (i.e., they were non-Khazar), but instead they were assimilated within Europe, primarily of Italian and Old French origins. Richards summarized the findings on the female line as such: "[N]one [of the mtDNA] came from the North Caucasus, located along the border between Europe and Asia between the Black and Caspian seas. All of our presently available studies including my own, should thoroughly debunk one of the most questionable, but still tenacious, hypotheses: that most Ashkenazi Jews can trace their roots to the mysterious Khazar Kingdom that flourished during the ninth century in the region between the Byzantine Empire and the Persian Empire." The 2013 study estimated that 80 percent of Ashkenazi maternal ancestry comes from women indigenous to Europe, and only 8 percent from the Near East, while the origin of the remainder is undetermined. According to the study these findings "point to a significant role for the conversion of women in the formation of Ashkenazi communities."
text_ai_base: In 2013, a study led by Martin B. Richards from the University of Huddersfield in England investigated Ashkenazi mitochondrial DNA and reached conclusions supporting the pre-2006 origin hypothesis. The research analyzed the complete 16,600 DNA units of mitochondrial DNA—unlike the 2006 Behar study, which examined only 1,000 units. It revealed that the four primary female Ashkenazi founders had ancestral lines established in Europe 10,000 to 20,000 years ago. Most of the other minor founders also shared a deep European heritage. The study suggested that the vast majority of Ashkenazi maternal lineages did not originate from the Near East (meaning they were non-Israelite) or the Caucasus (meaning they were non-Khazar). Instead, they were assimilated within Europe, mainly from Italian and Old French backgrounds. Richards summarized the findings, noting that none of the mtDNA was sourced from the North Caucasus, a region between Europe and Asia. He stated that these studies, including his own, should dispel the persistent but doubtful theory that most Ashkenazi Jews trace their roots to the Khazar Kingdom, which existed in the ninth century between the Byzantine and Persian Empires. The 2013 study estimated that 80 percent of Ashkenazi maternal lineage is from European women, only 8 percent from the Near East, and the remainder is unknown. These findings suggest a significant role for the conversion of women in forming Ashkenazi communities.
text_ai_humanized: Back in 2013, Martin B. Richards from the University of Huddersfield in England spearheaded a groundbreaking study on Ashkenazi mitochondrial DNA. Unlike the Behar study of 2006, which only scratched the surface by examining 1,000 DNA units, Richards ventured deeper, analyzing the entire suite of 16,600 DNA units. The revelations were quite striking, indicating that the main ancestral lines of the four foundational Ashkenazi women were rooted firmly in Europe, stretching back as far as 10,000 to 20,000 years. The smaller founders didn't stray far from this pattern either, showing similarly entrenched European heritage. So, what does this all mean? In essence, the research paints a picture of Ashkenazi maternal lineage that diverges from some traditional narratives. Most of these lineages didn't hail from the Near East (Israelite regions) or the Caucasus (Khazar territories). Instead, the DNA threads lead back to European absorption, particularly from regions like Italy and what we consider Old France. Richards didn't hold back when summarizing the study, pinpointing that no Ashkenazi mtDNA could be traced to the North Caucasus—a region straddling Europe and Asia. He was pretty clear that these studies, including his, should put to rest the stubborn but questionable theory that the majority of Ashkenazi Jews have roots in the Khazar Kingdom of the ninth century, nestled between the Byzantine and Persian Empires. The 2013 study's numbers were telling: a whopping 80% of Ashkenazi maternal lineage stems from European women while only about 8% is linked to the Near East, leaving the rest shrouded in mystery. It seems likely then that the conversion of women played a significant part in shaping these Ashkenazi communities—a poignant reminder of how complex history can be.

text_human: By the early 18th century, the Maratha Kingdom had transformed itself into the Maratha Empire under the rule of the Peshwas (prime ministers). In 1737, the Marathas defeated a Mughal army in their capital, Delhi itself in Battle of Delhi (1737). The Marathas continued their military campaigns against Mughals, Nizam, Nawab of Bengal and Durrani Empire to further extend their boundaries. Gordon explained how the Maratha systematically took control over new regions. They would start with annual raids, followed by collecting ransom from villages and towns while the declining Mughal Empire retained nominal control and finally taking over the region. He explained it with the example of Malwa region. Marathas built an efficient system of public administration known for its attention to detail. It succeeded in raising revenue in districts that recovered from years of raids, up to levels previously enjoyed by the Mughals. For example, the cornerstone of the Maratha rule in Malwa rested on the 60 or so local tax collectors who advanced the Maratha ruler Peshwa a portion of their district revenues at interest. By 1760, the domain of the Marathas stretched across practically the entire subcontinent. The north-western expansion of the Marathas was stopped after the Third Battle of Panipat (1761). However, the Maratha authority in the north was re-established within a decade under Peshwa Madhavrao I. The defeat of Marathas by British in third Anglo-Maratha Wars brought end to the empire by 1820. The last peshwa, Baji Rao II, was defeated by the British in the Third Anglo-Maratha War. With the defeat of the Marathas, no native power represented any significant threat for the British afterwards.
text_ai_base: By the early 18th century, the Maratha Kingdom had evolved into the Maratha Empire under the leadership of the Peshwas, or prime ministers. In 1737, the Marathas achieved a significant victory by defeating a Mughal army in Delhi during the Battle of Delhi. Their military campaigns continued against the Mughals, the Nizam, the Nawab of Bengal, and the Durrani Empire, further expanding their territory. Historian Gordon described how the Marathas systematically seized control of new regions. Initially, they conducted annual raids, followed by demanding ransoms from villages and towns, while the weakening Mughal Empire maintained nominal control—all culminating in the eventual takeover of these areas. Gordon illustrated this with the example of the Malwa region. The Marathas developed a highly efficient system of public administration, noted for its meticulous attention to detail, and successfully increased revenue in districts that recovered from years of raids to levels comparable to those under Mughal rule. Notably, the foundation of their control in Malwa relied on approximately 60 local tax collectors who paid a portion of their district revenues as a loan to the Maratha ruler, the Peshwa. By 1760, the Maratha domain spanned almost the entire subcontinent. However, their northwestern expansion was halted after their defeat in the Third Battle of Panipat in 1761. Nonetheless, Maratha authority in northern India was restored within a decade under Peshwa Madhavrao I. The empire's decline was marked by its defeat in the Third Anglo-Maratha War by the British, culminating in 1820. The last Peshwa, Baji Rao II, was overthrown by the British, after which no native power posed a significant threat to British dominance in the region.
text_ai_humanized: In the early 18th century, the Maratha Kingdom transformed into the Maratha Empire, guided by the shrewd leadership of the Peshwas, occupying roles akin to prime ministers. A landmark moment came in 1737 when the Marathas clinched a pivotal victory by vanquishing a Mughal force at Delhi's Battle. Emboldened by this success, they pressed on with extensive military campaigns against regional powers like the Mughals, the Nizam, the Nawab of Bengal, and the Durrani Empire, aggressively broadening their territorial claims. Delving into their conquest strategy, historian Gordon detailed how the Marathas snatched up new regions through calculated measures. Their method was anything but straightforward—beginning with relentless annual raids, followed by opportunistic ransom demands from terrified villages and towns. During this period, the Mughal Empire retained only nominal control, barely a shadow of its former strength, leading to an eventual Maratha takeover. Gordon highlighted the capture of Malwa, illustrating these tactics with vivid examples. The Marathas established a superbly efficient administrative system, noted for its meticulous attention to bureaucratic minutiae. It's impressive how they managed to ramp up revenue collection—so much so that districts recovering from the tumultuous raids rivaled the fiscal standing they enjoyed during Mughal times. A fascinating aspect of their control mechanism relied on roughly 60 local tax collectors in Malwa; these officials would fork over a portion of their district’s revenue as a loan to the Maratha leader, the Peshwa. By 1760, the Maratha Empire had unfurled its dominion across nearly the entire Indian subcontinent. However, they struck a bump in the road with the Third Battle of Panipat in 1761, stalling their western advance. But don't count them out yet—the Marathas reclaimed their grip over northern India within a decade under the helm of Peshwa Madhavrao I. Yet, it all came crashing down with the Third Anglo-Maratha War, leading to their submission to British forces by 1820. In a decisive blow, the last Peshwa, Baji Rao II, fell to the British, extinguishing the Marathas' flicker of resistance. After this defeat, no native power in India could meaningfully challenge British supremacy in the region, marking a pivotal turning point in the subcontinent's history.

text_human: Kurita passed through San Bernardino Strait at 03:00 on 25 October and headed along the coast of Samar. The only thing standing in his path were three groups (Taffy 1, 2 and 3) of the Seventh Fleet, commanded by Admiral Thomas Kinkaid. Each group had six escort carriers, with a total of more than 500 planes, and seven or eight destroyers or destroyer escorts (DE). Kinkaid still believed that Lee's force was guarding the north, so the Japanese had the element of surprise when they attacked Taffy 3 at 06:45. Kurita mistook the Taffy carriers for large fleet carriers and thought he had the whole Third Fleet in his sights. Since escort carriers stood little chance against a battleship, Adm. Clifton Sprague directed the carriers of Taffy 3 to turn and flee eastward, hoping that bad visibility would reduce the accuracy of Japanese gunfire, and used his destroyers to divert the Japanese battleships. The destroyers made harassing torpedo attacks against the Japanese. For ten minutes Yamato was caught up in evasive action. Two U.S. destroyers and a DE were sunk, but they had bought enough time for the Taffy groups to launch planes. Taffy 3 turned and fled south, with shells scoring hits on some of its carriers and sinking one of them. The superior speed of the Japanese force allowed it to draw closer and fire on the other two Taffy groups. However, at 09:20 Kurita suddenly turned and retreated north. Signals had disabused him of the notion that he was attacking the Third Fleet, and the longer Kurita continued to engage, the greater the risk of major air strikes. Destroyer attacks had broken the Japanese formations, shattering tactical control. Three of Kurita's heavy cruisers had been sunk and another was too damaged to continue the fight. The Japanese retreated through the San Bernardino Strait, under continuous air attack. The Battle of Leyte Gulf was over; and a large part of the Japanese surface fleet destroyed.
text_ai_base: Kurita moved through the San Bernardino Strait at 03:00 on October 25 and advanced along the coast of Samar. Standing in his way were three groups—Taffy 1, 2, and 3—of the Seventh Fleet, led by Admiral Thomas Kinkaid. Each group consisted of six escort carriers, totaling over 500 aircraft, alongside seven or eight destroyers or destroyer escorts. Kinkaid assumed that Lee’s force was protecting the northern area, which allowed the Japanese to attack Taffy 3 by surprise at 06:45. Kurita mistakenly identified the Taffy carriers as large fleet carriers and believed he was confronting the entire Third Fleet. Aware that escort carriers were vulnerable against battleships, Admiral Clifton Sprague ordered Taffy 3's carriers to flee eastward, hoping poor visibility would hinder Japanese gunners, while deploying destroyers to distract the enemy battleships. The destroyers launched aggressive torpedo attacks on the Japanese, causing the Yamato to execute evasive maneuvers for ten minutes. Although two U.S. destroyers and a destroyer escort were sunk, they achieved enough disruption to allow the Taffy groups to launch their planes. Taffy 3 retreated south, enduring hits on some of its carriers and losing one. The quicker Japanese forces gained ground, attacking the other Taffy groups, but at 09:20, Kurita unexpectedly withdrew northward. He realized he wasn't facing the Third Fleet and prolonged engagement risked significant air strikes. Destroyer assaults had scattered the Japanese formations, hampering their tactical control. Three of Kurita’s heavy cruisers were sunk, and another was too damaged to keep fighting. The Japanese retreated through San Bernardino Strait under continuous aerial assault. The Battle of Leyte Gulf concluded with a significant portion of the Japanese surface fleet destroyed.
text_ai_humanized: In the early, predawn darkness of October 25, Kurita's fleet navigated through the San Bernardino Strait, edging closer to the coast of Samar. Anticipating little resistance, he advanced, yet standing in his path were three divisions of the Seventh Fleet—Taffy 1, 2, and 3—under the command of Admiral Thomas Kinkaid. Each division boasted six escort carriers, collectively fielding over 500 aircraft, and was accompanied by seven to eight destroyers or destroyer escorts. Kinkaid had assumed Admiral Lee's contingent was safeguarding the northern flank, thus leaving an opening. Taking advantage, the Japanese launched a surprise attack on Taffy 3 at 06:45. In a crucial error, Kurita perceived Taffy's carriers as full-fledged fleet carriers, leading him to believe they opposed the entire Third Fleet. With escort carriers notoriously ill-suited to battle battleships, Admiral Clifton Sprague made a swift decision. He ordered Taffy 3's carriers to head east, banking on poor visibility to stymie Japanese marksmen, whilst organizing a bold counter-move. The destroyers, akin to agile terriers among wolves, lunged forward with torpedo salvos, forcing the massive Yamato into wild evasive maneuvers lasting ten tense minutes. Despite the grim loss of two American destroyers and a destroyer escort, the assault sowed just enough chaos to give Taffy groups leeway to launch their aircraft. As Taffy 3 retreated to the south, it endured substantial damage, including losing a carrier, yet determination prevailed. The Japanese, fierce and swift, soon closed the gap, attacking the remaining Taffy groups. However, at 09:20, in an unexpected twist, Kurita ordered a retreat to the north. Realization dawned—it was not the Third Fleet confronting him, and a continued clash would invite destructive air strikes. The tenacious American destroyers had fractured the Japanese lines, further complicating their command structure. This disruption led to the sinking of three of Kurita's heavy cruisers; one more was left incapably damaged. Eventually, battered and beleaguered, the Japanese managed a parallel retreat through San Bernardino Strait, but not without sustaining relentless aerial assaults. Thus, the Battle of Leyte Gulf drew to a dramatic close with a significant part of the Japanese surface fleet in ruins—a stark demonstration of both strategic blunders and audacious bravery.

text_human: The islands are at relatively low altitudes, with central Ireland and southern Great Britain particularly low lying: the lowest point in the islands is Holme, Cambridgeshire at −2.75 m (−9.02 ft). The Scottish Highlands in the northern part of Great Britain are mountainous, with Ben Nevis being the highest point on the islands at 1,343 m (4,406 ft). Other mountainous areas include Wales and parts of Ireland, however only seven peaks in these areas reach above 1,000 m (3,281 ft). Lakes on the islands are generally not large, although Lough Neagh in Northern Ireland is an exception, covering 150 square miles (390 km2).[citation needed] The largest freshwater body in Great Britain (by area) is Loch Lomond at 27.5 square miles (71 km2), and Loch Ness, by volume whilst Loch Morar is the deepest freshwater body in the British Isles, with a maximum depth of 310 m (1,017 ft). There are a number of major rivers within the British Isles. The longest is the Shannon in Ireland at 224 mi (360 km).[citation needed] The river Severn at 220 mi (354 km)[citation needed] is the longest in Great Britain. The isles have a temperate marine climate. The North Atlantic Drift ("Gulf Stream") which flows from the Gulf of Mexico brings with it significant moisture and raises temperatures 11 °C (20 °F) above the global average for the islands' latitudes. Winters are cool and wet, with summers mild and also wet. Most Atlantic depressions pass to the north of the islands, combined with the general westerly circulation and interactions with the landmass, this imposes an east-west variation in climate.
text_ai_base: The islands have relatively low altitudes, with central Ireland and southern Great Britain being particularly flat. The lowest point is in Holme, Cambridgeshire, at −2.75 meters (−9.02 feet). In contrast, the Scottish Highlands in northern Great Britain are mountainous, with Ben Nevis as the highest peak at 1,343 meters (4,406 feet). Other mountainous regions include Wales and parts of Ireland, though only seven peaks exceed 1,000 meters (3,281 feet) there. Lakes on these islands are generally small, except for Lough Neagh in Northern Ireland, which covers 150 square miles (390 km²). The largest freshwater body in Great Britain by area is Loch Lomond, spanning 27.5 square miles (71 km²), while Loch Ness has the largest volume, and Loch Morar is the deepest, reaching 310 meters (1,017 feet). Major rivers include the Shannon in Ireland, the longest at 224 miles (360 km), and the River Severn in Great Britain at 220 miles (354 km). The isles enjoy a temperate marine climate, influenced by the North Atlantic Drift, also known as the Gulf Stream. This current from the Gulf of Mexico brings significant moisture and raises temperatures by 11 °C (20 °F) above the global average for these latitudes. Winters are cool and wet, while summers are mild and also wet. Most Atlantic depressions pass north of the islands, and with the general westerly winds and land interactions, this creates an east-west climate variation.
text_ai_humanized: Nestled in the northwest corner of Europe, these islands boast landscapes that reveal an intriguing topographical contrast. Central Ireland and southern England stand out for their notably low elevations, characterized by a flatness that extends over vast expanses. The nadir of British terrain lies at Holme in Cambridgeshire, dipping to a mere -2.75 meters, or -9.02 feet below sea level. Yet, journey northward, and the terrain strikingly shifts with the Scottish Highlands rising into view. Here, the majestic Ben Nevis claims the title of highest peak, towering at 1,343 meters (4,406 feet)—a striking contrast to the flatlands. Wales and parts of Ireland join the Highlands in their ruggedness, though only seven peaks across these regions breach the 1,000-meter (3,281-foot) mark. While the islands’ lakes don't typically stretch vast, exceptions like the sprawling Lough Neagh in Northern Ireland break the mold, spreading over 150 square miles (390 km²). On the British mainland, Loch Lomond wins the prize for surface area, covering 27.5 square miles (71 km²), whereas Loch Ness is celebrated for its sheer volume. Meanwhile, Loch Morar plunges to depths of 310 meters (1,017 feet), earning it the title of deepest. Rivers weave across the landscape, carrying history and lifeblood to the towns they pass. Ireland's River Shannon flows tirelessly for 224 miles (360 km), rivalling Britain's River Severn, which runs a slightly shorter course of 220 miles (354 km). The North Atlantic Drift, also known—and perhaps better recognized—as the Gulf Stream, is the hidden conductor of a temperate marine climate across these islands. Its warm waters elevate temperatures by about 11°C (20°F) beyond what you'd expect at these latitudes, lending a mild touch to both the cool, wet winters and the comparably damp summers. The constant dance between Atlantic depressions and prevailing westerly winds crafts a fascinating east-west divide in weather patterns. Luckily—or not, depending on your love for rain—the bulk of these storms swing north of the isles, sparing locals from their full wrath.

text_human: The average annual rainfall ranges from very low in the northern and southern fringes of the desert to nearly non-existent over the central and the eastern part. The thin northern fringe of the desert receives more winter cloudiness and rainfall due to the arrival of low pressure systems over the Mediterranean Sea along the polar front, although very attenuated by the rain shadow effects of the mountains and the annual average rainfall ranges from 100 mm (3,93 in) to 250 mm (9,84 in). For example, Biskra, Algeria and Ouarzazate, Morocco are found in this zone. The southern fringe of the desert along the border with the Sahel receives summer cloudiness and rainfall due to the arrival of the Intertropical Convergence Zone from the south and the annual average rainfall ranges from 100 mm (3,93 in) to 250 mm (9,84 in). For example, Timbuktu, Mali and Agadez, Niger are found in this zone. The vast central hyper-arid core of the desert is virtually never affected by northerly or southerly atmospheric disturbances and permanently remains under the influence of the strongest anticyclonic weather regime and the annual average rainfall can drop to less than 1 mm (0.04 in). In fact, most of the Sahara receives less than 20 mm (0.79 in). Of the 9,000,000 km2 of desert land in the Sahara, an area of about 2,800,000 km2 (about 31% of the total area) receives an annual average rainfall amount of 10 mm (0.39 in) or less, while some 1,500,000 km2 (about 17% of the total area) receive an average of 5 mm or less. The annual average rainfall is virtually zero over a wide area of some 1,000,000 km2 in the eastern Sahara comprising deserts of Libya, Egypt and Sudan (Tazirbu, Kufra, Dakhla, Kharga, Farafra, Siwa, Asyut, Sohag, Luxor, Aswan, Abu Simbel, Wadi Halfa) where the long-term mean approximates 0.5 mm per year. The rainfall is very unreliable and erratic in the Sahara as it may vary considerably year by year. In full contrast to the negligible annual rainfall amounts, the annual rates of potential evaporation are extraordinarily high, roughly ranging from 2,500 mm/year to more than 6,000 mm/year in the whole desert. Nowhere else on Earth has air been found as dry and evaporative as in the Sahara region. With such an evaporative power, the Sahara can only be desiccated and dried out further more and the moisture deficit is tremendous.
text_ai_base: The average annual rainfall in the Sahara varies significantly, being very low on the desert's northern and southern edges and nearly nonexistent in its central and eastern regions. The northern fringe experiences more winter cloudiness and rainfall due to low-pressure systems over the Mediterranean Sea along the polar front. Despite the rain shadow effects from surrounding mountains, this area receives between 100 mm (3.93 in) and 250 mm (9.84 in) annually, with cities like Biskra, Algeria, and Ouarzazate, Morocco situated here. The southern edge, near the Sahel, receives summer rainfall from the Intertropical Convergence Zone, with similar annual averages ranging from 100 mm to 250 mm. Cities like Timbuktu, Mali, and Agadez, Niger fall within this zone. In stark contrast, the central hyper-arid core of the desert remains unaffected by atmospheric disturbances from the north or south, staying under a persistent anticyclonic weather regime with less than 1 mm (0.04 in) of rainfall annually. Most of the Sahara receives under 20 mm (0.79 in) yearly. Out of the desert's 9,000,000 km², roughly 2,800,000 km² (31% of the total area) receive 10 mm (0.39 in) or less, and about 1,500,000 km² (17%) receive 5 mm or less. The eastern Sahara, encompassing parts of Libya, Egypt, and Sudan (including areas such as Tazirbu, Kufra, Dakhla, Kharga, Farafra, Siwa, Asyut, Sohag, Luxor, Aswan, Abu Simbel, and Wadi Halfa), sees virtually no rainfall with long-term averages around 0.5 mm annually. Rainfall in the Sahara is extremely unpredictable and can vary widely from year to year. In contrast to the minimal rainfall, the annual potential evaporation rates are extraordinarily high, ranging from 2,500 mm to over 6,000 mm. Nowhere else on Earth is the air as dry and evaporative as in the Sahara, leading to further desiccation and a substantial moisture deficit.
text_ai_humanized: Across the vast expanse of the Sahara Desert, rainfall patterns are anything but uniform, fluctuating dramatically based on local geography. In the desert's marginal northern and southern reaches, rain intermittently graces the land, yet the central and eastern stretches continue to thirst without relief. Up north, the edge of the arid zone witnesses winter clouds and rains brought on by low-pressure systems over the Mediterranean Sea and the polar front battling the rain shadow of neighboring mountains. This region, where cities like Biskra in Algeria and Ouarzazate in Morocco are situated, manages to collect between 100 mm (3.93 in) and 250 mm (9.84 in) of annual rainfall. Venturing south, the fringes close to the Sahel offer a different tale, with summer rains thanks to the Intertropical Convergence Zone. These areas match the northern rainfall averages, drawing cities such as Timbuktu in Mali and Agadez in Niger into this slightly wetter band. But if we're honest, the Sahara is not known for its hospitality to rain. The core—a hyper-arid barren stretch—stands unyielding under an anticyclonic battle against rain, letting less than 1 mm (0.04 in) trickle down each year. To put it in perspective, the vast majority of the Sahara routinely sees under 20 mm (0.79 in) of rainfall annually. Out of the Sahara’s colossal 9 million km², around 2.8 million km² (31%) barely receive 10 mm (0.39 in), and another 1.5 million km² (17%) get a paltry 5 mm or less—a bit like trying to water an entire garden with a thimble. Eastern Sahara, including stretches of Libya, Egypt, and Sudan in places like Tazirbu, Kufra, and Kharga, is almost entirely forsaken by rain, with long-term averages hovering at a meager 0.5 mm per year. What makes this even more striking is the shocking contrast with the sky-high evaporation rates—somewhere between 2,500 mm and a mind-bending 6,000 mm annually. It's no wonder the Sahara beats all records for its arid atmosphere; you won't find air dryer anywhere else, and the land’s insatiable thirst only worsens the moisture deficit. Predictability? That's not the Sahara's forte. Its rainfall and evaporation patterns keep you guessing from year to year, like a capricious script in Earth’s climatic theater.

message.content:
Across the vast expanse of the Sahara Desert, rainfall patterns are anything but uniform, fluctuating dramatically based on local geography. In the desert's marginal northern and southern reaches, rain intermittently graces the land, yet the central and eastern stretches continue to thirst without relief. Up north, the edge of the arid zone witnesses winter clouds and rains brought on by low-pressure systems over the Mediterranean Sea and the polar front battling the rain shadow of neighboring mountains. This region, where cities like Biskra in Algeria and Ouarzazate in Morocco are situated, manages to collect between 100 mm (3.93 in) and 250 mm (9.84 in) of annual rainfall.

Venturing south, the fringes close to the Sahel offer a different tale, with summer rains thanks to the Intertropical Convergence Zone. These areas match the northern rainfall averages, drawing cities such as Timbuktu in Mali and Agadez in Niger into this slightly wetter band. But if we're honest, the Sahara is not known for its hospitality to rain. The core—a hyper-arid barren stretch—stands unyielding under an anticyclonic battle against rain, letting less than 1 mm (0.04 in) trickle down each year.

To put it in perspective, the vast majority of the Sahara routinely sees under 20 mm (0.79 in) of rainfall annually. Out of the Sahara’s colossal 9 million km², around 2.8 million km² (31%) barely receive 10 mm (0.39 in), and another 1.5 million km² (17%) get a paltry 5 mm or less—a bit like trying to water an entire garden with a thimble. Eastern Sahara, including stretches of Libya, Egypt, and Sudan in places like Tazirbu, Kufra, and Kharga, is almost entirely forsaken by rain, with long-term averages hovering at a meager 0.5 mm per year.

What makes this even more striking is the shocking contrast with the sky-high evaporation rates—somewhere between 2,500 mm and a mind-bending 6,000 mm annually. It's no wonder the Sahara beats all records for its arid atmosphere; you won't find air dryer anywhere else, and the land’s insatiable thirst only worsens the moisture deficit. Predictability? That's not the Sahara's forte. Its rainfall and evaporation patterns keep you guessing from year to year, like a capricious script in Earth’s climatic theater.

text_human: After Cassander's death in 298 BCE, however, Demetrius, who still maintained a sizable loyal army and fleet, invaded Macedon, seized the Macedonian throne (294) and conquered Thessaly and most of central Greece (293-291). He was defeated in 288 BC when Lysimachus of Thrace and Pyrrhus of Epirus invaded Macedon on two fronts, and quickly carved up the kingdom for themselves. Demetrius fled to central Greece with his mercenaries and began to build support there and in the northern Peloponnese. He once again laid siege to Athens after they turned on him, but then struck a treaty with the Athenians and Ptolemy, which allowed him to cross over to Asia minor and wage war on Lysimachus' holdings in Ionia, leaving his son Antigonus Gonatas in Greece. After initial successes, he was forced to surrender to Seleucus in 285 and later died in captivity. Lysimachus, who had seized Macedon and Thessaly for himself, was forced into war when Seleucus invaded his territories in Asia minor and was defeated and killed in 281 BCE at the Battle of Corupedium, near Sardis. Seleucus then attempted to conquer Lysimachus' European territories in Thrace and Macedon, but he was assassinated by Ptolemy Ceraunus ("the thunderbolt"), who had taken refuge at the Seleucid court and then had himself acclaimed as king of Macedon. Ptolemy was killed when Macedon was invaded by Gauls in 279, his head stuck on a spear and the country fell into anarchy. Antigonus II Gonatas invaded Thrace in the summer of 277 and defeated a large force of 18,000 Gauls. He was quickly hailed as king of Macedon and went on to rule for 35 years.
text_ai_base: Following Cassander's death in 298 BCE, Demetrius, backed by a strong army and fleet, invaded Macedon. He claimed the Macedonian throne in 294 BCE and proceeded to conquer Thessaly and most of central Greece between 293 and 291 BCE. However, in 288 BCE, Lysimachus of Thrace and Pyrrhus of Epirus attacked Macedon from two fronts, swiftly dividing the kingdom. Demetrius escaped to central Greece with his mercenaries, seeking support there and in the northern Peloponnese. Having initially laid siege to Athens after they opposed him, he negotiated a treaty with the Athenians and Ptolemy, which enabled him to move to Asia Minor and challenge Lysimachus’ control in Ionia, leaving his son Antigonus Gonatas to manage affairs in Greece. Despite some early victories, Demetrius was captured by Seleucus in 285 BCE and died in captivity. Lysimachus, who had taken control of Macedon and Thessaly, was drawn into conflict with Seleucus after his territories in Asia Minor were invaded. He was defeated and killed in 281 BCE at the Battle of Corupedium, near Sardis. Seleucus then sought to conquer Lysimachus' European lands in Thrace and Macedon but was assassinated by Ptolemy Ceraunus ("the thunderbolt"), who had found asylum at the Seleucid court and declared himself king of Macedon. Ptolemy was slain during a Gaul invasion in 279 BCE, leading to chaos as his head was mounted on a spear. In response, Antigonus II Gonatas advanced into Thrace in the summer of 277 BCE, vanquishing a formidable force of 18,000 Gauls. He was promptly proclaimed king of Macedon and held the throne for 35 years.
text_ai_humanized: When Cassander passed away in 298 BCE, Demetrius didn't waste time. With a formidable army and a powerful fleet by his side, he made his move on Macedon, successfully securing the throne by 294 BCE. Over the next couple of years, from 293 to 291 BCE, he expanded his realm, seizing control of Thessaly and much of central Greece. However, his reign met turbulence in 288 BCE. Lysimachus of Thrace and Pyrrhus of Epirus launched a coordinated assault on Macedon, effectively slicing the kingdom into two parts and forcing Demetrius to retreat to central Greece. Cleverly, he sought alliances there and in the northern Peloponnese, aiming to rebuild his strength. In a dramatic turn, after initially besieging Athens due to their resistance, Demetrius brokered a deal. By negotiating with the Athenians and Ptolemy, he managed to shift his focus towards Asia Minor, confronting Lysimachus' influence in Ionia. He appointed his son, Antigonus Gonatas, to oversee the situation back home in Greece. Sadly, though, fortune didn't favor him forever. In 285 BCE, Seleucus captured Demetrius, and he ultimately died in captivity before he could turn the tides fully in his favor. Following these events, Lysimachus, having seized control over Macedon and Thessaly, faced his own troubles. His territories in Asia Minor came under threat from Seleucus, and in the confrontation that ensued, Lysimachus met his end during the Battle of Corupedium in 281 BCE near Sardis. With Lysimachus gone, Seleucus eyed his European territories, aiming to incorporate Thrace and Macedon into his domain. Yet, before he could accomplish this, he fell victim to assassination at the hands of Ptolemy Ceraunus—aptly nicknamed "the thunderbolt"—who had taken refuge in the Seleucid court only to declare himself king of Macedon thereafter. Ptolemy's reign, however, was short-lived. In 279 BCE, he met a grisly fate at the hands of invading Gauls, his head gruesomely displayed on a spear. The chaos that followed was met by Antigonus II Gonatas, who marched into Thrace during the summer of 277 BCE to confront the looming threat. His victory over an intimidating force of 18,000 Gauls cemented his claim to the throne of Macedon, a seat he would hold with authority for the next 35 years.

text_human: Constantius, ordered Liberius into exile in 356 giving him, then, three days to comply. He was ordered into banishment to Beroea, in Thrace; Beroea (Thrace). He sent expensive presents, too, if he were to accept the Arian position but were refused. He sent him, indeed, five hundred pieces of gold "to bear his charges" but Liberius refused them, saying, he might bestow them on his flatters; as he did also a like present from the empress, bidding the messenger learn to believe in Christ, and not to persecute the Church of God. Attempts were made to leave the presents in The Church, but Liberius threw them out. Constantius hereupon sent for him under a strict guard to Milan, where, in a conference recorded by Theodoret, he boldly told Constantius that Athanasius had been acquitted at Sardica, and his enemies proved calumniators (see: "calumny") and impostors, and that it was unjust to condemn a person who could not be legally convicted of any crime. The emperor was reduced to silence on every article, but being the more out of patience, ordered him into banishment. Liberius went into exile. Constantius, after two years went to Rome to celebrate the twentieth year of his reign. The ladies joined in a petition to him that he would restore Liberius. He assented, upon condition that he should comply with the bishops, then, at court. He subscribed the condemnation of Athanasius, and a confession or creed which had been framed by the Arians at Sirmium. And he no sooner had recovered his see that he declared himself for the Creed of Niceae, as Theodoret testifies. (Theodoret, Hist. lib. ii. c. 17.). The Emperor knew what he wanted people to believe. So did the bishops at his court. Athanasius stuck by the orthodox creed. Constantius was an avowed Arian, became sole ruler in 350, at the death of his brother, Constans.
text_ai_base: In 356, Constantius ordered Liberius into exile, giving him just three days to comply. Liberius was banished to Beroea in Thrace. Constantius attempted to persuade him to accept the Arian position with expensive gifts, including five hundred pieces of gold "to cover his expenses," but Liberius refused, suggesting they be given to flatterers instead. He similarly rejected a gift from the empress, advising the messenger to follow Christ and not to persecute the Church of God. Attempts were made to leave the gifts in the Church, but Liberius threw them out. As a result, Constantius had him brought to Milan under strict guard. In a conference documented by Theodoret, Liberius boldly informed Constantius that Athanasius had been acquitted in Sardica, and that his accusers were proven false. He argued it was unjust to condemn someone not legally convicted of a crime. Constantius, unable to refute him, ordered his banishment again. Liberius went into exile. Two years later, Constantius visited Rome to celebrate the twentieth year of his reign. The women of Rome petitioned him to restore Liberius, and Constantius consented on the condition that Liberius comply with the bishops present at court. Liberius subscribed to the condemnation of Athanasius and accepted a creed composed by the Arians at Sirmium. Upon regaining his position, he reaffirmed the Nicene Creed, as noted by Theodoret (Hist. lib. ii. c. 17). Both the Emperor and the court bishops were clear on their beliefs, while Athanasius remained steadfast to the orthodox creed. Constantius, an avowed Arian, had become the sole ruler in 350 after his brother Constans's death.
text_ai_humanized: The year was 356, and Emperor Constantius issued a swift decree that left Liberius with a mere three days to pack his things and disappear into exile. Beroea in Thrace became his destination, a consequence of his staunch refusal to embrace the Arian cause. Despite efforts to win him over with lavish gifts—among them, a purse stuffed with five hundred pieces of gold supposedly meant to "cover his expenses"—Liberius remained unmoved. He curtly suggested these offerings would better serve the sycophants surrounding the emperor. Even when approached by the empress's envoy, he stood firm, urging the messenger to follow Christ's teachings rather than persecute the Church. Tries to sneak the unwanted gold into the Church were foiled by Liberius himself, who decisively discarded them. Constantius, undeterred, ordered Liberius to be transported under heavy guard to Milan. There, a crucial meeting unfolded, detailed by Theodoret. Liberius confronted Constantius, asserting the innocence of Athanasius, previously vindicated at Sardica, while exposing his detractors as liars. He rightly pointed out the gross unfairness of condemning a man who had not been found guilty according to the law. Presented with these arguments, Constantius found himself at a loss, responding with little more than reinstating Liberius's exile. Fast forward two years, and Constantius made his way to Rome, eager to mark the two-decade milestone of his rule. A remarkable plea arrived from the women of Rome, imploring him to restore Liberius. Constantius agreed but attached conditions: Liberius had to align with the bishops in his court. Thus, Liberius relented, endorsing the condemnation of Athanasius and adopting the Sirmium Creed, fashioned by the Arians—in itself a significant compromise. Yet, upon reclaiming his role, Liberius quickly reaffirmed his allegiance to the original Nicene Creed, a move highlighted by Theodoret (Hist. lib. ii. c. 17). The Emperor and his bishops were resolute in their Arian convictions, juxtaposed against Athanasius, who defiantly clung to the orthodox belief. With the death of his brother Constans, Constantius had emerged as the sole ruler back in 350, firmly steering his kingdom toward Arianism.

Despite efforts to win him over with lavish gifts—among them, a purse stuffed with five hundred pieces of gold supposedly meant to "cover his expenses"—Liberius remained unmoved. He curtly suggested these offerings would better serve the sycophants surrounding the emperor. Even when approached by the empress's envoy, he stood firm, urging the messenger to follow Christ's teachings rather than persecute the Church. Tries to sneak the unwanted gold into the Church were foiled by Liberius himself, who decisively discarded them.

Constantius, undeterred, ordered Liberius to be transported under heavy guard to Milan. There, a crucial meeting unfolded, detailed by Theodoret. Liberius confronted Constantius, asserting the innocence of Athanasius, previously vindicated at Sardica, while exposing his detractors as liars. He rightly pointed out the gross unfairness of condemning a man who had not been found guilty according to the law. Presented with these arguments, Constantius found himself at a loss, responding with little more than reinstating Liberius's exile.

Fast forward two years, and Constantius made his way to Rome, eager to mark the two-decade milestone of his rule. A remarkable plea arrived from the women of Rome, imploring him to restore Liberius. Constantius agreed but attached conditions: Liberius had to align with the bishops in his court. Thus, Liberius relented, endorsing the condemnation of Athanasius and adopting the Sirmium Creed, fashioned by the Arians—in itself a significant compromise.

Yet, upon reclaiming his role, Liberius quickly reaffirmed his allegiance to the original Nicene Creed, a move highlighted by Theodoret (Hist. lib. ii. c. 17). The Emperor and his bishops were resolute in their Arian convictions, juxtaposed against Athanasius, who defiantly clung to the orthodox belief. With the death of his brother Constans, Constantius had emerged as the sole ruler back in 350, firmly steering his kingdom toward Arianism.

text_human: One hundred years after the fall of Constantinople in 1453, Pierre Belon described in his work Observations in 1553 that pissasphalto, a mixture of pitch and bitumen, was used in Dubrovnik for tarring of ships from where it was exported to a market place in Venice where it could be bought by anyone. An 1838 edition of Mechanics Magazine cites an early use of asphalt in France. A pamphlet dated 1621, by "a certain Monsieur d'Eyrinys, states that he had discovered the existence (of asphaltum) in large quantities in the vicinity of Neufchatel", and that he proposed to use it in a variety of ways – "principally in the construction of air-proof granaries, and in protecting, by means of the arches, the water-courses in the city of Paris from the intrusion of dirt and filth", which at that time made the water unusable. "He expatiates also on the excellence of this material for forming level and durable terraces" in palaces, "the notion of forming such terraces in the streets not one likely to cross the brain of a Parisian of that generation". But it was generally neglected in France until the revolution of 1830. Then, in the 1830s, there was a surge of interest, and asphalt became widely used "for pavements, flat roofs, and the lining of cisterns, and in England, some use of it had been made of it for similar purposes". Its rise in Europe was "a sudden phenomenon", after natural deposits were found "in France at Osbann (BasRhin), the Parc (l'Ain) and the Puy-de-la-Poix (Puy-de-Dome)", although it could also be made artificially. One of the earliest uses in France was the laying of about 24,000 square yards of Seyssel asphalt at the Place de la Concorde in 1835.
text_ai_base: A century after Constantinople fell in 1453, Pierre Belon documented in his 1553 work *Observations* the use of pissasphalto—a blend of pitch and bitumen—in Dubrovnik for ship tarring. This mixture was exported to Venice, where it was available for purchase. An 1838 edition of *Mechanics Magazine* notes that asphalt was used early on in France. A pamphlet from 1621 by Monsieur d'Eyrinys describes large asphalt deposits near Neufchatel, proposing its use for various applications—particularly in constructing airtight granaries and protecting Parisian watercourses from dirt and filth, which then contaminated the water supply. He also praised asphalt's suitability for creating level, durable palace terraces, though the idea of using it for street terraces wasn't considered by Parisians of that era. Despite its promise, asphalt was largely overlooked in France until the 1830 revolution, after which interest surged. By the 1830s, asphalt was widely adopted for pavements, flat roofs, and cistern linings; similar uses were noted in England. Europe's rapid embrace of asphalt followed discoveries of natural deposits in France at Osbann (Bas-Rhin), the Parc (l'Ain), and Puy-de-la-Poix (Puy-de-Dome), although it could also be synthesized. A notable early application in France was the laying of 24,000 square yards of Seyssel asphalt at the Place de la Concorde in 1835.
text_ai_humanized: Almost a hundred years after the fall of Constantinople, Pierre Belon captured a curious snapshot of maritime innovation in his 1553 treatise *Observations*. He noted that in Dubrovnik, artisans crafted a sticky concoction known as pissasphalto—a mix of pitch and bitumen—to coat ships. This gooey blend found its way to Venice, where merchants sold it to eager buyers. Fast forward to an 1838 edition of the *Mechanics Magazine*, where we find asphalt making its debut in France. Delving back to the early 17th century, Monsieur d'Eyrinys penned a pamphlet in 1621, boasting of substantial asphalt reserves near Neufchatel. He envisioned this versatile material transforming the world around him: airtight granaries, Parisian waterways shielded from dirt and debris—no more pesky contaminants sullying city water. And yet, for all its potential, d'Eyrinys' contemporary Parisians never warmed to asphalt's promise for street terraces, albeit he championed its role in crafting splendid, enduring palace floors. For many years, asphalt languished in obscurity in France until it caught the nation's imagination following the upheaval of the 1830 revolution. Suddenly, by the 1830s, asphalt became a staple: pavements, flat roofs, and cistern linings all benefited from its durable charm—a practice England mirrored with enthusiasm. It didn't hurt that Europe had stumbled upon significant asphalt deposits across France; noteworthy locations included Osbann (Bas-Rhin), Parc (l'Ain), and Puy-de-la-Poix (Puy-de-Dome), though the material could be made in laboratories too. One of its grand showcases occurred in 1835 when French workers laid a swath of Seyssel asphalt, covering 24,000 square yards at the Place de la Concorde—a testament to the material's enduring utility and appeal.
