This gooey blend found its way to Venice, where merchants sold it to eager buyers. Fast forward to an 1838 edition of the *Mechanics Magazine*, where we find asphalt making its debut in France.

Delving back to the early 17th century, Monsieur d'Eyrinys penned a pamphlet in 1621, boasting of substantial asphalt reserves near Neufchatel. He envisioned this versatile material transforming the world around him: airtight granaries, Parisian waterways shielded from dirt and debris—no more pesky contaminants sullying city water. And yet, for all its potential, d'Eyrinys' contemporary Parisians never warmed to asphalt's promise for street terraces, albeit he championed its role in crafting splendid, enduring palace floors.

For many years, asphalt languished in obscurity in France until it caught the nation's imagination following the upheaval of the 1830 revolution. Suddenly, by the 1830s, asphalt became a staple: pavements, flat roofs, and cistern linings all benefited from its durable charm—a practice England mirrored with enthusiasm. It didn't hurt that Europe had stumbled upon significant asphalt deposits across France; noteworthy locations included Osbann (Bas-Rhin), Parc (l'Ain), and Puy-de-la-Poix (Puy-de-Dome), though the material could be made in laboratories too. One of its grand showcases occurred in 1835 when French workers laid a swath of Seyssel asphalt, covering 24,000 square yards at the Place de la Concorde—a testament to the material's enduring utility and appeal.

text_human: As Western Europe witnessed the formation of new kingdoms, the Eastern Roman Empire remained intact and experienced an economic revival that lasted into the early 7th century. There were fewer invasions of the eastern section of the empire; most occurred in the Balkans. Peace with Persia, the traditional enemy of Rome, lasted throughout most of the 5th century. The Eastern Empire was marked by closer relations between the political state and Christian Church, with doctrinal matters assuming an importance in eastern politics that they did not have in Western Europe. Legal developments included the codification of Roman law; the first effort—the Theodosian Code—was completed in 438. Under Emperor Justinian (r. 527–565), another compilation took place—the Corpus Juris Civilis. Justinian also oversaw the construction of the Hagia Sophia in Constantinople and the reconquest of North Africa from the Vandals and Italy from the Ostrogoths, under Belisarius (d. 565). The conquest of Italy was not complete, as a deadly outbreak of plague in 542 led to the rest of Justinian's reign concentrating on defensive measures rather than further conquests. At the emperor's death, the Byzantines had control of most of Italy, North Africa, and a small foothold in southern Spain. Justinian's reconquests have been criticised by historians for overextending his realm and setting the stage for the Muslim conquests, but many of the difficulties faced by Justinian's successors were due not just to over-taxation to pay for his wars but to the essentially civilian nature of the empire, which made raising troops difficult.
text_ai_base: While new kingdoms emerged in Western Europe, the Eastern Roman Empire remained largely intact and saw an economic resurgence lasting into the early 7th century. The empire faced fewer invasions, with most occurring in the Balkans. Peace with Persia, Rome's traditional adversary, persisted through much of the 5th century. In the Eastern Empire, politics intertwined closely with the Christian Church, making doctrinal issues more prominent in eastern politics than in Western Europe. Significant legal advancements included the codification of Roman law; the Theodosian Code was completed in 438. Emperor Justinian (r. 527–565) undertook another major legal compilation—the Corpus Juris Civilis. Justinian spearheaded the construction of the Hagia Sophia in Constantinople and the reconquest of North Africa from the Vandals and Italy from the Ostrogoths, led by his general Belisarius (d. 565). However, Italy was not fully conquered, as a devastating plague outbreak in 542 shifted Justinian's focus to defense instead of further expansion. By the end of his reign, Byzantines controlled much of Italy, North Africa, and a small portion of southern Spain. Historians have criticized Justinian’s reconquests for overextending his realm and paving the way for Muslim conquests, yet the challenges faced by his successors stemmed not only from heavy taxation to fund his wars but also from the empire's civilian nature, which made troop recruitment difficult.
text_ai_humanized: As new kingdoms sprouted across Western Europe, the Eastern Roman Empire, more commonly known as Byzantium, stayed largely intact. This relative stability ushered in an era of economic growth lasting until the early 7th century. Unlike its western counterparts, the empire faced fewer invasions; those it did encounter were primarily situated in the Balkans. Meanwhile, the longstanding conflict with Persia took a back seat—much of the 5th century saw a rare peace between these traditional foes. Politics in the Byzantine realm had an intimate relationship with the Christian Church, where doctrinal matters stirred eastern political waters far more than they did in the west. On the legal front, noteworthy strides were made, such as the completion of the Theodosian Code in 438, which marked a significant codification of Roman law. Emperor Justinian, who reigned from 527 to 565, didn't stop there. Undertaking another major legal endeavor, he compiled the Corpus Juris Civilis, leaving a lasting legacy on European law. But Justinian's ambitions stretched beyond the legal world—he masterminded the construction of the grand Hagia Sophia in Constantinople and orchestrated the reconquest of North Africa from the Vandals and Italy from the Ostrogoths under the skilled command of General Belisarius, who passed away in 565. Although Italy wasn't entirely recaptured—largely owing to a devastating plague outbreak in 542 that redirected Justinian's efforts towards defense—the Byzantines managed to hold onto sizeable chunks of Italy, North Africa, and even a sliver of southern Spain by the close of his reign. Criticism of Justinian's expansive reconquests swirls among historians; they argue he stretched the empire too thin, unwittingly paving paths for later Muslim conquests. However, the Byzantine successors wrestled with more than just the shadow of Justinian's expansionism. The strains of heavy taxes that funded wars and the civilian nature of the empire impaired the recruitment of troops, proving to be thorny obstacles in their rule.

message.content:
As new kingdoms sprouted across Western Europe, the Eastern Roman Empire, more commonly known as Byzantium, stayed largely intact. This relative stability ushered in an era of economic growth lasting until the early 7th century. Unlike its western counterparts, the empire faced fewer invasions; those it did encounter were primarily situated in the Balkans. Meanwhile, the longstanding conflict with Persia took a back seat—much of the 5th century saw a rare peace between these traditional foes. Politics in the Byzantine realm had an intimate relationship with the Christian Church, where doctrinal matters stirred eastern political waters far more than they did in the west.

On the legal front, noteworthy strides were made, such as the completion of the Theodosian Code in 438, which marked a significant codification of Roman law. Emperor Justinian, who reigned from 527 to 565, didn't stop there. Undertaking another major legal endeavor, he compiled the Corpus Juris Civilis, leaving a lasting legacy on European law. But Justinian's ambitions stretched beyond the legal world—he masterminded the construction of the grand Hagia Sophia in Constantinople and orchestrated the reconquest of North Africa from the Vandals and Italy from the Ostrogoths under the skilled command of General Belisarius, who passed away in 565.

Although Italy wasn't entirely recaptured—largely owing to a devastating plague outbreak in 542 that redirected Justinian's efforts towards defense—the Byzantines managed to hold onto sizeable chunks of Italy, North Africa, and even a sliver of southern Spain by the close of his reign. Criticism of Justinian's expansive reconquests swirls among historians; they argue he stretched the empire too thin, unwittingly paving paths for later Muslim conquests. However, the Byzantine successors wrestled with more than just the shadow of Justinian's expansionism. The strains of heavy taxes that funded wars and the civilian nature of the empire impaired the recruitment of troops, proving to be thorny obstacles in their rule.

text_human: American comic books have adopted the character type for stories of their own like the mutant-villain Silver Samurai of Marvel Comics. The design of this character preserves the samurai appearance; the villain is “Clad in traditional gleaming samurai armor and wielding an energy charged katana” (Buxton, 2013). Not only does the Silver Samurai make over 350 comic book appearances, the character is playable in several video games, such as Marvel Vs. Capcom 1 and 2. In 2013, the samurai villain was depicted in James Mangold’s film The Wolverine. Ten years before the Wolverine debuted, another film helped pave the way to ensure the samurai were made known to American cinema: A film released in 2003 titled The Last Samurai, starring Tom Cruise, is inspired by the samurai way of life. In the film, Cruise’s character finds himself deeply immersed in samurai culture. The character in the film, “Nathan Algren, is a fictional contrivance to make nineteenth-century Japanese history less foreign to American viewers”.(Ravina, 2010) After being captured by a group of samurai rebels, he becomes empathetic towards the cause they fight for. Taking place during the Meiji Period, Tom Cruise plays the role of US Army Captain Nathan Algren, who travels to Japan to train a rookie army in fighting off samurai rebel groups. Becoming a product of his environment, Algren joins the samurai clan in an attempt to rescue a captured samurai leader. “By the end of the film, he has clearly taken on many of the samurai traits, such as zen-like mastery of the sword, and a budding understanding of spirituality”. (Manion, 2006)
text_ai_base: American comic books have introduced similar character types in their narratives, such as Marvel Comics' mutant-villain Silver Samurai. This character retains the traditional samurai appearance, described as "Clad in traditional gleaming samurai armor and wielding an energy charged katana" (Buxton, 2013). The Silver Samurai has featured in over 350 comic book appearances and is playable in video games like Marvel Vs. Capcom 1 and 2. In 2013, James Mangold’s film, *The Wolverine*, showcased this samurai villain. A decade earlier, another film helped bring the samurai culture to American cinema: *The Last Samurai*, released in 2003 and starring Tom Cruise, drew inspiration from the samurai way of life. In the movie, Cruise's character becomes deeply immersed in samurai culture. Nathan Algren, the character, is crafted to make nineteenth-century Japanese history more accessible to American audiences (Ravina, 2010). Captured by samurai rebels, Algren grows sympathetic to their cause. Set during the Meiji Period, Cruise portrays US Army Captain Nathan Algren, sent to Japan to train a novice army against samurai rebels. Immersed in his new environment, Algren joins the samurai to rescue a captured leader. "By the end of the film, he has clearly adopted many samurai traits, such as zen-like sword mastery and a budding understanding of spirituality" (Manion, 2006).
text_ai_humanized: American comic books have a knack for introducing characters shaped by rich cultural archetypes. Take Marvel's mutant-villain Silver Samurai, for example—a striking figure in traditional samurai attire, expertly wielding an energy-infused katana. This eye-catching character has become a staple in over 350 comic book episodes and has crossed over into the gaming world in titles like *Marvel Vs. Capcom* 1 and 2. His cinematic presence was felt when James Mangold featured him in the 2013 film *The Wolverine*, bringing an intriguing twist to the screen. On a similar note, a decade earlier, *The Last Samurai* hit theaters in 2003 and offered a profound exploration of samurai heritage. Starring Tom Cruise, the movie dives deep into this centuries-old way of life, casting American eyes on the samurai culture during Japan's Meiji Period. Cruise plays Nathan Algren, a U.S. Army Captain tasked with training a fledgling Japanese army, intended to combat samurai rebels. But what happens next is where the movie truly finds its soul. Captured by these rebels, Algren's perspective shifts—he begins to sympathize, even admire their cause. It's fascinating watching his transformation, isn't it? By the end, Algren embodies samurai virtues, showing zen-like mastery over the sword and engaging with the spiritual elements woven throughout their tradition. *The Last Samurai* makes 19th-century Japanese history accessible to American viewers, lending them a glimpse into another world while highlighting the universal themes of honor and perseverance. Whether Silver Samurai's exploits in comic lore or Cruise's immersion into the samurai ethos on screen, both narratives bridge cultural divides and ponder complex identities in the process.

text_human: The area now called Galicia was first inhabited by humans during the Middle Paleolithic period, and it takes its name from the Gallaeci, the Celtic peoples living north of the Douro river during the last millennium BC, in a region largely coincidental with that of the Iron Age local Castro culture. Galicia was incorporated into the Roman Empire at the end of the Cantabrian Wars in 19 BC, being turned into a Roman province in the 3rd century AD. In 410, the Germanic Suebi established a kingdom with its capital in Braga (Portugal) which was incorporated into that of the Visigoths in 585. In 711, the Arabs invaded the Iberian Peninsula, taking the Visigoth kingdom, but soon in 740 Galicia was incorporated into the Christian kingdom of Asturias. During the Middle Ages, the kingdom of Galicia was occasionally ruled by its own kings, but most of the time it was leagued to the kingdom of Leon and later to that of Castile, while maintaining its own legal and customary practices and personality. From the 13th century on, the kings of Castile, as kings of Galicia, appointed an Adiantado-mór, whose attributions passed to the Governor and Captain General of the Kingdom of Galiza from the last years of the 15th century. The Governor also presided the Real Audiencia do Reino de Galicia, a royal tribunal and government body. From the 16th century, the representation and voice of the kingdom was held by an assembly of deputies and representatives of the cities of the kingdom, the Cortes or Junta of the Kingdom of Galicia, an institution which was forcibly discontinued in 1833 when the kingdom was divided into four administrative provinces with no legal mutual links. During the 19th and 20th centuries, demand grew for self-government and for the recognition of the personality of Galicia, a demand which led to the frustrated Statute of Autonomy of 1936, and to the Statute of Autonomy of 1981, currently in force.
text_ai_base: Galicia, initially settled during the Middle Paleolithic era, derives its name from the Gallaeci, a Celtic tribe that resided north of the Douro River in the last millennium BC, an area reflecting the Iron Age Castro culture. At the end of the Cantabrian Wars in 19 BC, Galicia became part of the Roman Empire, and by the 3rd century AD, it was a Roman province. In 410, the Germanic Suebi established a kingdom with Braga, Portugal, as its capital, later absorbed by the Visigoths in 585. In 711, the Arabs conquered the Iberian Peninsula, including the Visigothic kingdom. However, by 740, Galicia was integrated into the Christian kingdom of Asturias. During the Middle Ages, while sometimes having its own rulers, Galicia was often linked to the kingdom of Leon and subsequently Castile, preserving its legal customs and unique identity. From the 13th century, the Castilian kings, as rulers of Galicia, appointed an Adiantado-mór. These duties eventually shifted to the Governor and Captain General of the Kingdom of Galicia in the late 15th century. The Governor led the Real Audiencia do Reino de Galicia, a royal tribunal and governing body. From the 16th century, Galicia's assembly of city representatives, known as the Cortes or Junta of the Kingdom of Galicia, voiced the kingdom's interests until it was dissolved in 1833 when Galicia was split into four administrative provinces without legal ties. In the 19th and 20th centuries, there was a growing movement for self-government and recognition of Galicia's distinct identity. This led to the proposed but unrealized Statute of Autonomy in 1936 and the current Statute of Autonomy enacted in 1981.
text_ai_humanized: Galicia's roots delve deep into history, reaching back to the Middle Paleolithic period. Its name proudly bears the legacy of the Gallaeci—a Celtic tribe who made their home north of the Douro River during the final stretch of the last millennium BC. This region vividly manifesting the Iron Age Castro culture was swept into the Roman fold in 19 BC, at the tail end of the Cantabrian Wars. By the 3rd century AD, Galicia had been sculpted into a Roman province, a testament to the empire's reach. Fast forward to 410, when the tides of power shifted dramatically as the Germanic Suebi carved out their own kingdom, planting their capital in Braga, Portugal. This kingdom, a short-lived beacon and later swallowed whole by the Visigoths in 585. But the story didn't end there. Another seismic shift occurred in 711 when Arab forces conquered the Iberian Peninsula, overtaking the Visigothic realms. Yet, by 740, Galicia found itself nestled under the Christian kingdom of Asturias—a defiant integration. The medieval era was a constantly evolving tapestry for Galicia. It sometimes stood on its own, ruling independently, but frequently connected with the kingdoms of Leon and later Castile, while safeguarding its own legal traditions and unique identity. From the 13th century onward, the kings of Castile stepped in as rulers of Galicia, assigning the role of Adiantado-mór. However, as times changed towards the late 15th century, these responsibilities were handed over to the Governor and Captain General of Galicia. There, the Governor helmed the Real Audiencia do Reino de Galicia—a royal tribunal doubling as a governing body. From the 16th century, the assembly known as the Cortes or Junta of the Kingdom of Galicia gathered representatives from its cities, delivering the voice of the realm until 1833 when Galicia's fate took another turn. It was split into four administrative provinces, stripped of legal connections. The 19th and 20th centuries saw calls for self-rule grow louder, championing Galicia's distinct identity. Though a Statute of Autonomy was proposed in 1936, it wasn't until 1981 that the current statute came into being, finally codifying Galicia's autonomy—a long journey with intermittent victories and setbacks.

Yet, by 740, Galicia found itself nestled under the Christian kingdom of Asturias—a defiant integration.

text_human: Faced with the stripping of their powers, Wu Sangui, later joined by Geng Zhongming and by Shang Kexi's son Shang Zhixin, felt they had no choice but to revolt. The ensuing Revolt of the Three Feudatories lasted for eight years. Wu attempted, ultimately in vain, to fire the embers of south China Ming loyalty by restoring Ming customs, ordering that the resented queues be cut, and declaring himself emperor of a new dynasty. At the peak of the rebels' fortunes, they extended their control as far north as the Yangtze River, nearly establishing a divided China. Wu then hesitated to go further north, not being able to coordinate strategy with his allies, and Kangxi was able to unify his forces for a counterattack led by a new generation of Manchu generals. By 1681, the Qing government had established control over a ravaged southern China which took several decades to recover. Manchu Generals and Bannermen were initially put to shame by the better performance of the Han Chinese Green Standard Army, who fought better than them against the rebels and this was noted by Kangxi, leading him to task Generals Sun Sike, Wang Jinbao, and Zhao Liangdong to lead Green Standard Soldiers to crush the rebels. The Qing thought that Han Chinese were superior at battling other Han people and so used the Green Standard Army as the dominant and majority army in crushing the rebels instead of Bannermen. Similarly, in northwestern China against Wang Fuchen, the Qing used Han Chinese Green Standard Army soldiers and Han Chinese Generals such as Zhang Liangdong, Wang Jinbao, and Zhang Yong as the primary military forces. This choice was due to the rocky terrain, which favoured infantry troops over cavalry, to the desire to keep Bannermen in the reserves, and, again, to the belief that Han troops were better at fighting other Han people. These Han generals achieved victory over the rebels. Also due to the mountainous terrain, Sichuan and southern Shaanxi were also retaken by the Han Chinese Green Standard Army under Wang Jinbao and Zhao Liangdong in 1680, with Manchus only participating in dealing with logistics and provisions. 400,000 Green Standard Army soldiers and 150,000 Bannermen served on the Qing side during the war. 213 Han Chinese Banner companies, and 527 companies of Mongol and Manchu Banners were mobilized by the Qing during the revolt. 400,000 Green Standard Army soldiers were used against the Three Feudatories besides 200,000 Bannermen.
text_ai_base: Faced with the loss of their powers, Wu Sangui, later supported by Geng Zhongming and Shang Kexi's son Shang Zhixin, felt compelled to rebel. The resulting Revolt of the Three Feudatories persisted for eight years. Wu's efforts to ignite Ming loyalty in Southern China by reinstating Ming customs, abolishing the resented queues, and proclaiming himself emperor of a new dynasty ultimately failed. At the height of their power, the rebels controlled territory as far north as the Yangtze River, nearly splitting China. However, Wu hesitated to advance further north due to a lack of strategic coordination with his allies, which allowed Kangxi to consolidate his forces for a counterattack led by a new generation of Manchu generals. By 1681, the Qing government regained control over a devastated southern China, which took decades to recover. Initially, the Manchu generals and Bannermen were outperformed by the more effective Han Chinese Green Standard Army, noted by Kangxi, who then assigned Generals Sun Sike, Wang Jinbao, and Zhao Liangdong to lead these troops against the rebels. The Qing preferred using the Green Standard Army as the main force, believing Han Chinese were better at fighting their fellow Han and reserving Bannermen. In northwestern China, against Wang Fuchen, the Qing also deployed Han Chinese Green Standard Army soldiers and Han generals like Zhang Liangdong, Wang Jinbao, and Zhang Yong as the primary military forces, due to the terrain favoring infantry over cavalry and again favoring Han troops for their effectiveness against other Han. These generals succeeded in defeating the rebels. In the mountainous regions of Sichuan and southern Shaanxi, the Han Chinese Green Standard Army, led by Wang Jinbao and Zhao Liangdong, recaptured territory in 1680, with Manchu involvement mainly in logistics and supplies. During the conflict, the Qing army included 400,000 Green Standard soldiers and 150,000 Bannermen. In all, 213 Han Chinese Banner companies and 527 Mongol and Manchu Banner companies were mobilized by the Qing during the revolt, with 400,000 Green Standard soldiers and 200,000 Bannermen engaged against the Three Feudatories.
text_ai_humanized: Faced with a dramatic shift in their fortunes, Wu Sangui—initially at the helm—found himself backed by Geng Zhongming and the son of Shang Kexi, Shang Zhixin, as they felt the urge to revolt. This tumultuous period, known as the Revolt of the Three Feudatories, stretched over an exhausting eight years. Wu attempted to rekindle Ming loyalties in Southern China by bringing back old Ming customs, getting rid of the widely disliked queues, and, in a bold move, declaring himself emperor of a new dynasty. Nevertheless, his aspirations crumbled. At their zenith, the rebels held sway over territories reaching up to the Yangtze River, threatening to sever China in two. Yet Wu faltered, hesitating to press north because he couldn’t quite align strategically with his companions, leaving Kangxi space to gather his strength for a formidable counterstrike through a new wave of Manchu generals. By 1681, the Qing reasserted dominance over a battered southern landscape that would take decades to heal. Initially, the Qing’s Manchu generals and Bannermen found their match in the more proficient Han Chinese Green Standard Army—a performance observed and noted by Kangxi. This led him to appoint Generals Sun Sike, Wang Jinbao, and Zhao Liangdong, entrusting them to command these troops for the crucial battles against the rebels. The Qing favored deploying the Green Standard Army, believing these Han soldiers had the upper hand when confronting fellow Han, reserving the Bannermen for other tasks. Marching through northwestern territories against Wang Fuchen, the Qing employed the Green Standard Army again, under the leadership of Han generals like Zhang Liangdong, Wang Jinbao, and Zhang Yong, taking advantage of the terrain that favored infantry over mounted units. In regions where mountains ruled, such as Sichuan and southern Shaanxi, the Green Standard forces led by Wang Jinbao and Zhao Liangdong captured lost ground by 1680. Interestingly, the Manchu’s role swung mostly toward logistics and supply efforts. Throughout this strife, the Qing army fielded a staggering 400,000 Green Standard soldiers and 150,000 Bannermen. They mobilized 213 Han Chinese Banner companies alongside 527 Mongol and Manchu Banner outfits for the revolt. The Qing ultimately unleashed 400,000 Green Standard fighters and 200,000 Bannermen against the Three Feudatories, a testament to the scale and intensity of this chapter in history.

text_human: The vast Seleucid Empire was, like Egypt, mostly dominated by a Greco-Macedonian political elite. The Greek population of the cities who formed the dominant elite were reinforced by emigration from Greece. These cities included newly founded colonies such as Antioch, the other cities of the Syrian tetrapolis, Seleucia (north of Babylon) and Dura-Europos on the Euphrates. These cities retained traditional Greek city state institutions such as assemblies, councils and elected magistrates, but this was a facade for they were always controlled by the royal Seleucid officials. Apart from these cities, there were also a large number of Seleucid garrisons (choria), military colonies (katoikiai) and Greek villages (komai) which the Seleucids planted throughout the empire to cement their rule. This 'Greco-Macedonian' population (which also included the sons of settlers who had married local women) could make up a phalanx of 35,000 men (out of a total Seleucid army of 80,000) during the reign of Antiochos III. The rest of the army was made up of native troops. Antiochus III the great conducted several vigorous campaigns to retake all the lost provinces of the empire since the death of Seleucus I. After being defeated by Ptolemy IV's forces at Raphia (217), Antiochus III led a long campaign to the east to subdue the far eastern breakaway provinces (212-205) including Bactria, Parthia, Ariana, Sogdiana, Gedrosia and Drangiana. He was successful, bringing back most of these provinces into at least nominal vassalage and receiving tribute from their rulers. After the death of Ptolemy IV (204), Antiochus took advantage of the weakness of Egypt to conquer Coele-Syria in the fifth Syrian war (202-195). He then began expanding his influence into Pergamene territory in Asia and crossed into Europe, fortifying Lysimachia on the hellespont, but his expansion into Anatolia and Greece was abruptly halted after a decisive defeat at the Battle of Magnesia (190 BCE). In the Treaty of Apamea which ended the war, Antiochus lost all of his territories in Anatolia west of the Taurus and was forced to pay a large indemnity of 15,000 talents.
text_ai_base: The expansive Seleucid Empire, like Egypt, was largely controlled by a Greco-Macedonian political elite. This elite, predominantly composed of Greeks from the cities, was strengthened by immigrants from Greece. Such cities included new colonies like Antioch, the cities of the Syrian tetrapolis, Seleucia (north of Babylon), and Dura-Europos on the Euphrates. Although these cities maintained Greek city-state institutions like assemblies, councils, and elected magistrates, true power remained with the royal Seleucid officials. Beyond these cities, the empire had numerous Seleucid garrisons (choria), military colonies (katoikiai), and Greek villages (komai), established to solidify their rule. The 'Greco-Macedonian' population, including descendants of settlers who married locals, could field a phalanx of 35,000 men in Antiochos III's reign, out of a total Seleucid army of 80,000, with the remainder composed of native troops. Antiochos III embarked on several aggressive campaigns to reclaim provinces lost since Seleucus I's death. Despite a setback by Ptolemy IV's forces at Raphia in 217, Antiochos III launched a lengthy campaign from 212 to 205 to subdue the eastern provinces—Bactria, Parthia, Ariana, Sogdiana, Gedrosia, and Drangiana—successfully bringing them under nominal vassalage. Following Ptolemy IV's death in 204, Antiochos capitalized on Egypt's vulnerability to conquer Coele-Syria in the fifth Syrian war (202–195). He pushed into Pergamene territory in Asia and moved into Europe, fortifying Lysimachia on the Hellespont. However, his expansion into Anatolia and Greece was abruptly stopped after his defeat at the Battle of Magnesia in 190 BCE. The resulting Treaty of Apamea stripped him of his territories in Anatolia west of the Taurus and imposed a hefty indemnity of 15,000 talents.
text_ai_humanized: The vast Seleucid Empire, much like Egypt, found itself under the sway of a predominantly Greco-Macedonian ruling class. This elite group, largely hailing from Greek cities, saw its ranks bolstered by newcomers from Greece itself. Among these urban centers were the newly established colonies such as Antioch and the Syrian tetrapolis cities, along with places like Seleucia—situated north of Babylon—and Dura-Europos, nestled on the banks of the Euphrates. While these locales retained their Greek city-state trappings, complete with assemblies, councils, and magistrates, the real power lay firmly with the appointed Seleucid officials. But venture outside these cities, and you'd find a plethora of Seleucid garrisons—known as choria—alongside military colonies termed katoikiai and Greek villages, or komai. These were set up to cement the empire's grip on the region. The 'Greco-Macedonian' populace, interwoven with descendants from mixed marriages, showcased their military might through a phalanx boasting 35,000 men during Antiochos III's era. This was part of a larger Seleucid army of 80,000, where the remainder was composed of native troops. Antiochos III was no stranger to ambition, as he launched formidable campaigns to reclaim territories lost since Seleucus I passed away. True, he faced a setback against Ptolemy IV at the Battle of Raphia in 217 BCE. However, undeterred by this stumble, Antiochos mounted a protracted campaign from 212 to 205 BCE aimed at bending the eastern provinces—Bactria, Parthia, Ariana, Sogdiana, Gedrosia, and Drangiana—to his will, succeeding in making them nominal vassals. In the wake of Ptolemy IV's demise in 204 BCE, Antiochos seized the moment to swoop into a weakened Egypt, capturing Coele-Syria in what became known as the Fifth Syrian War (202–195 BCE). His influence didn't stop there. He ventured into Asia, pressuring Pergamene territories and even advancing into Europe, where he fortified Lysimachia on the Hellespont. Yet, his reach was finally curtailed following a resounding defeat at the Battle of Magnesia in 190 BCE. The terms hammered out in the Treaty of Apamea were harsh, stripping him of his Anatolian territories west of the Taurus Mountains and saddling him with a staggering indemnity of 15,000 talents.

text_human: It is not clear exactly where collegiate a cappella began. The Rensselyrics of Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute (formerly known as the RPI Glee Club), established in 1873 is perhaps the oldest known collegiate a cappella group.[citation needed] However the longest continuously-singing group is probably The Whiffenpoofs of Yale University, which was formed in 1909 and once included Cole Porter as a member. Collegiate a cappella groups grew throughout the 20th century. Some notable historical groups formed along the way include Princeton University's Tigertones (1946), Colgate University's The Colgate 13 (1942), Dartmouth College's Aires (1946), Cornell University's Cayuga's Waiters (1949) and The Hangovers (1968), the University of Maine Maine Steiners (1958), the Columbia University Kingsmen (1949), the Jabberwocks of Brown University (1949), and the University of Rochester YellowJackets (1956). All-women a cappella groups followed shortly, frequently as a parody of the men's groups: the Smiffenpoofs of Smith College (1936), The Shwiffs of Connecticut College (The She-Whiffenpoofs, 1944), and The Chattertocks of Brown University (1951). A cappella groups exploded in popularity beginning in the 1990s, fueled in part by a change in style popularized by the Tufts University Beelzebubs and the Boston University Dear Abbeys. The new style used voices to emulate modern rock instruments, including vocal percussion/"beatboxing". Some larger universities now have multiple groups. Groups often join one another in on-campus concerts, such as the Georgetown Chimes' Cherry Tree Massacre, a 3-weekend a cappella festival held each February since 1975, where over a hundred collegiate groups have appeared, as well as International Quartet Champions The Boston Common and the contemporary commercial a cappella group Rockapella. Co-ed groups have produced many up-and-coming and major artists, including John Legend, an alumnus of the Counterparts at the University of Pennsylvania, and Sara Bareilles, an alumna of Awaken A Cappella at University of California, Los Angeles. Mira Sorvino is an alumna of the Harvard-Radcliffe Veritones of Harvard College where she had the solo on Only You by Yaz.
text_ai_base: The origins of collegiate a cappella are somewhat unclear, but one of the oldest known groups is the Rensselyrics from Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute, founded in 1873 as the RPI Glee Club.[citation needed] Meanwhile, Yale University's Whiffenpoofs, formed in 1909 and once boasting Cole Porter among its members, are likely the longest continuously-performing ensemble. Collegiate a cappella steadily expanded throughout the 20th century, giving rise to historic groups such as Princeton University's Tigertones (1946), Colgate University's The Colgate 13 (1942), Dartmouth College's Aires (1946), Cornell University's Cayuga's Waiters (1949) and The Hangovers (1968), the University of Maine Steiners (1958), the Columbia University Kingsmen (1949), the Jabberwocks of Brown University (1949), and the University of Rochester YellowJackets (1956). All-women groups emerged soon after, often humorously riffing on the men's groups with formations like the Smiffenpoofs of Smith College (1936), The Shwiffs of Connecticut College (The She-Whiffenpoofs, 1944), and The Chattertocks of Brown University (1951). Interest in a cappella surged in the 1990s, thanks in part to stylistic innovations from the Tufts University Beelzebubs and the Boston University Dear Abbeys, who incorporated vocals simulating rock instruments and vocal percussion or "beatboxing." Many larger universities now host multiple groups, and these ensembles frequently participate in on-campus collaborations, such as the Georgetown Chimes’ Cherry Tree Massacre, a three-weekend a cappella festival each February since 1975 featuring over a hundred collegiate groups and highlights like International Quartet Champions The Boston Common and the commercial act Rockapella. Co-ed ensembles have nurtured a range of notable artists, including John Legend from Penn's Counterparts and Sara Bareilles from UCLA's Awaken A Cappella. Mira Sorvino also performed in Harvard's Veritones, showcasing her talent with a solo on "Only You" by Yaz.

Smith College's Smiffenpoofs (born 1936) and The Shwiffs from Connecticut College (1944) added a playful touch, and by 1951, The Chattertocks of Brown University were setting their sound free. Their bold shifts included making voices mimic rock instruments and the vibrant addition of vocal percussion, or "beatboxing." text_human: After a three-year hiatus, a fifth Digimon series began airing on April 2, 2006. Like Frontier, Savers has no connection with the previous installments, and also marks a new start for the Digimon franchise, with a drastic change in character designs and story-line, in order to reach a broader audience. The story focuses on the challenges faced by the members of D.A.T.S. ("Digital Accident Tactics Squad"), an organization created to conceal the existence of the Digital World and Digimon from the rest of mankind, and secretly solve any Digimon-related incidents occurring on Earth. Later the D.A.T.S. is dragged into a massive conflict between Earth and the Digital World, triggered by an ambitious human scientist named Akihiro Kurata, determined to make use of the Digimon for his own personal gains. The English version was dubbed by Studiopolis and it premiered on the Jetix block on Toon Disney on October 1, 2007. Digivolution in Data Squad requires the human partner's DNA ("Digital Natural Ability" in the English version and "Digisoul" in the Japanese version) to activate, a strong empathy with their Digimon and a will to succeed. 'Digimon Savers' also introduces a new form of digivolving called Burst Mode which is essentially the level above Mega (previously the strongest form a digimon could take). Like previously in Tamers, this plot takes on a dark tone throughout the story and the anime was aimed, originally in Japan, at an older audience consisting of late teens and people in their early twenties from ages 16 to 21. Because of that, along with the designs, the anime being heavily edited and localized for western US audiences like past series, and the English dub being aimed mostly toward younger audiences of children aged 6 to 10 and having a lower TV-Y7-FV rating just like past dubs, Studiopolis dubbed the anime on Jetix with far more edits, changes, censorship, and cut footage. This included giving the Japanese characters full Americanized names and American surnames as well as applying far more Americanization (Marcus Damon as opposed to the Japanese Daimon Masaru), cultural streamlining and more edits to their version similar to the changes 4Kids often made (such as removal of Japanese text for the purpose of cultural streamlining). Despite all that, the setting of the country was still in Japan and the characters were Japanese in the dub. This series was the first to show any Japanese cultural concepts that were unfamiliar with American audiences (such as the manju), which were left unedited and used in the English dub. Also despite the heavy censorship and the English dub aimed at young children, some of the Digimon's attacks named after real weapons such as RizeGreymon's Trident Revolver are not edited and used in the English dub. Well Go USA released it on DVD instead of Disney. The North American English dub was televised on Jetix in the U.S. and on the Family Channel in Canada.

Similar to Frontier, Digimon Savers is independent from previous installments, introducing a fresh start for the franchise. (Digital Accident Tactics Squad) members who strive to conceal the existence of the Digital World and Digimon from humanity, while addressing Digimon-related incidents on Earth. Digimon Savers introduces Burst Mode, a digivolving form beyond Mega, previously the highest level. Like Digimon Tamers, the story adopts a darker tone and originally targeted a Japanese audience aged 16 to 21. However, for the English dub aimed at children aged 6 to 10 with a TV-Y7-FV rating, Studiopolis heavily edited, localized, and censored the content. This included Americanizing character names and cultural elements (e.g., Marcus Damon for Daimon Masaru), akin to 4Kids' approach. Despite the modifications, the setting remained Japan with Japanese characters. Unfamiliar cultural aspects like manju remained unchanged in the English version, and names of Digimon attacks such as RizeGreymon's Trident Revolver were retained despite censorship elsewhere. The series was released on DVD by Well Go USA instead of Disney, and the North American dub aired on Jetix in the U.S. and the Family Channel in Canada.
text_ai_humanized: After taking a three-year hiatus, the fifth installment of the Digimon series, Digimon Savers, hit screens on April 2, 2006. Veering away from its predecessors, much like Frontier, it offered a clean slate for the franchise with entirely new character designs and a gripping storyline, hoping to hook a wider audience. At the heart of the narrative are the members of D.A.T.S., or Digital Accident Tactics Squad. They're entrusted with keeping the Digital World and Digimons' existence under wraps from the general human populace and tackling any Digitally-induced conundrums that spill over into our reality. Yet, things take a more intense turn when D.A.T.S. finds itself embroiled in a major showdown between Earth and the Digital World, triggered by none other than Akihiro Kurata. This human scientist is hell-bent on harnessing Digimon for his selfish ends. Fast forward to October 1, 2007, and Studiopolis had dubbed the English version, which saw its debut on Jetix via Toon Disney. Now, in Data Squad, Digivolution gets a bit of a twist. It leans not just on the trusty companionship of a human partner but also on their DNA—coined Digital Natural Ability in English, or Digisoul in its original Japanese context. Throw in a dollop of empathy and determination, and you've got the recipe. Plus, there's a slick new Burst Mode, taking digivolving beyond the previous Mega cap. Originally crafted with a darker narrative tone, akin to Digimon Tamers, it was meant for a Japanese demographic ranging from 16 to 21. However, the English dub, with its eye on kids aged 6 to 10, carried a TV-Y7-FV rating and saw Studiopolis giving it the makeover treatment. This wasn't just superficial either—they toned down, localized, and even censored parts, Americanizing character names much like 4Kids was known to do. So Daimon Masaru became Marcus Damon, for instance. Yet, despite all this tweaking, the setting stubbornly stayed rooted in Japan, even leaving some cultural oddities like manju untouched. Digimon attacks, such as RizeGreymon's Trident Revolver, also managed to sneak past the censors largely unscathed. Rather than Disney, Well Go USA took on the task of releasing the series on DVD. And across North America, fans got their fill through Jetix in the United States and the Family Channel in Canada.

After taking a three-year hiatus, the fifth installment of the Digimon series, Digimon Savers, hit screens on April 2, 2006. Veering away from its predecessors, much like Frontier, it offered a clean slate for the franchise with entirely new character designs and a gripping storyline, hoping to hook a wider audience. At the heart of the narrative are the members of D.A.T.S., or Digital Accident Tactics Squad. They're entrusted with keeping the Digital World and Digimons' existence under wraps from the general human populace and tackling any Digitally-induced conundrums that spill over into our reality.

Yet, things take a more intense turn when D.A.T.S. finds itself embroiled in a major showdown between Earth and the Digital World, triggered by none other than Akihiro Kurata. This human scientist is hell-bent on harnessing Digimon for his selfish ends. Fast forward to October 1, 2007, and Studiopolis had dubbed the English version, which saw its debut on Jetix via Toon Disney.

Now, in Data Squad, Digivolution gets a bit of a twist. It leans not just on the trusty companionship of a human partner but also on their DNA—coined Digital Natural Ability in English, or Digisoul in its original Japanese context. Throw in a dollop of empathy and determination, and you've got the recipe. Plus, there's a slick new Burst Mode, taking digivolving beyond the previous Mega cap.

Originally crafted with a darker narrative tone, akin to Digimon Tamers, it was meant for a Japanese demographic ranging from 16 to 21. However, the English dub, with its eye on kids aged 6 to 10, carried a TV-Y7-FV rating and saw Studiopolis giving it the makeover treatment. This wasn't just superficial either—they toned down, localized, and even censored parts, Americanizing character names much like 4Kids was known to do. So Daimon Masaru became Marcus Damon, for instance. Yet, despite all this tweaking, the setting stubbornly stayed rooted in Japan, even leaving some cultural oddities like manju untouched. Digimon attacks, such as RizeGreymon's Trident Revolver, also managed to sneak past the censors largely unscathed.

Rather than Disney, Well Go USA took on the task of releasing the series on DVD. And across North America, fans got their fill through Jetix in the United States and the Family Channel in Canada.

text_human: Like the reptiles, birds are primarily uricotelic, that is, their kidneys extract nitrogenous waste from their bloodstream and excrete it as uric acid instead of urea or ammonia through the ureters into the intestine. Birds do not have a urinary bladder or external urethral opening and (with exception of the ostrich) uric acid is excreted along with feces as a semisolid waste. However, birds such as hummingbirds can be facultatively ammonotelic, excreting most of the nitrogenous wastes as ammonia. They also excrete creatine, rather than creatinine like mammals. This material, as well as the output of the intestines, emerges from the bird's cloaca. The cloaca is a multi-purpose opening: waste is expelled through it, most birds mate by joining cloaca, and females lay eggs from it. In addition, many species of birds regurgitate pellets. Males within Palaeognathae (with the exception of the kiwis), the Anseriformes (with the exception of screamers), and in rudimentary forms in Galliformes (but fully developed in Cracidae) possess a penis, which is never present in Neoaves. The length is thought to be related to sperm competition. When not copulating, it is hidden within the proctodeum compartment within the cloaca, just inside the vent. The digestive system of birds is unique, with a crop for storage and a gizzard that contains swallowed stones for grinding food to compensate for the lack of teeth. Most birds are highly adapted for rapid digestion to aid with flight. Some migratory birds have adapted to use protein from many parts of their bodies, including protein from the intestines, as additional energy during migration.
text_ai_base: Similar to reptiles, birds are mainly uricotelic, meaning their kidneys filter nitrogenous waste from the bloodstream and expel it as uric acid through the ureters into the intestine, instead of urea or ammonia. Unlike most mammals, birds lack a urinary bladder or external urethral opening. Except for ostriches, they excrete uric acid with feces as a semi-solid waste. However, birds like hummingbirds can switch to being ammonotelic, releasing most nitrogenous waste as ammonia. Birds excrete creatine, as opposed to mammals, which excrete creatinine. All waste materials exit through the cloaca, a versatile opening used for expelling waste, mating, and egg-laying. Additionally, many bird species regurgitate food pellets. Certain male birds, including those in Palaeognathae (except kiwis), Anseriformes (except screamers), in rudimentary form in Galliformes, and fully developed in Cracidae, have a penis—absent in Neoaves—which stays hidden inside the proctodeum part of the cloaca when not in use. The bird digestive system is unique, featuring a crop for storage and a gizzard with ingested stones to grind food, compensating for the absence of teeth. Birds are usually adapted for fast digestion to enhance flight efficiency, and some migratory birds even utilize protein from various body parts, including the intestines, as extra energy for migration.
text_ai_humanized: Much like their reptilian counterparts, birds primarily process nitrogenous waste by converting it to uric acid, which their kidneys efficiently expel into the intestines via the ureters. Instead of urea or ammonia, this uric acid makes its way out of the body mingled with feces, resulting in a semi-solid waste—an exception being the ostrich, which handles waste differently. Intriguingly, hummingbirds have a unique ability to pivot, often relying on ammonia excretion rather than sticking to uric acid, showcasing their ammonotelic traits. When it comes to excreting creatine, birds veer away from the mammalian habit of producing creatinine, setting them apart once more. This orchestration of waste disposal all comes to a head at the cloaca—a multi-functional exit used by birds for defecation, mating rituals, and the wondrous act of egg-laying. Before food reaches this terminal structure, it might itself make a return journey—as in, many birds, take for instance owls, might regurgitate indigestible parts like bones and fur as pellets. Further revealing the complexities of bird anatomy, some male birds boast a cloaca-concealed penis. This trait appears in Palaeognathae (save for kiwis), Anseriformes (excluding screamers), in a basic form among Galliformes, and fully developed in Cracidae, but it's absent in Neoaves. You might find it intriguing how this penile structure stays hidden within the proctodeum segment of the cloaca until needed. A glance at a bird’s digestive system unveils its distinctiveness: they're equipped with a crop—a kind of storage pouch—and a gizzard, which uses ingested stones to grind food, stepping in where teeth would otherwise do the job. This setup is a testament to evolution's clever adaptations, crucial for birds' typically rapid digestion—an essential for maintaining flight agility. Migratory birds push this adaptability further, tapping into proteins from various body tissues, including their intestines, to fuel their exhaustive journeys across vast distances.

text_human: An adolescent's environment plays a huge role in their identity development. While most adolescent studies are conducted on white, middle class children, studies show that the more privileged upbringing people have, the more successfully they develop their identity. The forming of an adolescent's identity is a crucial time in their life. It has been recently found that demographic patterns suggest that the transition to adulthood is now occurring over a longer span of years than was the case during the middle of the 20th century. Accordingly, youth, a period that spans late adolescence and early adulthood, has become a more prominent stage of the life course. This therefore has caused various factors to become important during this development. So many factors contribute to the developing social identity of an adolescent from commitment, to coping devices, to social media. All of these factors are affected by the environment an adolescent grows up in. A child from a more privileged upbringing is exposed to more opportunities and better situations in general. An adolescent from an inner city or a crime-driven neighborhood is more likely to be exposed to an environment that can be detrimental to their development. Adolescence is a sensitive period in the development process, and exposure to the wrong things at that time can have a major effect on future decisions. While children that grow up in nice suburban communities are not exposed to bad environments they are more likely to participate in activities that can benefit their identity and contribute to a more successful identity development.

Consequently, youth—a period covering late adolescence and early adulthood—has become a more significant life stage. This shift has made various factors crucial during development. Many elements shape an adolescent's social identity, including commitment, coping mechanisms, and social media, all influenced by their environment. Children from privileged backgrounds generally have greater access to opportunities and favorable conditions. Adolescence is a delicate time in the growth process, and negative exposure during this period can impact future choices significantly. While children in suburban communities avoid harmful environments, they are more likely to engage in activities that enhance identity development, leading to more successful outcomes.

text_human: The political structure of Western Europe changed with the end of the united Roman Empire. Although the movements of peoples during this period are usually described as "invasions", they were not just military expeditions but migrations of entire peoples into the empire. Such movements were aided by the refusal of the western Roman elites to support the army or pay the taxes that would have allowed the military to suppress the migration. The emperors of the 5th century were often controlled by military strongmen such as Stilicho (d. 408), Aspar (d. 471), Ricimer (d. 472), or Gundobad (d. 516), who were partly or fully of non-Roman background. When the line of western emperors ceased, many of the kings who replaced them were from the same background. Intermarriage between the new kings and the Roman elites was common. This led to a fusion of Roman culture with the customs of the invading tribes, including the popular assemblies that allowed free male tribal members more say in political matters than was common in the Roman state. Material artefacts left by the Romans and the invaders are often similar, and tribal items were often modelled on Roman objects. Much of the scholarly and written culture of the new kingdoms was also based on Roman intellectual traditions. An important difference was the gradual loss of tax revenue by the new polities. Many of the new political entities no longer supported their armies through taxes, instead relying on granting them land or rents. This meant there was less need for large tax revenues and so the taxation systems decayed. Warfare was common between and within the kingdoms. Slavery declined as the supply weakened, and society became more rural.[F]
text_ai_base: With the fall of the Roman Empire, Western Europe's political landscape transformed significantly. While the movements of peoples during this era are often termed "invasions," they were not merely military campaigns but involved entire populations migrating into the empire. These migrations were facilitated by western Roman elites' refusal to back the military or pay taxes that would have enabled the army to hinder these movements. In the 5th century, emperors were frequently under the sway of military leaders like Stilicho, Aspar, Ricimer, and Gundobad—figures who were wholly or partly of non-Roman descent. When the line of western emperors ended, many kings who took their place shared these backgrounds. Intermarriage between these new kings and Roman elites became common, leading to a blending of Roman culture with the customs of the tribes, such as popular assemblies that provided free male tribal members with more political voice than typical in the Roman state. The material culture left behind by Romans and invaders shows similarities, with tribal artifacts often modeled after Roman ones. Additionally, the intellectual culture of the new kingdoms drew heavily from Roman traditions. However, a notable change was the gradual decline in tax revenue for these new political entities. Many stopped funding their armies through taxes, instead granting them land or rents, reducing the need for large-scale taxation systems, which subsequently deteriorated. Warfare was rampant both between and within these kingdoms. As the supply diminished, slavery decreased, and life grew more rural.
text_ai_humanized: The Roman Empire's collapse brought on a seismic shift in Western Europe's political scene. It's tempting to label the movements of this period as "invasions," but calling them just that misses the bigger picture: whole communities were on the move, uprooting into the empire rather than merely mounting military offensives. A critical factor in these migrations was the western Roman elites' unwillingness to support the military or pay taxes that might have bolstered defenses against such incursions. In the tumultuous 5th century, Roman emperors often found themselves under the thumb of prominent military figures like Stilicho, Aspar, Ricimer, and Gundobad—men whose heritage was either partly or wholly non-Roman. With the western emperors' line extinguished, their successors, many of whom hailed from similar backgrounds, took the throne. Marriage between these nascent monarchs and the elites was commonplace, forging a fusion of Roman traditions with the newcomers' customs. This mingling ushered in practices like popular assemblies that conferred greater political influence on free male tribal members than they typically enjoyed under Roman governance. What's left behind from both Romans and newcomers reveals striking similarities: tribal artifacts often took a cue from Roman designs. Meanwhile, these fledgling kingdoms drew heavily from Roman intellectual traditions, though they witnessed a marked shift in financial dynamics. The tax revenue necessary for sustaining armies started drying up, giving way to land grants or rents as a form of compensation—a shift that eroded large-scale taxation systems. As is often the case with power struggles, warfare became rampant among and within kingdoms. As resources dwindled, slavery declined, marking a shift towards a more agrarian way of life. The echoes of the Roman past were still evident, yet the landscape had undeniably transformed—not unlike the unpredictability of history itself, where change is the only constant.

What's left behind from both Romans and newcomers reveals striking similarities: tribal artifacts often took a cue from Roman designs. Meanwhile, these fledgling kingdoms drew heavily from Roman intellectual traditions, though they witnessed a marked shift in financial dynamics. The tax revenue necessary for sustaining armies started drying up, giving way to land grants or rents as a form of compensation—a shift that eroded large-scale taxation systems.

As is often the case with power struggles, warfare became rampant among and within kingdoms. As resources dwindled, slavery declined, marking a shift towards a more agrarian way of life. The echoes of the Roman past were still evident, yet the landscape had undeniably transformed—not unlike the unpredictability of history itself, where change is the only constant.

text_human: On 29 November 1947, the United Nations General Assembly recommended the adoption and implementation of the Partition Plan for Mandatory Palestine. This UN plan specified borders for new Arab and Jewish states and also specified an area of Jerusalem and its environs which was to be administered by the UN under an international regime. The end of the British Mandate for Palestine was set for midnight on 14 May 1948. That day, David Ben-Gurion, the executive head of the Zionist Organization and president of the Jewish Agency for Palestine, declared "the establishment of a Jewish state in Eretz Israel, to be known as the State of Israel," which would start to function from the termination of the mandate. The borders of the new state were not specified in the declaration. Neighboring Arab armies invaded the former Palestinian mandate on the next day and fought the Israeli forces. Israel has since fought several wars with neighboring Arab states, in the course of which it has occupied the West Bank, Sinai Peninsula (1956–57, 1967–82), part of Southern Lebanon (1982–2000), Gaza Strip (1967–2005; still considered occupied after 2005 disengagement) and the Golan Heights. It extended its laws to the Golan Heights and East Jerusalem, but not the West Bank. Efforts to resolve the Israeli–Palestinian conflict have not resulted in peace. However, peace treaties between Israel and both Egypt and Jordan have successfully been signed. Israel's occupation of Gaza, the West Bank and East Jerusalem is the world's longest military occupation in modern times.[note 2]

This plan outlined borders for separate Arab and Jewish states and designated Jerusalem and its surrounding area to be governed by the UN under an international regime. The British Mandate for Palestine was scheduled to end at midnight on May 14, 1948. On that very day, David Ben-Gurion, head of the Zionist Organization and president of the Jewish Agency for Palestine, proclaimed the creation of a Jewish state in Eretz Israel, named the State of Israel, to become effective at the mandate's end. The declaration did not detail the new state's borders. The following day, neighboring Arab armies invaded the former mandate, engaging Israeli forces. Israel extended its laws to the Golan Heights and East Jerusalem, but not to the West Bank. text_human: Tensions over rising Polish nationalism and the economic effects of the Continental System led to renewed confrontation with Russia. To enforce his blockade, Napoleon launched an invasion of Russia in the summer of 1812. The resulting campaign witnessed the catastrophic collapse of the Grand Army, forcing the French to retreat, as well as leading to the widespread destruction of Russian lands and cities. In 1813, Prussia and Austria joined Russian forces in a Sixth Coalition against France. A chaotic military campaign in Central Europe eventually culminated in a large Allied army defeating Napoleon at the Battle of Leipzig in October. The next year, the Allies invaded France and captured Paris, forcing Napoleon to abdicate in April 1814. He was exiled to the island of Elba. The Bourbons were restored to power and the French lost most of the territories that they had conquered since the Revolution. However, Napoleon escaped from Elba in February 1815 and took control of the government once again. The Allies responded by forming a Seventh Coalition, which ultimately defeated Napoleon at the Battle of Waterloo in June. The Royal Navy then thwarted his planned escape to the United States in July, so he surrendered to the British after running out of other options. The British exiled him to the remote island of Saint Helena in the South Atlantic. His death in 1821 at the age of 51 was received with shock and grief throughout Europe. In 1840, a million people witnessed his remains returning to Paris, where they still reside at Les Invalides.

text_human: Since annelids are soft-bodied, their fossils are rare. Polychaetes' fossil record consists mainly of the jaws that some species had and the mineralized tubes that some secreted. Some Ediacaran fossils such as Dickinsonia in some ways resemble polychaetes, but the similarities are too vague for these fossils to be classified with confidence. The small shelly fossil Cloudina, from 549 to 542 million years ago, has been classified by some authors as an annelid, but by others as a cnidarian (i.e. in the phylum to which jellyfish and sea anemones belong). Until 2008 the earliest fossils widely accepted as annelids were the polychaetes Canadia and Burgessochaeta, both from Canada's Burgess Shale, formed about 505 million years ago in the early Cambrian. Myoscolex, found in Australia and a little older than the Burgess Shale, was possibly an annelid. However, it lacks some typical annelid features and has features which are not usually found in annelids and some of which are associated with other phyla. Then Simon Conway Morris and John Peel reported Phragmochaeta from Sirius Passet, about 518 million years old, and concluded that it was the oldest annelid known to date. There has been vigorous debate about whether the Burgess Shale fossil Wiwaxia was a mollusc or an annelid. Polychaetes diversified in the early Ordovician, about 488 to 474 million years ago. It is not until the early Ordovician that the first annelid jaws are found, thus the crown-group cannot have appeared before this date and probably appeared somewhat later. By the end of the Carboniferous, about 299 million years ago, fossils of most of the modern mobile polychaete groups had appeared. Many fossil tubes look like those made by modern sessile polychaetes , but the first tubes clearly produced by polychaetes date from the Jurassic, less than 199 million years ago.
text_ai_base: Annelids have soft bodies, making their fossil record sparse. Polychaetes' fossils primarily consist of the mineralized tubes some species secreted and the jaws they possessed. Some Ediacaran fossils, such as Dickinsonia, resemble polychaetes in certain aspects, but the similarities are too ambiguous to confidently classify them as annelids. The small shelly fossil Cloudina, dating from 549 to 542 million years ago, has been variably classified as an annelid or a cnidarian (the phylum including jellyfish and sea anemones). Until 2008, the earliest widely accepted annelid fossils were the polychaetes Canadia and Burgessochaeta from Canada's Burgess Shale, formed roughly 505 million years ago during the early Cambrian. Myoscolex, found in Australia and slightly older than the Burgess Shale, may also be an annelid but lacks certain typical annelid features while exhibiting traits linked to other phyla. Later, Simon Conway Morris and John Peel reported Phragmochaeta from Sirius Passet, about 518 million years old, concluding it was the oldest known annelid. Debates have persisted over whether the Burgess Shale fossil Wiwaxia was a mollusk or an annelid. Polychaetes underwent diversification in the early Ordovician, approximately 488 to 474 million years ago, marking when the first annelid jaws appeared. This suggests the crown group emerged post-Ordovician. By the end of the Carboniferous, around 299 million years ago, fossils of most modern mobile polychaete groups had emerged. Though many fossil tubes resemble those produced by contemporary sessile polychaetes, the first unequivocal polychaete tubes date from the Jurassic, less than 199 million years ago.
text_ai_humanized: Annelids, with their soft-bodied nature, have left behind a rather scarce fossil record. Most of the fossils attributed to polychaetes, for instance, are those mineralized tubes that some species crafted, along with their distinctive jaws. The challenge arises when considering Ediacaran fossils like Dickinsonia, which share certain resemblances with polychaetes. Yet, the connections are too tenuous to definitively place them within the annelid family. Cloudina, a small shelly fossil dating back to about 549-542 million years ago, has stirred some confusion. It’s been classified variously, sometimes as an annelid, other times as a cnidarian—yes, the group that includes creatures like jellyfish and sea anemones. Before 2008, the annelid group had its oldest recognized members in the form of Canadia and Burgessochaeta, uncovered in Canada's Burgess Shale. This formation, crafted roughly 505 million years ago during the early Cambrian, remains a key piece of the puzzle. Australia brought forth Myoscolex, slightly older than its Burgess counterparts, stirring interest through its atypical blend of traits, both annelid and not. Phragmochaeta, found in Sirius Passet and reported by Simon Conway Morris and John Peel, shifted the timeline back by 13 million years, to 518 million years ago, claiming the title of the oldest known annelid. Meanwhile, a lively debate swirls around Wiwaxia from the same Burgess Shale—mollusk or annelid? Entering the early Ordovician period, about 488 to 474 million years ago, polychaetes began to diversify significantly. It’s here we see the first annelid jaws make an appearance, indicating the crown group’s emergence likely came after the Ordovician epoch. By the Carboniferous period's end, nearly 299 million years ago, fossils of most modern, mobile polychaete groups had been established. Though numerous fossil tubes bear a striking likeness to those of modern sessile polychaetes, the first indisputable polychaete tubes hail from the Jurassic period, which is less than 199 million years ago.

message.content:
Annelids, with their soft-bodied nature, have left behind a rather scarce fossil record. Most of the fossils attributed to polychaetes, for instance, are those mineralized tubes that some species crafted, along with their distinctive jaws. The challenge arises when considering Ediacaran fossils like Dickinsonia, which share certain resemblances with polychaetes. Yet, the connections are too tenuous to definitively place them within the annelid family. Cloudina, a small shelly fossil dating back to about 549-542 million years ago, has stirred some confusion. It’s been classified variously, sometimes as an annelid, other times as a cnidarian—yes, the group that includes creatures like jellyfish and sea anemones.

Before 2008, the annelid group had its oldest recognized members in the form of Canadia and Burgessochaeta, uncovered in Canada's Burgess Shale. This formation, crafted roughly 505 million years ago during the early Cambrian, remains a key piece of the puzzle. Australia brought forth Myoscolex, slightly older than its Burgess counterparts, stirring interest through its atypical blend of traits, both annelid and not. Phragmochaeta, found in Sirius Passet and reported by Simon Conway Morris and John Peel, shifted the timeline back by 13 million years, to 518 million years ago, claiming the title of the oldest known annelid. Meanwhile, a lively debate swirls around Wiwaxia from the same Burgess Shale—mollusk or annelid?

Entering the early Ordovician period, about 488 to 474 million years ago, polychaetes began to diversify significantly. It’s here we see the first annelid jaws make an appearance, indicating the crown group’s emergence likely came after the Ordovician epoch. By the Carboniferous period's end, nearly 299 million years ago, fossils of most modern, mobile polychaete groups had been established. Though numerous fossil tubes bear a striking likeness to those of modern sessile polychaetes, the first indisputable polychaete tubes hail from the Jurassic period, which is less than 199 million years ago.

text_human: Although Ottoman madaris had a number of different branches of study, such as calligraphic sciences, oral sciences, and intellectual sciences, they primarily served the function of an Islamic centre for spiritual learning. "The goal of all knowledge and in particular, of the spiritual sciences is knowledge of God." Religion, for the most part, determines the significance and importance of each science. As İnalcık mentions: "Those which aid religion are good and sciences like astrology are bad." However, even though mathematics, or studies in logic were part of the madrasa's curriculum, they were all centred around religion. Even mathematics had a religious impulse behind its teachings. "The Ulema of the Ottoman medreses held the view that hostility to logic and mathematics was futile since these accustomed the mind to correct thinking and thus helped to reveal divine truths" – key word being "divine". İnalcık also mentions that even philosophy was only allowed to be studied so that it helped to confirm the doctrines of Islam." Hence, madaris – schools were basically religious centres for religious teachings and learning in the Ottoman world. Although scholars such as Goffman have argued that the Ottomans were highly tolerant and lived in a pluralistic society, it seems that schools that were the main centres for learning were in fact heftily religious and were not religiously pluralistic, but centred around Islam. Similarly, in Europe "Jewish children learned the Hebrew letters and texts of basic prayers at home, and then attended a school organised by the synagogue to study the Torah." Wiesner-Hanks also says that Protestants also wanted to teach "proper religious values." This shows that in the early modern period, Ottomans and Europeans were similar in their ideas about how schools should be managed and what they should be primarily focused on. Thus, Ottoman madaris were very similar to present day schools in the sense that they offered a wide range of studies; however, these studies, in their ultimate objective, aimed to further solidify and consolidate Islamic practices and theories.
text_ai_base: Ottoman madaris offered a variety of studies, including calligraphic, oral, and intellectual sciences, but their primary role was as an Islamic center for spiritual learning. The ultimate aim was the knowledge of God, with religion dictating the importance of each science. İnalcık notes: "Those which aid religion are good, and sciences like astrology are bad." Although logic and mathematics were part of the curriculum, they were taught with a religious focus, as understanding them was seen as a way to uncover divine truths. İnalcık also observes that even philosophy was studied to affirm Islamic doctrines. Thus, madaris were essentially religious centers for Islamic teachings in the Ottoman era. While scholars like Goffman suggest that the Ottomans were tolerant and lived in a diverse society, the schools were firmly rooted in Islam, not religious pluralism. Similarly, in Europe, Jewish children learned Hebrew prayers at home and studied the Torah at synagogue-organized schools. Wiesner-Hanks notes that Protestants also emphasized teaching "proper religious values." This reflects a commonality between Ottoman and European approaches to education in the early modern period, focusing on religious foundations. Ottoman madaris offered diverse studies, much like contemporary schools, but aimed to reinforce Islamic beliefs and practices.
text_ai_humanized: Ottoman madaris were not just educational institutions; they were vibrant centers of Islamic spiritual learning. Their curriculum, while diverse—spanning calligraphy, oral traditions, and intellectual sciences—was deeply intertwined with religious instruction. At the heart of their mission was the pursuit of divine knowledge, with religious teachings ranking the significance of each subject. İnalcık captures the ethos well: he points out that sciences supporting religion were revered, whereas fields like astrology were deemed unworthy. Even logic and mathematics were approached with a religious lens, celebrated as pathways to understanding divine truths. Interestingly, philosophy found a place in the curriculum, primarily as a means to bolster Islamic doctrine. While scholars such as Goffman argue that the Ottomans embraced diversity within their society, the madaris remained firmly tethered to Islamic principles rather than fostering religious pluralism. This focus on religion isn't unique to the Ottomans; across Europe, Jewish children received instruction in Hebrew prayers at home, guided by synagogue-run schools, and Protestants placed significant emphasis on imparting "proper religious values," as noted by Wiesner-Hanks. It's fascinating to observe this parallel between Ottoman and European educational practices during the early modern era, where religious foundations were paramount. Though Ottoman madaris offered an array of academic pursuits, much like today's schools, at their core, they sought to strengthen Islamic beliefs and customs. It's a reminder of how education across cultures has often mirrored religious philosophies, regardless of geographic or cultural barriers.
